div.l: ¶ Incipit tractatus Galfr͗i Chaucer de Gestis Peregrinoꝝrum v̉ersus Cantuariam
Whan that Auerell wᵗith his shoures soote
The droght of Marche hath ꝑperced to the roote
And bathed euꝰery veyne in swych licour
Of whiche vꝰertu . engendrid is the flour
Whan zephirus eek . wᵗith his swete breeth
Enspired hath in euꝰery holt and heth
The tendre croppes . and the yonge sonne
Hath in the Ram . his half cours y ronne
And smale fowels / maken melodie
That slepen all the nyght with open eye
So priketh hem nature / in her corages
Than longen folke to goon on pilgrymages
And palmers for to seken straunge strondes
To ferne halwes couthe in sondry londes
And specially from euꝰery shires ende
Of Engelond to Caunterbury they wende
The holy blysfull martir forto seke
That hem hath holpen . when that they were seke
Bifell that in that sesoun . on a day
In Southwerk / at the Tabard as I lay
Redy to wenden on my pilgrymage
To Caunterbury . with wel deuout Corage
At nyght was come in to that hostelrie
Wel . xxix . in a compaignye
Of sondry folk / by auenture y falle
In felaueshipe . and pilgrymes were they alle
That toward Caunterbury wolden ryde
The Chambres ⁊ the stables weren wide
And well we weren eesed at the beste
And shortly . whanne the sonne was to reste
So hadde I spoken with hem euꝰerychon̄
That I was of hir felawship̄ anon̄
And made forward erly for to ryse
To take oure wey ther as I yow deuyse
But nartheles while I haue tyme ⁊and space
Er that I ferther in this tale pace
Me theyncketh it accordᵃunt to resoun̄
To telle yow alle the condicioun
Of eiche of hem . so as it semed mee
And whiche they were ⁊and of what degree
And eek in what array that they were ynne
And at a knyght than will I first begynne
A knyght ther was . ⁊and that a worthy man
That fro the tyme that he first began
To ryden oute he loued cheualrie
Treuthe and honour fredom ⁊and curteisie
Full worthi was he in his lordis werre
And ther to hadde he riden noman ferre
As well in Cristendom as hethenesse
At Alisaundre he was whan it was wonne
And euꝰer honoured for his worthynesse
Full ofte tyme he had the bord bygonne
A boue all nacions in pruce
In lettow had he reised and in Ruce
No Cristen man so ofte of his degree
In Gernade at the sege eke had he bee
At Algezir and riden in Belmarie
At lieis was he / and at Satalye
Whan they were wonne . and in the grete see
At many a noble armee had he bee
At mortell batailles hadde he ben̄ Fyftene
And foughten for oure feith / at Tramyssene
In lystes thries / and ay slayn his foo
This ilke worthy knyght had ben also
Som̄ tyme with the lord of palatye
A gayn̄ a nother hethen in Turkye
And euꝰer more he had a souꝰereyn pris
And thow that he were worthy he was wys
And of his port as meke as is a mayde
Ne neuere yet no vylenye he sayde
In alle his lyfe vnto no maner wight
He was a verrey ꝑperfit gentel knyght
His hors was good but he ne was not gay
But for to tellen yow of his array
Of Fustyan he wered a Gypoıı̄un
Al bysmotred with his hawbergeoıı̄un
For he was late comen from his viage
And wente for to do his pilgrymage
With hym ther was his sone a yong squyer
A louer and a lusty bacheler
With lokkes crulle . as they were leyd in presse
Of . xx . yeer he was of age I gesse
Of his stature he was of euene lengthe
And wonderly delyuere . and of grete strengthe
And he had ben̄ sontyme / in chyuachye
In Flaundrys / in Artoys / And Pykardye
And born̄ hym wele as in so litell space
In hope to stonden in his ladies grace
Enbrouded was he / as it were a mede
All full of freisshe floures white and reede
Syngyng he was . or Floytyng alle the day
He was as freisshe / as is the monthe of May
Short was his gowne / with sleues longe ⁊and wyde
Wele coude he sitte on hors and faire ride
He coude songes well make / and endite
Iuste and eke daunce / and well purtreye ⁊and write
So hote he louede / that by nyghter tale
He slepte namore / than dooth a nyghtyngale
Curteys he was . lowely . and seruysable
And carf byforn his Fader at the table
A yeman had he / and seruᵃntz namo
At that tyme / for hym lyst ryde so
And he was clad / in cote ⁊and hode of grene
A sheef of Pecok arwes . bright ⁊and kene
Vnder his belte he bare full thriftely
Wele coude he dresse his takel yemanly
His arwes drouped nought with fetheres lowe
And in his hond he bare a myghty bowe
A nott heed had he / with a broun̄ visage
Of wodecraft wel koude he / alle the vsage
Vpon his arme he bare a gay bracer
And by his syde a swerd / and a bokeler
And on that oother syde / a gay daggere
Harneysed wel . and sharp̄ as poynt of spere
A xp̄christofre on his breest of siluer shene
An horn̄ he bare / the bawdryk / was of grene
A Forster was he / soothly as I gesse
Ther was also a Nonne a Prioresse
That of her smylyng was full symple ⁊and coy
Hir grettest ooth / was but by seynt loy
And she was cleped Madame Eglyntyne
Full well she songe the seruyse dyuyne
Entuned in her nose / full semely
And Frensshe she spak full faire ⁊and fetisly
After the scole of Stratford atte bowe
For Frensshe of Parys was to hir vnknowe
Atte mete wele taught was she wtith alle
She leet no morsell from her lippes falle
Ne wette her fyngeres / in her sauce depe
Wele coude she carie a morsell ⁊and wele kepe
That no drope fel vpoıı̄un her breest
In curtesie was set full mochel her leest
Her ouer lippe wiped she so clene
That in here cuppe / ther was no ferthyng sene
Of grees whan she dronken had hir draught
Full semely aftir her mete she raught
And sykerly she was of greet disport
And full plesaunt and amyable of port
And peyned hire to countrefete chere
Of court . And estatlyche of manere
And to ben holden digne of reuerence
But for to speken of hire conscience
She was so charitable ⁊and so pitous
She wolde wepe / if that she saugh a Mows
Caught in a trappe / if it were ded or bledde
Of smale houndes had she that she fedde
With rosted fleisshe or melke or wastel breed
But soore wepte she / if oon̄ of hem were deed
Or if men smote it with a yerd smerte
And all was conscience and tendre herte
Full symely her wympel pynched was
Hire nose streight / hire eyen grey as glas
Hire mouthe full smal / and therto softe ⁊and reed
But sikerly she hadde a faire forheed
It was almost a spanne brood I trowe
For hardely she was not vnder growe
Full fetys was hire cloke as I was ware
Of small corall a boute hire arm she bare
A peyre of bedys / gauded al with grene
And ther on henge a broche of gold full shene
On whiche was first writen̄ a crowned A
And aftir . Amor vincit / om̄mnia .
A nother nonne with hire had she
That was hire chapeleyn̄ . and preestes thre
A Monke ther was a faire for the maistrie
An out ridere that loued venerie
A manly man to been an Abbot Able
Full many a deynte hors hadde he in stable
And when̄ he rood men myght his bridell here
Gyngle in a whystelyng wynd as clere
And eke as loude / as doth the chapell belle
There as this lord was kepere of the Selle
The reule of seynt Maure or of seynt Benett
By cause that it was olde ⁊and somdell streit
This ilke monke leet olde thynges pace
And helde aftir the newe world the space
He yaf not of that text a pulled hen̄
That seith that hunters ben̄ noon̄ holy men̄
Ne that a Monke whan that he is reccheles
Ys lykkened till a Fissh that is waterles

This is to seyn̄ / a Monke out of his Cloystre
and I saide his opynyon was
But thilke tixte held he not worth an oystre
And I saide his opynyoıı̄un was good
What sholde he studie . ⁊and make hym seluen̄ wood
Vpon̄ a book / in Cloistre alwey to poure
Or swynk with his hondes ⁊and laboure
As Austyn̄ bit . how shall the world be serued
Lat Austyn̄ to hym haue his swynk reserued
Therfore he was a prikesour a right
Greyhoundes he had as swyft as fowel in flyght
Of Prykyng and of huntyng for the hare
Was all his lust for no cost wolde he spare
I saugh his slefes purfiled at the hond
With Grys and that the fynest of a lond
And for to festene his hood vnder his chyn̄
He had of golde wrought a full curious pyn̄
A loue knotte in the gretter ende ther was
His heed was balled that shoon̄ as ony glas
And eke his face as he had ben̄ anoynt
He was a lord full fat ⁊and in good poynt
His eyen̄ stepe / and rollyng in his hed
That semed as a furneys of a leed
His botes souple / his hors in greet estat
Now serteinly / he was a feire pꝰerlat
He was not pale . as is a forpyned goost
A fat swan loued he best of any roost
His Palfrey was as broun̄ as any berye
A Frere ther was . a wantoıı̄un⁊and a merie
A lymytour . a full solempne man
In all the ordres foure / is non̄ that kan
So myche of daliaunce / and faire langage
He had maked full many amariage
Of yong wymen / at his owne cost
Vn to his ordre he was a noble post
Full well byloued ⁊and famulier was he
With frankeleyns ouꝰeral in his cuntre
And eke with worthy women̄ of the toun
For he had pouer of confessioun
As seide hym self . more than a curat
For of his ordre he was licenciat
Full swetely herd he confessioun
And plesaunt was his Absolucoun
He was an esy man to yeue penance
Ther as he wiste to haue a good pitaraunce
For vn to a pore ordre for to yeue
Is signe that a man̄ is well shryue
For if he yaf he durste make auaunt
He wist that a man̄ was repentaaunt
For many a man so herde is of hert
He may not wepe though that he soore smerte
Therfore in stede of wepyng and preieris
Men̄ mote yeue siluer to the pore freris
His tipet was ay farsed full of knyfes
And pynnes for to yeue faire wyfes
And certeynly he had a mury note
Wele coude he syngen̄ and pleyen̄ at a Rote
Of yeddynges he bare outerly the prys
His nekke white was as the floure delys
Therto he stronge was as a champioun
He knew the tauernes well in eủery toun
And eủery hostiler ⁊and tappestere
Bet than a lazar or a beggere
For vn to swiche a worthy man̄ as hee
Accorded nat as by his facultee
To haue with sike lazers Acqueyntaraunce
Yt is not honest it may not avaunce
For to delyn with no such poraille
But all with riche and sellers of vitaille
And ouꝰer all ther as ꝓprofit sholde arise
Corteys he was ⁊and lowely of seruyse
Ther was noman nowher so vertuous
He was the beste begger of his hous
And yaf a certeyn̄ ferme for the garaunt
Noon of his bretheren̄ coom in his haunt
For thogh a widwe had not a shoo
So plesaunt was his In Principio
Yet wolde he haue a ferthyng er he went
His purchas was well bettre than his rent
And rage he coude as it were right a whelp̄
In louedaies koude he mochell help̄
For ther he was not lyke a Cloystrer
With a thredbare cope as is a poore scoler
But he was lyke a maister / or a pope
Of double worsted was his semy cope
And rounded as a belle out of the presse
Somwhat he lypsed for his wantownesse
To make his englysshe swete vpoıı̄un his tonge
And in his harpyng whan he hadde songe
Hise eyen twynkeled in his heed aright
As doon the sterres in the frosty nyght
This worthy lymytour was cleped huberd
A Marchaunt was ther / with a forked berd
In motlee / and heigh on hors he sat
Vpon his heed a Flaundrissh beuer hat
His bootes clapsed / faire and fetisly
Hise resouns he spak full solempnely
Sownyng alwey thencres of his wynnyng
He wold the see were kept for any thyng
Bitwix Middelburgh and Orewelle
Wele koude in eschaunge / sheldes selle
This worthy man full well his wit bysette
Ther wist no wyght that he was in dette
So estatly was he of his goủernaunce
With his bergeynes / and with his cheuysaunce
Forsoth he was a worthy man with alle
But sooth to seyn̄ I note how men hym calle
A Clerk ther was of Oxenford alsoo
That vnto logyk hadde longe y goo
As lene was his hors / as is a rake
And he was not right fat I vndertake
But loked holwe and therto sobrely
Full threedbare was his ouerist courtepy
For he had geten hym / yet no benefice
Ne was so wordly for to haue office
For hym was leuere / haue at his beddes heed
Twenty bokes / clad in blak or reed
Of Aristotell / and his philosophie
Than robes riche / or fithle / or gay sawtrie
But all be that he was a philosophre
Yet hadde he / but litel gold in Coffre
But all that he myght of his frendes hente
On bokes and on lernyng he it spente
And bysely gan for the soules preye
Of hem that yaf hym wherwith to scoleye
Of stodie toke he moost cure / and moost hede
Nat a word spake he / more than was nede
And that was seide / in fourme and reuerence
And short and quyk and full of high sentence
Sownyng in morall sentence v̉ertu was his speche
And gladly wolde he lerne / and gladly teche
A sergeaunt of the lawe war and wys
That often hadde ben at the parvys
That was also full riche of excellence
Discret he was / and grete reuerence
He semed swiche / hise wordes weren so wise
Iustice he was full often in assise
By patent and by pleyn cōmmyssioun
For his science / and for his high renoun
Of fees and robes hadde he many oon
So greet a purchasour was nowher noon
Al was fee simple to hym in effecte
His paarchasyng myght noght ben infecte
Nowhere so besy a man / as he ther nas
And semed besier than he was
In termes hadde he caas ⁊and domes alle
That from the tyme of kyng william were falle
Therto he coude endite / and make a thyng
Ther koude no wight pynche at his wrytyng
And eủery statut koude he playn by rote
He rood but hoomly / in a medlee cote
Girt with a seint of silke / wtith barres smale
Of his array telle I no lenger tale
A Frankeleyn was in his companye
Whit was his berd / as is the daiesye
Of his complexion / he was sangwyn
Wele loued he by the morwe / a soppe in wyn
To lyuen in delyt was eủer his wone
For he was Epicurus owne sone
That helde opynyon / that pleyn delyt
Was verrey felicitee ꝑperfit
An housholdere / ⁊and that a greet was he
Seynt Iulyan he was in his Cuntre
His breed / ⁊and Ale / was alweys aftir oon
A bettre envyned man / was neủer noon
With outen bake mete was neủer his hous
Of fisshe and fleissh / and that so plentevous
It snewed in his hous / of mete ⁊and of drynke
Of alle deyntees / that men couthe bythynke
Aftyr the sondry sesons / of the yeer
So chaunged he his mete / and his soper
Full many a fat partriche / hadde he in mewe
And many a breem / and many a luce in stue
Woo was his Cook but if his sauce were
Poynaunt and sharp / and redy all his gere
His table dormaunt in his halle alway
Stood redy coủered all the longe day
At Sessions ther was he lord and sire
Full ofte tyme he was knyght of the shire
An Anlas and a Gipser all of selke
Heng at his gurdell white as morn melke
A shirreue had he ben / and countour
Was nowher suche a worthy vauasour
An habirdaisshere / and a Carpentere
A webbe / a dyer / a Tapicer
And they were clothed all in o lyuere
Of a solempne / and a grete fraternyte
Full freisshe and newe / hire geere a piked was
Hire knyfes were chaped / noght with bras
But all with siluer / wroght / full clene ⁊and wele
Hire girdles and hire pouches eueridele
Wele semed eche of hem / a faire burgeys
To sitten in a yeldhalle on a deys
Eủerych for the wisdom that he kan
Was shaply for to ben an Alderman
For catell had thay I nough and rente
And eeke hire wifes / wold it wele assente
Or elles serteyn / they were to blame
It is full faire to be clepid madame
And goon to vigiles al byfore
And haue a mantell realliche y bore
A Cook thay hadde with hem for the nones
To boille the Chiknes And the Maribones
And poudre Marchaunt tart ⁊and galyngale
Wele / koude he knowe / a draught of londoıı̄un ale
He koude rooste and sethe / and broille and frie
Maken Mortreux . and wel bake a pie
But greet harm was it . as it thoughte me
That on his shȳnne / a mormall hadde he
For blak manger / that made he with the beste
A shipman̄ was there wonyng fer by weste
For ought I woot he was of Dertemouthee
He rood vpon a rouncy as he couthee
In a gowne of Faldyng to the knee
A dagger on a lace hongyng had hee
A boute his nekke / vnder his arme a doun
The hote somer / hadde made his hewe all broun
And certeynly he was a good felawe
Full many a draught of wyn hadde he drawe
Fro Burdeux warde / whill that the chapman sleep
Of nyce conscience toke he no keep
If that he faught and hadde the hier hond
By watre he sente hem hoom / to eủery lond
But of his crafte to rekene wele his tydes
Hys stremys and his daungers / hym bysydes
His herberwe / and his moone / his lodemenage
Ther was noon suche / fro hulle to cartage
Hardy he was / and wys to vndirtake
With many a tempest hadde his berde ben shake
He knewe alle the hauenes as they were
Froo Scōotlond to the Cape of Fynystere
And eủery Crike in Britaigne and in Spayne
His barge I cleped was the Mawdelayne
With vs ther was a doctour of Phisike
In all this world ne was ther noon hym lyke
To speken of Phisyk and of Surgerie
For he was grounded / in Astronomye
He kepte his pacient a full greet deel
In houres by his magik naturell
Wele koude he fortunen / the Ascendent
Of hise ymages for his pacient
He knewe the cause of eủery maladye
Were it of hoot or coold or moyst or drye
And where it engendrid and of what humour
He was a verray practisour
The cause y knowe / and of his harme the roote
Anoon he yaf the syke man his bote
Full redy had he hise Apothecaries
To senden hym his dregges and letuaries
For eche of hem made other for to wyn̄ne
Hire frendship was nought newe for to begynne
Well knewe he / the olde Esculapius
And discorides / and eke Rusus
Olde ypocras / haly and Galien
Serapion Razis / and Auycen
Averrois Damascien and Constantyn /
Bernard and Gatesden / and Gilbertyn
Of his diete mesurable was hee
For it was of noo suꝑperfluytee
But of grete norissynge / and digestible
His studie was but litle on the bible
In sangwyn̄ and in Pers he clad was al
Lyned with taffata and with sendal
And yet he was but easy of dispense
He kepte that he wan in pestilence
For gold in Phisik is a cordiall
Therfore he loued gold in speciall
A good wife was ther of bysyde bathe
But she was somdel deef and that was scathe
Of clooth makyng she hadde suche an haunt
She passed hem of Ipres and of Gaunt
In all the parisshe wife ne was ther noon
That to the offryng byfore here sholde goon
And if ther didde certein so wroth was she
That she was oute of alle charite
Hire keuerches full fyn were of ground
I durste swere they weyeden ten pound
That on a sonday weren on her hed
Hire hosen were of fyne scarlet reed
Full streite y teyd / and shoes full moist ⁊ newe
Bolde was her face / and faire and reed of hewe
She was a worthy woman all here lyue
Housbandes at chirche dore / she hadde fyue
With outen other compaignye in youthe
But ther of nedeth nat to speke as nouthe
And thries had / she ben̄ at Ierusalem
She hadde passed many a stronge streem
At Rome she hadde ben̄ / and at Boloyne
In Galys at seynt Iame / and at Coloyne
She koude moche of wandryng by the weye
Gattothed was she / sootly for to seye
Vpon an amblere / esily she sat
Wympled wel / and on here hede an hat
As brood as is a bokeler . or a targe
A foot mantel a boute here hipes large
And on here feet apeire of spores sharpe
In felaushipe / wele couthe she laugh ⁊and karpe
Of remedies of loue she knewe ꝑperchaunce
For she couthe of that arte the olde daunce
A good man was there of religioun
And was a pore ꝑperson of a toun
But riche he was of holy thought ⁊and werke
He was also a lerned man a Clerke
That Cristes gospell treuly wolde preche
Hise parisshens / deuoutly wolde he teche
Benigne he was / and wonder diligent
And in adủersite full pacient
And swiche he was preued ofte sithes
Full looth were hym to cursen for his tithes
But rather wolde he yeuen oute of doute
Vn to his poore parisshens aboute
Of his offrynge / and eke of his substaunce
He couthe in litel thyng haue suffissaunce
Wide was his parisshe / and houses fer asonder
But he ne lefte nat / for reyne ne thonder
In sikenesse nor in meschef to visite
The ferrest in his parisshe / moche ⁊and lite
Vpon̄ his feet . and in his hoond a staf
This noble ensample to his sheep̄ he yaf
That first he wroughte / ⁊and aftirward / that he taught
Oute of the gospel he tho wordes caught
And thys figure he added eke therto
That if golde ruste what / what sholde yren do
For if a preost be foule in whom we truste
No wonder is a lewed man to ruste
And shame it is if a preest take kepe
An shiten shipherd / and a clene shepe
Wele ought a preest ensample for to yeve
To hys spee parchons how they shold lyve
He sette nought his benefice to hire
And leet his sheep̄ encombred in the myre
And ranne to loundoıı̄un / vnto seint poules
To seken hym a Chauntrie for soules
Or with a bretherhede to ben witholde
But dwelte at hoom ⁊and kepte wele his foolde
So that the wolfe made it not myscarie
He was a sheephurd / and nat a mercenarie
And though he holy were and vertuouse
He was not to synfull men dispetouse
Ne of of his speche daungerous ne digne
But in his techyng discreet and benygne
To drawen folke to heuen / by faiernesse
By good ensample / this was his besynesse
But it were any ꝑpersone obstynat
What so he were of high or lowe estat
Hym wolde he snybben / sharply for the nonys
A better preest I trowe ther nowher noon is
He wayted / aftir noo pompe ne reuerence
Ne maked hym a spiced conscience
But cristes lore / and hise apostles twelue
He taughte / but first he folwed it hym selue
With hym ther was a plowman . was his brother
That had y ladde of donge full many a fother
A trewe swynkere / and a good was he
Lyuyng in pees / and ꝑperfit charite
God loued he best with all his hole herte
Atte alle tymes / though hym gamed or smerte
And than his neighebore / right as hym selue
He wolde thresshe / and therto dyke and delue
For cristis sake for eủer y pore wight
With outen hire if it lay in his myght
His tithes paide he full faire ⁊and well
Bothe of his ꝓpropre swynke / and his catell
In his tabard he rood vpon a Mere
Ther was also a Reeue and a Millere
A sompnour and a pardoner also
A Manciple and my selfe ther were namo
Miller
The Millere was a stoute karl for the nones
Full bigg he was of braun ⁊and eke of bones
That preued wele / for oủer all ther he cam
At wrastlyng he wolde haue alway the Ram
He was short sholdred brood a thikke knarre
Ther was no dore that he ne wolde heue of harre
Or breke it at a rennyng with his heed
His berde as any sowe / or fox was reed
And therto brood as though it were a spaade
Vpon the coppe right of his nose he hade
A wert. and ther on stood a tofte of heris
Reed as the brustles of a sowe eeris
Hise nosethirles blake were ⁊and wide
A swerde and a bokeler bare he be his side
His Mouthe as grete was / as a greet furneys
He was a Ianglere / and a Goliardeis
And that was moste of synne / and harlotries
Wele couthe he stelen corn / and tollen thries
And yet he hadde a thombe of golde ꝑperdee
A white cote and a blewe hood wered he
A bagge pipe wele coude he blowe and sowne
And therwith al / he brought vs oute of towne
Maıı̄unciple
A gentell Maunciple was ther of a temple
Of whiche all chatours myght take exemple
For to ben wise in bying of vitaille
For whether that he paide or toke by taille
Algat he waited so in his achate
That he was ay byforn and in good state
Now is not that of god a full faire grace
That swiche a lewed mannys witte shall pace
The wisdom of an heep / of lerned men
Of Maistres hadde he moo / than twies ten
That were of lawe exꝑpert and curious
Of whiche ther were a duzeyn̄ in that hous
Worthy to ben stiwardes / of rent and lond
Of any lord that is in Engelond
To make hym lyue by his ꝓpropre good
In honour dettelees / but he were wood
Or lyve as scarsly / as hym lyst desire
And able for to helpen all a shire
In any caas / that myghte falle or happe
And yet this Maunciple / sette her aller cappe
The Reue was a sklender Coleryk man
His berde was shaue / as neigh as eủer he kan
His heer was by hise erys full rounde y shorn
His topp was dokked lyke a preest byforn
Full longe were his legges / and full lene
I lyke a staf ther was no calfe y sene
Wele couthe he kepe / a gerner and a bynne
Ther was noon Auditour / koude on hym wynne
Wele wiste he by the droughte / And by the Reyn
The yeldyng of his seed and of his greyn
His lordeshep / his neet / his deyerie
His swyn his hors / his stoor / and his pultrie
Was holly in this Reues gouernyng
And by his couenant / yaf the rekenyng
Syn that his lord was twenty yere of age
There coude noman brynge hym in arerage
Ther nas baillif ne herde / nor other hyne
That he ne knewe his sleighte / ⁊and his couyne
They were a dradde of hym / as of the deth
His wonyng was full faire / vpon an heth
With grene trees shadwed was his place
He koude bettre than his lord purchace
Full Riche he was a stored priuely
His lorde wele koude he pleasen subtilly
To yeue and lene hym of his owne good
And haue a thank and yet a coot and a hood
In youthe he lerned hadde / a good myster
He was a well good wright a Carpenter
This Reue satte vpon a wele good stot
A longe Surcote of peers vpon he hadde
And by his side he bare a rusty blade
Of Northfolke was this Reeue / of whiche I telle
Byside a toun̄ men clepe Baldeswelle
Tukked he was / as is a frere a boute
And eủer he rood the hyndrest of oure route
A Sompnour was there with vs in that place
That hadde a fire reed Cherubyns face
For Saucefleme / he was with eyen narwe
And hoot he was / and lecherous as a sparwe
With scaled browes blake / and piled berd
Of his visage children weren a ferd
Ther nas quik siluer / litarge ne brymston̄
Borace ceruce ne oile of tartre noon
Ne oygnement that wolde clense and bite
That hym myght helpen of hise welkes white
Ne of the knobbes sittyng on his chekys
Wele loued he garlek onyons ⁊and eke lekes
And for to drynken strong wyn reed as blood
Than wolde he and crie as he were wood
Than wolde he speke no word but in latyne
That he had lerned out of som decree by tyme
No wonder is / he hard it all the day
And eeke ye knowen wele how that a Iay
Kan clepen watte / as wele as kan the pope
But who so koude in other thyng hym grope
Than had he spent all his Philosophie
Ay questio quid iuris wold he crie
He was a gentell harlot and a kynde
A bettre felawe / sholde men nought fynde
He wolde suffre for a quart of wyn
A good felawe to haue his concubyn
A twelfe monthe / and excusen hym atte fulle
Full priuely a fynche eke coude he pulle
And if he foond o where a good felawe
He wolde techen hym to haue noon awe
In suche caas / as the Ercedeknes curs
But if mannes soule / were in his purs
For in his purs he sholde punysshed be
Purs is the Ercedeknes helle seide he
But wele I woot he lied right in dede
Of cursyng ought iche gilti man drede
For curs wole slee / right as a soillyng sauyth
And also ware hym of a Significauit
In daunger hadde he atte his owne gyse
The yonge gerles / of the diocise
And knewe her counseill / and was all hire reed
A garland hadde he set vpon his heed
As grete as it were for ale stake
A bokeler hadde he made hym of a Cake
With hym ther rood a gentell pardoner
Of Rouncyual his frende and his comper
That streight was comen from the court of Rome
Full loude he songe come hedir loue to me
This sompnour bare to hym a styf burdoun
Was neuer trompe . of halfe so greet a soun
This pardoner had heer as yelowe as wexe
And smothe it henge as doth a strike of flexe
By ounces henge his lokkes that he hadde
And ther with he his sholdres oủer spradde
But thynne it lay by colpons oon and oon
But hood for Iolite wered he noon
For it was trussed vp in his walet
Hym thought he rood all of the newe gett
Discheuelee saue his cappe he rood all bare
Swiche glaryng eyen hadde he as an hare
A vernycle had hee sowed vpon his cappe
His walet byforn hym in his lappe
Bret full of pardoun / comen from Roome all hoot
A voys he hadde as smalle as hath a goot
No berde hadde he / ne neủer sholde haue
As smothe it was / as it were late y shaue
I trowe he were a geldyng or a Mare
But of his crafte fro Berwik in to ware
Ne was there suche a nother ꝑpardonere
For in his male / he hadde a pilwe bere
Whiche that he saide / was oure lady veile
He seide he hadde a gobet of a seile
That seint petir hadde / whan that he wente
Vpon the see til Ihu crist hym hente
He hadde a crosse of latoun full of stones
And in a glasse he hadde pigges bones
But with these relykes / whan that he fond
A pore parson dwellyng vpon lond
Vpon a day he gate hym more moneye
Than that the ꝑparsoun gate in Monthes tweye
And thus with feyned flaterie and Iapes
He made the ꝑparsoun and the peple his Apes
But treuly to tellen atte laste
He was in chirche a noble Ecclesiaste
Wele koude he reede a lessoun ⁊and a storie
But alther beste he song an offertorie
For well he wist whan that songe was songe
He moste preche / and wele affile his tonge
To wynne siluer / as he full wele koude
Therfore he songe the murierly ⁊and loude
Now haue I told yow sootly in a clause
Thestaat tharray / the nombre and eke the cause
Why that assembled was this compaignye
In Southwerk / in that gentil hostelrie
That hight the Tabard fast by the belle
But now is tyme to yow for to telle
How that we baren / vs that ilke nyght
Whan that we were in that hostelrie a light
And aftyr wole I telle of oure viage
And all the remenant of oure pilgrimage
But now first I pray yow of youre curtesie
That ye narette it not my vilenye
Though that I pleynly speke in this matere
To telle yow here wordes ⁊and here chere
Ne though I speke her wordes ꝓproprely
For this ye knowen / also wele as I

l.hi: Who so shall telle a tale aftir a man
He moot reherce as eủer he kan

div.l: Eueriche a word if it be in his charge

l.hi: All speke he neủer so rudelyche and large
Or ellys moot telle his tale vntrewe
Or feyne thyng or fynde wordys newe
He may not spare all though he were his brother
He moot as wele seye o word as a nother
Crist spake hym selfe full brood in holy writ
And wele ye woot no vileynye is it
Eke plato seith who so kan hym rede
The wordes mote be Cosyn to the dede

div.l: Also I pray yow to foryeue it mee
All haue I not set folke in here degree
Here in this tale as that they sholde stonde
My witte is short ye may wele vndirstonde
Greet chere made oure hoost vs euerichon
And to the sopere / sette he vs a noon
He serued vs with vitaille at the beste
Stronge was the wyn ⁊ wele to drynke vs leste
A semely man oure hoost was with alle
For to been a Marchal in an halle
A large man he was with eyen stepe
A fairer burgeis is ther noon in chepe
Bolde of his speche / ⁊and wis ⁊and wele y taught
And of manhood hym lakked right naught
Eke therto he was a mury man
And aftir souper / pleynen he bygan
And spake of myrthe / amonges other thynges
Whan that we hadde made oure rekenynges
And seide thus / now lordes treuly
Ye ben to me right welcome hertely
For by my trouthe yf that I shall not lye
I saugh not this yeere so meri a companye
At oones in this herburgh as is now
Fayne wolde I doon yow myrthe wyste I how
And of a myrthe I am right now bythought
To doon yow ease / ⁊and it it shall cost yow nought
Ye goon to Caunterbury ward god yow spede
The blysfull martir quyte yow youre mede
And wele I woot . as ye goon by the wey
Ye shapen yow to talen and to pleye
For treuly comfort ne myrthe is noon
To ride by the wey dombe as a stoon
And therfore wole I maken yow desport
As I saide erst ⁊and do yow som comfort
And if yow liketh all by oon assent
For to stōnden at my Iugement
And for to werken as I yow saye
To Morwe whan ye riden by the waye
Now by my fader soule that is deed
But ye be mury I wole yeve yow myn heed
Holde vp youre hondes with outen Moore speche
Oure counseille was not longe for to seche
Vs thought it was nat worth to make it wyse
And graunted hym with wotyn moore auyse
And bade hym seye this voirdit as hym lyeste
Lordynges qduod he / now herkneth for the beste
But taketh it nat I pray yow in desdeyn
This is the poynt to speke short and pleyn
That eche of yow / to short with oure weye
In this viage shall telle tales tweye
To Caunterbury ward I mene it soo
And homward he shall tellen other twoo
Of Auentures that whilom haue byfalle
And whiche of yow that bereth best of alle
That is to seyn / that tellith in this caas
Tales of beste sentence / and most solaas
Shall haue a soper / at oure allere cost
Here in this place / sittyng by this post
Whan that we come agayn to Caunterbury
And for to make yow the more mury
I wol my self goodly with yow ride
Ryght at myn owne cost / and be youre gyde
And who so wole my Iugement with seye
Shall paye all that we spende by the weye
And if that ye vouche sauf that it be soo
Telle me a noon with outen wordes moo
And I wole erly shape me therfore
This thyng was graunted and oure othes swore
With full gladde herte / and preyden hym also
That he wolde fouche sauf forto do so
And that he wolde be oure goủernour
And of oure tales Iugge and reportour
And sette a soper atte a certeyn pris
And we wole reuled ben at his deuys
In high and lough / and thus by oon assent
We ben accorded to his Iugement
And ther vpon the wyn was fet a noon
We dronken and to reste echon
With outen any lenger tarying
A Morwe whan that day bygan to spryng
Vp roos oure oost ⁊and was oure aller cokke
And gadrid vs to gedir in a flokke
And forth we riden a litel moore than pas
Vn to the wateryng of seint Thomas
And there oure hoost bygan his hors areste
And seide lordynges herkeneth if yow leste
Ye woot youre forward / ⁊ it yow recorde
If euesong and morwe song accorde
Lat see now whoo shall telle the first tale
As eủer mote I drynke wyn or ale
Who so be rebel to my Iuggement
Shall pay for all that by the wey ys spentby the wey ys spent
Now draweth cutte er that we ferther twynne
He whiche that hath the shortest shall begynne
Sire knyght quod he / my maister and my lord
Now draweth cutte for that is myn accord
Cometh neer quod he my lady prioresse
And ye sire Clerke / late be youre shamefastnesse
Ne studieth nat lay hond to eủery man
Anoon to drawen eủery wight bygan
And shortly for to tellen as it was
Were it by auenture / or sort / or cas
The soth is this / the cutte fell to the knyght
Of whiche full blithe was eủery wight
And telle he moste his tale as was resoun
By forward and by composicoun
As ye han herde what nedeth wordes moo
And whan this good man saugh that it was soo
As he that wyse was / and obedient
To kepe his forward by his free assent
He seide syn I shall bygynne the game
What welcome be the cutte in goddis name
Now late vs ride / and herkeneth what I seye
And whth that word we riden forth oure weye
And he bygan with right amery chere
His tale a noon and seide as ye may here

l.hi: Iamque domos patria scithice post aspera gentis laurigero et cetera

div.l:
Iamqꝫue domos patria Scithite post asꝑpera gentis laurigers ⁊cetcetera
Here bigynneth the knygtis tale
Wilom as olde stories tellen vs
Ther was a Duke that hight Theseus
Of Athenes / he was lorde ⁊and gouernour
And in his tyme swyche a conquerour
That gretter was ther noon vnder the sonne
Full many a Riche cuntree / hadde he wonne
What with his wisdom / and his chiualrie
He conquered all the reigne of femenye
That whilom was I cleped Scithia
And wedded the queene Ypolita
And brought hire hom with hym in his contree
With mychel glorie ad solempnytee
And eeke hire suster Emelie
And thus with victorie ⁊and with melodie
Late I this noble duke to Athenes ride
And alle his hoost in armes hym byside
And certes if it nere to long to here
I wolde haue tolde fully the manere
How wonnen was the reigne of femenye
By theseus . and by his chiualrie
And the grete bataille for the nones
Bitwixen Athenes / ⁊and Amazones
And how asseged was Ipolita
The faire hardy queene of Scithia
And of the feste that was at hire weddynge
And of the tempest of her home comynge
But all that thynge I mote as now forbere
I haue god woot a large felde to ere
And wayke ben the Oxen in my plow
The remenant of my tale is longe I now
I wolle nat letten eke noon of this route
Late eủery felawe telle his tale a boute
And lat see now whoo shall the soper wynne
And there I lefte I wole a yein bygynne
¶ Incipit / narracio
This duke of whom I make of mencoun
Whan he was comon almoost to the toun
In alle his wele and in his moste pride
He was ware as he caste his eye aside
Where that there kneled in the hie weye
A Compaignye of ladies twey ⁊and tweye
Eche aftir other / cladde in clothes bakeblakeblake
But swiche a crie / and swyche a woo they make
That in this worlde nys creature lyuynge
That herd suche a nother waymentynge
And of this crie . they nolde neủer styntyn
Til they the reynes of his bridell hentyn
What folke be ye / that at myn home comynge
Parturben so my feste / with criynge
Quod Theseus / haue ye so grete enuye
Of myn honour that thus compleyne ⁊ crie
Or who hath yow mysboden / or offendid
And tellith me if it may ben amendid
And why that ye ben clothed thus in blak
The oldest lady of hem alle spak
Whan she hadde swowned with a dedly chere
That it was reuthe to seen ⁊and here
She saide lorde to whom fortune hath yeuen
Victorie / and / as a Conquerour to lyuen
Nat greueth vs / youre glorie and youre honour
But we bysechen mercy and socour
Haue mercy on oure woo / and oure distresse
Som drope of pitee / thurgh thy gentilnesse
Vppon vs wrecched women / late thow falle
For certes lorde / ther is noon of vs alle
That she ne hathe ben a duchesse or a quene
Now be we caitifes / as it is wele sene
Thanked be fortune and his false whele
That noon estate assureth to be wele
Now certes lorde to abiden youre p̉ersence
Here in this Temple of the goddesse clemence
We haue ben waytyng all this fourten nyght
Now helpe vs lord sith it lith in thy myght
I wrecche whiche that wepe ⁊and waille thus
Was whilom wyfe to kyng Canpaneus
That starf at Thebes / cursed be the day
And alle we that ben in this array
And maken all this lamentacoun̄
We losten all oure housbondes at that toun
While that the sege ther a boute lay
And yet now the olde Creon weylaway
That lord / is now at Thebes the Cite
Fulfild of Ire and of Iniquite
He for despit . and for his Tirannye
To doon the deed bodies vileynye
Of alle oure lordes / whiche that ben slawe
Hath alle the bodies on an hepe I drawe
And wol nat suffren hem / by noon assent
Neither to ben I buryed nor I brent
But maketh houndes eten hem in despite
And with that worde with oute more respite
They fillen gruf and criden pitously
Haue on vs wrecched womenne som mercy
And late oure sorwe / synke in thyn herte
This gentil duke / doun from his courser sterte
With herte pitous / whan he herde hem speke
Hym thought that his herte wolde breke
Whan he saugh hem / so pitous and so maat
That whilom weren of so greet estaat
And in his Armes / he hem alle vp hente
And hem comforteth in full good entente
And swoor his ooth / as he was trewe knyght
He wolde doon so ferfoth his myght
Vpon the Tirant Creon hem to wreke
That alle the puple of grece / sholde speke
How Creon was / of Theseus y serued
As he that hadde his deth wele deserued
And right a noon / with outen moore a bood
His banner he desplaieth and forth rood
To Thebesward and alle his oost biside
No neer Athenes / wolde he goo nene ride
Ne take his eese / fully halfe a day
But outward on his way / that nyght he lay
And sente A noon Ipolita the queene
And Emelie her yonge sister sheene
Vn to the toun of Athenes to dwelle
And forth he ritte ther is nomore to telle
The reed statue of Mars / wtith spere and targe
So shyneth in his white baner large
That alle the feldes glitren vp ⁊and doun
And by his baner. born is his penoun
Of golde full riche / in whiche ther was y bete
The Mynotaur / whiche that he wan in Crete
Thus rit this Duk thus rit this conqueroure
And in oost of Chiualrie the floure
Tyl he cam to Thebes / and a light
Faire in a felde / ther as he thought fight
But shortly for to speken / of thys thyng
With Creon whiche that was of Thebes kyng
He faught / and slough hym manly as a knyght
In pleyn bataille / and put the folke to flyght
And by Assaut he wan the Citee after
And rente a doun / bothe walle ⁊and sparre ⁊and rafter
And to the ladies he restored a gayn
The bones of her freendes / that weren slayn
To doon obsequies / as was tho the gise
But it were alto longe for to deuyse
The grete clamour / and the waymentyng
That the ladies made / at the brennyng
Of the bodies / and the grete honour
That Theseus / the noble Conquerour
Doth to the ladies / whan they from hym went
But shortly for to telle / is myn entent
Whan that this worthy duk this Theseus
Hath Creon slayn / and wonne Thebes thus
Stille in that felde . he took all nyght his reste
And dide with all the Cuntre as hym leste
To ransake in the taas / of the bodies deede
Hem for to strepe of harneys / and of weede
The Pilours deden bysynesse and cure
Aftir the bataille and disconfiture
And soo byfel that in the taas they founde
Thourgh girt with many a grevous blody wounde
Two yonge knyghtes lyggyng by and by
Booth in oon armes wrought full richely
Of whiche twoo / Arcita hight that oon
And that other knyght hight Palamon
Nat fully quyk / ne fully deed they were
But by here cote armures / and by here gere
The heraudes knewe hem best in special
As they that weren / of the blood roial
Of Thebes / and of sustren two y born
Out of the taas / the pilours han hem torn
And han hem caried softe / vn to the tente
Of theseus / and full sone he hem sente
To Athenes / to dwellen in prisoun
ꝐPerpetuelly / he nolde no raunsoun
And whan this worthy duk hath thus ydoon
He toke his hoost and hoom he ritte a noon
With laurer crowned as a Conqueerour
And there he loueth in Ioy and in honour
Terme of his lyfe what nedith wordes moo
And in a tours in anguysshe and in woo
This Palamon and his felawe arcite
For euer moore / ther may no golde hem quite
This passeth yer by yer / and day by day
Til it felle ones in a morwe of May
That emelie that fairer was to sene
Than is the lilie vpon his stalke grene
And fressher than the May with floures newe
For with the roos colour stroof hire hewe
I not the whiche was fyner of hem twoo
Er hit were day / as was here wone to doo
She was a rysen / and all redy dight
For May wol haue / no slogardie a nyght
The seisoıı̄un priketh eủery gentil hert
And maketh hym oute of his slepe to sterte
And seith arys / and do thyn obseruaunce
This maked Emelye haue remembraunce
To doon honour to May / and for to ryse
I Clothed was shee fresshe for to deuyse
Her yolewe heer / was broided in a tresse
By hynde her bakke a yerd longe I gesse
And in the gardyn at the sonne vpriste
She walketh vp and doun / and as hir lyste
She gadreth floures partie white and reede
To make a subtil garlond for hir heede
And as an Aungel heuenysshly she songe
The greet toure that was so thykke ⁊and stroonge
Whiche of the Castell was the chief doungeoun
There as the knyghtes weren in prisoun
Of whiche I tolde yow / and tellen shalle
Was euen Ioynaunt to the walle
Ther as this Emelye / hadde hir pleyinge
Bright was the sonne / ⁊and clere that morwenynge
And Palamon thys wofull prisoner
As was his wone / By leue of his gailer
Was risen and Romed in a Chambre on heigh
In whiche he alle the noble Citee seigh
And eke the gardeyn full of braunches grene
There as this fresshe Emelye the shene
Was in her walke ⁊and romed vp and doun
This wooful louere this Palamon
Gooth in the Chambre romyng to and froo
And to hym selfe complaynyng of his woo
That he was born full ofte he saide allas
And so byfell / by auenture or caas
That thourgh a wyndowe thikke of many a barre
Of iren greet / and square as any sparre
He caste his eye vpon Emelia
And ther withal he bleynt ⁊and cried A.
As though he stongen were vn to the herte
And with that crie Arcite anoon vpsterte
And seide Cosyn myn what eyleth thee
That art so pale / and dedely to see
Why cridestowe / whoo hath the doon offence
For goddys loue take all in pacience
Oure prisoun / for it may noon other bee
Fortune hath yeven vs this adủersitee
Sōmme wikked aspect or disposicoıı̄un
Of Saturne / by som constillacoıı̄un
Hath yeue vs this / al though he had it sworn
So stood the heuene / whan that we were born
We most endure / this is the short and playn
Thys Palamon answerd a gayn
Cosyn forsoth of this opynyoıı̄un
Thou haste a vayn Imagynacouıı̄un
This prisoun caused nat to crie
But I was hurt right now thourgh out myn yeye
In to myn hert / that wolle my bane be
The fairnesse of that lady that I see
Yond in the gardyn / rennen to and froo
Ys cause of all my criyng / and my woo
I noot wher she be wōmman or goddesse
But venus is it as I gesse
And there with alle / on knees doun he fylle
And saide venus if it be thy wille
Yow in this gardeyn to taransfigure
Byfore me sorwefull wrecchid creature
Oute of this prisoun / helpe that we may scape
And if so be / oure destyne by shape
Be eterne worde / to deyen in prisoun
Of oure linage haue som compassioun
That is so lowe I brought by tyrannye
And with that worde Arcite bygan aspie
Where as this ladie romed to and froo
And with that sight her beute hurt hym soo
That if that Palamon was woundid soore
Arcite is hurte / as moche as he or more
And with a sigh / he seide pitously
The fresshe beaute Cleth me sodenly
Of hire that rometh in the yonder place
And but I haue hire mercy and hire grace
That I may seen hire / at the leste weye
I nam but deed / ther is namore to seye
This Palamon whan he tho wordes herde
Despittously he loked and answerde
Wheither seist thou this / in ernest or in pley
Nay quod Arcite in ernest by my fay
God helpe me so / me lyste euyl for to pley
This Palamon gan knytte his browes tweye
It nere to the quod he / noo greet honour
For to be fals / ne for to be traitour
To me that am thy Cosyn and thy brother
I Sworn full deope / and eche of vs til other
That neuere for to deyen in the peyne
Til that the deeth / departe shall vs tweyne
Neither of vs in loue to hyndre oother
Ne in noon other caas / my leue brother
And that thow sholdest treuly forthre me
In eủery caas / and I shall forthre the
This was thyn ooth / ⁊and myn also certeyn
I wote it wele thou darst it not with seyn
Thus Artow of my counseille oute of doute
And now thow woldest ben falsly a boute
To loue my lady whom I loue and serue
And eủer shalle til that myn hert sterue
Nay certes false Arcite / thou shalt nat soo
I loued her firste and tolde the my woo
As to my counseille and to my brother sworn
To forthre me as I haue tolde biforn
For whiche thou art bounden as a knyght
To helpe me / if it lay in thy myght
Or ellys artowe fals I dar well seyn
This Arcite full proutly spak ageyn
Thou shalt quod he be rather fals than I
But thou art fals I telle thee vttrely
For paramour I loued here furst er thow
What woltow seyn / thow worest nat yet now
Whether she be a woman / or goddesse
Thyn is affeccoıı̄un of holynesse
And myn is loue as to a creature
For whiche I tolde the myn auenture
As to myn Cosyn and to myn brother sworn
I pose / thow louedest hire byforn
Wostowe nat wele the olde clerkes sawe
That whoo shall yeue a louere any lawe
Quis / legem det amantibꝫus
Loue is a gretter lawe be my pan
Than may be yeuen / of any erthely man
And therfore positif lawe / and swiche decree
Is broken al day for loue in eche degree
A man mot nedes loue maugre his heed
He may not flen it / though he sholde be deed
Al be she maide or widewe or ellys wyf
And eke it is not lykly all thy lyf
To stonden in her grace namore shal I
For wele thou woost thy self vereilly
That thou and I ben dampned to prisoun
ꝐPerpetuelly vs gayneth noo raunsoıı̄un
We stryuen / as dyde the houndes for the bon
They fought alday . and yette here parte was noon
Ther kam a kyte / while they were so wrothe
And bare a way the boon / bitwixe hem bothe
And therfore at the kynges court my brother
Eche man for hym selfe ther is noon oother
Leef it []ifif thee lyst / for I loue ⁊ ay shall
And soothly leef brother this is all
Here in this prisoun / mote we endure
And eủeryche of vs / take his auenture
Greet was the stryfe and longe bytwixe hem tweye
If that I hadde leyser for to seye
But to theffect / yt happid on a day
To telle it yow / so shortly as I may
A worthy duk that hight Parotheus
That felawe was to duk Theseus
Syn thilke day / that they were children lite
Was come to Athenes his felawe to visite
And for to pleye as he was wont to doo
For in this worlde he loued noman soo
And he loued hym / as tenderly a geyn
So wele they loued as olde bokes seyn
That whan that oon was deed / soothly to telle
His felawe went and sought hym doun in helle
But of that storie liste me not to write
Duk ꝐPerotheus loued wele Arcite
And hadde hym knowe at thebes / yere by yere

div.l: (base) And finally at request and prayere
(base) Of ꝐPerotheus wyth oute[]enyenyraunsoun
(base) Frely to goon wher that hym lyste oueral
(base) Duk Theseus hym leet out of prisoun
(base) In suche a gyse as I yow tellen shall
(base) This was the forward pleynly for tendite
(base) Bitwixen Theseus / and hym Arcite
(base) That if so were that Arcite were y founde
(base) Euer in his lyfe by day . or nyght or stounde
(base) In any cuntre of this Theseus
(base) And he were caught it was a corded thus
(base) That with a swerd he sholde lese his heed
(base) Ther nas noon other remedye ne reede
(base) But taketh hys leue / and homward he hym spedde
(base) Late hym beware hys lyfe lieth to wedde
(base) How grete a sorwe / suffreth now arcite
(base) The deeth he feleth / thurgh his herte smyte
(base) He weepeth / wailleth / crieth / pitously
(base) To sleen hym selfe he waiteth priuely
(base) He seide allas / the day that I was born
(base) Now is my pirisoun wors than byforn
(base) Now is me shape eternally to dwelle
(base) Nat in my purgatorie / but in helle
(base) Allas that euꝰer knewe I Parotheus
(base) For ellys hadde I dwelled with Theseus
(base) I fetrid in his prisoun euꝰer moo
(base) Than hadde I ben in blysse / and nat in woo
(base) Only the sight of hire / whom that I serue
(base) Though that I neuꝰer / here grace may deserue
(base) Wolde haue suffised right I now for me
(base) O dere Cosyn Palamon quod he
(base) Thyn is the vittorie / of this auenture
(base) Full blysfully / in pirisoun maistow ıııı dure
(base) In pirisoun ; certes nay / but in paradys
(base) Wele hath fortune / I turned thee the dys
(base) That haste the sight of hire / and I . thabsence
(base) For possible is / syn thou hast hire pꝰersence
(base) And art a knyght / a worthy man and able
That by som caas . syn fortune is chaungeable
Thow maiste to thy desire / somtyme Attayne
But I that am exiled and barayne
Of alle grace / and in so greet despeire
That ther nys / erthe / water / fire / ne eyre
Ne creature that of hem maked is
That may me heele / or doon confort in this
Wele ought I sterue in wanhope and distresse
Fare wele my lyfe my luste and my gladnesse
Allas why playnen folke / so in comune
On purueyaunce of god or of fortune
That yeueth hem full ofte / in many agise
Wele bettre than thay kan hem selue deuyse
Som man desireth for to haue richesse
That cause is of his moerdre or grete sikenesse
And som man wolde / out of prisoun fayn
That in his hous / is of his meynee slayn
Infinite harmes ben in this matere
We woot nat what thyng that we parayen here
We fare as he that dronke is as a mous
A dronke man woot weele he hath an hous
But he not whiche the right weye is thyder
And to a dronke man / the wey is slyder
And certes / in this worlde so faren we
We sekyn []fastfast after felicite
But wee goon wronge / full ofte trewely
Thus May we seyn alle / and nameliche I
That wende ⁊and hadde a greet opynyon
That if I myght / scape fro prison
Than had I ben in Ioy / and ꝑperfit hele
Ther now I am exiled fro my wele
Syn that I may nat sene / yow emelye
I nam but deed ther nys no remedye
Vpon that other syde / Palamon
Whan that he wiste Arcite was a gon
Swiche sorwe he makith / that the grete tour
Resouneth of his yowlyng / and clamour
The pure fettres / on his shynes grete
Were of his bittre salte teeres weete
Allas quod he / Arcita Cosyn myn
Of alle oure stryfe god woot the fruyt is thyn
Thow walkest now at thebes at thy large
And of myn woo / thow yeuest litell charge
Thow maiste syn thow haste wisdom ⁊and manhede
Assemblen alle the folke of oure kynrede
And make a werre so sharpe on this Citee
That by som auenture or som trete
Thow maiste haue hire to lady and to wyfe
For whom that I most nedes lese my lyfe
For as by wey of possibilite
Sith thou art at thy large / of prison free
And art a loord greet in thyn auantage
Moore than is myn that sterue here in a cage
For I mote wepe / and waille while I leue
With alle the woo / that prisoun may me yeue
And eke with peyne / that loue me yeueth alsoo
That doubleth all my torment and my woo
Ther with the fire of Ialousie vp sterte
With ynne his breest and hent hym by the herte
So woodly that he like was to biholde
The boxtree / or the Asshen deed or coolde
Than seide he / o cruel goddes that goủerne
This world with byndyng of youre worde eterne
And writen in the table of Atthamant
Youre ꝑparlement and youre eterne graunt
What is mankynde / moore vn to yow holde

seg.seg: Than ys the shepe that rowkyth in the Folde

div.l: For slayn is man right as a nother beest
And dwelleth eke in prisoun and areest
And hath sikenesse / and greet adủersite
And ofte tymes gilteles pardee
What goủernaunce is in this p̉erscience
That gilteles tormenteth . Innocence
And yet incresceth this / all my penaunce
What man is bounden to her obseruaunce
For goddes sake to letten of his wille
Ther as a beest may all his lust fulfille
And whan a beest is th[]thth deed / he hath no peyne
But man aftir his deeth / mote wepe ⁊and pleyne
Though he in this worlde haue care ⁊and woo
With outen doute it may stonden soo
The answere of this / lete I to deuynys
But wele I woot that in this worlde grete pyne is
Allas I see a serpent or a theef
That many a trewe man hath doo myschief
Goon at his large / and where hym lyst may turne
But I moot ben in prisoıı̄un thourgh Saturne
And eke thourgh Iuno / Ialous and eek wood
That hath destruyed wel ny all the blood
Of Thebes with his waste walles wide
And Venus sleeth me / on that other syde
For Ialousie and feere / of hym Arcite
Nowe wole I stynte of Palamon a lite
And lete hym in his prisoun stille dwelle
And of Arcita forth I wolle yow telle
The somer passeth / and the nyghtes longe
Encrescit double wise / the peynes stronge
Bothe of the louere / and the prisoner
I noot whiche hath / the wofuller myster
For shortly for to seyn this Palamon
ꝐPerpetuelly / is dampned to prison
In cheynes and fettres to ben deed
And Arcita is exiled vpon his heed
For eủer moo / as out of that cuntree
Ne neủer moo / ne shalle his ladie see
Yow louers axe I now this question
Who hath the worse Arcite or Palamon
That oon may seen his lady day be day
But in prisoun mote he dwelle alway
That oother where hym lyste may ryde or goo
But sen his lady shall he neủer moo
Now demeth as yow lyst ye that kan
For I wolle telle forth as I began
Whan Arcite to Thebes comen was
Full ofte a day / he swelte and saide allas
For seen his lady shall he neủer moo
And shortly to concluden alle his woo
So mychel sorwe hadde neủer creature
That is or shall / whil that the world may dure
His sleep his meete / his drynke is hym byrafte
That lene he wexe / and drie as is a shafte
His eyen holwe and grysly to byholde
His hewe falowe and pale / as aisshen coolde
And solitarie he was / and eủer alone
And waylyng all the nyght makyng his mone
And if he harde songe or Instrument
Than wolde he wepe / he myght not be stent
So feble eke were his spirites / and so lowe
And chaungid so / that no man koude knowe
His speche nor his voys / though men it herde
And in his geer for alle the werld he ferde
Nat oonly lyke the louers madye
Of hereos but rather lyke Manye .gama.
Engendred / of humour malencolyke
By forn his celle Fantastyke
And shortly torned was all vp so doun
Both habite and disposicoūn
Of hym this wofull louere / daun Arcite
What sholde I al day / of his woo endite
Whan he engendurid hadde / a yeer or twoo
This cruell turment / and this peyne and woo
At Thebes in his Cuntre as I seyde
Vpon a nyght / in sleep as he hym leyde
Hym thought how that the wynged god M̉ercurye
By forn hym stood and bade hym to be murye
His slepy yerde in hoond he bare vp right
An hatte he wered vppon his heris bright
Arraied was this god as he toke kepe
As he was whanne that Argus took his sleepe
And seide hym thus / too / Atthenes shaltow wende
Ther is the shapen of thy woo an ende
And with that worde Arcite wooke ⁊and sterte
And trewely how soore that me smerte
Quod he Tatthenes right now wole I fare
Nee fore dreed of deth / shall I nat spare
To see my lady that I loue ⁊and serue
In hire p̉resence I recche nat to sterue
And with that worde he caught a gret myrrour
And saugh that chaunged was all his colour
And saugh his visage all in a nother kynde
And right a noon it ran hym in hys mynde
That sith his face was so disfigured
Of maladie the whiche he hadde endured
He myght wele / if that he bare hym lowe
Lyue in Athenes eủer moore vnknowe
And seen his lady / wel nygh day be day
And rith a noon / he chaunged his array
And cladde hym as a pore laborer
And alle allone / saue oonly a squier
That knewe his priuetee / and alle his caas
Whiche was disgysed poorely as he was
Tatthenes / is he goon / the nexte way
And to the Courte he wente vpon a day
And at the gate he ꝓprofreth his ʆseruice
To drugge and drawe what so men wol deuyse
And shortly of this matere for to seyn
He felle in office with a Chamberleyn
The whiche that dwellyng was with Emelye
For he was wise / ⁊and koude soone espie
Of eủery seruant whiche that seruyth here
Wele koude he hewen wood and water bere
For he was yong and myghty for the nones
And therto he was stronge and bigge of bones
To doon that ony wight kan hym deuyse
A yere or two / he was in this seruyse
Page of the Chambre of Emelye the bryght
And Philostrat he seyde that he hight
But halfe so wele byloued a man as he
Ne was ther neủer in court of his degre
He was so gentell of condicioun
That thourgh out all the Court was his renoun
They seiden that it were a charitee
Tha Theseus wolde enhaunsen his degree
And putten hym in worshepfull seruyce
Ther as he myght his vertu excercise
And thus with ynne a while his name is spronge
Bothe of his dedis / and of his good tunge
That Theseus hath taken hym so ner
That of his Chambre / he made hym a squier
And gaf hym golde to maynten his degree
And eke men brought hym oute of his countree
Fro yeer to yere priuely his rente
But honestly and slyghly he it spente
That noman wondred / how that he it hadde
And three yeer in this wise / his lyfe he ladde
And bare hym soo in pees and eke in werre
Ther was noman that Theseus hath derre
And in this blisse lete I now arcite
And speke I wolle of Palamon a lyte
In derknesse / and horrible and strong prison
This seuen yeere / hath seten Palamon
Forpyned what for woo / and for distresse
Whoo feeleth double soore and heuynesse
But Palamon that loue distreyneth soo
That wood oute of his witte he gooth for woo
And eek therto he is a prisoner
Perpetuelly / nat oonly for a yeer
Who koude Ryme in englysshe ꝓproprely
His martirdoom for soth it am not I
Therfore I passe as lightly as I may
Hit felle in that seuenthe yeer of May
The thridde nyght as olde bokes seyn
That all this storie tellen more pleyn
Were it by auenture / or destynee
As whan a thyng is shapen it shall bee
That soone aftir the Midnyght palamon
By helpyng of a frende brake prison
And fleeth the Citee / fast as he may goo
For he hadde yeue / his gailere drynke soo
Of a Clarre maad of certeyn wyn
Whiche Nercotikes ⁊and opy of Thebes fyn
That all that nyght though men wolde hym shake
The gayller sleep he myght not a wake
And thus he fleeth as faste as eủer he may
The nyght was short and fast by the day
That nedes coste he most hym seluen hide
And tille a groue there fast bysyde
With dreedfull foot than stalked Palamon
For shortly / this was his opynyon
That in that groue he wolde hym hyde alday
And in the nyght than wolde he take his way
To Thebes ward / his freendes for to pray
On theseus / to helpe hym to werreye
And shortly outher wolde he lese his lyfe
Or wynnen Emelye vn to hys wyfe
This theffecte and his entent playn
Now wole I turne vn to Arcite a gayn
That litel wiste / how nygh that was his care
Tylle that fortune hadde brought hym in the snare
The besy larke Messenger of day
Salueth in here songe the morwe gray
And fyry Phebus riseth vp so bright
That all the Orient laugheth of the lyght
And with his stremes drieth in the greues
The siluer dropes hongyng on the leues
And Arcita that in the Court Roial
With Theseus his squyer principal
Is risen and loketh on the mury day
And for to doon his obseruaunce to May
Remembryng on the poynt of his desire
He on a Coursour starlyng as the fire
Is riden in to the feldes hym to pleye
Out of the Court were it amyle or tweye
And to the groue of whiche that I yow tolde
By auenture / his weye he gan to holde
To maken hym a garland of the greues
Were it of woodbynde / or haughthorn leues
And loude he songe a yein the sonne shene
May with all thy floures and thy grene
Welcome be thou / faire fresshe May
In hope that I som grene gete may
And from his courser with a lusty herte
In to the groue / full hastely he sterte
And in a paath / he rometh vp and don
There as by auenture this Palamon
Was in a busshe / that no man myght hym see
For soore a ferde of his deth was hee
No thynge ne knewe he / that it was Arcite
God woot he wolde haue trowed it full lyte
But sooth is seyde / go sithen many yerys
That feeld hath eyen / and the wood hath eeris
It is full faire / a man to bere hym / euene
For alday meten men at vnsette steuene
Ful litel woot Arcite of his felawe
That was so nygh to herknen al his sawe
For in the busshe he sitteth now full stille
Whan that Arcite hadde romed all his fille
And sungen all the roundel lustely
In a studie he felle sodenly
As doon these loueris / in here queynte geres
Now in the Croppe / now doun in the breres
Now vp now doun / as boket in a welle
Right as the friday soothly for to telle
Now it shyneth / now it reyneth faste
Right soo gan gery venus oủer caste
The hertes of her folke right as hire day
Is gerefull right soo / chaungeth she array
Selde is the friday / all the weke y leke
Whan that Arcite hadde songen / he gan to syke
And sette hym doun with oute any moore
Allas quod / he that day that I was bore
How longe Iuno thurgh thy crueltee
Woltow werreyen Thebes the Citee
Allas y brought / is to confusion
The blood Roial / of Cadme and Amphyon
Of Cadmus whiche that was the first man
That Thebes bulte or firste the toun by gan
And of the Citee first was crowned kyng
Of his lynage am I / and his of spryng
By verray ligne / as of the stok roial
And now I am so caityf and so thral
That he that is my mortal enemy turne over\v lefes to thys sygne
And in the grace / at tyme and place yset
This Arcite / and this Palamon ben met
To chaungen gan the colour in her face
Ryght as the huntere / in the regne of trace
That stondeth att / gappe with a spere
Whan hunted is the lyoun and the bere
And hereth hym come russhyng in the greues
And breke both bowes and the leues
And thynketh here cometh my mortal enemy
With oute faile / he moot be deed or I .
For outher I moot sleen hym at the gappe
Or he moot slee me / yf that me myshappe
So ferden they / in chaungeyng of her hewe
As fer as eủeryche of hem / oother knewe
Ther nas noo good day . ne no saluynge
But streight with outen worde / or rehersyng
Eueriche of hem heelp to arme other
As freendy as he were his owen brother
And aftir that with sharpe speris stronge
They foynen eche at other wonder longe
Thow myghtest wene that this Palamon
In his fightynge were a wood leon
And as a cruel Tygre was Arcite
As wilde bores / gon̄ they to smyte
That frothen white as foom / for Ire wood
Vp to the Ancle fought they in her blood
And in this wise I lete hem fightyng dwelle
And forth I wole of Theseus yow telle
The destyne / mynystre gen̉eral
That executeth / in the world oủeral
The purueyaunce that god hath seyn byforn
So stronge it is that though the world had sworn
The contrarie of a thynge be yee or nay
Yet somtyme it shall fallen on a day
That falleth nat efte / wᵗith Inne a thousand yere
For certeynly oure Appetites here
Be it of werre / or pees / or haat or loue
Al is this reuled by the syght a boue
This mene I now / by myghty Theseus
That for to hunten / is so desirus
And namely at the grete herte in may
That in his bedde / ther daweth hym no day
That he nys clad and redy for to ride
With hunte and horne / and houndis hym bysyde
For in his huntyng hath he suche delyte
That it is all his Ioye and Appetite
To ben hym selfe the greet hertis bane
For aftir Mars / he serueth now Dyane
Cleer was the day / as I haue tolde ere this
And Theseus with all Ioy and blys
With his Ipolita the faire quene
And Emelie clothed all in grene
On huntynge be they riden really
And to the groue that stode ful faste by
In whiche ther was an herte as men hym tolde
Duk Theseus the streit wey hath holde
And to the launde / he rideth hym full right
For thid̉er was the hert wont to haue his flyght
And oủer a brook and so foorth on his way
This Duk wol han a cours at hym or tway
With houndes suche as hym lyste cōmmaunde
And whan this Duk was comen in to the launde
Vnder the sonne he loketh / and a noon
He was ware of Arcite and Palamoon
That foughten breme as it were bulles twoo
The bright swerdes wenten to and froo
So hidously that with the leste stroke
It semed as it wolde falle an oke
But what they were no thyng he ne woote
This duke his Courser with his spores smote
And at a sterte he was be twene hem twoo
And pulled out a swerd and cried hoo
Nomore vp peyne of leesyng of youre hed
Be myghty Mars he shall a noon be ded
That smytyth any strook that I may seen
But telleth me what myster men ye ben
That ben so hardy for to fight here
With outen any Iuge / or other officere
As it were in a lystes really
This Palamon answerd hastily
And seide sire what nedith wordes moo

l.seg: And seide sire what nedith wordes moo

div.l: We haue the deeth deserued bothe twoo
Twoo woofull wrecches ben we / two caitifes
That ben encombred of oure owne lyfes
And as thou art a rightfull lorde and Iuge
Ne yeue vs neither mercy ne refuge
But slee me first / for seint charitee
But sle my felawe eke as wele as me
Or slee hym first / for though thow knowist hit lite
This is thy mortal foo this is Arcite
That from thy londe is banysshed on his heed
For whiche he hath deserued for to be deed
For this is hee that come vn to thy gate
And seyde that he hight Philostrate
Thus hath he Iaped the full many a yere
And thow hast maked hym thy squyere
And this he / that loueth Emelie
For sithe the day is come that I shal dye
I make pleynly my confession
That I am thilke wofull Palamon
That hath thy prisoun broken wikkedly
I am thy mortal foo and it am I .
That loueth soo Emelia the bryght
That I wol dye p̉re sent in her syght
Wherfore I axe deth and my Iewyse
But slee my felawe in the same wise
For bothe haue we deserued to be slayn
This worthy duke answerde a noon a gayn
And saide this is a short conclusioun
Youre owne mouth / by youre confessioun
Hath dampned yow / and I wolle it recorde
It nedith not to pyne yow with the corde
Ye shull be deed by myghty Mars the reede
The queene a noon / for verrey womanhede

div.l: (base) Gan for to wepe / and so dide Emelye
(base) And alle the ladies in the compaignye
(base) Grete pyte was it as it thought hem alle
(base) That euer swyche a chaunce sholde falle
(base) For gentel men they were / of greet estaat
(base) And nothyng but for loue was thys debaat
(base) And saugh hire blody woundes wyde and soore
(base) And alle criden bothe lasse and moroemooremorore
(base) Haue mercy lorde / vpon vs wymen alle
(base) And on hire bare knees / a doun they falle
(base) And wolde haue kyst hys feet / ther as he stood
(base) Til atte laste / a slaked was his mood
(base) For pitee renneth soone in gentel herte
(base) And though he furst for Ire quook ⁊ sterte
(base) He hath considered shortly in a clause
(base) The trespas of hem bothe / and eke the cause
(base) And al though that his ire / hire gilt accused
(base) Yet in his resoun hem bothe / excused
(base) As thus he thought wele that euꝰery man
(base) Wolle helpen hym selfe in loue if that he kan
(base) And eke delyuꝰere hym selfe out of prisoūn
(base) And eke his herte hadde compassioūn
(base) Of wōmmen for they wepten euꝰer in oon
(base) And in his gentil hert he thought a noon
(base) And softe vn to hym selfe / he seyde fy
(base) Vpon a lorde / that wol haue non mercy
(base) But be a leon / both in worde and dede
(base) To hem that ben in repentaunce and drede
(base) As wele as to a proude dispittous man
(base) That wole mayntene / that he first bygan
(base) That lorde hath litel of discrecioun
(base) That in suche a caas / can no deuysioun
(base) But weyeth pride and humblenesse aftꝰer oon
(base) And shortly whan his Ire is thus agoon
(base) He gan to loken vp / with eyen light
(base) And spake these wordes al on hight
(base) The god of loue a benedicite
(base) How myghty and how greet a loord is he
A yeins his myght ther gayneth noon obstacles
He may be cleped a god for his myracles
For he kan maken at his owne gyse
Of eủer yche hert as lyste hym deuyse
Loo here this Arcite and ⁊and this Palamoun
That quytly were oute of my prysoun
And myght haue leued in thebes reallye
And witen I am here mortal Enemye
And that hire deth light in my myght also
And yet hath loue maugre here yen twoo
Brought hem hyder both for to dye
Now loketh is not this an hie folie
Who may ben a fool / but if he loue ?
Byholde for goddes sake / that sitte a boue
Se how they blede / be they nought wele arraied
Thus hath hire lord / the god of loue y paied
Hire wages and her fees of hire seruyse
And yet they wenen / for to ben ful wise
That seruen loue for ought that may byfalle
And this is yet the beste game of alle
That shee / for whom they haue this Iolyte
Kan hem therfore / as moche thanke as me
Shee woot namore / of alle this hoot fare
By god than woot / a kokkowe or an hare
But alle m̄oot ben assaied hoot ⁊and coold
A man mote ben a foole / oỷer yong or olde
I woot it by my selfe / full yore a gon
For in my tyme a seruaunt was I oon
And therfore syn I knowe of loues peyne
And woot how sore / it kan a man destreyne
As he that hath ben caught / ofte in his laas
I yow foryeue al holly thys trespaas
At request of the quene / that kneleth here
And eeke of Emely my doughter dere
And ye shall booth a noon vnto me swere
That neuere moo / ye shall my cuntre dere
Ne make werre vpon me / nyght nor day
But ben my frendes in alle that ye may
I yow foryeue this trespas eủerydele
And they hym swore his axyng faire and wele
And hym of lordshep̄e and mercy praide
And he hem graunteth grace / and thus he sayde
To speke of Roial linage / and richesse
Though that shee were a quene or a pⁱrincesse
Eche of yow bothe / is worthy douteles
To wedden whan tyme is but natheles
I speke as for my dougter Emelye
For whom ye haue thys stryfe and Ialousye
Ye woot youre selfe / she may not wedden twoo
At ones though ye fighten eủer moo
That oon of yow / al be hym looth or leef
He moot goo pipen / in an yuy leef
This is to sayn she may not wedden bothe
Al be ye neủer so Ialous ne so wrothe
And forthy / I yow putte in thys degre
That eche of yow shall haue his destyne
As hym is shape / and harkeneth in what wyse /
Lo here youre ende of that I shall deuyse /
My wille is this / for plat conclusioun
With outen any replicacoıı̄un
Yf that yow lyketh / take it for the beste
That eủeryche shall goon where hym leste
Frely with outen raunsoun / or daunger
And this day fyfty wekes / fer ne ner
Eủeryche of yow / shall brynge an hundred knyghtes
Armed for lystes / vp at alle rightes
Al redy to darreyne hire by bataille
And this byhote I yow with outen faille
Vpon my trouth and as I am a knyght
That whether of yow bothe hath that myght
That is to seyne that whether he or thow
May with his hundrid as I spake of now
Slee his contrarie / or oute of lystes dryfe
Than shalle I yeve Emelia to wyfe
To whom that fortune yeueth so faire a grace
The lystes shall I maken on this place
And god so wissely on my soule rewe
As I shall euen Iuge ben and trewe
Ye shulle noon other eende with me make
That oon of yow ne shall be deed or take
And if yow thynketh this is wele y saide
Sey youre Auys / and holde yow apaide
This is youre ende and conclusion /
Whoo loketh lyghtly but Palamon
Whoo spryngeth vp for Ioy but Arcite
Whoo couthe telle or whoo couthe endite
The Ioy that maked is in that place
Whan Theseus hath doon so faire a grace
But doun on knees wente eủery maner of wight
And thonken hym with all her herte myght
And namely the Thebans ofte sithe
And thus with good hope / and wᵗith herte blithe
They take her leue / and homewarde gon they ryde
To Thebes with his walles wyde
The ordinaunce of lystys that Thesyus ordeynyd ⁊and c
I Trowe men wolde deme it necligence
Yf I foryete to telle the dispence
Of Theseus that gooth so bysyly
To maken vp the lystes really
That suche a noble Theatre as it was
I dar wele seyn / in this worlde ther nas
The circuyt a myle was aboute
Walled with stoon and diched al with oute
Rounde was the shap in man̉er of compas
Full of degrees the hight of fyfty paas
That whan a man was sette on oo degree turne x leves bakward
He letted noght his felawe forto see to thys syne
Estward ther stood a gaat of Marbel whyte
Westwarde suche another right in the oposyt
And shortly to concluden / swiche a place
Was noon in erthe / as in so litel a space
For in the londe ther was no crafty man
That Geometrie / or ars metryk kan
Ne pᵃartraier ne keruer of ymages
That Theseus ne yaf mete ⁊and wages
The Theatre for to maken ⁊and deuyse
And for to doon his rite ⁊and sacryfyse
He Estward / vpon the gaat a boue
In worsshep of venus goddesse of loue
Doon maken an auter / and an Oratorie
And on the westward in memorie
Of Mars he maked hath right suche a nother
That coste largely of golde a Fother
And Northward in a touret on the walle
Of Alabastre white ⁊and reed / coralle
An oratorie riche for to see
In worshep of Dyane of chastite
Hath Theseus doon wrought in noble wise
But yet hadde I forgeten to deuyse
The noble keruyng and the purtraitures
The shap and the cuntenance / and the figures
That weren in these Oratories three
First in the Temple of Venus maistow see
Wrought on the walle ful pitous to beholde
The broken slepes / and the sikes colde
The sacred teeris / and the waymentynge
The fyry strokes of the desirynge
That loues seruauntes in thys lyfe enduren
The oothes / that hire couenantz assuren
Plesaunce ⁊and hope / desire and fool hardynesse
Beaute and youthe / baudrie ⁊and richesse
Charmes and force / lesynges ⁊and flaterye
Despense bysynesse / and Ialousie

l.hi: That wered of yelow gooldes a gerland
And a Cokkowe syttyng on her hand

div.l: Feestes Instrumentz / caroles daunces
