div.l: Luste and array ⁊and alle the circumstaunces
Of loue whiche that I rekne shalle and rekne shalle
By ordre weren paynted on the walle
And moo than I kan make of mencoıı̄un
For sootly all the mounte of Citheron
Wher venus hath hire pⁱrincipallyeye dwellynge
Was shewed on the walle in purtraynge
With all the gardeyne ⁊and lustynesse
Nat was foryeten / the porter ydelnesse
Ne Narcisus the faire of yore a goon
Ne yet the folie of kyng Salamon
Ne yet the greet strenght of heEheErcules
Thenchauntementz of Medea and Circes
Ne of Turnes / with the hardi fiers corage
The riche Cresus / caytyf in seruage
Thus may ye seen that wysdom ne richesse
Beaute ne sleyght strenght hardynesse
Ne may wᵗith venus holde chamꝑpartie
For as hire luste / the worlde than may she gye
Loo all these folke so kaught were in hire laas
Til they for woo ful ofte seide allas
Suffiseth heer ensamples oon or twoo
And though I koude rekne a thousand moo
The statue of venus / glorious for to see
Was naked fleotyng in the colde see
And fro the nauel doun / al couered was
With wawes grene / and bright as any glas
A Citole in hire right honde had shee
And on hire heed ful semely for to see
A rose garland fresshe ⁊and wele smellynge
A boue hire heed / hire dowues flykerynge
Byforn hire stood hire sone Cupidoo
Vpon hise sholdres wynges hadde he twoo
And blynde he was / as it is ofte sene
A bowe he bare and arwes bright ⁊and kene
Why sholde I nat as wele / eke telle yow alle
The purtreture that was vpon the walle
With Inne the Temple of myghty Mars the reed
Al peynted was the walle / in lenght and brede

seg.seg: Lyke to the estres of the grysly place

div.l: That hight the greet Temple of Mars in Trace
In thilke colde frosty regyoun
Ther as Mars hath his soủereyne mansioun
First on the walle was peynted a forest
In whiche ther dwelleth neyther man ne beest
With knotty knarry / barreyn trees olde
Of stubbes sharpe / and hidouse to beholde
In whiche ther ranne a rumbel in a swogh
As though a storme / sholde bresten eủery bogh
And dounward from an hulle / vnder a bente
Ther stood the Temple of Mars Armypotente
Wrought al of burned steel / of whiche the entree
Was longe and streite ⁊and gastly for to see
And ther oute kam a rage / and suche a veze .i. impetꝰus
That it made all the gate for to rese
The Northren light / yn at the dores shoon
For wyndowe on the walle / ne was ther noon
Thurgh whiche men myghten / any light discerne
The doore was all of Adamaund eterne
I clenched oủer twhart ⁊and endelong
With Iren towe and for to make it stronge
Euery piler the temple to sustene
Was tonne greet / of Iren bright ⁊and shene
Ther say I firste the derke ymagenynge
Of felonye / ⁊and all the compasynge
The cruel Ire / as reed as any gleede
The Pykepurs / and eke the pale drede
The smylere with the knyf vnder the clooke
The shepne brennyng / with the blake smoke
The tresoun of the morthryng / in the bedde
The opne werre with woundes al by bledde
Conteke with blody knyfe and sharpe manace
Al ful of chirkyng / was that sory place
The sleer of hym selfe / yet saugh I there
His herte blood / hath bathed al his here
The nayle I dryue / in the shode a nyght
The colde dethe / wᵗith mouth gapyng vpryght
A myddes of the temple sate meschaunce
With discomfort and sory contenaunce
Yet saugh I woodnes / laughhyng in his Rage
Armed compleynt thouthes / and fiers outrage
The karoyne in the busshe . wᵗith throte y corue
A thousand slayn / on noght of qual y storue
The Tyraunt with the praie / by force y rafte
The Toun destruyed ther was no thyng lafte
Yet saugh I brent the shippes hoppesteres
The hunte strangled with the wilde beres
The sowe freten the childe / right in the cradel
The cook y scalded for alle his long ladel
Nought was forgeten / by the Infortune of Marte
The Cartere ouer riden with his carte
Vndir the wheel full lowe he lay a doun
There were also of Martes dyuysyoun
The barbour and the bochier / and the smyth
That forgeth sharpe swerdes / on his stith
And alle a boue depeynted in a toure
Saugh I conquest sittyng in greet honoure
With the sharpe swerde oủer his heed
Hangyng by a subtill twyned threed
Depaynted was the slaughter of Iulius
Of grete Nero / ⁊and of Anthonius
Al by that thilke tyme they were vnborn
Yet was her deth / depainted ther byforn
By manasyng of Mars / right by figure
So was it shewed in that portreiture
As is depeynted in the sterrys a boue
Whoo shall be slayn / or ellys deed for loue
Sufficeth oon ensample / in stories olde
I may noght rekne hem alle / thogh I wolde
The statue of Mars / vpon a Cart stode
Armed and loked / grym as he were woode
And oủer his heed ther shynen two figures
Of sterris that ben clept in scriptures
That oon Puella / that other Rubeus
This god of armes / was arraied thus
A wolfe ther stood byforn hym at his feet
With eyen reed and of a man he eet
With subtil pensil / was depainted this storie
In redoutyng of Mars / ⁊and of his glorie
Now to the Temple of dyane the chaste
As shortly as I kan I wole me haste
To telle yow all the descripcioun
Depeinded ben the walles vp ⁊and doun
Of huntyng and of shamefast / chastitee
Ther sawe I / how woful Calystopee
Whan that Dyane / a greued was wᵗith here
Was turned from a woman til a bere .visa maior.
And after was she made the lood sterre
Thus was it peynted I kan sey yow no ferre
Here sone is eke a sterre as men may see
Ther saugh I dane y turned til a tree
I mene not the goddesse dyane
But Penneus doughter / whiche that hight dane
Ther saugh I Attheon an hert y maked
For vengeaunce that he saugh dyane al naked
I saugh how that his houndes haue hym caught
And fretyn hym / for that they knewe hym naught
Yet poynted was a lytel forther more
How Attalante hunted the wilde boore
And Meliagree and many a nother moo
For whiche diane / wrought hym care ⁊and woo
Ther saugh I many a nother wondre storie
The whiche me lyst noght drawe to memorie
This goddesse on an herte full high seet
With smale houndes / all a boute her feet
And vnderneth her feet / she hadde a moone
Wexyng it was / and sholde wanye sone
In gaudee grene / hire statue y clothed was
With bowe in hoond and arwes in a caas
Her eyen caste she full lowe a doun
Ther pluto hath his derke regyoun
A woman trauelyng was hire byforn
But for hire childe / so longe was vnborn
Full Pitously lucyna / gan she calle
And seide helpe for thou maist beste of alle
Wele koude he peynte / lyfly that it wrought
With many a floryn he the hewes bought
Now ben these lystes made ⁊and Theseus
That at his greet coste / arraied thus
The Temples / and the Tyatre eueridele
Whan it was doon / hym lyked wonder wele
But stynte I wole of Theseus a lyte
And speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
The day approcheth of her retournyng
That eủeryche an hundred knyghtes shulde bryng
The bataille to darreyn / as I yow tolde
And til Athenes hire couenant for to holde
Hath eủeryche of hem / y brought an hundred knyghtes
Wele armed for the werre at alle rightes
And sikirly ther trowid many a man
That neủer sithen that / the worlde bygan
As for for to speke of knyghthode of hire hond
As fer as god hath maked see and lond
Nas of soo fewe / so noble a compaignye
For eủery wight that loued chiualrye
And wolde his thankes han a passaunt name
Hath praide that he myght ben at that game
And wele was hym / that therto chosen was
For if ther felle to morwe / swiche a caas
Ye knowen wele that eủery lusty knyght
That loueth ꝑparamours / ⁊and hath his myght
Were it in Engelonde / or ellys where
They wole her thankes / wilnen to be there
To fight for a lady benedicite
Yt were a lusty sight for to see
And right so ferden they with Palamon
With hym ther wenten knytes many oon
Som wole ben armed in an haubergeon
And in a brestplate / and in a light gipeon
And som wil haue / a peire plates large
And som will haue / a pruce sheeld or a targe
Som wolle ben armed / on his legges wele
And haue an axe / and som̄ a maas of stele
Ther nys non newe gyse / that is nat olde
Armed were they as I haue yow tolde
Eueriche after his opynyon
Ther maistow sen comyng wᵗith Palamon
Lygurge hym selfe / the grete kyng of Trace
Blakke was his berde / and manly was his face
The sercles of hys yen / in his heed
They gloweden bytwixen yelewe and reed
And like a Gryffoun / loked he a bouttee
With kempe heres / on his browis stoute
Hys lymes grete / his braune is harde ⁊and stronge
His shuldres brood / his armes rounde ⁊and longe
And as the gyse was in his cuntree
Full hie vpon a chare of gold stood hee
With foure white boles in the Trays
In stede of coot armure / ouer his harneys
With nailes yelwe / ⁊and bright as any golde
He had a beres skyn / colblak / for olde
His longe heer was kymbed behynde his bak
As any Rauoıı̄uns fether it shoon for blak
A wrethe of golde / arme grete of huge wight
Vpon his heed / set full of stones bright
Of fyne Rubies / and of diamauntes
A boute his chare / there wente white Alauntez
Twenty and moo / as greet as any stere
To hunten at the leoun / or the deere
And folwed hym with mosel faste y bounde
Colerd of golde / and turretis filed rounde
An hundred lordes / had he in his route
Armed full wele / with hertes sterne ⁊and stoute
With Arcita / in stories as men fynde
The grete Emetryus / the kyng of ynde
Vppon a steed bay trapped in steel
Couered in a cloth of golde diapred wele
Cam rydyng lyke the god of armes Mars
His coot Armure was of clooth of Taars
Couched wᵗithꝑperles / white ⁊and rounde and grete
His sadel was of brend gold new ybete
A Mantelet vpon his sholder hangynge
Bretful of Rubies / reed as fuyr sparklynge
His crispe heer / lyke rynges was y ronne
And that was yelowe / and glyttred as the sonne
His nose was high / his yen bright as cytryn
Hise lyppes rounde / his colour was sanguyn
A fewe frakenes / in his face y spreynd
Bytwixe yelowe / and somdel blakke y meynd
And as a lyoun he his lokyng caste
Of fyue and twenty yere / his age I caste
His berde was wele bygonne for to sprynge
His voys was as a trompe thonderynge
Vpon his heed he wered of laurer grene
A garland fresshe and lusty for to sene
Vpon his honde / he bare for his deduyt
An Egle tame as any lylye white
An hundred lordes / hadde he wᵗith hym there
Al armed / saue her hedes in all here gere
Full richely in all maner thynges
For trusteth wele that dukes Erlys ⁊and kynges
Were gaderid in all this compaignye
For loue ⁊and encrece of chyualrie
A boute this kyng ther ranne on eủery part
Full many a tame leoun / ⁊and leopart
And in these wise / these lordes alle ⁊and some
Ben on the sonday to the Cite come
A boute prime / and in the toun a lyght
This Theseus this duke this worthy knyght
Whan he hadde brought hem in to his Citee
And Ioyned hem / eủeryche at his degree
He festeth hem / and doth so grete labour
To easen hem / ⁊and don hem alle honour
That yet men wenen / that no mannes wit
Of noon estate ne koude amende it
The mynstralcye / the seruyce atte feste
The greet yeftes / to the meste and leste
The riche array of theseus Paleys
Ne whoo satte furst ne laste / vpon the deys
What ladies fairest ben / or beste daunsynge
Or whiche of hem / kan daunsen beste ⁊and synge
Ne whoo most felyngly / speketh of loue
What haukes sitten on the perche a boue
What houndes liggen on the flore adoune
Of alle this make I now no mencyoune
But alle theffecte thynketh me the beste
Now cometh the poynt ⁊and herkeneth if ye leste
The soneday nyght or day bygan to sprynge
Whan Palamon / the larke harde synge
Al though it nere nought day by oures twoo
Yet songe the larke and Palamon right thoo
With holy herte ⁊and with an hie corage
He roos to wenden on his pilgrymage
Vn to the blysfull Citherea benyngne
I mene venus honurable ⁊and digne
And in hire oure / he walketh forth a paas
Vn to the lystes / there hire temple was
And doun he kneleth ⁊and with humble chere
And herte soor / he seide as ye shull here
Fairest of faire o lady myn venus
Doughter to Ioue / and spouse of vulcanus
Thow glader of the mounte Citheron
For thilke loue thou haddest to Alteon
Haue pitee of my bittre teeris smert
And take myn humble praiere at thyn herte
Allas I ne haue no langage to telle
Theffecte ne the torment of myn helle
Myn herte may nat myn harmes nat by wreye light cares do easly speake
I am soo confus that I kan not seye But greate ye harm do breake
But mercy lady bright that knowest wele
My thought ⁊and seest what harmes that I fele
Considre all this / and rewe vpon my sore
As wissely as I shall for eủer more
Emforth my myght / thy trewe seruant be
And holden werre alway with chastite
That make I myn avowe / so ye be myn helpe
I kepe nat of armes for to yelpe
Ne I axe not to morwe to haue victorie
Ne renoun in this caas / ne veyne glorie
Of pris of armes / blowen vp and doun
But I wolde haue fully possessioun
Of Emely / ⁊and dye in thy seruyse
Fynde thow the maner / howe ⁊and in what wise
I recche nat / but it may bettre be
To haue victorie of hem / or thay of me
So that I haue myn lady in myn armes
For thogh so be / that Mars is god of armes
Youre vertue is so greet in heuene a boue
That if yow lyste I shall wele haue myn loue
Thy temple wole I worshepe eủer moo
And on thyn Auter where I ride or goo
I wole doon sacryfice / and fires bete
And if ye wol nat so / my lady swete
Thanne pray I the / to morwe with a spere
That Arcite / me thurgh the herte bere
Than rekke I not whan I haue lost my lyf
Though that Arcite / wynne hire to his wyf
This is the effecte and ende of my praiere
Yef me my loue / thou blisfull lady dere
Whan the Orisoun was doon of Palamon
His sacryfice he dide and that a noon
Full pitously with alle circumstaunces
Alle telle I nat as now his obseruaunces
But atte laste / the statue of venus shook
And made a signe / wherby he took
That his praier / accepted was that day
For though the signe shewed a delay
Yet wiste he wele / that gᵃraunted was his boone
The thridde oure / inequal that Palamon
Began to venus temple for to gon
Vp roos the sonne / and vp roos Emelye
And to the temple of diane gan hie
Hire maidens / that she thider with hire ladde
Full redyly / with hem the fire they hadde
Thencens / the clothes / and the remenaunt all
That to the sacryfice longen shall
The hoornes full of Meeth / as was the gyse
Ther lakked noght to don̄ her sacryfice
Smokyng the temple / full of clothes faire
Thys Emely / with herte debonaire
Hire body waisshe with water of a welle
But how she dide hire ryte / I dar nat telle
But if it be any thynge general
And yet it were a game to heren al
To hym that meneth wele it nere no charge
But it is good a man be at his large
Hire bright here was kembed vntressed alle
A corone of a grene ooke cerialle
Vpon hire heed was sette ful faire ⁊and mete turne over x levys to
Two fires on the auter / gan shee bete thys sygne ✡
And dide hire thynges / as men may byholde ✡
In state of Thebes / and thise bokes olde
Whan kyndelyd was the fire with pitous chere
Vn to dyane / she spak as ye may here
O chaste goddesse / of the wodes grene
To whom bothe heuene / ⁊and erthe and see is sene
Quene of the reigne of Pluto derke ⁊and lowe
Goddesse of Maydons myn hert hast knowe
Full many a yere / and woste what I desire
As kepe me / from thyn vengeaunce thananthanan thyn Ire
That Attheon a bought cruelllycruellyycruelllycruellyy
Chaste goddesse / wele wostowe that I
Desire to ben / a mayden / all my lyfe
Ne neủer wol I be / no loue ne wyfe
I am thou woste yet of thy companye
A maide and loue huntyng and venerie
And for to walken in the wodes wilde
And noght to ben a wyfe and ben with childe
Nat wolle I knowe / compaignye of man
Now helpe me lady / sith ye may and kan
For thoo three formes / that thow haste in the
And Palamon that hath suche loue to me
And eke Arcite / that loueth me so sore
This grace I praye the with oute moore
And sende loue and pees / bytwixe hem twoo
And fro me turne a wey hire hertes soo
That al hire hote loue / and hire desire
And alle hire besy turment and hire fire
Be queynte or torned in a nother place
And if so be / thow wilt nat do me grace
Or if my destynee / be shapen soo
That I shall nedes / han oon of hem twoo
As sende me hym / that moost desireth mee
Byholde goddesse / of clene chastitee
The bittre teeris / that on my chekes falle
Syn thou art mayde / and keper of vs alle
My Maidenhood thow kepe and wele conserue
And while I leue a mayde I wol the serue
The fires brenne / vp on the auter clere
While Emelye was thus in hire praiere
But sodenly she seigh a sight queynte
For right a noon / oon of the fires queynte
And quyked agayn̄ / and aftir that a noon
That other fier was queynt and alle a goon
And as it queynte it made a whistelyng
As doon these weet brondes in her brennyng
And at the brondes ende / out ranne a noon
As it were blody dropes many oon
For whiche so soore agaste was Emelye
That she was wel nygh madde / ⁊and gan to crye
For she ne wist / what it signyfyed
But oonly for the fere / thus hath she cried
And wepe that it was pite for to here
And there with alle Diane gan apere
With bowe in honde / right as an hunteresse
And seide doughter stynte thyn heuynesse
Amonge the goddis hie it is affermed
And by eterne worde / writen and confermed
Thow shalte by wedded vn to oon of thoo
That han for the / so moche care ⁊and woo
But vn to whiche of hem I may noght telle
Fare wele for I ne may no lenger dwelle
The fires / whiche that on myn auter brenne
Shulle the declaren / er that thow goo henne
Thyn auenture of loue / as in this caas
And with that worde / the arwes in the caas
Of the goddesse / clatren faste and rynge
And forth she wente / and made a vanysshynge
For whiche this Emelye / astoyned was
And saide what amounteth this allas
I putte me / in thy protecciōun
Diane / and in thy disposicioun
And hom shee gooth a noon the nexte weye
This is the effecte ther nys namore to seye
The next houre of Mars folwyng thys
Arcite vn to the temple walked is
Of fiers Mars / to doon his sacryfise
With all the rightes / of his paien wise
With pitous herte and high deuocioun
Ryght thus to Mars / he seide his orisoun
O stronge god that in the regnes colde
Of Trace honoured art / lord I holde
And haste in eủery reigne / and eủery londe
Of Armes / all the bridel in thyn honde
And hem fortunest as the lyst deuyse
Accepte of me / my pitous sacryfise
Yf so be that my youthe may deserue
And that my myght may be worthy for to serue
Thi godheed / that I may ben oon of thyne
Than pray I the / to rewe vpon my pyne
For thilke peyne / and thilke hoot fyr
In whiche thow whilom brendest for desir
Whan that thow vsedest the beaute
Of faire yonge freisshe venus free
And haddest hire in armes at thi wylle
All thogh that thee oones / on a tyme mysfylle
Whanne vulcanus hadde caught the in his laas
And fonde the lyggyng by his wif allas
For thilke sorwe that / was in thyn herte
Haue reuthe vpon my peynes smerte
I am yonge and vnkonnyng as thow woost
And as I trowe with loue offendid moost
That eủer was / any lyues creature
For she that dooth me al this woo endure
Ne reccheth neủer where I synke or flete
And wele I woot or she me mercy hete
I mote with strenght wynne her in the place
And wele I woot with outen helpe or grace
Of thee / ne may my strenght nought availle
Than helpe me lorde / to morwe in my bataille
For thilke fir / that whilom brent the
As wele as thilke fire now brenneth me
And do / that I to morwe haue victorie
Myn be the trauaille / and thyn be the glorie
Thy soủereigne temple wole I moost honouren
Of any place / and alwey moost labouren
In thy plesaunce / and in thy craftes stronge
And in thy temple / I wolle my banner honge
And alle the armes of my companye
And eủer moo / vn tille that day I dye
Eterne fire / byfore the I wole fynde
And eke to this avowe / I wolle me bynde
My beerd myn here / that hongith longe a doun
That neủer yette felte offensioun
Of Rasour nor of shire / I wole the yeue
And ben thyn trewe seruant while I leue
Now lorde haue reuthe vpon my sorwes sore
Yef me the victorie / I aske the nomore
The praiere stynte of Arcita the stronge
The rynges on the temple dore that honge
And eke the dores clatereden full faste
Of whiche Arcita / somwhat of hym agaste
The fires brenden / vpon the auter bryght
That it gan all the temple for to lyght
And swete smel / the grounde a noon vp yaf
And Arcita / a noon his hand vp haf
And more encense / in to the fire he caste
With other rites moo / and atte laste
The statue of Mars bygan his hauberke rynge
And with that soun / he hard a murmurynge
Full lowe ⁊and dym that seide thus. victorie
For whiche he yaf to Mars / honour ⁊and glorie
And thus with Ioye / and hope wele to fare
Arcite a noon / in to his Inne is fare
As fayn as fowel is of the bright sonne
And right a noon / suche stryfe ther is bygonne
For thilke gᵃrauntyng in the heuene a boue
Betwixe venus and the goddesse of loue
And Mars the sterne god omnipotente
That Iubiter was besy it to stente
Til that the pale / saturnus the colde
That knewe so manye / of auentures olde
Fonde in his olde exꝑperience / an arte
That he ful sone / hath pleised eủery part
As soth is saide / elde hath grete avauntage
In elde is bothe wisdom ⁊and vsage
Men may the olde at renne / and noght at rede
Saturne a noon to stynten stryf and drede
All be it that it is a gayn his kynde
Of alle this stryfe he gan / a remedye fynde
My dere doughter venus qd saturne
My cours that hath so wide for to turne
Hath more powere / than woot any man
Myn is the drenchyng in the see so wan
Myn is the prisoun in the derke cote
Myn is the stranglyng and hangyng by the throte
The murmur and the cherles rebellyng
The groynynge / and the priue empoisonyng
I doo vengeaunce / and plein correccioun
While I dwelle in the signe of the lyoun
Myn is the Iuyne / of the hie halles
The fallyng of the toures / and of the walles
Vpon the mynour or the carpunter
I slough Sampson / shakyng the pilere
And myne ben the maladies colde
The derke tresoun / and the castes olde
My lokyng is the fader of pestilence
Now weep namore I shall doon diligence
That palamon that is thyn owen knyght
Shalle haue the lady as thow haste hym hight
Thow mars shalle helpe his knyght yet nartheles
Betwixe yow ther mote be somtyme be pees
Al be ye noght of oo complexion
That causeth al day suche dyuysion
I am thyn Aiel / redy at thi wille
Weep now namore / I shall thy luste fulfille
Now wole I stynten of the goddesse a boue
Of mars and of venus / goddesse of loue
And telle yow as pleynly as I kanne
The greet effecte for whiche that I beganne
Grete was the feste in Athenes that day
And eke the lusty sesoun of that may
Made eủery wight to bene in suche plesaunce
That al that moneday Iuste they and daunce
And spende it in venus high seruyse
But by the cause that they sholde ryse
Erly for to seen that grete sight
Vn to her reste / wente they at nyght
An on the morwe / whan that day gan sprynge
Of hors and harneys / noyse and claterynge
There was in hostelries al aboute
And to the Paleys rood there many a route
Of lordes vpon stedis / and palfrays
Ther maistow see dyuysyng of harneys
So vnkouth and so riche / and wroght so weel
Of goldsmythrie / of broudyng and of stele
The sheldes bryght / testeres / and trappures
Gold hewen helmes / hauberkes cote armures
Lordes in parementz / on hire coursers
Knyghtes of retenue / and eke squyers
Naylyng the speres / and helmes bokelyng
Gyggyng of sheldes / with layners lasyng
Ther as nede is / they were nothyng ydel
The fomy stedys / on the golden bridel
Gnawyng and faste the armures also
With file ⁊and hamour priken to and fro
Yemen on fote / and comunes many oon
With short staues / thikke as they may goon
Pype Trompes / Nakers / claryons
That in the bataille blowen blody souns
The Paleys full of poeple vp ⁊and doun
Here three there ten / holdynge here questioun
Deuynyng of these thebane knyghtes two
Sōmme seiden thus / sōmme seide it shal be so
Sōmme helden with hym / with the blake berde
Sōmme with the balled sōmme wtith the thik herde
Sōmme seide he loked grȳmme / and he wolde fight
He hath a sparth / of twenty pounde of wight
Thus was the halle fulle of deuynyng
Longe after that the sonne gan to spryng
The grete Theseus that of his sleep awaked
With mynstralsie and noyse that was maked
Heeld yet the chambres / of his paleys riche
Tille that the Thebane / knyghtes / bothe ylyche
Honoᵘured weren / in to the Paleys fet
Duk Theseus / is at the wyndowe sette
Arraied right as he were a god in trone
The peple preyseth thiderward ful sone
Hym for to sen / and doon high reuerence
And eke to herkene his heest and his sentence
An heraud on a scaffolde made an oo
Till all the noyse / of the peple was doo
And whan he say the noyse of the peple al stille
Thus shewed he / the myghty dukes wille
The lorde hath of his hie discrecioun
Considerid that it were distruccioun
To gentil blood / to fighten in this gyse
Of mortal bataille / now in this emprise
Wherfore to shapen that they shall not dye
He wole his furst pᵃrapos modyfye
Noman therfore vpon peyne of losse of lyfe
No maner shot ne pollax / ne short knyfe
In to the lystes sende / or thider brynge
Ne short swerde for to stoke wᵗith poynt bytynge
Noman ne drawe / ne bere it be his syde
Ne no man shall vn to his felawe ryde
But o cours / with a sharpe ygrounde spere
Foyne if hym lyst on foot / hym selfe to were
And he that is at myschef shal be take
And noght slayn / but be broght vn to the stake
That shall ben ordeyned on eyther syde
And thider he shall by force / and there abyde
And if so falle / the chiefteyn be take
On outher syde / or ellys sleen his make
No lenger shall the turneynge laste
God spede yow goo forth and ley on faste
Wit longe swerde and with mace / fighteth youre fille
Goo now youre wey this is the lordis wille
The voys of peple / touched the heuene
So loude cried they / with mery steuene
God saue suche a lorde that is so good
He wilneth no distruccoıı̄un of blood
Vp goth the trompes / and the melodye
And to the lystes / rit the compaignye
By ordynaunce / thourgh out the citee large
Hanged with cloth of golde and nat with sarge
Ful lyke a lorde / this noble duke gan ryde
These twoo thebanes / vpon either syde
And after rood the queene / ⁊and Emelye
And aftir that a nother compaignye
Of oon and other aftir hire degree
And thus they passen thourgh oute the citee
And to the lystes come they bytyme
It nas nat at the day yet fully prime
Whan sette was Theseus full riche ⁊and hie
Ipolyta the queene ⁊and Emelye
And other ladies in degrees a boute
Vn to the setes preseth all the route
And westward thurgh the gatis vndir Mart .I. sub Marte
Arcite ⁊and eke the hundrid of his part
With baner reed is entrid right anoon
And in that selue moment Palamon
Is vnder venus / Estward in that place
With baner white ⁊and hardy chere ⁊and face
In all the worlde to seken vp ⁊and doun
So euene with oute variacioun
There nere / suche compaignyes tweye
For there nas noon so wise that couthe seye
That any hadde of other avauntage
Of worthynesse / ne of estate ne age
So euen were they chosen for to gesse
And in two renges / faire thay hem dresse
Whan that hire names / was radde euerichon
That in thaire nombre / gyle were there noon
Thoo were the gates shette / and cried was loude
Do now youre deuoir / yonge knyghtes proude
The heraudes / lefte her prikyng vp ⁊and doun
Now ryngen trompes loude and clarioun
There is nomoore to seyn but weste ⁊and Este
In goth the speres full sadly in the arrest
In goth the sharpe spore / in to the side
Ther seen men / whoo kan Iuste ⁊and who kan ride
There shirieren shaftes / vpon sheldes thykke
He feleth thurgh the hert spoon the prikke
Vp spryngen speres / twenty foot on hight
Oute gon the swerdes / as the silủer bright
The helmes they hewen and to shrede
Out brest the blood / with sterne stremes rede
With myghti maces / the bones they to breste
He thurgh the thikkest of the thronge gan threste
There stomblen steedys stronge / and doun goth alle
He rolleth vnder foot / as doth a balle
He foyneth on his feet / with his troıı̄unchon
And he hym hurtlyth wᵗith his hors a doun
He thurgh the body is hurt / ⁊and sithen y take
Maugre his heed / and brought vn to the stake
As forward was / right there he moste abyde
A nother lad is on that other syde
And somtyme doth hem Theseus to reste
Hem to refresshe / and drynke yf hem leste
Full ofte a day / haue these Thebanes twoo
To gidre y mette / and wroght his felawe woo
Vnhorsed hath eche other / of hem twey
Ther was no tigre in the vale of Galgophey
Whan that hire whelpe is stole / whan it is lyte
So cruel on the hunte / as is Arcite
For Ialous herte / vpon this Palamon
Ne in Belmarie / ther nys so felle leon
That hunted is / or for his hunger wood
Ne of his praye / desireth so the blood
As Palamon / to slen his foo Arcite
The Ialous strokes / on hir helmes bite
Oute renneth blood / on bothe hire sides rede
Somtyme an ende ther is of eủery dede
For er the sonne vnto the reste wente
The stronge kyng Emetryus / gan hente
This Palamon as he faught with Arcite
And made his swerde / depe in his fleisshe to byte
And by the force of twenty / is he take
Vnyolden / and y drawen to the stake
And in this rescus / of this Palamon
The stronge kyng lygurge ys born a doun
And kyng Emetryus for all his strenghthe
Is born oute of his sadell / a swerde lengthe
So hitte hym Palamon er he were take
But al for noght he was ledde vn to the stake
His hardy hert myght hym helpe naught
He moste abide whan that he was kaught
By force ⁊and eke by composicoun

div.l: (base) Whoo sorwith now / but woful Palamon
(base) That mote namore goon a gayn to fight
(base) Whan that Theseus hadde seyn that sight
(base) Vn to the folke / that foughten thus echoon
(base) He cried hoo namore for it is doon
(base) I wole be trewe Iuge / and not partie
(base) Arcite of Thebes shall haue EmelyeEmelye
(base) That by his fortune hath hire faire y wonne
(base) A noon ther is a noyse of people bygonne
(base) For Ioye of this so loude and hie with alle
(base) Yt semed that the lystes sholde falle
(base) What kan now faire venus doo a boue
(base) What seith she now / what dooth this queene of loue
(base) But wepyth so / for wantyng of her wille
(base) Til that hire teeris / in the listes fille
(base) She saide I am a shamed douteles
(base) Saturnus saide doughter holde thi pees
(base) Mars hath his wille / his knyght hath al his boone
(base) And be myn heed thou shalt ben eased soone
(base) The trompours with the loude mynstralcye
(base) The heraudes / that fulle loude yelle ⁊ crie
(base) Ben in here wele / for ioye of daun Arcite
(base) But herkneth me ⁊ stynteth noyse alyte
(base) Whiche amyracle ther byfel a noon
(base) This fiers Arcite hath of his helme y doon
(base) And ouꝰer a courser for to shewe his face
(base) He priketh endelong / the large place
(base) Lokyng vpwarde / vpon this Emelye
(base) And she agayn hym caste a frendeliche ye
(base) For wymen as speketh the comune
(base) They folowe the fauour of Fortune
(base) And was all his chere as in his herte
(base) Oute of the grounde a fury infernal sterte
(base) From Pluto sente at request of Saturne
(base) For whiche his hors for fere gan to turne
(base) And lepte a side / and foundred as he leepe
(base) And er that Arcite / may taken kepe
(base) He pight hym on the pomel of his heed
(base) That in the place / he lay as he were deed
(base) His breest to brosten. with his sadel bowe
(base) As blak he lay as any cole or crowe
So was the blood y ronnen in his face
A noon he was y born oute of the place
With herte soor / to Theseus Paleys
Tho was he koruen out of his harneys
And in a bedde y brought full faire and blyue
For he was yet in memorie and a lyue
And alway cryeng aftir Emelye
Duke Theseus with all his compaignye
Is comen hoom / to Athenes his citee
With alle blysse / and grete solempnytee
Al be it that this Auenture was falle
He nolde noght discomforten hem alle
Men saide eeke / that Arcite shall not dye
He shall ben helid of his maladye
And of another thynge they were as fayne
That of hem alle / ther was noon y slayn
Alle were they soore I hurte / and namely oon
That with a spere / was thirled his breest boon
To othere woundes and to broken Armes
Sōmme hadden salues and sōmme hadden charmes
Fermacies of herbes and eke saue
They dronken for they wolde her lymes haue
For whiche this noble duke as he wele kan
Comforteth and honoureth eủery man
And made reuel / al the longe nyght
Vn to the straunge lordes as was right
Ne ther was holden / no disconfitynge
But as a Iustes or a tourneyinge
For sootly ther was non disconfiture
For fallyng is nat but an auenture
Ne to be ladde by force vn to the stake
Vn yolden and with twenty knyghtes take
O ꝑpersone all with outen moo
And haried forth / by arme foot and too
And eke his stede dryuen forth with staues
With footmen / bothe yemen ⁊and eke knaues
Yt was arettid hym no vylenye
Ther may noman clepe it cowardie
For whiche a non duke Theseus lete crie
To stynten all rancour / and enuye
The gree as wele of oo syde as of other
And eyther syde ylyke as otheris brother
And yaf hem yeftes after hire degree
And fully helde a feste of daies three
And conueyed the knyghtes worthyly
Oute of his toun / a iorney largely
And hoom wente eủery man / the right way
There was nomore / but farewel haue good day
Of this bataille / I wolle nomore endite
But speke of Palamon / and of Arcite
Swellith the breest of Arcite / and the sore
Encrescit at his herte moore ⁊and more
The clothered blood for any lechecrafte
Corrupteth and is in his bouke y lafte
That neither veyne blood / ne ventusynge
Ne drynke of herbes may ben his helpynge
The vertue expulsif or animal
Fro thilke vertue / cleped natural
Ne may the venym voiden ne expelle
The pipes of his longes gan to swelle
And eủery lacerte / in his breest a doun
Ys shent with venym and corrupcioun
Hym gayneth not to gete his lyfe
Vomet vpwarde / ne dounward laxatyfe
Al is brosten that Regioun
Nature hath no dominacioun
And certeynly there nature wol not werche
Fare wele Phesyke go bere the man to cherche
This is al ⁊and som / that Arcita moot dye
For whiche he sendith after Emelye
And Palamon that was his cosyn dere
Thanne seide he thus as ye shal aftir here
Nat may the woful spirit in myn herte
Declare apoint of alle my sorwes smerte
To yow my lady / that I loue moste
But I be quethe yow / the seruyse of my goste
To yow a bouen euery creature
Syn that myn lyfe may no lenger dure
Allas the woo / allas the peynes stronge
That I for yow haue suffred and that so longe
Allas the dethe / Allas my Emelye
Allas deꝑpertyng of oure companye
Allas my hertes queene / Allas my wife
Myn hertes lady / ender of my lyfe
What is this worlde / what axeth men to haue
Now with his loue / now in his colde graue
Allone with outen any companye
Fare wele my swete foo / my Emelye
And softe take me / in youre armes tweye
For loue of god / and herkene what I shall seye
I haue here with myn cosyn Palamon
Hadde stryfe and rancour many a day a gon
For loue of yow / and for my Ialosye
And Iuppit̉er so wys my soule gye
To speken of a seruaunt ꝓproprelye
With circumstaunces alle trewelye
That is to seyn / trouth / honour / knyghthede
Wysdome / humblesse / estate / ⁊and highe kynrede
Fredom / and all that longith to that arte
So Iuppiter haue / of myn soule parte
As in this worlde / right nowe ne knewe I noon
So worthy to ben loued / as Palamon
That serueth yow / ⁊and wolle don al his lyfe
And if that eủer ye shall ben a wyfe
Foryet nat Palamon the gentil man
And with that worde his speche faile gan
For froom his feet vp to his breste was come
The colde of dethe / that hadde hym oủercome
And yet more oủer for in his armes twoo
The vital strenght is lost ⁊and all a goo
Oonly the intellecte with outen moore
That dwelled in his herte / syke and soore
Gan faillen whan the herte felte dethe
Dusked hise yen two / and failled breeth
But on his ladie / yet caste he his eye
His laste worde was mercy Emelye
His spirit chaunged hous ⁊and went there
As I kam neủer I kan noght tellen where
Therfore I stynte I am no dyuynystre
Of soules fynde I nat in this Registre
Ne me ne lust / thilke opynyon to telle
Of hem / thoght that they wretyn where they dwelle
Arcite is colde / the Mars his soule gye
Now wole I speken forth of Emelye
Shrighte Emelye / and howleth Palamon
And Theseus his suster took a noon
Swownyng and bare here from the corps a way
What helpeth it to tarien forthe the day
To tellen how she weep bothe euen ⁊and morwe
For in suche caas / women han suche sorwe
Whan that hire housbandes ben from hem a goo
That for the more part they sorwen soo
Or ellys fallen in swyche maladie
That at the laste / certeynly they dye
Infynyte ben the sorwes / and the teeris
Of oolde folke / and of folke of tendre yeeris
In all the toun / for the dethe of this Theban
For hym ther wepeth / bothe childe ⁊and man
So greet wepyng was ther noon certayn
Whan Ector was y brought al fresshe y slayn
To Troye allas the pitee that was there
Cracchyng of chekes / rentyng eeke of here
Why woldestow be dede / these women crye
And haddest golde y now ; and Emely
Noman myghten glade Theseus
Sauyng his olde fader Egeus
That knewe this worldes transmutacoun̄
As he hadde seyn it chaunge vp and doun
Ioy aftir woo and woo aftir gladnesse
And shewed hem ensample / and lyknesse
Ryght as ther deyed neủer man quod heeArgumentūm
That he ne leued in erthe in som degree
Ryght so ther lyued neủer man he seyde
In all this worlde that somtyme he ne deyde

l.hi: This worlde / nys but a thurghfare ful of woo
And we be pilgrymes passyng to and froo

div.l: Deth is an ende / of eủery worldes sore
And oủeral this yet seide he mochel more
Theffeite full wisly / to enhorte
The peple that they sholde hem reconforte
Duke Theseus / with all his busy cure
Caste now / wher that the sepulture
Of good Arcite / may beste y maked bee
And eek moost honurable / in his degree
And atte laste he toke conclusioun
That ther as first Arcite and Palamon
Hadden for loue / the bataille hem bytwene
That in the selue groue soote and grene
Ther as he hadde his Amorouse desires
Hise compleynte and for loue his hoot fires
He wolde make a fier in whiche the office
(base) Funeral / he myght al accomplice
And leet a noon cōmmaunde / to hakke and hewe
The ookes olde / and ley hem on a rewe
In colpons wele arraied for to brenne
Hise Officers / with swift feet they renne
And ride a noon at his cōmmaundement
And aftir this Theseus hath ysent
After a beere / and it al oủerspradde
With cloth of golde / the richest that he hadde
And of the same sute / he cladde Arcite
Vpon his hondes his gloues white
Eek vpon his heed / a crowne of laurer grene
And in his hande a swerde ful bright and kene
He leyde hym bare / the visage on the beere
Ther with he weep̄e / that pite was to here
And for the peple sholde sen hym alle
Whan it was day / he broght hym to the halle
That roreth of the cryeng and the soun
Thoo cam this woful Theban Palamon
With flotery berde / and ruggy asshi heeris
In clothis blake / y dropped all with teris
And passyng other / of wepyng Emelye
The rufelest of alle the compaignye
In as myche as the seruyce sholde bee
The moore noble / and riche in his degree
Duk Theseus / leet forth three steedys brynge
That trapped were in stele all gleterynge
And kouered with the armes of daun Arcite
Vpon these steedis grete ⁊and white
There seten folke of whiche oon bare his sheelde
A nother his spere / in his Armes helde
The thrid baar with hym / his bowe Turkeys
Of brende golde was the caas and eke the harneys
And riden forthe a paas with sorowfull chere
Toward the groue / as ye shull aftyr here
The noblest of the grekes that there were
Vpon hire shuldres / carieden the bere
With slakke paas / and yen reede ⁊and wete
Thurgh oute the citee / by the maister strete
That spradde was al wtith blak / and wonder heighe
Ryght of the same is the strete y wrye
Vpon the right honde wente olde Egeus
And on that other syde duk Theseus
With vessels in hir hand of gold full fyn
Alle full of hony / melke blood and wyn
Eke Palamon with full grete compaignye
And after that kam woofull Emelye
With fier in hande as was that tyme the gyse
To doo the office of funeral seruyse
High labour and full greet apparaillynge
Was at the seruyse and the fier makynge
That with hise grene toppe / the heuene raught
And twenty fadme of brede / the armes straught
This is to seyn the bowes were so broode
Of stree first ther was leyde many a loode
But how the fier was makad vp on hight
Ne eke the names how the trees hight
As Ook fier / birche / Aps / holm / popler /
Wylow / Elme / Plane / Assh / Boxe chestayn / lynde / laurer
Mapul / thorn / beeche / hasel / ewe / whippul tree
How they weryn filde / shal not be tolde for me
Ne how the goddis ronnen vp and doun
Disherited of hire habitacioun
In whiche they woneden in reste and pees
Nymphes / Fawnes / and Amadrydes
Ne how the beestes / and the briddes alle
Fledden for fere / whan the wood was falle
Ne how the grounde agast was of the lyght
That was not wont / to seen the sonne bright
Ne how the fier / was couched first with stree
And than with drye stykkes clouen a three
And thanne with grene wood and spicerie
And thanne with clooth of golde and with perrye
And gerlandes hangyng / wtith full many a floure
The mirre thensens / with also swete sauour
Ne how Arcite lay / Among all this
Ne what richesse aboute his body is
Ne how that Emelye as was the gise
Putte in the fuyr / of funeral seruyse
Ne how she swowned whan men made the fuyre
Ne what she spakke / ne what was hire desire
Ne what Iewels men in the fyr caste
Whan that the fuyr was greet ⁊and brente faste
Ne how sōmme cast her shelde / ⁊and sōmme her spere
And of hire vestymentis / whiche that they were
And coppes full of melke / and wyn ⁊and blood
In to the fuyr that brent as it were wood
Ne how the grekys / with an huge route
Thries ridden all the fuyr aboute
Vpon the lefte honde / with a loude shoutyng
And thries with her speres claterynge
And thries how the ladies gonne crye
And how that ladde was / homward / Emelye
Ne how Arcite is brent with asshen colde
Ne how that the lyche wake was y holde
Al thilke nyght ne how the Grekes pleye
The wake pleyes ne kepe I nat to seye
Who wrastleth best naked with oyle enoynt
Ne who that bare hym best / in no disioynt
I wolle nat tellen al / how they gon
Hoom til Athenes whan the pleye is doon
But shortly / to the poynt than wolle I wende
And make of myn longe / tale an ende
By ꝓprocesse and by lengthe of certeyn yeris
Al stynte is the mournyng and the teeris
Of grikes by oon gen̉eral assent
Than semed me / ther was a ꝑperlement
At Athenes / vpon a certeyn poynt and caas
A monge the whiche poynte y spoken was
To haue with certeyn̄ cuntrees Alliaunce
And haue fully of Thebans obeissaunce
For whiche this noble Theseus a noon
Leet sendyn aftyr gentil Palamon
Vnwist of hym / what was the cause ⁊and why
But in his blake clothes sorwefullye
He cam at his cōmmaundement in hye
Thoo sente Theseus for Emelye
Whan they were sette and huste was al the place
And Theseus abyden hath a space
Er any worde cam from hise wise breest
His yen sette hee / ther as was hys luest
And with a sadde visage he siked stille

l.note: And after that ryght thus he seyde hys wylle

div.l: The firste mtext struck throughoıı̄unere / of the cause a boue
Whan he first made / the faire chayne of loue
Greet was theffecte / and highe was his entente
Wele wiste he why / and what ther of he mente
For with that faire chayne / of loue he bonde
The fire the Aier the water and the londe
In certeyn boundes / that they / may nat flee
That same prince / and that moeuere quod hee
Hath stabliced in this wrecched worlde a doun
Certayn daies and duracioun
To al that is engendred in this place
Ouer the whiche day thay may nat pace
Al mowe they yet / thoo daies abregge
Ther nedeth noon Auctorite to allegge
For it is ꝓproued by exꝑperience
But that me luste declaren my sentence
Than may men wele / by this ordre discerne
That thilke moeuere / stable is and eterne
Wele may men knowe / but if it be a fool
That eủery part is deryued from his hool
For nature hath nat taken his begynnyng
Of no partie / or of cantel of a thyng
But of a thyng that ꝑperfite is and stable
Descendyng so / til it be corrumpable
And therfore his wise purueyaunce
Hath so wele byset his ordynaunce
That peces of thynges and ꝓprogressioıı̄uns
Shullen enduren by successioıı̄uns
And noght eterne with outen any lye
This maistow vndirstande and seen at eye
Loo the ook that hath so longe a norisshynge Exemplūn
Fro the tyme that it first gynnyth to sprynge
And hath so longe a lyfe as ye may see
Yet at the laste / wasted is the tree
Considereth eeke / how that the harde stoon /
Vndir oure foot on whiche we treed or goon /
It waasteth / as it lieth by the wey
The brood ryuer / somtyme wexeth drey
The grete townes / se we wane ⁊and wende
Than ye see / that all thys thynges hath ende
Of man and wōmman se we wele alsoo
That nedes in oon / of the termes twoo
This is so seyn / in youthe or ellys age
He moot be deed / the kyng as shal a page
Som in his bedde / som in the depe see
Som in the large felde / as ye may see
Ther helpeth noght / al goth that ilke weye
Than may I seyn that all this thyng moot deye
What maketh this but Iuppit̉er the kyng ;
That is pⁱrince and kyng of alle thyng
Conủertyng alle vn to his ꝓpropre welle
From whiche it is deryued sooth to telle
And here agayns no creature on lyue
Of noo degree auailleth for to stryue
Thanne is it wisdom / as it thynketh me

l.hi: To maken v̉ertue / of necessite

div.l: And take it wele / that we may nat eschue
And nameliche that / to vs alle is due
And who so grucchith ought / he doth folye
And rebel is to hym that all may gye
And certeynly a man hath moost honour
To deyen in his excellence and flour
Whan he is siker of his good name
Than hath he doıı̄un his frende ne hym no shame
And gladder ought his frende ben of his deth
Whan with honour y yolden is his breth
Thanne whanne his name / a palled is for age
For al forgeten / is his vasselage
Thanne is it beste / as for a worthy fame
To deyen whan he is beste of name
The contrarie of alle this / is wilfulnesse
Why grucchen we / why haue we heuynesse
That good Arcite of Chiualrie floure
Departed is with duete ⁊and honour
Oute of this foule prysoun of thys lyf
Why grucchen here / his cosyn and his wyf
Of his welefare that loueth hem so wele
Kan he hem thanke / nay god wote neủer adeel
That bothe his soule / and eke hem offende
And yet they mowe / hire lustes nat amende
What may I conclude / of this longe serie
But aftir woo / I reede vs to be merye
And thonken Iuppiter of alle his grace
And ere we departe from this place
I reed we make / of sorwes twoo
O ꝑperfit Ioye / lastynge eủer moo
And loketh now / wher moost sorwe is here ynne
There wole firste a menden and bygynne
Suster quod he / this is my full assent
With alle Thauys / here of my parlement
That gentil Palamon / youre owne knyght
That serueth yow / with wille ⁊and herte ⁊and myght
And eủer hath doon / sith ye first hym knewe
That ye shulle of youre grace / vpon hym rewe
And taken hym / for housbonde and for lorde
Lene me youre hande / for this is myn accorde
Late see now / of youre womanly pitee
He is a kynges brother sone pardee
And thogh he were a poore bachilere
Syn he hath serued yow / so many a yere
And hadde for yow / so grete adủersitee
It most be consydered leueth mee
For gentil mercy ought to passen right
Than saide he thus / to Palamon the knyght
I trowe ther nedeth lytell sermonyng
To maken yow / assenten to thys thyng
Come neer and taketh youre lady / by the hond
Bytwixe hem was made a noon the bond
That hight matrymoigne / or mariage
By all the counseil / and the baronage
And thus with alle blisse and melodye
Hath Palamon y weddid Emelye
And god that alle this worlde hath wroght
Sende hym his loue / that hath it dere a bought
For now is Palamon in alle wele
(base) Lyuynge in blysse in richesse ⁊and in wele
And Emely hym loueth so tendrelye
And he hir serueth so gentillye
That was there no worde hem bytwene
Of Ialousye / or any other tene
Thus endith Palamon and Emelye
And god saue alle this faire compaignye
Here endith the knyghtys tale
Here bigynnyth the ꝓprohemye of the Milleris tale
W Whan that the knyght / had thus his tale y tolde
In alle the compaignye / nas there yong ne olde
That he ne seyde / it was a noble storie
And worthy for to drawen to memorie
And namely the gentils euerichon
Oure hoost lough / and swore so mote I goon
This gooth a right / vnbokelid is the male
Lat se now who shalle telle a nother tale
For trewely the game is wele bygonne
Now telleth ye sire Monke / if that ye konne
Somwhat to quyte with the knyghtes tale
The Miller that for dronken was al pale
So that vnnethe vpon his hors he satte
He nolde avalen neither hood ne hatte
Ne abyden noman for his curteisie
But in pilatꝰus voys he gan to crye
And swoor by armes ⁊and by blood and bones
I kan a noble tale for the nones
With whiche I wille nowe quyte the knyghtes tale
Oure hoost saugh that he was dronke of ale
And seyde abyde Robyn / leue brother
Som bettre man / shalle telle vs first a nother
A byde and lete vs werken thriftely
By goddes soule quod he that wolle nat I
For I wole speke / or ellys go my way
Oure hoost answered / tel on a deuel way
Thou arte a fole . thy witte is oủercome
Nowe herkeneth quod the Millere alle ⁊and som
But first I make a ꝓprotestacioun
That I am dronke I knowe it by my soun
And therfore if that I myspeke or seye
Wite it the ale of Southwerk I preye
For I wolle telle a legende and a lyfe
Bothe of a Carpenter and of his wyfe
How that a Clerke / hath sette the wrightes cappe
The Reeue answered and seide stynte thy clappe
Let be thy lewed dronken harlotrye
It is a synne / and eke a greet folye
To apairen any man / or hym defame
And eke to bryngen wyfes in suche fame
Thow maist ynow of other thynges sayn
This dronken Millere spake ful sone agayn
And seide leue brother Oswolde
Whoo hathe no wyfe / he is no Cokewolde
But I say nat therfore that thow art oon
Ther ben full good wyfes many oon
Why art thow angry with my tale nowe
I haue a wife parde as wele as thowe
Yet nolde I for the Oxen in my plough
Take vpon me more than I nough
As demen of my selfe that I were oon
I wole byleue wele that I am noon
An housbond shall nought ben inquisityf
Of goddys priuete / nor of his wyf
So he may fynden goddes foyson there
Of the remeniıı̄unt nedeth not to enquere
What sholde I more seyn / but this Millere
He nolde his wordes for noman forbere
But tolde his cherles tale in his manere
Me athynketh that I shall reherse it here
And therfore eủery gentil wight I preye
Demeth nat fore goddis loue that I seye
Of yuel entente / but for I moote reherce
Here tales alle / be they bette or werse
Or ellys falsen som of my matere
And therfore who so list it nat to here
Turne oủer the leef and chese a nother tale
For he shall fynde I nowe grete and smale
Of storial thyng that toucheth gentillesse
And eke moralite / and holynesse
Blameth nat me / yf that ye chese amys
The Miller is a cherle / ye knowe wele this
Soo was the Reeue eke / and other moo
And harlatrie they tolden bothe two
Auyseth yow / and put me out of blame
And eke men shal nat make ernest of game
Here begynneth the Milleris tale
Whilom ther was dwellyng at Oxenforde
A riche gnoffe that gestes helde to borde
And of his crafte he was a Carpenter
With hym ther was dwellyng a pore scoler
Hadde lerned arte but all his fantesye
Was turned for to lere Astrologye
And koude a certein of conclusions
To demen by interrogacions
Yf that men axed hym certein houres
Whan that men sholden haue drought or ellys shoures
Or if men axed hym / what shall byfalle
Of eủery thynge .I. may nat rekne hem alle
This Clerke was cleped hende Nicholas
Of derne loue he koude / and of solas
And therto he was slygh and ful pⁱriue
And lyke a mayden meke for to see
A chambre hadde he / in that hostelrye
A lone with outen any compaignye
Full fetisly dight with herbes swote
And he hym selfe as swete as is the roote
Of likorice / or any setewale
His Almageste / and his bokes grete ⁊and smale
His Astrelabye / longyng for his arte
Hise Augrym stones leyen faire a part
On shelues couched at his bedd is heed
His presse I kouered with a faldyng reed
And alle aboue ther lay a gay sautrye
On whiche he made a nyghtes melodye
So swetely that alle the chambres ronge
And Angelus ad virginem he songe
And aftir that he songe the kynges note
Full often blessed was his mery throte
And thus this swete clerke his tyme spente
Aftir his frendys fyndyng and his rente
This carpenter hadde weddid anewe wif
Whiche that he loued moore than his lyf
Of xviij . yere she was of age
Ialows he was ⁊and helde her narwe in Cage
For she was wilde and yong and he was olde
And demed hym selfe ben lyke a Cokewolde

l.hi: He knewe not katoun / for his witte was rude
That badde / man sholde wed his similitude
Men sholden wedden aftir hire estaate
For youthe and elde / is often at debate
But sith that he was / fallen in the snare
He moste endure as other folke his care

div.l: Faire was this yonge wyf and ther with al
As any wisele / hire body gent and smal
A seynt she werid barred all of selk
A barm cloth / as white as morwe melke
Vpon her lendes full of many a gore
Whit was hire smokke / and broiden all byfore
And eke byhynde / on hire coler aboute
Of Colblak sylke wtith Inne ⁊and eke with oute
The tapes of hire white volupere
Were of the same sute / of hir colere
Hire filet brood of selke and sette ful hie
And sikurly she hadde a lykerous ye
Full smale y pulled were hire brow is two
And thoo were bent and blake as any sloo
She was ful moore blysfull on to see
Than is the newe perionete tree
And softer than the wolle is of a wether
And by hire gurdell heng a purs of lether
Tasseled with silke / and ꝑperlid with latoun
In all this worlde to seken vp ⁊and doun
Ther nys noman so wys that koude thenche
So gay a popelote / or swyche a wenche
Ful brighter was the shynyng of her hewe
Than in the toure / the noble y forged newe
But of hire songe / it was as loude and yerne
As any swalwe / sittyng on a berne
Therto she koude skippe / and make game
As any kyde or calf / folwyng his dame
Hire mouthe was swete / as bragot or the meth
Or hoord of apples leyd in hey or heeth
Wynsyng she was as is a ioly colte
Longe as a maste and vp right as a bolte
A broche she bare / vpon hire loue coler
As brood as is the boos of a bokeler
Hire shoos were laced on hire legges highe
She was a primerose / a piggesnye
For any lorde to liggen in his bedde
Or yet for any good yeman to wedde
Now sire and efte sire / so byfel the caas
That on a day this hende Nicholas
Felle with this yonge wyfe to rage and pleye
While that hire housbond was at Oseneye
As Clerkes ben ful subtel and full queynte

And doun goth alle / he fonde neither to selle
Breed ne ale / til he cam to the selle
Vpon the floor / and there a swowne he lay
Vp stirte hire Alisoun / and Nicholay
And criden oute and harrow / in the strete /
The neighebores / both smale and grete
In ronnen forto gauren on this man
That a swowne lay bothe pale ⁊and wanne
For with the falle / he borsten hadde his arme

For whanne he spak / he was a non bore doun
With hende Nicholas and Alisoun
They tolden eủery man that he was wood
He was a gaste of Nowelis flood
Thurgh fantasye / that of his vanytee
He hadde y bought hym / knedyng tubbes three
And hadde hem honged in the roof a boue
And that he praied hem for goddis loue

That he was holden wood in al the toun
For eủery clerke anon right helde with other

These foure sparkles longen vn to elde
Oure olde lymes mowe wele ben vnwelde
But wille ne shal nat faile that is soth
And yet haue I alwey a coltes toth
As many a yere as it is passed henne
Sith that my tap of lyfe bygan to renn
For sikerly whan I was born a noon

div.l: He seide what amounteth all this witte
What shall we speke alday of holy writte
The deuel made a Reue for to preche
Or of a souter / a shipman / or a leche
Sey forth thy tale / and tarie nought the tyme
Lo depeford / and it is half wey prime
Lo Grenewiche / ther many a shrewe is ynne
It were al tyme thi tale to be gynne
Now seres quod this Oswold the Reue
I pray yow alle that ye // yow // noughtyow noughtnought yow greue
Thow I answere / and somdele sette his howue
For leueful it is with force / force of showue
This dronken Millere hath I tolde vs here
How that bygyled was a Carpentere
ꝐParauenture in scorne for I am oon
And by youre leue I shall hym quyte a noon
Right in his cherles termes wole I speke
I pray to god his nekke mote breke
He kan wele in myn ye seen a stalkle stallestalke
But in his owen / he kan not sen a balke
At Trompyngton nat fer fro Cantebrigge Narrat
Ther gooth a broke and oủer that a brigge
Vpon the whiche brook ther stant a MeilleMilleMelle
And this is verray soth that I yow telle
A Miller was ther dwellyng many a day
As any peocokpocokpecok / he was prout and gay
Pipen he koude / and fisshe and nettes bete
And tourne coppes / and wele wrastle and shete
And by his belte he bare a longe panade
Made of a swerde / full trenchaunt was the blade
A Ioly popper bare he in his pouche
Ther was noman for paril durst hym touche tochetouche
A sheffeld thwitel / bare he in his hose
Rounde was his face / and camuse was his nose
As piled as an ape / was his sculle
He was a Market beter / atte fulle
Ther durst no wight / hande vpon hym legge
That he ne swoor / he sholde a noon abegge
A Theef he was / for soth / of corn and mele
And that a slygh / and vsand for to stele
His name was I hoten / deynous symkyn
A wife he hadde / come of noble kyn
The ꝑpersoun of the toun / her fader was
With hire he yaf / full many a panne of bras
For that Symkyn sholde / in his blood alye
She was y fostred in a Nonnerye
For Symkyn wolde no wyfe as he saide
But she were wele y norysshed and a mayde
To sauen his estaat of yemanrye
And she was prout and pert as is a pye
A full faire syght was vpon hem two
On holydayes / byforn hire wolde he goo
With his tipet wounde a boute his heed
And she came aftir in a gyte of reed
And Symkyn hadde hosen of the same
Ther durste no wight clepen hire but dame
Was noon so hardy that wente by the way
That with hire durst rage / or ones play
But if he wolde be slayn of Symkyn
With panade / or with knyf or with boydekyn

div.l: And eke for she was somdel smoterliche
She was as digne / as water in a diche
And full of hoker and of besmare
Here thought that a lady sholde hire spare
What for hire kynrede / and hire nortelrye
That she hadde lerned / in the Nonnerye
A doughter hadde they / bytwixe hem twoo
Of xxⁱⁱ yere with outen any mo
Sauyng a childe that was of halfe yere age

And right faire was hire here / I wolle nat lye
The ꝑpersoun of the toun for she was faire
In purpos was to maken hire his ayre
Bothe of his catel and of his mesuage

div.l: Greet sookne hath this Millere oute of doute
With wheet and malt of al the lande a boute
And namely ther was a greet Collegge
Men clepeth the Soler halle / at Cantebregge
There was hire wheet / and eke hire malte y grounde
And on a day / it happed on a stounde
Syke lay the Mauncyple / on a Maladie
Men wenden wisly / that he sholde dye
For whiche this Millere stale both mele and corn
An hundred tyme more than byforn
For there byforn he stale but curteisly
But now he was a theef outrageously
For whiche the wardeyn chidde and made fare
But ther of sette the Millere not a tare
He craked boost and swore it was nat soo
Thanne were there yonge pore scolers too
That dwelten in the halle / of whiche I sey
Testyf they were / and lusty for to pley
And oonly for hire myrthe / and reuerye
Vpon the wardeyn besyly they crye
To yeue hem leue but a lytel stounde
To goon to Mille / and sen her corn y grounde
And hardely they durst ley her nekke
The Millere sholde nat stele hem halfe a pekke
Of corn by sleyght / as be force hem reue
And at laste / the wardeyn yaf hem leue
Iohn hight that oon / and Aleyn hight that other
Of oon toun were they borne / that hight Strother
Fer in the north / I kan nat telle where
This Aleyn maketh redy all his gere
And on an hors the sakke / he caste a noon
Forth goth Aleyn the Clerke and also Iohn
With good swerde and with bokeler by hire syde
Iohn knewe ther wey / hym nedid no gyde
And at the Mille the sakke a doun he leyth
Alayn spak furst alheil Symond in feyth
How fares thy faire doughter and thy wyfe
Aleyn welcome qduod qduod Symkyn be my lyfe
And Iohn also / how now / what doo ye here
By god quod Iohn / nede hath naonona pere
Hym byhoues serue hym selfe that has na swayn
Or ellys he is fool / as clerkys sayn

div.l: Swa werkes ay / the wanges in his heed

I pray yow / spede vs heythen that ye may
It shal by doon quod Symkyn by my fay
What wole ye doon / while that it is in hande
By god / right by the hoper wole I stande
Quod Iohn / and se how the corn gas In
Yet saugh I neủer by my fader kyn
How that the hoper wagges til and fra
Aleyn answerde / Iohn wiltow swa
Than wil I be byneth / by my croun
And se / how that the mele falles a doun
In to the trough / that be shal my desport
For Iohn in faith / I may ben of youre sort
I is as ille a Milner / as ar ye
This Miller smyled of hire nycete
And thought thoughthought all this nys don but for a wile
They wene that noman may hem bygyle
But be my thrift yet shal I blere hire ye
For alle her sleyght / in hire philosophye

The more wole I stele whan I tak

div.l: As whilom to the wolfe thus spake the mare
Of alle hire arte counte I nat a tare
Out at the dore he goth full priuely
When that he saugh hys tyme full softely
He loketh vp and doun / til he hath founde
The Clerkys hors / ther as it stode y bounde
Byhynde the Mille vndir a leefsele
And to the hors he goth hym faire and wele
He strepith of the bridel right a noon
And whan the hors was lous / he gynneth goon
Toward the fenne there wilde mares renne
And forthwith wehe / thurgh thykke and thourgh thenne
This Millere goth a gayn / no worde he seyde
But doth his note / and with the clerkys pleyde

And whan the mele is sakked and y bounde
This Iohn oute and fynt his hors a way

Oure hors is lost Aleyn for goddis banes

div.l: And he that bettre sholde haue knyt the reyne

And whan the Millere seigh / that they were gon̄
He half a boisshel of hire floure hath take

He seyde I trowe the Clerkys were a ferde

For alle here art · yhe late hem goon hire weye

These sely clerkys ronne vp and doun
With keep kepe / stande stande / Iossa warderer

Wery and weet as beest is in the reyn
Comth sely Iohn / and with hym comth Aleyn
Allas quod Iohn / the day that I was born
Now arne we dryuen / til hethyng and til scorn
Oure corn is stoln / men wole vs foles calle
Bothe the wardeyn and oure felawis alle
And namely the Milnere weillaway
Thus pleyneth Iohn as he goth by the way
Toward the Mille / and bayard in his hand

For it was nyght and ferther myght they noght
But for the loue of god / they hym by soght

The Millere seide a geyn if ther be eny

Ye kan by argumentz make a place

Lat see now / if this place may suffise

div.l: Lo here oure siluer redy forto spende
This Miller in to toun his doughter sende

With sheetes and chalons faire y spredde
Nat from his owen bedde / ten foot other twelue
His doughter hadde a bedde al by hire selue

It myght be no bette and cause why
Ther was no roumer herborw in the place

A Prentise whilom dwelled in oure Citee
Of a crafte of vitaillers was h
And Gaylard was he / as a Goldfynche in the shawe

Daunce he coude so wele and Iolely

For in the toun nas ther no prentise

If I so ofte myght han wedded be
And alle were worthy men in here degre
But me was toold certeyn nat longe a goon is

l.hi: That sith that crist ne went neure but onys
To weddyng in the Cane of Galilee
That by the same ensample taught he me
That I ne shulde wedded ben but onys

div.l: Herke eke lo whiche a sharp word for the nonys
Beside a welle Ihesus god and man
Spake in repreef of the Samaritan
Thow haste y hadde .v. housbondis quod he
And that ilke man whiche that now hath the
Is nought thyn housbond . thus he seide certeyn
What that he ment ther by . I can nat seyn
But that I axe why that the fifthe man
Was noon housbonde to the Samaritan
How many myght she haue in mariage
Yet herde I neure tellen in myn age
Vppon this nombre difinicioun
Men may dyuyne and glosen vp and doun
But wele I woot expresse with outen lye
God bade vs for to wexe and multiplie
That gentil texe can I wele vndirstonde
Eke wele I woot that he saide myn housbonde
Shulde lete fader and Moder and take to me
But of no nombre mencioun made he
Of bigamye or of octogamye /
Why sholde men thanne speke of it vilenye ;
Lo here the wyse kyng Daun Salamon
I trowe he hadde wyfes moo than oon
As wolde god it lefull were to me
To be refresshed halfe so ofte as he
Whiche yefte of god hadde he for al his wyues
Noman hath . suche that in this world a lyue is
God woot this noble kyng as to my witte
The first nyght hadde many a mery fitte
With eche of hem so wele was hym on lyue /
Blessed be god that I haue wedded fyue
Of whiche I haue piked oute the beste
Booth of hire nether purs / and of hire cheste
Dyủers scoles maken dyủers clerkes
And dyủers praktyke in many sondry werkys
Maketh ye ꝑperfite man sikirly
Of .v. housbondes scoleyng am I
Welcome the sexte whan that eure he shalle
For sith I wil not kepe me chaste in alle
Whan myn housbond is fro the world a goon
Some cristen man shalle wedde me a noon
For than thapostle seith that I am fre
To wedde a goddis halfe where it lyketh me /
He seith that to be wedded is non synne
Bet is to be wedded than to brynne
What rekketh me theigh folke sey vyleynye
Of shrewed lameth / and his bygamye
I wote wele Abraham was an holy man
And Iacob eke as fer as eure I kan
And eche of hem hadde wyues mo than twoo
And many an other holy man also /
Where can ye say in any man̉er age
That heigh god defended mariage /
By expresse worde I prey yow telleth me /
Or where cōmmaunded he virginite /
I wote as wele as ye it is no drede
Thapostle whan he speketh of maydenhede
He seyde that p̉recept ther of hadde he noon /
Men may conseile a woman to be oon
But counseillyng nys no cōmmaundement
He put it in oure owne Iugement
For hadde god cōmmaunded maydenhed /
Than hadde he dampned weddyng wtith the dede /

l.hi: And certes if there were no sedes y sowe

div.l: Virginite thanne wher of sholde it growe ;
Poule durst nought cōmmaunden atte leste
A thynge of whiche his maister yaf noon heste
The darte is sette vp for virginitee
Catche who so may / who renneth best lete see
But this worde is nought take of eủery wight
But there as god lust yeue it of his myght /
I woot wele that thapostle was a maide
But natheles though he wroot or saide
He wolde that eủery wight were suche as he /
Al nys but conseil to virginite
And for to be a wyfe he yaf me leue
Of indulgence / so is it no repreue
To wedde me yef that my make dye
With oute excepcioun of bygamye /
Al were it good no woman for to touche
He mente as in his bedde or in his couche
For ꝑperil is bothe fire and tough tasemble
Ye knowe what this sample may resemble
This al and som he helde virginitee
More ꝑperfit thanne weddyng in freltee
Freelte clepe I but that he and she
Wolde leden al hire lyfe in chastite
I graunte it wele . I haue noon enuye
Though maydenhede p̉referre bygamye
It liketh hem to be clene in body and gooste
Of myn estat ne wille I make noo booste
For wele ye knowe a lord in his housholde
Ne hath nat eủery vessel all of golde
Some ben of tree and doon hire lorde seruyse
God clepith folke to hym in sundry wyse
And eủery hath of god a ꝓpropre yefte
Some this som that as hym liketh shefte
Virginite is greet ꝑperfeccioun
And contynence eke with deuocioun
But Crist that of ꝑperfeccioun is welle
Bad nat euery wight he sholde go selle
Alle that he hadde and yeue it to the pore
And in suche wyse folwe hym ⁊and his fore
He spak to hem that wil lyue ꝑperfitly /
And lordynges be youre leue that am nat I
I wole bystowe the floure of alle myn age
In thactes and in fruyt of mariage
Telle me also what conclusioun
Were membres made of generacioun
And of so ꝑperfit wys a wyght I wrought
Trusteth right wele they were nat made for noght
Glose who so wole and sey bothe vp and doun
That they were made for purgacioun
Of vryn and other thynges smale
Was eke to knowe a femele fro a male
And for noon other cause . sey ; ye ; noo
The exꝑperience wote wele it is nat soo
So that the Clerkes be nat with me wrooth
I sey this that they maked bothwerebothwere for both
That is to seyn for office and for ese
Of engendrure there we nat god displese
Why sholde men elles in hire bokes sette
That man shal yelden to his wif his dette
Now where with sholde he paie his paiement
Yef he ne vsed his sely instrument
Thanne were they made vpon a creature
To pourge vryne and eke for engendrure
But I sey nat that eủery wight is holde
That hath suche harneys as I to yow tolde
To goon and vsen hem in engendrure
Thanne sholde men take of chastite no cure
Crist was a maiden and shapen as a man
And many a seint sith that the worlde bygan
Yet leued they eure in ꝑperfit chastite
I nyl enuye ; no virginite
Lete hem be breed of pured whete seede
And late vs wyues hate barly brede
And yet with barly breed Marke telle can
Oure lord IħuIhesu refresshed many a man
In suche estaat as god hath clepid vs
I wil ꝑperseure I nam nought precious
In wyfhode wil I vse myn Instrument
As frely as my maker hath it sent
Yef I be daungerous god yef me sorwe
Myn housbonde shal it han bothe eue ⁊and morwe
Whan that hym lyst come forth and paie his dette
An housbond wole I haue . I wil nat lette
Whiche shal be bothe my dettour and my thral
And haue his tribulacioun with al
Vpon his fleisshe while that I am his wyf /
I haue the poere duryng al my lyf
Vpon his ꝓpropre body and not he
Right thus thapostle tolde it vn to me
And bade oure housbondes for to loue vs wele
Al this sentence me lyketh eủery dele /
Vp stirt the ꝑperdoner and that a noon
Now dame quod he by god and by seynt Iohn
Ye ben a noble prechour in this caas
I was a boute to wedde a wif allas
What sholde I bye it on my fleissh so dere
Yet had I leure wedde no wyf to yere /
Abyde quod she / my tale is not bygonne
Nay thow shalt drynken of another tonne
Or that I goo ; shal sauoᵘur wors than ale
And whan that I haue tolde the forth my tale
Of tribulacioun in mariage
Of whiche I am exꝑpert in al myn age
This is to sey my selfe hath ben the whippe /
Than maistowe chese whether that thow wilt skippe
Of thilke tonne that I shal a broche
Be ware of it or thow to nyegh approche
For I shalle telle ensamples mo than ten

l.hi: Who so that nel bewar by oother men
By hym shal oother men corrected be

div.l: Thyse same wordes wroot Ptholome
Rede in his Almageste and take it there /
Dame I wolde prey yow if youre wille it were
Seide this ꝑperdoner as ye bygan
Telle forth youre tale spareth for noman
And teche vs yonge men of youre practyke /
Gladly quod she syn it may yow lyke
But that I pray to alle this companye
Yef that I speke aftir my fantasye
As taketh nat a greef of that I seye
For myn entent is but for to pleye
Now sir than wille I telle yow forth my tale
As eure moot I drynke wyn or ale
I shal sey soth / thoo housbondes that I hadde
As three of hem were good / and two were badde
The three men were riche good and olde
Vnneth myght they the statuyte holde
In whiche that they were bounden vnto me
Ye woot wele what I mene of this parde
As helpe me god I laughe whan I thynke .
How pitously a nyght I made hem swynke
But be my fey I tolde of it noo store
They hadde me yeuen hire lande and here tresore
Me neded nat do lenger diligence
To wynne here loue or doon hem reủerence
They loued me so wele by god a boue
That I ne tolde no deynte of hire loue
A wise woman wole besy her eủer in oon
To gete her loue ȝhe there that she hath noon
But sith I hadde hem holy in myn honde
And sithe that they hadde yeuen me al here londe
What sholde I take kepe hem to please
But it were for myn profit and myn ease
I set hem so awerke be my fay
That many a nyght they songen weloway
The bacoun was nought for hem I trowe
That som men han in Essex at donmowe
I goủerned hem so wele aftir my lawe
That iche of hem ful blysful was and fawe
To brynge me gay thynges from the feyre
They were ful glad whan I spak to hem feyre
For god it wote I chidde hem spitously
Now herkeneth how I bare me ꝓproprely
These wyse wyfes that kūnne vndirstonde
Thus sholde ye speke and bere hem wrong an honde
For halfe so boldely ther can no man
Swere and lye as a woman kan
I sey nat this by wyfes that ben wyse
But if it be whan thay hem mysauyse
A wyse wif if that she kan hire good
Shal bere hym an honde the cow is wood
And take witnesse of hire owne maide
Of hire assent . but herkeneth how I saide
Sire olde kaynarde is this thy array
Why is myn neighbours wife so gay
She is honoᵘured / oủeral there she gooth
I sitte at hoom I haue no thrifty cloth .
What dostowe at myn neighbours hous
Is she so faire art thow so amerous
What roune ye with oure maiden benedicite
Sir olde lechour lat thy Iapes be
And yef I haue a gossip or a frende
With outen gilt ye chyuden as a fende
Yef that I walke or pley vnto his hous
Thow comyst hoom as dronken as a mous
And prechest on thy benche with yuel preef
Thow seist to me it is a greet myschief
To wedde a pore woman for costage
And if that she be riche of high parage
Than seistow that it is a tormentrie
To suffre hire pride and hire malencolye
And if that she be faire thow verry knaue
Thow seist that eủery holour wil hire haue

l.hi: She may noo while in chastite a byde
That is assailled vpon iche a syde

div.l: Thow seist som folke desire vs for richesse
Som for oure shappe and som for oure fairnesse
And sōmme for she kan either synge or daunce
And som for gentillesse and daliaunce
Sōmme for hir hondes and hire Armes smale
Thus goth alle to the deuyl by thy tale
Thow seist men may nat kepe a castel walle
It may so longe assailled ben oủer alle
And if that she be foule thow seist that shee
Coueyteth eủery man that she may see
For as a spaynell she wille on hym lepe
Til that she fynde som man hire to chepe
Ne noon so grey goos goth there in the lake
As seistow wil be with outen make
And seist it is an harde thynge for to wolde
A thyng that noman wille his thankes holde
Thus seistowe lorel whan thow goost to bedde
And that no wise man nedeth for to wedde
Ne no man that entendith vn to heuene
With wilde thonder dynt . and fyry leuene
Mote thy welked nekke be to broke
Thow seist that droppyng houses and eke smoke
And chidyng wyues make men to flee
Oute of here owne houses a benedicite
What eileth suche an olde man for to chide
Thow seyst we wyues wil oure vices hide
Til we be fast / and thanne we wille hem shewe
Wele may that be a proủerbe of a shrewe /
Thow seyst that oxen assen hors and houndes

l.hi: Thay ben assaied at dyủers stoundes
Basynes lauours or that men hem bye
Spones stoles and alle suche husbandrye
And so be pottes clothes and array
But folke of wyues make noon assay
Til thay be wedded ( olde dotard shrewe )
And than saistowe we wole oure vices shewe

div.l: Thow saist also that it displeseth me
But if that thow wolt preise my beaute
And but thow poure alway vppon my face
And clepe me faire dame in eủery place
And but thow make a feste on thilke day
That I was born and make me fresshe ⁊and gay
But that thow doo to my norice honour
And to my chamberer with yn my bour
And to my faders folkes and to his allies
Thus seistow olde barel ful of lyes
And yet of oure Apprentise Iankyn
For his crips here shynyng as golde so fyn
And for he squiereth me both vp ⁊ doun
Yet hastow caught fals suspeccioun
I wile hym nought though thow were ded to morow
But tel me this why hidestow with sorow
The keyes of thy chest a way fro me
It is myn̄ good as wele as thyn parde
What wenestow to make an Idyot of oure dame
Now by that lord that called is seint Iame
Thow shalt nought bothe though that thow were wood
Be maistre of my body and my good
That oon thow shalt forgoo maugre thyn eighen
What helpeth it on me enquiren ⁊and spien
I trowe thow woldest locke me in thy chiste
Thow sholdest sey wyfe goo where the lyste
Take youre disport . I nyl leue no talys
I knowe yow for a trewe wyfe dame Alys
We loueth noman that taketh kepe or charge
Wher that we goon / we wol be at oure large /
Of alle men I blessed mote he be
The wyse Astrologen daun Ptholome
That seith this prou ̉erbe in his almageste /

l.hi: Of alle men his wysdom is higheste
That rekketh nat who hath the worlde in honde

div.l: By this proủerbe thow shalt vndirstonde
Haue though what thar the recke or care
How myryly that other folkes fare
For certes olde dotarde by youre leue
Ye shall han queynte // ynough // right at eue /
He is to grete a nygarde that wil werne
A man to light a candel at his lanterne /
He shal han neurᵉ the lasse lyght parde
Haue thow I nough the thar nat pleyne the /
Thow saist also that if we make vs gay
With clothyng and wtith precious array
That it is ꝑperil of oure chastite
And yet with sorwe thow moste enforce the
And sey these in thApostelis name
In habit made with chastite and shame
Ye women shall apparail yow quod he
And not in tressed hire and gay perre
As ꝑperles ne with golde ne clothes riche
Aftir thi texte ne aftir thy rubriche
I wolle nat worke as moche as is a gnatte
Thow seidest this that I was lyke a catte
But who so wolde senge a cattis skynne
Than wolde the catte wele dwelle in his ynne
And if the cattis skyn be slyke and gay
She wil nought dwellyn in house half a day
But forth she wil or any day by dawed
To shewe her skyn and goo a katwrawer The scribe noticed that he forgot to write this line, so he wrote it to the right of the next line.
This is to sey if I be gay sir shrewe
I wolle renne oute my borel for to shewe
Sire olde foole what helpeth the tospien
Though thow pray Argus wtith his hundreth yen
To be my warde corps as he can beste
In feith he shall not kepe me but me leste /
Yet couthe I make his berde as mote I thee /
Thow seidest eke that ther ben thynges three
The whiche thynges troblen al this erthe
And that no wight may endure the ferthe /
O leue sir shrewe IħuIhesu short thy lyfe
Yet prechestow and saist that an hatful wyfe
I rekened is for oon of this myschaunces
Ben ther noon other resemblaunces
That ye may lykne youre parablis too
But if a sely wif ben oon of thoo ;
Thow lyknest eke womans loue to helle
To bareyn londe the water may nat dwelle /
Thow lyknest it also to wild fire
The more it brenneth the more it hath desire
To consume eủery thyng that brent wol be /
Thow seist right as wirmes shenden a tree /
Right so a wif distroieth hire housbonde /
Thys knowen they that \ben/to wyues ben bondethat to wyues ben bondeben to wyues bonde
Lordynges right thus as ye han vndirstonde
Bare I styfly myn olde husbondes on honde
That thus they seyden in here dronkenesse
And alle was fals but that I toke witnesse
On Iankyn and on my norce alsoo /
O lorde the pyne I dede hem and the woo
Ful giltlees by goddes swete pyne
For as an hors I couthe bite and whyne /
I couthe pleyne and I was in the gilte
Or elles often tyme I had ben spilte /
Whoo so that first to mylle cometh first grynt /
I pleyned first / so was oure werre stynt
They were ful glad to excuse hem ful blyue
Of thyng of whiche they neure a gilt her lyue /
Of wenches wolde I beren hem on honde
Whan that for sike they myght vnneth stonde
Yet tikled I his herte for that he
Wende I had hade of hym so grete chierte
I swore that al my walkyng oute be nyght
Was for to espie wenches for to dight that he dight
Vndir that colour hadde I many a myrthe
For all suche witte is yeue vs in oure byrthe
Deceyt wepyng spynnyng god hath yeue
To wymen kyndely while the may lyfe leue
And thus of oon thyng I avaunt mee
Atte ende I hadde the bette at eche degree
By sleight or force or som man̉er thynge
As by contynuel murm̉er or grucchynge
Namely a bedde hadde they myschaunce
There wolde I chide and do hem no plesaunce /
I wolde no lenger in the bedde abyde
Yef that I felt his arme oủer my syde
