Til he hadde made his raunceon vn to me /
Thanne wolde I soffre hym do his nycete /
And therfore eủery man this tale I telle
Wynne who so may for alle is for to selle
With empty honde men may noon haukes lure
For wynnyng wolde I al his lust endure
And make me a feyned Appetite
And yet in bacoun hadde I neure delite
That made me that eure I wolde hemhem chide
For though the pope haddeUnclear superscript text is added. bysyde
I wolde nought spare hem at here owne borde /
For by my trouthe I quyt hem worde for worde /
As helpe me verrey god om̄nipotent
Though I right nough sholde make my testament
I ne owe hem nat a word that it nys quytte
I brought it so a boute by my witte
That they most yeue it vp as for the beste
Or elles hadde we neure ben in reste
For though he loked as a wood lyoun
Yet sholde he faille of his conclusioun
Thanne wolde I sey good lyef take kepe
How mekely loketh wilkyn oure sheep
Come nere my spouce late me bat thy cheke
Ye shulden be al pacient and mek
And han a swete spiced conscience
Sith ye so preche of Iopes pacience
Suffreth alway / sith ye kan so wele preche /
And but ye doo certeyn we shal yow teche /
That it is faire to han a wife in pees /
On of vs two must bowen douteles /
And sith a man is more resonable
Than woman is / ye most ben suffrable /
What eyleth yow to grucche thus ⁊and grone
Is it for ye wolde haue my queynte alone
Wy take it al loo haue it euery dele
Petir I shrewe yow but ye loue it wele
For if I wolde selle my bele chose
I couthe walke as fresshe as is arose
But I wole kepe it for youre owen toth
Ye be to blame by god I sey yow soth /
Suche maner wordes hadde we an hond /
Now wil I speke of my ferth housbond
Mi fierthe housbond was a reuelour
This is to seyn he had a paramour
And I was yonge and ful of ragerye
Stibourn and stronge and Ioly as a pye
How couthe I daunce to an harpe smale
And syng I wys as any nyghtyngale
Whan I hadde dronken a draught of swete wyn
Metellyus the foule cherle the swyn
That with a staf byraft his wif her lyfe
For she dranke wyn ; though I hadde ben his wyfe
Ne sholde nat han daunted me for drynke
And aftir wyn on venus most I thynke
For also siker as colde engendreth haille

l.hi: A likerous mouth most han a likerous taille

div.l: In woman vynolent is no defence /
This knowen lechours by exꝑperience
But lord crist whan that it remembreth me
Vpon my youthe and my Iolyte /
It tikeleth me a boute myn herte roote
Vnto this day it doth myn hert boote
That I haue hadde my worlde as in my tyme
But age allas that alle wole envenyme
Hath me byraft my beaute and my pith
Lat goo fare wele the deuel goo ther with
The floure is goon ther is nomore to telle
The branne as I beste can now most I selle
But yet to be right mery wole I fonde /
Now wille I telle of my fierth housbonde
I sey I hadde in hert gret despit
That he of any other hadde delyt
But he was quytte by god and by seint Ioce
I made hym of the same wood a troce
Nat of my body in no foule manere
But certeynly I made folke suche chere
That in his owne grece I made hym frye
For angre and for verry Ialosye /
By god in erthe I was hise purgatorie
For whiche I hope his soule be in glorie
For god it woot he sate full ofte ⁊and songe
Whan that his shoo full bitterly hym wronge /
Ther was no wight saue god and he that wist
In many wise how sore I hym twist
He deide whan I come from Ierlm̄Ierusalem
And lieth y graue vndir the rood beem
Al is his toumbe nought so corious
As was the sepulcre of hym Baryus
Whiche that Appellus wrought so sotilly
It nys but waste to bury hym preciously
Lat hym fare wele god gyfe his soule reste
He is now in his graue and in his cheste /
Now of my fifthe housbond wil I telle
God late his soule neure come to helle
And yet was he to me the moost shrewe /
That fele I on my rybbes al by rewe
And eure shal vn to myn endyng day /
But in oure bedde he was so freisshe ⁊and gay
And ther with also wele couthe he me glose
Whan that he wolde han my bele chose
That though me bete on euery boon
He couthe wynne a gayn my loue a noon
I trow I loued hym beste / for that he
Was of his loue daungerous to me /
>Manicule in left margin.The women han ( if that I shal nat lye )

l.hi: In this matere a queynt fantasye /
Wayte what thyng we may not lyghtly haue
Ther aftir wille we crye alday and craue
Forbede vs thyng and that desyren wee
Prees on vs faste and thanne wille we flee
With daunger outer we alle oure chaffare
Greet prees at market maketh dere ware
And to grete cheep is holden at lytel prys
This knoweth eủery wōmman that is wys /

div.l: My fifthe housbonde god his soule blesse
Whiche that I toke for loue and for noo richesse
He somtyme was a Clerke of Oxenford
And hadde lafte scole and at hoom to boord
Wyth my gossyp dwellyng in oure toun
God haue hire soule / hir name was Alisoun /
She knewe myn herte and eke my pryuete
Bet than oure parisshe preest as mote I thee
To hire by wreyed I myn counseil alle
For hadde myn housbond pissed on a walle
Or doon a thyng that sholde haue cost his lyfe
To hire and to a nother worthy wyfe
And to my nece whiche that I loued wele
I wolde han tolde his counsel eueridele
And so I ded ful ofte god it wote
That made his face often reed and hoote
For verrey shame / and blamed hym selfe for he
Hadde tolde to me so greet a pryuete /
And so bifel that ones in a lente
So oftyn tymes I to my gossip wente
For eủer yet I loued to be gay
And for to walke in Marche Aperel ⁊and May
From hous to hous to hure sundry talys
That Iankyn Clerke and myn gossip Alys
And I my selfe in to the feldes wente
Myn housbond was at london al that lente
I hadde the better leyser for to pleye
And for to see and eke for to be seye
Of lusty folke what wist I where that my grace
Was shapen for to be or in what place ;
Therfore I made my visitacions
To vigilees and to processions
To prechyng eke and to pilgrimages
To pleies of myracle and of mariages
And wered vpon / my gay scarlet gytes /
This wormes ne this moththes ne thys mytes
Vpon my parel fret hem neủer a dele
And woostowe why ; for they were vsed wele /
Now wole I tellen forth what happed me /
I sey that in the feldes walked we
Tyl trewely we hadde suche dalyaunce
This clerke and I that of my purueaunce
I spake to hym and saide hym how that he /
( Yef I were widewe ) shulde wedde me
For certeynly I sey for no bobbaunce
Yet was I neure with outen purueaunce
Of mariage nof other thynges eke
I holde a mouses herte nought worth a leke
That hath but oon hole for to sterte too
And yef that faille / than is al I doo /
I bare hym on honde he hadde enchaunted me /
My dame taught me that sotilte
And eke I seide I met of hym al nyght /
He wolde han slayn me / as I lay vp right /
And al my bedde was ful of verrey blood /
But yet I hope ye shal do me good /
For blood bytokeneth golde as me was taught /
And alle was fals I dremed of it right naught /
But as I folwed ay my dames lore
As wele of that as of other thynges more /
But now sire lat me see what shal I sayn
A ha ; by god I haue my tale agayn
Whan that my fourthe housbonde was on bere
I wepe algate and made sory chere
As wyfes moten / for it is vsage /
And with my koủercheef coủered my visage
But for that I was purueyd of a make
I wepte but smal And that I vndirtake
To chirche was myn housbond born a morwe
With neighbours that for hym maden sorwe
And Iankyn oure clerke was oon of thoo
As helpe me god whan that I saugh hym goo
After the bere me thought he hadde a peire
Of legges and of feet so clene and faire
That al myn herte I yaf vn to his holde
He was I trowe twenty wynter olde
And I was fourty yef I shal sey soth
But yet I hadde alway a coltes tooth /
Gat tothed I was and that bycame me wele
I hadde the prynt of seint venus sele
As helpe me god I was a lusty oon
And faire and riche and yonge ⁊and wele bygoon
And trewely as myn housbondes tolde me
I hadde the best quoniam myght be /
For certes I am all veneryen
In felyng and myn hert is marcien
Venus me yaf my luste / my likerousnesse
And Mars yaf me / my stordy hardynesse
Myn ascendaunt was taure and Marce ther ynne
Allas Allas that eủer loue was synne
In folwyng ay myn inclinacion
Be vertue of my constellacion
That made me that I coude not withdrawe
My chaumber of venus from a good felawe
Yet haue I a marke of Mars vppon my face
And also in a nother pryue place
For god so wissely be my sauacion
I leued neủer be noon diserecion
But eủer folwed myn Appetite
Al were he longe short blak or white
I toke no kepe so that he liked me
How pore he was ne of what degre
What sholde I say but at the mouthes ende
This Ioly Clerke Iankyn that was so hende
Hath weddid me with greet solempnyte
And to hym yaf I bothe lond and fee
That ̉er was yeue me therfore /
But aftirward me repentid it full sore
He nolde suffre no thyng of my lyst
By god he smote me ones on the lyst
For that I rent out of his book a leef
That of the strooke myn ere was al deef
Stybourn I was as is a lyonesse
And of my tonge a verrey Iangleresse
And walke I wolde as I had doon by forn
From hous to hous al though he had it sworn
For whiche he often tymes he wold preche
And me olde Romayn gestes teche
How he Symplicius Gallus lafte his wyf
And hire forsoke terme of alle his lyf
Nought but for open heueded he hir say
Lokyng out at his dore vpon a day /
An other Romayn tolde he me by name
That for his wif was at a someres game
With outen his wyttyng he forsoke hire eke /
And thanne wolde he vpon his bible seeke
That ilke proủerbe of ecclesiaste
Where he cōmmaundeth and forbedeth faste
Man shal not suffre his wyf go royle a boute /
Than wolde he sey right thus ( wtithouten doute )

l.hi: Who so that bylldeth his hous al of salwes
And priketh his blynde hors oủer the falwes
And suffreth hys wyf to go seken halwes
Is worthy to be honged on the galwes

div.l: But al for nought I sette nat an hawe
Of his ꝓprouerbes ne of his olde sawe
Ne I wolde nat of hym corrected be
I hate hem that my vices tellen me
And so doo moo god wote of vs than I
This made hym with me wood al outrely
I nolde nat forbere hym in no caas /
Now wole I sey yow soth by seynt Thomas
Why that I rent outo of his boke a leef
For whiche he smote me so that I was def /
He hadde a book that gladly nyght and day
For his disporte he wolde rede alway
He clepid it valerye and Theofraste
At whiche book he lough alway ful faste
And eke ther was somtyme a Clerke at Rome
A Cardinal that hight Ierome
That made a book a gayn Iouynyan
In whiche book eke ther was Tertulan
Crisippus Trotula and helowys
That was Abbesse nought fer fro parys
And eke the parables of Salamon
Ouydes arte and bokes many oon
And alle these were bounden in oo volume
And eủery nyght and day was his custume
Whan he hadde layser and vacacioun
From other wordly occupacioun
To reden in this booke of wikked wyues
He knewe of hem mo legendes and lyues
Than ben of good wyues in the bible
For trusteth wele it is an inpossible
That any clerke wil speke good of wyues
But yef it be of holy seintes lyues
Nof noon other wōmman neủer the moo

l.hi: Who peynted the leoun telle me whoo ;

div.l: By god yef women hadde writen stories
They wolde haue writen of men more wickednesse
Than al the merke of Adam may redresse
As Clerkes han with ynne here oratories
The Children of Mercurye and venus
Be in hire wirkyng ful contrarious
Mercurie loueth wisdom and science
And venus loueth riot and dispence
And for hire dyuers disposicioun
Eche failleth in otheris exaltacioun
As thus / god wote Mercurie is desolat
In pisces where venus is exaltat
And venus failleth where Mercurie is reyse
Therfore no woman of no clerke is preised
The Clerke whan he is olde ⁊and may nought doo
Of venus werkys worth his olde shoo
Thanne sitte he doun and writeth in his dotage
That wemen kan not kepe hire mariage /
But now to purpos why I tolde the
That I was beten for a book parde /
Vpon a nyght Iankyn that was oure sire
Radde on his book as he sate by the fire
Of Eua first / that for hire wykkednesse
Was al mankynde brought to wrecchidnesse
For whiche that IħuIhesu Crist was slayn
That bought vs with his hert blood agayn /
Lo here expresse of wȳmmen may ye fynde
What woman was the losse of al mankynde /
Tho redde he me how Sampson lost his heres
Slepyng his lēmman kyt it with hire sheres
Thourgh whiche tresoun loste he both his eyen /
Thoo redde he me yef I shal not leyen
Of Hercules and of Dyanyre
That caused hym to sette hym selfe a fyre /
Nothyng forgate he the care and woo
That Socrates hadde with hys wyues twoo
How Xantipa caste pisse vppon his heed
This sely man satte stille as he were deed
He wipt hys heed / no more durst he sayn /
But or that thonder stynt / cometh a rayn /
Of Pasipha that was the quene of Crete
For shrewidnesse hym thought the tale swete /
Fy speke nomore it is a grysly thyng
Of Orrible luste and hire lykyng
Of Clitermystra for hire leccherie
That falsly made hire housbond for to dye /
He redde it with ful good deuocyoun
He tolde me eke for what occasyoun
Amphiorax at Thebes lost his lyfe /
Myn housbond hadde a legend of his wife
Exiphilem / that for a nouche of golde
Hath pryuely vn to the Grekes tolde
Where that hire housbond hidde hym in a place
For whiche he hadde at Thebes sory grace /
Of lyuia tolde he me and of lucye
They bothe made hire housbondes for to dye /
That oon for loue / that other for haate /
Lyuia hire housbonde on an euen late
Enpoisoned hath for that she was his foo
Lucia likerous loued hire housbond soo
For thatForFor thatThat for he sholde alway vppon hire thynke
She yafe hym suche a maner loue drynke
That he was deed or it was by the morwe /
And thus Algates housbondes hadden sorwe /
Than tolde he me how oon latumyus
Complayned vn to his felawe Arryus
That in his gardyne growid suche a tree
On which he saide how that hys wyfes three
Honged hem selfe for hertes despetous /
O leue brother quod this Arryus
Yef me a plante of thilke blyssed tree
And in myn gardyn planted shal it bee /
Of latter date of wyues hath he
That some han slayn hire housbondes in hire bedde
And late hire lecchour dight hire al the nyght
While that the corps lay in the flore vpright /
And some haue dryven nailes in hire brayn
While that they sleep and thus thay han hem slayn /
Some haue youe hem poison in here drynke /
He spakke more harme than hert may bythynke /
And ther with alle he knewe moo prouerbes
Than in this worlde ther growen grasse or herbes /
Bet is quod he thyn habitacioun
Be with a leoun or a foule dragoun
Than with a woman vsyng for to chide /
Bet is quod he hiegh in the roof abyde
Than with a wikked woman doun in the hous
They ben so wikked and contrarious
They haten that hire housbondes loueth ay /
He saide a woman caste hire shame a way
Whan she cast of her smokke / and forther mo
A faire woman but she be chaste also
Is lyke a gold ryng in a sowes ere nose /
Who wolde wene or who wolde suppose /
The woo that in myn hert was and pyne /
And whan I sey he wolde neủer fyne
To reden on this cursed book al nyght
Al sodenly .iij. leues haue I plight
Oute of his boke right as he redde . and eke
I with my fyst so toke hym on the cheke
That in oure fire he felle bakward a doun /
And he vp sterte as doth a wood leoun
And with his fiste he smote me on the heed
That in the flore I lay as I were deed /
And whan he saugh how stille that I lay
He was a gaste and wolde haue fledde a way
Til atte laste oute of my swough I brayde
O hastow slayn me fals theef / I sayde /
And for my lande thus hastowe morthered me ;
Or I be deed / yet wole I kysse the /
And nerre he come and kneled faire a doun /
And seide dere syster Alysoun
As helpe me god I shal the neủer smyte /
That I haue doon it is thy selue to wite
Foryeue it me and that I the beseke /
And yet efte sones I hitte hym on the cheke
And saide theef thus mothe I me wreke /
Now wole I deye I may no lenger speke /
But atte laste with mochel care and woo
We fille accorded by vs seluen twoo
He yaf me al the bridel in myn honde
To haue the goủernaunce of hous and londe
And of his tonge and of his hoond also
And made hym brenne his book a noon right tho /
And whan that I hadde geten vn to me
By maistrie al the soueraignete
And that he seide myn owne trewe wyf
Do as the luste the terme of all thy lyf
Kepe thyn honour and kepe eke myn estate /
Aftir that day we hadde neure debate /
God helpe me so I was to hym as kynde
As ony wyfe from Denmarke vn to ynde
And also trewe and so was he to me
I pray to god that sitte in mageste
To blysse his soule for his mercy dere /
Now wole I sey my tale . yif ye wil here /
Here maketh yᵉ frere an interrupcoıı̄un of yᵉ wyfes tale
The frere loughe whan he had herde al this
Now dame quod he so haue I Ioye or blys
This is a longe p̉eramble of a tale /
And whenne the Sompnour herd the frere gale
Lo quod the Sompnour goddys Armes twoo
The Sompnoᵘur speketh of the Frere 
A frere wole entremete hym eủer moo
Lo good men a flye and eke a frere
Wille falle in eủery dysshe and matere /
What / spekest thow of p̉erambulacioun ;
What / Aunble or trotte / or pees / or goo sit doun /
Thow lettist oure disp̄orte in this manere /
Ye / wiltow soo sire Sompnour quod the frere ;
Now by my feith I shall or that I goo
Telle of a Sompnouur suche a tale or twoo /
That alle the folke shall laughen in this place /
Now ellys frere I wille by shrewe thy face
Quod this Sompnour and I be shrewe me
But if I telle tales twoo or three
Of frerys or I come to Sydyngbourne
That I shal make thyn herte for to mourne /
For wele I wote thy pacience is goon /
Oure ooste cride pees / and that a noon /
And seide late the woman telle hire tale /
Ye faren as folke that dronken ben of ale /
Do dame / telle forth youre tale and that is beste /
Al redy sire quod she / right as yow lest /
Yef I haue licence of this worthy frere /
Yis dame quod he / telle forth and I wille here
Here endeth the ꝓprologe of the tale
Here bygynneth the tale of the Wyfe of Bathe
IN olde dayes of the kyng Artour
Of whiche that Britons speken greet honour
Al was lande fulfilde of Fairie
The elf Quiene with hire ioly compaignye
Daunsed fulle ofte in many a grene mede /
This was the olde opynyon as I rede /
I speke of many C yeris a goo .
But now can no man se non elues mo
For now the grete charite and praieres
Of lymytours and other holy freris
That serchen euꝰery londe and euꝰery streem
As thykke as motes in the sonne beem
Blyssyng halles chambres kychynes bowres
Citees burghes castels hiegh towres
Thropes bernes Shipenes Dayeryes /
That maketh that ther ben no fairies
For there as wont to walken was an elf

l.hi: Ther walketh now the lymytour hym self

div.l: In vndermeles and in morwenynges
And saith his matyns and his holy thynges
As he gooth in his lymytacioun
Women may go [] now saufly vp and doun
In euꝰery busshe or vndir euꝰery tree
Ther is noon other Incubus but he
And he ne wil do hem but dishourdishonourdishonour
¶ And so byfel that thys kyng Arthour
Had in his hous a lustely bachelere
That on a day cam rydyng fro ryuere
And happed that alone as she was born
He sey a mayden walkyng hym byforn
Of whiche maide a noon maugre her hede
By verray force byrafte hire maidenhede
For whiche oppꝰerssion was suche clamour
And suche pursuyt vn to the kyng Artour
That dampned was the knyght to be ded
By cours of lawe and shulde han loste his hede
ꝐPerauenture suche was the statuit thoo
But that the quiene and other ladies moo
So longe preiden the kyng of grace
Til he his lyfe garaunted in the place
And yaf hym to the quene al at hire wille
To chese whether she wolde hym saue or spille
The quene thankyd the kyng with al hire myght
And aftir this thus spake she to the knyght
Whan that she saugh hire tyme vpon a day
Thow standest yet quod she in suche array
That of thy lyfe yet hastow no surete
I garaunte the lyfe if thow canst telle me
What thyng is []itit that women moost desiren
Be ware and kepe thy nekke boon froom Iren
And yef thow canst not telle it me a noon
Yet wole I yeue the leue for to goon
A twelf moneth and a day to seche and lere
An answere suffissaunt in this matere
And surete wil I han er that thow pace
Thy body for to yelden in this place /
Woo was this knyght and soroufully he siketh
But what / he may nat doon as hym lyketh
And atte laste he chees hym for to wende
And come a gaynne right at the yeres ende
With suche answere as godde hym wolde purueye
And taketh his leue and wendeth forth his weye /
He seketh euꝰery hous and euꝰery place
Where as he hopeth for to fynde grace
To lerne what thyng women louen moost /
But he ne couthe arryuen in no coost
Where as he myght fynde in this matere
Twoo creatures acordyng in fere /
Sōmme seyden women louen best richesse /
Sōmme seide honour / som seide Iolynesse /
Sōmme riche array / sōmme seiden lust a bedde /
And ofte tyme to be wedowe / and wedde
Sōmme saide that oure hert is moost eased
Whan that we ben y Flatꝰered and y pleased
He goth fulle nygh the sooth I wil nat lye /
A man shalle wynne vs best with flaterye
And with attendaunce and besynesse /
Ben we y lymed bothe more and lesse /
And some seyn that we louen best
For to be free and do right as vs lest /
And that noman reproue vs of oure vice /
But sey that we ben wyse and no thyng nyce /
For trewely ther is noon of vs alle
Yif any wight wille clawe vs on the galle /
That we nyl kyke for he seith vs soth
Assay and he shalle fynde it that so doth
For we be neure so vicious with ynne
We wolle beholden wyse and clene of synne /
And some seyn that grete delytte han we
For to be holden stable and eke secree
And in oo purpos stedfastly to dwelle
And nought bywrye thyng that men vs telle
But that tale is nought woorth a rake stele
Parde we women kon no thyng hele /
Witnes on Mida wil ye here the tale ;
Ouyde a monge other thynges smale
Seide Mida hadde vnder his long heres
Growyng vppon his heed twoo asses eres
The whiche vice he hidde as he best myght
Ful sotilly from euꝰery mannꝭes sight /
That saue his wife ther wist of it no moo /
He loued hire moost and trusted hire also
He preied hire that to noo creature
She sholde tellen of his disfigure /
She swore hym nay for al this world to wynne
She nolde do that vilenye or synne
To make hire housbond han so foule a name
She nolde nat telle it for hire owne shame /
But nathelees hire thought right that she dide
That she so longe a counseil shold hyde
Hire thought it swalle so sore a boute hire herte
That nedely som worde most hire a sterte /
And sithe she durst nat telle it to no man /
Doun to a Mareys fast by she ran
Til she come there hire herte was in a fire
And as a bitore bumbleth in the myre
She laide hire mouthe vn to the water doun
By wrey me nat thow water with thy soun
Quod she / to the I telle it and nomoo
Myn housbonde hath longe asses eres twoo
Now is myn herte al hole now it is oute
I myght no lenger kepe it oute of doute /
Here may ye see thow we a tyme byde
Yet oute it mote we con no counseil hyde /
The remenaunt of the tale yf ye wil here
Redith Ouyde and ther ye may it lere /
This knyght of whiche my tale is specially
Whan that he say he myght nat come ther by
This is to seyn what women louen most
With ynne his breest ful sorweful was the goost /
But hoom he gooth he myght nought soiourne
The day was come that hoom []wardward must he turne
And in his way it happed hym to ryde
In al this care vndir a forest syde
Where as he sey vpon adaunce goo
Of ladies foure and twenty and yit moo /
Towarde the whiche daunce he drough ful yerne /
In hope that som wisdom he shold lerne /
But certeynly or he come fully there
I vanysshed was this daunce / he nyst where /
No creature saugh he that bare lyf
Saue on the grene he sey sittyng a wyf
A fouler wight ther may noman deuyse /
A gayn the knyght this olde wife gan ryse
And saide sir knyght here forth ne lyeth no wey
Telle me what that ye seken be youre fey
ꝐPerauenture it may the better be /
This olde folke kan mochel thyng quod she /
My leue Moder quod this knyght certeyn
I nam but deed but yef that I kan seyn
What thyng it is that wymen most desire
Coude ye me wisse I wolde wele quite youre hire
Plyght me thy trouthe here in myn hande quod she
The next thyng that I require the
Thow shalt it do yef it be in thy myght
And I wille telle it yow or it be nyght /
Haue here my treuthe quod the knyght I graunt /
Than quod she I dar me wele auaunt
Thy lyfe is sauf for I wole stonde therby
Vpon my lyfe the quene wole sey as I .
Late see whiche is the proudest of hem alle
That wereth on a kerchief or a calle
That dar say nay of that I shal the teche /
Lete vs goo forth with outen longer speche /
Thoo rowned she a pistle in his ere
And bade hym be glade and haue no fere /
Whan thay ben comen to the court / this knyght
Seide / he hadde holde his day as he had hight
And redy was his answere as he seyde /
Fulle many a noble wyf and many a maide
And many a widwe for that they ben wise
The quene hire selfe / sittyng as Iustice
Assembled ben his answere for to here /
And aftirward this knyght was bode apere
To euꝰery wight cōmmaunded was silence
And that the knyght sholde telle in audience
What thyng that wordly women louen best /
This knyght ne stood nat stille as dooth a best
But to his questioun a noon answerd
With manly voys that alle the court it herd
¶ Mi lyge lady / generaly (quod he)

l.hi: Women desireth souereynte
As wele ouer hire housbonde as hire loue
And for to ben in maistrie hym a boue

div.l: This is moost desire though ye me kille
Dooth as yow lyst I am here at youre wille /
In al the court ne was ther wif ne maide
Ne widwe that contraried that he saide
But seyden he was worthy han his lyf /
And with that word / vp stert that olde wif
Whiche that the knyght sey sittyng on the grene
Mercy quod she my souꝰereigne lady quiene
Or that youre Court departe do me right
I taught this answere vnto the knyght
For whiche he plight me his treuthe there
The first thyng that I wold hym requere
He wolde it doo yef it lay in his myght
By fore the Court than pray I the sire knyght
Quod she / that thow me take vn to thy wyf

l.seg: For wel thow wost that y hath kept thy lyfe

div.l: If I sey fals say nay vpon thy fey /
This knyght answerd allas and and wellawey
I wote right wele that suche was my byheste
For goddes loue as chese a newe requeste /
Take al my good and late my body goo /
Nay than quod she I shrewe vs both two
For though that I be foule . olde ⁊ pore
I nolde for al the metal ne for ore
That vndir erthe is graue or lieth a boue
But yef thy wife I were and eke thy loue /
My loue quod he . nay my dampnacioun
Allas that any of my nacioun
Shulde eure so foule disꝑperaged be
But al for nought / the ende is this that he
Constreyned was he nedes / most hir wedde
And taketh his olde wif and goth to bedde /
¶ Now wolden som men sayn ꝑperauenture
That for my necligence I doo no cure
To tellen yow the Ioy and alle tharray
That atte feste was that ilke day
To whiche thyng shortly answere I shal
I sey ther nas no Ioy ne feste att al
Ther nas but heuynesse and moche sorwe
For priuely he weddid hire on the morwe
And alday aftir hidde hym as an Oule
So wo was hym his wyf loked so foule /
Grete was the woo the knyght hadde in his thought
Whan he was with his wife a bedde y brought
He walweth and he turneth to and froo /
His olde wif lay smylyng euꝰer moo
And saide o dere housband / benedicite
Fareth euꝰery knyght thus with his wif as ye ;
Is this the lawe of kyng Arthours hous ;
Is euꝰery knyght of his thus []lokeloke daungerous ;
I am youre owen loue and youre wif
I am she whiche that saued hath youre lyf /
And certis yet ne did I yow neur vnright
Why fare ye thus with me the first nyght ;
Ye faren like a man hadde lost his witte
What is my gilt ; for goddis loue telle it
And it shal be amendid yef I may /
Amended amendid quod this knyght allas / nay / nay /
It wil nat ben amended neuꝰer moo
Thow art so lothely and so olde also
And ther to comen of so lowe a kynde
That litel wondre is though I walwe and wynde /
So wolde god my herte wold brest /
Is this quod she the cause of youre vnrest ;
Ye certeynly quod he no wonder is .
Now sire quod she I couthe amende al this
Yef that me lyst or it were dayes thre
So wele ye myght bere yow to me /
¶ But for ye speken of suche gentelesse

l.hi: As is descended out of olde richesse
That therfore shulden ye be gentilmen
Swiche arrogaunce is nought worth an hen /
Loke who that is most vertuous alway
Pryue and apert and most intendeth ay
To doo the gentel dedes that he kan
Take hym for the grettest gentilman

div.l: ¶ Crist wil we clayme of hym oure gentillesse

l.hi: Nought of oure oldres for hire olde richesse
For though they yeue vs alle hire heritage
For whiche we clayme to be of heigh parage
Yet may thay nought byqueth for no thynge
To none of vs hire vertuous lyuyng
That made hem gentilmen I called be

div.l: And bade vs folwen hem in suche degre /
Wele can the wise poet of florence
That hight dant / speken of this sentence
Lo in suche maner Ryme is dantes tale
Ful selde vp riseth by his braunches smale
Prowesse of man / for god of his prowesse
Wil that of hym we clayme oure gentillesse

l.hi: For of oure Auncestres mow we no thyng clayme
But temporel thyng that man may hurte and mayme

div.l: Euery wight woot this as wele as I
Yef gentillesse were plaunted naturely
Vn to a certeyn lynage / doun the lyne
Pryue and apert than wold thay neure fyne
To doo of gentillesse the faire office
They myghte do no vileny or vice /
Take fire and bere it in the dirkest hous
Bytwixt this and the mount of kaucasous
And lete men shette the dore and goo thenne
Yet wol the fire as faire lye and brenne
As twenty thousand men myght it byholde
His office naturel ay wil it holde
Vp peril of my lyfe ay til it dye /
Here may ye see wele how that gentry

l.hi: Is not annexed to possessioun

div.l: Sith folke ne doon hire oꝑperacioun
Alwey as doth the fire lo in his kynde
For god it wote men may wele often fynde
A lordes sone don shame and vilonye
And he that wil han pris of his gentrye
For he was born of a gentel hous
Latin text in left margin[Untranscribed Latin] And hadde his Auncestres noble and vertuous
And nil hym siluen doo no gentel dedes
Ne folwe his gentel Auncestre that deed is

l.hi: He nys nat gentil be he duke or Erle
For vileyns / synful dedis maketh a cherle

div.l: For gentillesse nys but renomee
Of thyn Auncestres for hire heigh bounte /
Whiche is straunge thynge for thy ꝑpersone
Thy gentilnesse cometh from god alone
Than cometh oure verrey gentillesse of grace
It was no thyng byqueth vs / with oure place
Thynketh how noble as seyth valerius
Was thilke Tullius hostilius
That oute of pouꝰerte roos to hiegh noblece
Redeth Senek and redeth eke boece
There shul ye sen expresse that noo drede is
That he is gentil that doth gentil dedis
And therfore leue housbande I thus conclude
Al were it that myn Auncestres were rude
Yet may the heigh god and so hope I /
Graunte me grace to lyue vertuously
Thanne am I gentil whan that I begynne
To lyue vertuously and to weyue synne /
And there as ye of pouꝰerte me repreue
The hiegh god on whom that we bileue
In wilful pouerte ches to lyue his lyf
And certes euꝰery maiden and wif
May vndirstande that Ihesus heuen kyng
Ne wolde not chese a vicious lyuyng /
Glad pouerte is an honest thyng certeyn
This wil senek and other seyn[]seyn clerkys seyn
Who so that halt hym of his pouerte
I holde hym riche al had he nought a sherte
He that coueiteth is apore wight
For he wolde han that is nought in his myght
Buth he that nought hath ne coueiteth haue
Is riche al though ye holde hym but a knaue
Verrey synne is pouerte ꝓproprely
Iuueal seith of pouerte myryly
The poore man whan he goth by the way
Byfore the theues he may synge and play

l.hi: Pouerte is hateful good and as I gesse
A ful grete brynger oute of besynesse

div.l: A grete amender eke of sapience

l.seg: To hym that takyth hyt in pacyence

div.l: Pouerte is this al though it seme alenge
Possessioun that no wight wil calenge
Pouerte ful often whan aman is lowe
Maketh his god and eke hym self to knowe
Pouꝰerte a spectacle is as thynketh mee
Thurgh whiche he may his verrey frendis see
And therfore sire syn that I yow nought greue
Of my pouꝰerte nomore ye me repreue
Now sire of elde ye repreuen me
And certes sire though noon auctorite
Were in no boke ye gentils of honour
Sith that men shulde an olde wight don favour
And clepe hym fader for youre gentillesse
And Auctours shal I fynde as I gesse /
Now there ye sey I am foule and olde
Thanne drede yow nought to ben a kokewolde

l.hi: For filthe and elde (so mo I the)
Ben grete wardeyns of chastite

div.l: But natheles syn I knowe youre delyte
I shalle fulfille yow wordly appetite
Chese now quod she oon of this thynges twey
To han me olde and foule til that I dey
And be to yow a trewe humble wyfe
And neuꝰer yow displease in al my lyfe
Or ellys ye wille han me yonge and fayre
And take youre Auenture of the repaire
That shal be to youre hous by cause of me
Or in som other place . it may wele be
Now chese youre selfe whether that yow liketh /
This knyght auyseth hemhymheym and sore siketh
But atte last he seide in this manere
My lady and my loue and wif so dere
I put it in youre wise gouꝰernaunce
Cheseth youre selfe whiche may be moost plesaunce
And moost honour to yow and me also
I doo no force the whether of the two
For as yow liketh it sufficeth me /
Thanne haue I gete of the / maistrie quod she /
Syn I may chese and gouꝰerne as me leste /
Ye certes wyf quod he / I holde it best
Kys me quod she we be no lenger wroothe
For be my treuth I shal be to yow bothe
This is to seyn ye both faire and good /
I pray to god that I moot steruen wood
But I to yow be also good and trewe
As eure was wyf syn that the world was newe
And but I be to morwe as faire to sene
As ony lady Emprice or quene
That is bitwixe the Est and eke the West
Do with me lyfe and deth right as yow lest
Caste vp the curtayn loke how it is /
And when the knyght sey verely al thys
That she so faire was and yong ther to
For Ioy he hent hire in his Armys two
His hert bathed in a bath of blysse
A thousand tymetymeztymez of rewe he gan hire kysse
And she obeyed hym in euꝰery thyng
That myght do hym plesaunce or lykyng
And thus thay leue vn to her lyues ende
In ꝑperfit Ioy . and iħuihesu crist vs sende
Housbondes meke ⁊ yong and freissh a bedde
And grace to ouꝰerbyde hem that we wedde
And eke I pray iħuihesu short her lyues
That nought wil begouꝰerned of hire wyfes
And olde and angry nygardes of dispence
God sende hem sone verrey pestilence
Here endeth the tale of the Wyf of Bathe
Here bigynneth the prologe of the freris tale
This worthy lymytour this noble frere
He made alwey a maner louryng chere
Vpon the sompnorur . but for honeste
No vyleyns word / as yet to hym spake he
But at the laste he seyde vn to the wyfe
Dame quod he god yeue yow right good lyfe
Ye han here touched (Also mote I thee)
In scole matere grete difficultee
Ye han seyde moche thyng right wele I sey
But dame here as we riden by the wey
Vs nedeth not to speke but of game
And late Auctoritees on goddis name
To prechyng and scole of clergye
But it lyke to this compaignye
I wole yow of a sompnorur telle a game
Pardee ye may wel knowen by the name
That of a sompnorur may no good be saide
I pray that noon of yow be yuel a paide
A sompnour is a renner vp and doun
With maundementz for fornicacioun
And is I bete at euery townes ende /
Oure oost thoo spake a sire ye shulde be hende
And curteys as a man of youre estate
In compaignye we wil no debate
Telleth youre tale and lete the sompnour be
Nay quod the sompnour lete hym say to me
What so hym lyst / whan it cometh to my lotte
By god I shalle hym quite euꝰery grotte /
I shalle hym telle whiche a greet honour
It is to be a flatryng lymytour
And of many a nother cryme
Whiche nedeth not reherce for this tyme
And his office I shalle hym telle I wys /
Oure oost answerd pees nomore of thys
And aftir this he seyde vn to the frere
Telle forth youre tale leue maister dere /
Here endeth the ꝓprologe
And bygynneth the freris tale
Whylom ther was dwellyng in my cuntre
An erchedeken a man of heigh degre
That boldely did execucōn
In punysshyng of fornicacioūn
Of wichecrafte and eke of bauderye
Of diffamacioūn and avoutrye
Of chirche reues and of testamentz
Of contractez and eke of lak of sacramentz
Of vsure and of Symonye also
But certes lecchours did he grettist wo
They sholde syngen yef that they were hent
And smale titheris were foule I shent
Yef any ꝑpersone wolde vpon hem playne
Ther myght astir hym no pecunyal payne
For smale tythes and smale offeryng
He made the poeple pitously to syng
For or the bysshop caught hem with his hoke
They were in the Erchedekenes booke

note.hi: There was wokkinge in my country an erchdeken a man off hie degre

div.l: And thanne hadde he thourgh his iurisdiccioun
Pouer to doo on hem correccioun
He hadde a sompnorur redy to his honde
A sleigher boy was noon en Engelonde
For sotelly he hadde his espiaile
That taught hym where hym myght ought availe
He couthe spare of lechour oon or twoo
To techen hym []toto xxiiij moo
For theigh this sompnorur wood were as an hare
To telle his harlotrie I wil not spare
For we ben oute of his correccioun
They han of vs no iurisdiccioun
Ne neuꝰer shulle terme of al hire lyues /
Petir so ben wymen of the styves
Quod the sompnour I put out of oure Cure /
Pees with myschaunce and with mysauenture
Thus seide oure hoost and lete hym telle his tale /
Now telleth forth thow that the sompnour gale /
Ne spareth not myn owen maister dere
This fals theef this sompnorur / quod the frere
Hadde alwey baudes redy to his hoond
As any hauke to lure en Engelonde
That tolde hym al the secre that they knewe
For hire acqueyntaunce was nat come of newe
They weren his Approwours pryuely
He toke hym selfe a greet ꝓprofit ther by
His maister knewe nought alway what he wan
With outen maundement a lewed man
He couthe sompne up peyne of cristes curs
And they were glad for to fille his purs
And made hym greet festes atte nale
And right as Iudas hadde purses smale
And was a thef right suche a thef was he
His maister hadde but halfe his duete
He was / yef I shal yeuen hym his laude /
A Theef and eke a sompnorur and a baude /
He hadde eke wenches at his retenue
That whether sir Robert or sir hewe
Or Iakke or Rauf or who so that it were
That lay by hem they tolde it in his ere
Thus was the wenche and hee of oon assent
And he wolde fecche a feyned maundement
And somoun hem to chapitre bothe twoo
And pille the man and lete the wenche goo /
Than wolde he sey frende I shalle for thy sake
Do strike the oute of oure lettres blake
The dar no more as in this cas trauaile
I am thy frende there I the may availe /
Certeyn he knewe of brybryes moo
Thanne possible is to telle in yeris twoo /
For in this worlde nys dogge for the bowe
That kan an hurt dere from an hole knowe
Bet than this sompnour knewe a sleigh lecchour
Or a voutour or a paramour /
And for that was the fruyt of alle his rent
Therfore on it he sette al his entent /
And so byfel that onys on a day
This sompnour eure eure waytyng on his pray
Rood for to sompne a widowe an olde ribibe
Feynyng a cause for he wold han a brybe
And happed that he say byfore hym ryde
A gay yoman vndir a forest syde
A bowe he bare and Arwes bright an kene
He hadde vppon a courtpie of grene
An hatte vppon his heed with strynges blake /
Sire quod the sompnorur heille and wele a take /
Welcome quod he and euery good felawe
Where ridestow vndir this grene wood shawe
Seide this yoman wiltow fer to day ;
This sompnour hym answered and saide nay
Here fastliy quod / he is myn entent
To riden for to reisen vp a rent
That longeth to my lordes duete
A art thow thanne a bailly ; ye quod he /
He durst nought for verrey filth and shame
Sey he was a sompnour for the name /
Deꝑperdeux quod this yoman dere brother
Thow art a bailly and I am a nother /
I am vnknowen []asas in this countre
Of thyn acqueyntaunce I wol prey the
And eke of bretherhed yef that yow lest
I haue gold and siluer in my cheste
If that the happe to comen in oure shire
Al shalle be thyn right as thow wolt desire
Graunt mercy quod this sompnour by my feyth
Eueriche in otheris honde his treuth he leyth
For to be sworn brotherin til they deye /
In daliaunce they riden forth and pleye
This sompnour whiche that was as ful of Iangles
As fulle of venym ben these wery hangles
And eure enqueryng vpon euꝰery thyng
Brother quod he where is now youre dwellyng
A nother day if that I shulde yow seche ;
This yoman hym answerd in softe speche
Brother quod he fer in the North cuntree
Whe as I hope somtyme I shalle the see
Or we departe I shalle the so wele wisse
That of myn hous ne shaltow neure mysse /
Now brother quod this sompnour I yow prey
Teche me while that we ryden by the wey /
(Syn that ye ben a baillyf as am I)
Some subtilte and telle me feithfully
In myne office how I may moste wynne
And spareth nought for conscience ne synne
But as my brother telle me how do ye ;
Now by my treuthe dere brother saide he
As I shalle telle the a feithful tale /
My wages ben fulle streit and fulle smale /
My lorde is harde to me and daungerous
And myn office is fulle laberous /
And therfore by extorcions I leue
For sothe I take al that men wol me yeue
Algate by sleyght or by violence
Fro yere to yere I wynne al my despence
I can no better tellen feithfully /
Now certes quod this sompnour so fare I
I spare nought to taken god it wote
But if it be to heuy or to hote
What I may gete in counseil priuely
No manꝰer conscience of that haue I
Nere myn extorcion I myght not lyuen
Ne of suche Iapes wil I nouȝt be shreuen
Stomak ne conscience knowe I none
I shrewe this shreft faders euꝰery chone
Wele be we met by god and by seint Iame
But leue brother telle me than thy name /
Quod this sompnour in this mene while /
This yoman gan a litel for to smyle
Brother quod he wiltow that I the telle ;
I am a fende my dwellyng is in helle
And here I ryde a boute my purchasyng
To wite where men wold yeue me any thyng
My purchas is theffect of al my rent
Loke how thow ridest for the same entent
To wynne good thow rekkest neuꝰer how
Ryght so fare I for ryde wolde I now
Vn to the worldes ende for a praye /
A quod the sompnour benedicite what say ye
I wende ye were a yoman trewely
Ye han a mannes shappe as wele as I
Han ye a fygure than determynat
In helle ther ye ben in youre estaat ;
Nay certayn quod he there haue we noon
But whanne vs liketh we kūnne take vs oon
Or ellys make yow seme that we ben shape
Som tyme lyke a man / or lyke an ape /
Or lyke an Aungel can I ride or go /
It is no wonder thyng though it be so /
A lowsy Iogelour kan deceyue the
And parde yet kan / I do more than he /
Why quod the Sompnour ride ye thanne or gon
In sondry shap and nought alwey in oon
For we quod he wille vs suche fourmes make
As moost able is oure pray for to take.
What maketh yow to han al this labour ;
Ful many a cause leue sompnour
Saide this feend but alle thyng hath tyme
The day is short and it is passed prime
And yet ne wan I no thyng in thys day
I wille entende to wynnyng yef I may
And nought entende oure wittes to declare
For brother myne thy witte is alle to bare
To vnderstonde al though I tolde hem the
But for thow axest why labouren we
For somtyme we be goddys instrumentz
And menes for to doo his cōmmaundementz
Whan that hym lyste vpon his creatures
In dyuerse art and in dyuers figures
With outen hym we han no myght certayn
If that hym lyst stonde ther a gayn
And somtyme at oure praiere han we leue
Only the body and nought the soule greue
Witnesse on Iob whom that we dyden woo /
And somtyme han we myght on bothe twoo
This is to seyn of soule and body eke
And somtyme be we suffred for to seke
Vppon a man and do his soule vnrest
Not his body / and alle is for the best /
Whan he withstondith oure temptacion
It is a cause of his sauacion
Al be it that it was not oure entent
He sholde be saufe but that we wolde hym hent
And somtyme be we seruant vn to man
As to the Erchebisshop seint Dunstan
And to the Apostles seruaunt eke was I /
Yet telle me quod the sompnour feithfully
Make ye yow newe bodies thus alwey
Of elementz ; the fende answerde nay /
Somtyme we feyne and somtyme we aryse
With deed bodies in fulle sundry wyse
And speke as renably and faire and wele
As to the Phitonyssa did samuel /
And yet wole some men sey it wat not he
I doo no force of youre dyuynyte
But oo thyng warne I the I wil naught Iape
Thow wilte algates wyte. how we ben shape
Thow shalte here aftirwardes my brother deere
Come where the nedeth nought of me to lere
For thow shalt by thyn owen exꝑperience
Konne in a chaire rede of this sentence
Bet than virgile while he was a lyue
Or dant also now late vs ride blyue
For I wol holde compaignye with the
Til it be so that thow forsake me
Nay quod this sompnour / that shal neuꝰer bitide
I am a yoman / (knowen is ful wide)
My trouth wole I holde as in this cas
For though thow were the deuel Sathanas
My treuth wil I holde to the my brother
As I am sworn and eche of vs to other
For to be trewe brother in this cas /
And booth we goon a boute oure purchas
Take thow thy part what that men wil the yeue
And I shal myne. thus may we bothe lyue
And if that any of vs haue more than other
Lat hym bytrewe and part it with his brother /
I graunt quod the deuel be my fay
And with that worde they ryden forth hire way
And right at entryng of the townes ende
(To whiche this sompnour shope hym for to wende)
They seigh a cart that charged was with hey
Whiche that a carter drof forth in his wey /
Deep was the wey / for whiche the cart stood /
The carter smote and cried as he were wood
Hayt brok / hayt scot / what spare ye for the stones
The feend quod he yow fecche body and bones
As ferforthly as eure were ye foled
As mychel woo as I haue with yow tholed /
The deuel haue al / bothe hors ⁊ cart and hey /
The sompnour seide here shulle we han a pley
And ner the fende he drough as nought ne were
Ful piriuely and rowned in hyr ere
Herken my brother herken by thy feyth
Herestowe nat how that the Carter seith /
Hent it a noon for he hath yeue it thee /
Bothe hey and Carte and eke his Caples three
Nay quod the deuel god wote neuꝰer a dele
It is nat his entent / trust thow me wele
Axe hym thy selfe if thow nought trowist me
Or ellys stynt a while and thow shalt se
This Carter thakketh his hors on the croupe
And they bygonne to drawen and to stoupe
Heyt now quod he ther Iħuihesu crist yow blesse
And alle his handes werke bothe more and lesse
That was wele twight myn owne lyard boy
I prey god saue thy body and seynt loy
Now is my cart is oute of the slogh parde
Lo brother quod the fende what tolde I the
Here may ye sen my owen dere brother
The Carle spak o thyng / and ment a nother
Lete vs goo forth a bouten oure viage
Here wynne I no thyng vpon cariage /
Whan that they comen somwhat oute of toun /
This sompnour to his brother gan to roun /
Brother quod he here woneth an olde Rebekke
That hadde almoost as lief to lese her nekke
As for to yeue a peny []ofof hire good /
I wil haue xij pens though that she be wood
Or I wil somoun her to oure office
And yet god woot of hire knowe I no vice
But for thow canst nought as in this cuntre
Wynne thy coste / take here ensample of me /
This sompnour clappeth atte widowes gate
Come oute quod he thow olde viritrate
I trowe thow haste som frere or preest with the /
Who clappeth seide this wyfe / benedicite /
God saue yow sir what is youre swete wille
I haue quod / he of Somono a bille
Vppeyne of cursyng loke that thow bee
To morwe byfore the Erchedeknys knee
To answere to the Court of certeyn thynges /
Now lord quod she crist iħuihesu kyng of kynges
So wissely helpe me as I ne may
I haue ben sike and that fulle many a day
I may not go so fer quod she ne ryde
But I be deed so prikketh it in my syde
May I not axe a libel sire sompnour
And answere there be my procuratour ;
To swych thyng as men wolde opposen me ;
Yee quod this sompnour paie a noon let see
Xij pens to me and I wil the acquyte
I shalle no ꝓprofite han ther by but lyte /
My Maistre hath the ꝓprofit and nat I /
Come of and late me riden hastily /
Yef me xij pens I may no lenger tary /
Xij pens quod she / now lady seinte mary
So wisly helpe me out of care and synne
This world / though that I shuld wynne
Ne haue I nought xij pens with Inne my holde /
Ye knowen wele that I am pore and olde
Kythe youre Almesse on me pore wrecche /
Nay thanne quod he the foule fende me fecche
Yif I thexcuse though thow sholdest be spilt /
Allas quod she god wote I haue gilt /
Pay me quod he or by the swete seint Anne
As I wil bere a wey thy pannenewe pannepannenewe panne
For dette whiche thow owest me of olde
Whan that thow madest thyn housbond cokewolde /
I paied at home for thy correccioun /
Thow lyxt quod she be my sauacioun /
Ne was I neure or now widwe ne wif
Sompned vn to youre Courte in al my lyf
Ne neure I was but of my body trewe /
Vn to the deuel blak and rough of hewe
Yeue I thy body and my panne also
And whan that the deuel herde hir curse so
Vpon hire knees he seide in this manere
Now Mabely myne owne Moder dere
Is this youre wille in ernest that ye seye
The deuel quod she so fecche hym or he deye
And panne and alle but he wil hym repente /
Nay olde stotte that is not myn entente
Quod this sompnorur for to repente me
For any thyng that I haue hadde of the
I wolde I had thy smok and euꝰery cloth /
Now brother quod the deuel be not wrooth
Thy body and the this panne is myn by right /
Thow shalt with me to helle yet to nyght
Where thow shalt knowen of oure priuete
More than a Maister of dyuynyte
And with that word the foule fende hym hent
Body and soule he with the deuel went
Where as that sompnours han her heritage /
And god that made aftir his Image
Mankynde / saue and gyde vs alle ⁊ some
And leue this sompnorur good man to bycome /
Lordynges I couth haue told yow quod this frere
Hadde I hadde leyser for this sompnour here
Aftir the texte of crist poule and Iohn
And of oure other dottours many oon
Swiche peynes that youre hertis myght a gryse
Al be it so no tunge may deuyse
Though that I myght a thousand wynter telle
The peyne of thilke cursed hous of helle
But for to kepe vs fro that cursed place
Waketh and praieth iħuihesu for his grace
So kepe vs fro the temptorur Sathanas
Herkeneth this word / by ware as in this cas
The lyoun sitte in his awayte alway
To slee the Innocent yef that he may /
Disposeth ay youre hertis to wythstonde
The fende that wil yow make thralle ⁊ bonde /
He may not tempten yow ouꝰer youre myght /
For criste wil be youre champyon and knyght /
And preieth that this sompnour hym repent
Of his mysdedes or that the fende hym hente /
Here endith the Freris tale and bygynnyth
the prologe of the Sompnour
This sompnour in his stiropes hiegh he stood
Vpon this frere his hert was so wood
That lyke an Aspen lefe he quoke for Ire
Lordynges quod he but on thyng I desire
I yow beseke that of youre curtesye
Syn ye han herde this fals frere lye
As suffreth me I may my tale telle
This frere boosteth he knoweth helle
And god it wote that is lytel wonder
Freris and fendis ben but lytel a sonder
For parde ye han eft tyme herd telle
How that a frere vanysshed was to helle
Inspirith oones by a vysyoun
And as an Aungel ladde hym vp ad doun
To shewen hym the peynes that there were
In alle the place saugh he not a frere
Of other folke he say I now in woo
Vn to this Aungel spake the frere thoo
Now sire quod he han freris suche a grace
That noon of hem shalle come to this place
Yis quod this Aungel many a mylyoun
And vn to Sathanas he ledde hym doun
And now hath Sathanas seith he a taille
Brodder than of a Carryk is the sayle
Holde vp thy taille thow Sathanas quod he
Shewe forth thyn ers ⁊ lete the frere se
Where is the nest of freris in this place
And or that halfe a furlonge wey of space
Right so as bees out swarmen of an hyue
Oute of the deuels ers ther gon they dryue
Twenty thousand freris on a route
And thurgh out helle swarmeden a boute
And come a gayn as fast as tahay may gon
And in his ers they crepten euꝰerychon
He clapte his taille a gayn and lay fulle stille
This frere whan he loked had his fille
Vppon the tormentis of this sory place
His spirit god restored of his grace
Vn to his body agayn and he a woke
But natheles for fer yet he quoke
So was the deuels ers ay in his mynde
That is his heritage of verrey kynde
God saue yow alle saue this cursed frere
My ꝓprologe wol I ende in this manere
Here endeth the ꝓprologe of the Sompnorur
And bigynneth his tale
Lordynges ther is in yorke shire as I gesse
A Meirsshy countre called holdernesse
In whiche ther went a lymytour a boute
To preche and eke to begge it is no doute
And so byfelle that on a day this frere
Hadde preched at a chirche in his manere
And specially a bouen euꝰery thyng
Excited he the poeple in his prechyng
To trentals and to yeue for goddis sake
Where with men myghten holy houses make
Ther as dyuyne seruyce is honoured
Nat ther as it is wasted and deuoured
Ne there it nedeth not to be yeue
As to possessioıı̄uns that mowen leue
Thanked be god in wele and habundaunce
Trentals seide he delyureth from penaunce
Here frendes soules as wele olde as yonge
Ye whan that they hastely ben y songe
Nought for to holde a prest ioly and gay
He syngyth nought but o masse on a day
Delyureth oute quod he a noon the soules

l.seg: Ful hard yt ys wtith Fleshkoke or wtith oules

div.l: To ben I clawed or to brenne or bake
Now spede yow hastily for cristis sake
And whan this frere had seide al his entent
With qui cūn patre forth his wey he went
Whan folke in chirche hadde yeue hym what hem lest
He went his wey no lenger wolde he reste
With scrippe and tipped staf y tukked hye
In euꝰery hous he gan to poure and prie
And beggeth mele or chese or ellys corn
His felaw hadde a staffe tipped wtith horn
A peyre of tables alle of Iuery
And a poyntel polsshed fetisly
And wroot the names alwey as he stood
Of alle folke that yaf hym any good
A scaunces that he wolde for hem preye
Yef vs a busshel whete malt or reye
A goddis kechil or a trip of chese
A goddis halpeny or a masse peny
Or yeue vs of youre braun if ye haue eny
A dagoun of youre blanket leue dame
Oure sister dere lo here I write youre name
Bacoun or beof or swiche thyng as ye fynde
A sturdy harlot went ay byhynde
That was here oostes man and bare a sakke
And what men yaf hem leyd it on his bakke
And whan that he was oute atte dore a noon
He planed a wey the names euꝰerychoıı̄un
That byforn hadde wretyn in his tables
He serued hem with nyfles and with fables
Nay there thow lixt thow sompnorur quod the frere
Pees quod oure oost for cristes moder dere
Telle forth thi tale and spare it nought at al
So thryue I quod this sompnorur so I shal
So longe he went hous by hous til he
Come til an hous there he was wont to be
Refresshed more than in an hundred places
Sike lay the bonde man whose the place is
Bedred vpon a couche lowe he lay
Deus hic quod he. o Thomas frend good day
Seide this frere curtesly and softe
Thomas quod he god yeld yow ful ofte
Haue I vppon this benche faren ful wele
Here haue I eten fulle many amery mele
And from the benche he drof a way the catte
And lade a doun his potent and his hatte
And eke his scrippe and sette hym softe adoun
His felawe was go walked in to toun
Forth with his knaue in to that hostelrye
Where as he shope hym thilke nyght to lye
O dere maistre quod this sike man
How haue ye faren sith that Marche bygan
I saugh yow nought this fortenyght or more
God wote quod he laboured haue I fulle sore
And specially for thy sauacioun
Haue I seide many a pꝰercious orisoun
And for oure frendes god hem blesse
I haue to day ben at youre chirche at messe
And seide a sermon aftre my symple witte
Nat alle after the texte of holy writte
For it is harde to yow as I suppose
And therfore wil I teche yow al the glose
Glosyng is a glorious thyng certeyn
For lre sleeth so as we clerkys seyn
There haue I taught hem to be charitable
And spende here good ther it is resonable
And there I sey oure dame / a where is she
Yonde in the yerde I trowe that hee be
Seide this man and she wil come a noon
Ey Maister welcome be ye by seint Iohn
Seyde this wyf how fare ye hertyly
This frere ariseth vp ful curteisly
And hire embraseth in his armes narwe
And kysseth here swete and chirteth as a sparwe
With his lippes ; dame quod he right wele
As he that is youre seruaunt euꝰerydele
Thanked by god that yow yaf soule and lyf
Yet seigh I nat this day so faire a wyf
In alle the chirche god so saue me
Ye god amende defautes sire quod she
Algates welcome be ye be my fey
Graunt mercy dame this haue I found alwey
But of youre greet goodnesse by youre leue
I wolde prey yow that ye nat yow a greue
I wil with Thomas speke a litel throwe
These curates ben ful necligent and slowe
To grope tenderly a conscience
In shrift in prechyng is my diligence
And studie in Petris wordes and in Poules
I walke and fisshe cristen mennes soules
To yelde iħuihesu crist his ꝓpropre rent
To sprede his worde is sette alle myn entent
Now by youre leue . o dere maister quod she
Chideth hym wele for seint Trinite
He is as angry as a pissemyre
Though that he haue al that he can desire
Though I hym wrye a nyght and make hym warme
And on hym ley my legge other myn arme
He groneth lyke oure bore lieth in oure sty
Other disport right noon of hym haue I
I may not please in no manꝰer caas
O Thomas ieo vo9us dye Thomas Thomas
This maketh the fende this most ben amendid
Ire is a thyng that heigh god defendid
And ther of wil I speke a worde or twoo
Now maister quod the wyf or that I goo
What wil ye dyne / I wil goo ther a boute
Now dame quod he now iee vo9us dye saunȝ doute
Haue I nat of a capoun but the lyure
And of youre softe breed nat but a shyuere
And after that a rosted pigges hed
But that I nolde for me no beste were deed
Thanne hadde I with yow hoomly suffisaunce
I am a man of litel suffisaunce
Mi spirit hath his fosteryng in the bible
The body is ay so redy and penyble
To wake that my stomak is destroied
I pray yow dame be ye nouȝt a noyed
Though I so frendly yow my counseille shewe
By god I nolde nat telle it but a fewe
Now sire quod hee but o word or ye goo
Mi childe is deed with in this wekys twoo
Soone aftir that ye went oute of this toun
His deth seigh I be reuelacioun
Seide this frere at hoom in oure dortour
I dar wele sayn or that halfe an oure
After his deth . I seigh hym born to blysse
In myn avisioun so god me wisse
So dide oure sextein / and oure fermerer
That han be trewe freris fyfty yere
Thay may now god be thanked of his lone
Maken her Iubele and walke a lone
And vp I roos and alle oure couent eke
With many a tere trillyng on oure cheke
With outen noyse or clateryng of belles
Te deum was oure songe and no thyng elles
Saue that to criste I saide an orisoun
Thonkyng hym of my reuelacioun
For sir and dame tristeth me right wele
Oure orisons ben more effectuele
And more we sene of cristes secre thynges
Than burelle folke al though that they were kynges
We lyue in pouꝰerte and in abstynence
And burel folke in richesse and dispence
In mete and drynke and in here foule delite
We han this wordlis luste alle in despite
Lazar and dyues leueden dyuersly
And dyuꝰers guerdon had they ther by
Who so wil preye he mot fat ⁊ be clene
And fatte his soule . and make his body lene
We fare as seith thapostle clooth ⁊ foode
Suffiseth vs though they be not ful goode
The clennesse and the fastyng of vs freris
Maketh that []cristcrist accepteth oure praieris
Loo Moises fourty dayes and fourty nyght
Fasted or that the high god of myght
Spake with hym in the Mount of Synay
With empty wombe fastyng many a day
Receyued he the lawe that was writen
With goddes fynger and Elye wele ye weten
In Mount oreb or he had ony speche
With heigh god that is oure lyues leche
He fasted longe and was in contemplaunce
Aaron that hadde the temple in gouꝰernaunce
And eke that other prestes euꝰerychon
In to the temple whan that they sholde gon
To prey for the peple and seruyse
They nolde drynken in no manꝰer wyse
No drynke whiche that myght hem dronke make
But there in abstinence prey and wake
Lest that they deyden (take hede what I seye)
But they be sobre that for the peple preye
War that I say nomore for it suffiseth
Oure lord iħuihesu as holy writte deuyseth
Yaf vs ensample of fastyng and praieres
Ther fore we mendenauntz we sely freres
Ben wedded to pouert and contynence
To charite humblesse and abstinence
To ꝑpersecucioun for rightwysnesse
To wepyng mysericorde and clennesse
And therfore may ye see that oure preieris
(I speke of vs we mendynauntz we freris)
Be to the heigh god more acceptable
Than youres with youre festes atte table
Fro paradys first yf I shal nat lye
Was man out chased for his glotonye
And chast was man in paradys certeyn
But herken now Thomas what I shal seyn
I ne haue no texte of hit as I suppose
But I shalle fynde it in a manꝰer of glose
That specially oure swete lord iħusihesu
Spak this by freris when []hehe seide thus
Blyssed be they that pore in spirit ben
And so forth alle the gospel may ye sen
Wher it be lyker oure ꝓprofessioun
Or her that swymmen in possessioun
Fy on here pompe and on here glotonye
And on here lewidnesse I hem defye
Me thynkyth they ben lyke Iouynyau
Fatte as a whale ⁊ walkyng as a swan
As vynolent as botel yn the spence
Here Preyer ys of ful grete reuꝰerence
When they for soules sey the psalme of Dauid
Loo buff they sey cor meūn eructauit
Hoo Folwyth crystys gospel ⁊ hys lore
But we that pore humble ben ⁊ chast ⁊ pore
Wyrkers of goddys word not audyturs
Therefore right as an hauk vp at a sours
Vp spryngyth yn to theyre / right so preyers
Of Charytable ⁊ chast besy Freres
Makyng here sours to goddys eeres twoo /
Thomas Thomas so mote y ryde or goo
And by that lord that clepid ys synt Iue
Nere thou our brother sholdest thou not thryue
In Oure chapitre pray we day and nyght
To criste that he the sende hele and myght
Thy body for to welden hastily /
God wote quod he no thyng ther of fele I
As helpe me criste as I in fewe yerys
Haue spendid vpon dyuꝰers freris[]freris manꝰer freris
Fulle many a pound yet fare I neure the bette
Certeyn my good haue I almost bysette
Fare wele my good for it is al a goo /
The frere answerd o Thomas dostow so ;
What nedeth yow dyuers freris seche ;
What nedit hym that hath a ꝑperfit leche /
To sechen other leches in the toun ;
Thow inconstaunce is youre confusioun
Holde ye than me or ellys oure couent
To prey for yow ben insufficient ;
Thomas that Iape nys nat worth a myte
Youre maladie is / for we han to lyte /
A yeef that Couent halfe a quarter ootes
A yef that Couent xxiiij grotes
A yeue that frere a peny and late hym goo /
Nay nay Thomas it may no thyng be soo
What is a ferthyng worth parted in twelue
Loo eche thyng that is oned in hym selue
Is more stronge than whan it is scatred

l.seg: Thomas of me þu shalt noȝt bēn flatred

div.l: Thow woldest han oure labour al for nought /
The heigh god that al this world hath wrought
Seith that the wormanworkmanworkman is worthy his hire /
Thomas nought of youre Tresoure I desire
As for my selue but that alle oure couent
To pray for yow is ay so diligent
And for to bielden cristes owne chirche /
Thomas if ye wille lerne for to wirche
Of bieldyng vp of chirches may ye fynde
Yif it be good in Thomas lyfe of Inde /
Ye lye here fulle of anger and of Ire
With whiche the deuel set youre herte a fire
And chyden here the holy Innocent
Youre wyf that is so meke and pacient /
And therfore Thomas trowe me yef the lest
Ne stryue not with thy wyfe as for the best
And bere this word a wey now be thy feith /
Touchyng suche thyng lo what the wise man seith /
With Inne thyn hous ne be thow no leoun
To thy sogettis do non oppressioun
Ne make thyne acqueyntaunces not to flee /
And Thomas yet eft sones I charge thee
Be ware from Ire that in thy body slepith

l.hi: War from the serpent that so so sleighly crepith
Vndir the grasse and styngeth subtily

div.l: Be ware my sone and herken paciently
That twenty thousand men han lost her lyues
For stryuyng with her lemans and her wyues /
Now sith ye han so holy meke a wyf
What nedeth yow Thomas to make stryf ;
Ther nys I wys no serpent so cruel
Whan man treet on his taile / ne half so fel
As woman is whan she hath caught an Ire
Vengeaunce is thanne al that they desire /
Ire is a synne oon of the greet of sevene
Abhomynable vn to the god of heuene
And to hym self it is destruccioun
This euꝰery lewed vyker or persoun
Can sey how Ire engendreth homycide
Ire is in soth executour of pride
I Couthe of Ire sey so moche sorwe
Mi tale shuld laste vn tyl to morwe /
And therfore pray I god day and nyght
An Irous man god sende hym lytel myght
It is greet harme and eke greet pite
To sette an Irous man in highe degree
Whilom ther was an Irous potestat
As seith Senek duryng his estat
Vppon a day out ryden knyghtes two
And as fortune wolde that it were so
That oon of hem come home that other nought
A non the knyght byfore the Iuge is brought
That seide thus thow hast thy felawe slayn
For whiche I deme the to the deth certayn
And to a nother knyght cōmmaunded he
Go lede hym to the deth I charge the /
And happed as they wenten by the wey
Toward the place ther he shulde dey
The knyght cam whiche men wenden had ben ded
Than thought they it was the best reed
To lede hem bothe to the Iuge agayn
They seyden lord the knyght ne hath not slayn
His felaw / here he standeth hool a lyue
Ye shul be deed quod he so mote I thryue
That is to seyn both oon twoo ⁊ thre
And to the first knyght right thus spake he
I dampned the thow most nede be deed
And thow also most nedes lese thyn hed
For thow art cause why that thy felawe deyth
And to the thrid knyght right thus he seyth
Thow hast not doon that I cōmmaunded the
And thus he did do slen hem alle three
Irrous Cambises was eke drunken lewe
And ay delited hym to ben a shrewe /
And so bifelle a lorde of his Meynee
That loued vertuous moralite
Seide on a day bytwix hem two right thus
A lorde is loste if he be vicious
And drunkenesse is eke a foule recorde
Of any man and namely in a lorde
There is fulle many an eygh and many an ere
A waytyng on a lord / ⁊ he not where
For goddes loue drynke more a temprely /

l.hi: Wyn maketh man to lese wrecchedly

div.l: His mynde and his lymes euꝰerychon /
The reuers shaltow se quod he a non
And preue it be thyn owen exꝑperience
That wyn ne doth to folke no suche offence
Ther is no wyn bereueth me my myght
Of honde ne fote ne of myn eyghen sight
And in dispite he dranke fulle mychel more
An hundreth part than he had doon byfore
And right a non this irrous cursed wrecche
Lete this knyghtes sone byfore hym fecche
Cōmmaundyng hym he sholde byfore hym stonde
And sodenly he toke his bowe in honde
And vp the strenge he pulled to his ere
And with an arwe he slowe the childe right there
Now whether haue I a siker honde or noon
Quod he / ilisils al my myght and mynde a goon
Hath wyn byreued me myn eigh sight ;
What shulde I telle the answere of the knyght
His sone was slayn ther nys momore to seye /
Be ware therfore wtith lordes how ye pley
Synge placebo / and I shal yef I can /
But yef it be vn to a pore man /
To a pore man men sholde his vices telle
But nought to a lorde though he shuld / goo to helle /
Lo Irrous Cirus thilk percien
How he destroied / the ryuer of gysen
For that an hors of his was dreynt ther Inne
Whan that he went babyloyn to wynne
He made that the ryuer was so smal
That wymen myght wade ouꝰer al /
Loo what seide he that so wele teche can

l.hi: Ne be no felawe to non Irous man
Ne with noo wood man walke by the way
Leste the repent I wil no ferther sey

div.l: Now Thomas leue brother leue thyn Ire
Thow shalt me fynde as Iust as is a squyre
Hold not the Deuels knyf ay at thyn herte
Thyn angre doth the al to sore smerte
But shewe to me alle thyn confessioun /
Nay quod the sike man be seynt Symoun
I haue ben shreuen this day at my curat
I haue hym tolde al holly myn estat
Nedith nomore to speke of it seith he
But yef me lyst of myn humylyte /
Yeue me thanne of thy golde to make oure cloistre
Quod he for many a muscle ⁊ many an oystre
Whan other men han ben fulle wele at eyse
Hath ben oure fode oure cloistre for to reyse
And yet god wote vnnethe the foundement
ꝐPerformed is ne of the pauement
Nis nat a tile yet with Inne oure wones
By god we owen xl ls for stones
Now helpe Thomas for hym that harwed helle
For elles mote we oure bokes selle
And yef yow lakke oure pꝰerdicacioun
Than goth the world al to destruccioun
For who so fro this world wold vs byreue
So god me saue Thomas by youre leue
He wolde byreue oute of this world the sonne
For whoo can teche and werken as we konne
And that is nought of litel tyme quod he
But sithen Elye was or Elyse
Han freris ben that fynd I of recorde
In charite thanked be oure lorde
Now Thomas helpe for seint charite
And doun a noon sette he hym on his knee /
This sike man waxe fulle nygh wood for Ire
He wolde that the frere had ben a fire
With his fals dissymulacioun /
Swiche thyng as is in my possessioun
Quod sheheshe that may I yeue and noon other
Ye sey me this how that I am youre brother /
Ye certes quod this frere / trosteth wele
I toke oure dame lthe lettre of oure sele /
Now wele quod he and somwhat shal I yeue
Vn to youre holy Couent while I. leue
And in thyn hande thow shalt it han anoon
On this condicioun and other noon
That thow departe it so my dere brother
That euꝰery frere haue as moche as other
This shaltow swere on thy ꝓprofessioun
With outen fraude or cauelacioun /
I swere it quod the frere vpon my feith
And ther with al his honde in his he leyth
Lo here my fey in me shalle be no lakke /
Now thanne put thyn hand doun be my bakke
Seide this man . and grope wele byhynde
Byneth my buttok there shatthow fynde
A thyng that I haue hidde in priuetee /
A thought this frere that shalle goo with me /
And doun his hand he launcheth to the clfteclyfteclyfte
In hope for to fynde ther a yefte
And whan this sike man felt this frere
A boute his tuel grope there ⁊ here
A mydde his hande he lete the frere a fart
Ther nys no caple drawyng in a cart
That myght han late a fart of suche a soun /
The frere vp stert as dooth a wood leoun
A fals cherle quod he for goddes bones
This hastow for despite doon for the nones /
Thow shalt a bye this fart yef I may /
His meyne whiche that herden this affray
Cam lepyng Inne and chaced oute the frere
And forth he goth with a fulle angry chere
And fet his felawe ther as lay his store
He loked as it were a wilde bore
He grynt with his teeth so was he wrooth /
A sturdy paas doun to the Court he goth
Where as there woned a man of gret honour
To whom that he was alwey confessour
This worthy man was lord of that village /
This frere come as he were in a rage
Where as this lorde satte etyng at his borde
Vnnethe myght the frere speke a worde
Tille atte laste he seide god yow se /
This lord gan to loke and seide benedicite
What frere Iohn what manꝰer world is this
I se wele that som thyng is a mys
Ye loke as thow the wood were fulle of theuys /
Sit doun a non and telle me what youre grief is /
And it shalle be amendid if I may /
I haue quod he hadde a despite to day
God yeld yow a doun in youre village
That in this worlde there nys so poore a page
That he nolde haue abhominacioun
Of that I haue resceyued in youre toun /
And yet ne greueth me no thyng so sore
(As that this olde cherle with lokkes hore
Blasfemed ekethhathhatheketh oure holy couent eke /
Now maister quod this lorde I yow beseke /
No maister ꝸser quod he but seruytour
Though I haue had in scole that honour
God liketh nought that Raby men vs calle
Neither in Market nyn youre large halle /
No force quod he but telle me al youre grief /
Sire quod this frere an odious myschief
This day betidde is to myn ordre and me
And so ꝑper consequens to eche degree
Of holy chirche god amende it sone /
Sir quod the lorde ye woot what is to doone
Distempore yow nought ye be my confessour
Ye ben the salt of chirche and the sauour
For goddis loue youre pacience ye holde
Telle me youre grief / and he anoon hym tolde
As ye han herde byforn ye woot wele what /
The lady of the hous ay stille satte
Til she had herde what the frere saide
Ey goddis moder quod she blysfulle maide /
Is ther ought elles ; telle me feithfully /
Madame quod he how thynketh yow ther by ;
How that me thynketh quod she / so god me spede /
I sey a cherle hath don a cherles dede /
What sholde I sey ; god late hym neure the /
His sike heed is fulle of vanyte
I holde hym in a manꝰer frenesye /
Madame quod he by god I shal not lye
But I on hym other wise may be wreke
I shalle diffame hym ouꝰer al ther I speke /
This false blasfemour that charged me
To parte that wil nought deꝑparted be
To euꝰery man ylyche with myschaunce /
The lord sat stille as he were in a traunce
And in his hert he rolled vp ⁊ doun
How had this cherl ymaginacioun
To shewe suche a ꝓprobleme to a frere
Neuer erst er now herd I suche a matere
I trowe the deuel put it in his mynde
In ars metryke shal ther noman fynde
Byfore this day of suche a questioun
Who shulde make a demonstracioun
That euꝰery man shulde han y lyke his part
As of a soun or sauour of a fart /
O nyce proude cherle I shrewe his face
Lo sires quod the lord with harde grace
Who eure herde of suche a thyng eure[]eure or now ;
To euꝰery man y lyke telle me how;
It is an inpossible it may nat be
Ey nyce cherle god late hym neure the
The romblyng of a fart and euꝰery soun
Nys but of eyr reuerberacioun
And eure it wasteth lite and lite a wey
Ther nys no man can deme by my fey
Yef that it were deꝑparted equaly /
What loo my cherle lo yet how shrewdely
Vn to my confessour to day he spak
I holde hym certeynely demonyak
Now ete youre mete and late the cherle go pley
Late hym goo hange hym selfe a Deuel wey /
¶ Now stood the lordes squyer at the boord
That karf his mete and harde worde by word
Of alle thyng of whiche I haue yow seide /
My lorde quod he by ye nought yuel a paide
I couthe telle for a gowne cloth
To yow ꝸser frere so ye be nat wroth
How that this fart shulde euene y deled be
A mong youre couent / yef it lyked me
Telle quod the lord and thow shalt han anon
A goun cloth by god and by seint Iohn /
My lord quod he when that the wedder is feire
With outen wynde or ꝑpertourbyng of eyre
Late bryng a cartwheel here in to this halle
But loke that it haue his spokes alle
Twelue spokes hath a cart wheel comunely
And brynge me me thanne twelue freris . wot ye why ;
For xiij is a couent as I gesse /
Youre confessour here for his worthynesse
Shal ꝑperfourme vp the nombre of this couent
Than shalle they knele doun by oon assent
And to euꝰery spokes ende in this manere
Fulle sadly lay his nose shalle a frere
Youre noble confessour ther god hym saue
Shal holde his nose vpright vndir the naue
Than shal this cherle wyth a baly styf ⁊ tought
As any tabour hider ben I brought
And sette hym on the wheel right of this cart
Vpon the naue and make hym lete a fart
And ye shalle seen vp paril of my lyf
Be proef whiche that is demonstratyf
That equaly the soun of it wille wende
And eke the stynke vn to the spokes ende
Saue that this worthy man youre confessour
By cause he is a man of greet honour
Shalle han the first fruyt as resoun is
The noble vsage of freris yet is this
The worthy men of hem shulle first be serued
And certeynly he hath it wele deserued
He hath to day taught vs so mochel good
With prechyng in the pulpit ther he stood
That I may fouche saufe (I sey for me)
He had the first smel of Fartes thre
And so wolde al his couent hardely
He berith hym so faire and holyly /
¶ The lord the lady and eche man saue the frere
Seyden that Iankyn spak in this matere
As wele as Euclyde or ꝒProtholome /
Touchyng the cherle they seyde subtilite
An heigh witte made hym speke as he spak /
He nys no fole ne no demonyak
And Iankyn hath I wonne a newe gowne
My tale is doon we ben almost at towne
Here endeth the Sompnours tale
The ꝓprophemye of the Clerkys tale of Oxenford
Syr clerke of Oxenford oure ooste sayde
Ye ride as coy ⁊ stille as doth a maide
Were newe spoused / sittynge atte the bordde
This day ne herd I of youre tonge a worde
I trowe ye studie a boute som sophyme
But Salamoūn seith that euꝰery thyng hath tyme
For goddes sake as beth of better chere
It is no tyme for to studien here
Telle vs som mery tale by youre fay
For what man that is entred in a play
He nedis mot vnto the pley assente
But precheth not as freris doth in lente
To make vs for oure olde synnes wepe
Ne / that thy tale vs makt to slepe
Telle vs som mery thyng of aventures
Youre termes youre colours ⁊and youre figures
Keep hem in stoor til so be that ye endite
Heigh stile , as whan that men to kynges write /
Speketh so pleyne at this tyme we yow pray ,
That we may vndirstonde what ye say /
This worthy clerke benyngnely ansuerde /
Oost qdquod he , I am vndir youre yerde /
Ye han of vs as now the goủernaunce /
And therfore wole I do yow obeyssaunce
As fer as resoıı̄un axeth hardily
I wille yow telle a tale whiche that I
Lerned at Padow of a worthy Clerk
As pryved by his wordes ⁊and his werk
He is now deed ⁊and nailed in his cheste
I pᵃray to god so yeue his soule reste /
Fraunceys Petrak the laureat poete
Hight this clerke whoos rethorik swete
Enlumyned alle Itaille of Poetrie
As lynyan did of Philosophie
Or lawe or other arte ꝑparticuler /
But deeth that wille nat soeffre vs dwellen here
But as it were a twynkelyng of an eye
Hem both hath slayn / ⁊and alle shulle we deye /
But forth to tellen of this worthy man
That taught me this tale as I began
I sey that first with hie stile he enditeth
Er he the body of this tale writeth
Est ad ytale A ꝓprohemye in the whiche discryueth he
Pemond ⁊and of saluces the the cuntre
And speketh of Appenyn þᵉthe hilles hie
That ben the boundes of westlumbardie
And of mount vesulus in specialle
Where as the poo out of a welle smalle
Taketh his first spryngynge ⁊and his sours
That Estward ay encresith in his cours
To Emeleward to Ferare and Venyse
The whiche a long thyng were to deuyse
And trewely as to my Iugement
Me thynketh it a thyng inꝑpertynent
Saue that he wolle conuōyen his matere
But this is his tale whiche that ye may here
Here bygynneth the tale
grata placuaesTher is at the weste syde of Itaille
Doun̄ at þᵉthe root of vesulus the colde
A lusty playne habundaunt of vitaille
Where many a toure ⁊and town̄ thow maist biholde
That founded were in tyme of Fadres olde
And many a nother delitable sight
And Saluces this noble cuntre hight
ᵃ A Markis whilom lord was of that lond

l.hi: As were his worthi eldres hȳn bifore

div.l: And obeisaunt ay redy to his hond
Were alle his lieges both lasse ⁊and more
Thus in delite he lyueth ⁊and hath doon̄ yoore
Byloued ⁊and drad thourgh fauoᵘur of Fortune
Bothe of his lorde ⁊and of his comune
ᵃ Ther with he was to speke as of lynage
The genteleste y born̄ of lumbardye
A Faire ꝑpersone ⁊and stronge ⁊and yong of age
And fulle of honour ⁊and of curtesie
Discreet ynough his cuntre for to gye
Saue in som thynges that he was to blame
And Walter was this yong lordes name
ᵃ I blame hym thus þᵗthat he considerid nought
In tyme comyng what myght hym bitide
But on his lust p̉resent was al his thought
As for to hauke ⁊and hunte on eủery side
Wel neigh alle other cures leet he slide
And eeke he nolde ⁊andþᵗthat was worst of alle
Wedde no wife for nought that may bifalle
ᵃ Only that poynt his peple bare so sore
cat̉eruatim That flokmele on a day thay to hym went
And oon of hem that wisest was of lore
Or ellis that the lord wold best assent
That he sholde telle hym what his peple ment
Or ellis couthe he shewe wel swiche matere
He to the Markys saide as ye shalle here
ᵃ O noble Markys. youre humanyte
Assureth vs ⁊and yeueth vs hardynesse
As ofte as tyme is of necessite
That we to yow mow telle oure heuynesse
Accepteth lord now of youre gentillesse
That we with pitous hert vn to yow pleyne
And late youre eres not my voys dysdeyne
ᵃ Alle haue I nought to doon in this matere
More than a nother man hath in this place
Yet for as moche as ye my lord so dere
