Han alway shewed me fauoᵘur⁊and grace
I dar the bettre axe of yow a space
Of Audience to shewe oure request
And ye my lord to doon right as yow lest
ᵃ For certes lord . so wele vs liketh yow
And alle youre werke . ⁊and eủer han don þᵗthat we
Ne couth nat vs self deuysen how
We myght lyue in more filicite
Saue oon thyng lord if it youre wille be
That for to ben a wedded man yow lest
Than were youre peple in soủereyn hertꝭes rest
ᵃ Boweth youre nekke vndir þᵉthe blysfull yok
Of souereynete nought of seruyse
Whiche that men clepen spousaille or wedlok
And thenketh lord a monge youre thoughtis wise
How that oure daies passe in sundry wise
For though we slepe. or wake or renne or ride
Ay fleeth the tyme it nyl no man a byde
ᵃ And though youre grene youthe floure as yet
In crepeth age alway as stille as stoon
And deeth manaceth eủery age ⁊and smyt
In eche estate for ther ascapeth noon
And also certeyn as we knowe echoıı̄un
That we shalle die as vncerteyn we alle
Ben of that day whan deth shalle on vs falle
ᵃ Accepteth than of vs the trewe entent
That neủer yet refuseden thyn heste
And we wolle lorde if that ye wolle assente
Chese yow a wife in short tyme at the leste
Born of the gentelest ⁊and of the meste
Of alle this lond so that it oughte seme
Honour to god ⁊and yow as we kan deme
ᵃ Delyủer vs out of alle this besy drede
And take a wyfe for heygh goddys sake
For if it so bifell as god forbede
That thurgh youre deth youre lif shold slake
And that a straunge successour shold take
Youre heritage . woo were vs a lyue
Wherefore we pᵃray yow hastely to wyue
ᵃ Hir meke pᵃrayer ⁊and here petous chere
Made the Merkys hert han pite
Ye wol qdquod he myn owen poeple dere
To that me neủer erst thought streyne me
I me reioysed of my liberte
That selde tyme is founde in mariage
Ther I was free I mote ben in seruage
ᵃ But natheles I se youre trewe entent
And trust vppon youre wit ⁊and haue don ay
Wherfore of my fre will I woll assent
To wedde me as sone as eủer I may
But there as ye han ꝓprofred me to day
To chese me a wyfe I yow relese
That choys. ⁊and pᵃray yow of that ꝓprofre cese
ᵃ For god it wot that children ofte ben

l.hi: Vnlyke her worthy eldres hem byfore
Bounte cometh all of god nought of þᵉthe streen
Of whiche thay ben engendred and Ibore

div.l: I truste in goddis bounte ⁊and therfore
My Mariage ⁊and myn estate and reste
I hym bytake he may doon as hym leste
ᵃ Lete me allone in chesyng of my wife
That charge vppon my bakke I wolle endure
But I yow pray ⁊and charge vppon youre lyfe
What wif that I take ye me assure
To worship̄ hire while that hire lyfe may dure
In worde ⁊and werke both here ⁊and eủery where
As she an Emꝑperours doughter were
ᵃ And ferthermore this shalle ye swere þᵗthat ye
A gayn my choys shalle nother grucche ne stryue
For sith I shalle forgon my liberte
At youre request as eủer mote I thryue
Ther as myn hert is sette there wol I wyue
And but ye wolle assente in suche manere
I pᵃray yow speketh nomore of this matere
ᵃ With hertely wille they sworen ⁊and assenten
To alle this thyng ther saide no wight nay
Bysikyng hym of grace er that they wenten
That he wolde gᵃraunten hem a certeyn day
Of his spousaille as sone as eủer he may
For yet alway the peple somwhat dredde
Leste that the markys no wyfe wolde wedde
ᵃ He gᵃraunted hem a day swiche as hym leste
On whiche he wolde be wedded sikerly
And seide he dide alle this at here request
And they with humble entent buxomly
Knelyng vppon her knees fulle reủerently
Hym thanken alle. ⁊and thus they han an ende
Of hire entent ⁊and hom a gayn thay wende
ᵃ And here vppon he to his officers
Cōmmaundeth for the fest to puruey
And to his pryve knyghtes ⁊and squyers
Swiche charge yaf as hym lyst on hem ley
And they to his cōmmaundement obey
And eche of hem doth alle his diligence
To doon vnto the feste reủerence
Explicit prima pars // Incipit secunda pars
Nought fer from thilke Paleys honourable
Where as þs Markis shope his Mariage
Ther stood a throop of site delitable
In whiche that poure folke of that village
Hadden her bestes ⁊and her herbergage
And of her labour toke here sustenaunce
Aftir that the erthe yaf hem habundaunce
ᵃ A monge this pore folke ther dwelte a man
Whiche that was holden pouerest of hem alle
But heigh god somtyme senden can
His grace in to a litel oxes stalle
Ianicula men of that throop hym calle
A doughter had he faire I nough to sight
And Grisildis this yonge maiden hight
ᵃ But for to speke of vertuous beaute
Than was she oon the fairest vndir sonne
For poureliche y fostred was she
No likerous luste was thurgh her herte y ronne
Wele ofter of the welle then of the tonne
She dranke and for she wolde vertue plese

l.hi: She knewe wele labour but non ydel ese

div.l: ᵃ But though this maide tendre were of age
Yet in the brest of her virginite
Ther was enclosed ripe ⁊and sad corage
And in grete reủerence ⁊and charite
Hire olde pore fader fostred she /
A fewe sheep̄e spynnyng on felde she kept
She wolde not ben ydel til she slept /
ᵃ And whan she homward kam she wolde brynge
Wortes or other herbes tymes ofte
The whiche she shredde and seeth for her lyuynge
And made hire bedde full harde ⁊and no thyng softe
And ay she kepte her faders life on lofte
With eủeryche obeisaunce ⁊and diligence
That child may don to fadres reủerence
ᵃ Vppon Grisild this pore creature
Full ofte sithe this Markis set his eye
As he an huntyng rood ꝑperauenture
And whan it felle that he myght hire espie
He nought wᵗwith wantoun lokyng of folie
His eyen cast on hire. but in sad wise
Vppon hire chiere he wolde hym ofte avise
ᵃ Cōmmendyng in his hert her womanhede
And eke here vertue passyng any wight
Of so yonge age as wele in chere as dede /
For though the peple haue no greet insight
In vertue , he considered full right
Her bounte , ⁊and disposed that he wolde
Wedde hire oonly if eủer he wedde sholde /
ᵃ The day of weddyng cam but no wight can
Telle what woman that it sholde be /
For whiche merueile . wondred many a man
And seiden / when they were in pryuete /
Wolle not oure lord / yet leue his vanyte ?
Wolle he not wedde ? allas allas þᵉthe while /
Whi woll he thus hym self ⁊and vs bigile ?
ᵃ But natheles this Markis hath doon make
Of gemmes sette in golde ⁊andin Asure
Broches ⁊and rynges for Grisildes sake
And of here clothyng toke he the Mesure
Of a Maide like to hire stature
And eke of other Aournamentes alle
That vnto swiche a weddyng shold falle
ᵃ The tyme of vndren of the same day
Approcheth that this weddyng shold be
And alle the paleys putte was in array
Bothe halle ⁊and chambres eche in his degre
Houses of office stuffed with plente
Ther maistow sen of deynteuous vitaille
That may be founde as fer as laste Itaille
ᵃ This real Markys richely arraied
Lordys ⁊and ladys in his compaignye
The whiche that to the feste were y praied
And of his retenue the bachelrye
With many a souıı̄ of sundry melodye
Vnto the village of whiche I tolde
In this array the right wey han holde
ᵃ Grisilde of this god woot fulle Innocent
That for her shapen was all this array
To fecchen water at a welle it went
And cometh hoom as sone as eủer she may
For wele she hadde herde saide that thilke day
The Markis shold wedde and if she myght
She wolde fayn han seighen som of that sight
ᵃ She thought I wole with other maidens stonde
That ben my felawys in oure dore and see
The Markisesse ⁊and therfore wole I fonde
To doon at hoom as sone as it may be
The labour whiche that longeth vn to me
And than I may at leyser hire biholde
Yf she this wey vnto the castel holde
ᵃ And as she wolde oủer hire thresshold gon
The Markis cam ⁊and gan hir for to calle
And she sette doun hir water potte anoon
Biside the thresshold in an oxes stalle
And doun vppon hire knees she gan to falle
And with sadde cuntenance kneleth stille
Tille she hadde herd what was þe lordes wille
ᵃ This thoughtfulle Markis spake vnto this maide
Full sobrely and saide in this manere
Where is youre fader o Grisildis he saide
And she with reủerence in humble chere
Answerd lord he is al redy here
And in she goth wtith oute lenger lette
And to the Markis she hire fader fette
ᵃ He bi the honde than toke this olde man
And seide thus whan he hadde hym asyde
Ianicula I neyther may ne kan
Lenger the plesaunce of myn hert hide
Yf that thow foche safe . what so betide
Thy doughter wil I take er that I wende
As for myn vyfe vnto hire lyfes ende
ᵃ Thow louest me I wote it wele certeyn
And art my feithfulle ligeman y bore
And alle that liketh me I dare wele seyn
Yt liketh the ⁊and specially therfore
Telle me that poynt that I haue seide before
Yf that thow wolt vnto that pᵘurpos drawe
To take me as for thy sonne in lawe
ᵃ The sodeyn cas this man a stoyned so
That reed he wax a baist ⁊and all quakyng
He stood vnneth seide he wordis mo
But oonly thus. lord qdquod he my willyng
Ys as ye wolle ne ayeins youre lykyng
I wole no thyng ye be my lorde so dere
Right as yow lyst goủern̉erneth this matere
ᵃ Yet wole I qdquod this Markis softely
That in thi chambre .I. and thow ⁊and shee
Haue a collacioun ⁊and wostow why
For I wolle axe if it here wille be
To be my wyfe ⁊and rule hire aftir me
And alle this shalle be don in thi p̉resence
I wole nought speke oute of thyn audience
ᵃ And in the chambre while they were aboute
Hire tretys whiche ye shulle aftir here
The peple cam vnto the hous with oute
And wondred hem in how honest manere
And tentifly she kepte hire fadir dere
But outrely Gresildis wondre myght
For neủer erst saugh she suche a sight
ᵃ No wonder is though that she were astoned /
To see so gret a gest com in to that place
She neủer was to suche gestes woned
For whiche she loked with fulle pale face
But shortly forth this mater for to chace
These aren the wordes that þᵉthe Markys saide
To this benygne verrey feithfulel maide
ᵃ Grisilde he saide ye shulle wele vndirstonde
It liketh to youre fader ⁊and to me
That I yow wedde ⁊and eke it may so stonde
As I suppose ye wolle that it so be
But these demaundes axe I first qdquod he
That sith it shalle by don in hasty wise
Wole ye assente or elles yow avise
ᵃ I sey this be ye redy wᵗwith good herte
To al my lust ⁊and that I frely may
As me beste thynketh do yow laughe or smerte
And neủer ye to grucche it nyght ne day
And eke when I say ye . ye say nat nay
Neither by word ne frownyng countenance
Swere this and here I swere oure Alliaunce
ᵃ Wondryng vpon this word quakyng for drede
She saide lorde vndigne or vnworthy
I am to thilke honour that ye me bede
But as ye woll youre selfe right so wol I
And here I swere that neủer willyngly
In werke ne thought I nyl yow disobeye
For to be deed though me were looth to deye
ᵃ This is ynough Grisild myn qdquod he
And forth he goth with a full sobre chere
Oute atte the dore. and aftir that cam she
And to the peple he seide in this manere
This is my wife qdquod he that standith here
Honoureth hire and loueth hire I yow preye
Who so me loueth ther is nomore to seye
ᵃ And for that no thyng of hire olde gere
She sholde brynge in to his hous he bad
That women shold dispoillen hire right there
Of whiche thise ladies were nought right glad
To hāndle hire clothes where in she was clad
But natheles this maide bright of hewe
Fro foot to heed they clothed han al newe
ᵃ Her heres han thay kembd that lay vntressed
Full rudely ⁊and with here figers smale
A Crowne on her heed they han y dressed
And set hir full of Nowchis grete ⁊and smale
Of hir array what sholde I make a tale
Vnnethe the peple hire knewe for hire fairnesse
Whan she translated was in suche richesse
ᵃ This Markis hath hire spoused with a ryng
Brought for the same cause ⁊and thanne hire sette
Vpon an hors snow white ⁊and wele amblyng
And to his Paleys er he lenger lette
With Ioyfull poeple that hire ladde ⁊and mette
Convoied hire ⁊and thus the day they spende
In reuell til the sonne gan descende
ᵃ And shortly forth this tale for to chace
I sey that this newe Markisesse
God hath sent hire suche fauoᵘur of his grace
That it ne semyd nat by lyklynesse
That she was born ⁊and fedde in rudenesse
As in a Cote or in an Oxe stalle
But norisshed in an Emꝑperours halle
ᵃ To eủery wight she woxen is so dere
And worshipfull that folke there she was bore
And from hire birthe knewe hire yere by yere
Vnnethe trowed thay but durst haue swore
That to Ianicle of whiche I spake byfore
She doughter were for as by coniecture
Hem thoughte she was a nother creature
ᵃ For though that eủere vertuous was she
She was encresed in suche excellence
Of thewes good y sette in heigh bounte
And so discrete ⁊and faire of eloquence
So benyngne ⁊and digne of reuerence
And koude so the peples herte embrace
That iche her loueth that loketh on her face
ᵃ Naught only of Saluces in the town
Publisshed was the beaute of hire name
But eke bysyde in many a regioun
Yf oon seide wele a nother seide the same
So spradde of hire bounte the fame
That men ⁊and women as wele yonge as olde
Goon to Saluce vpon hire to byholde
ᵃ Thus Walter lowely : nay but really
Weddid with fortunat honeste
In goddis pees lyueth full esely
At hoom ⁊andoutward grace ynow hadde hee
And for he saugh that vndir lowe degree
Was ofte vertue hidde. the peple hym helde
A prudent man ⁊ that is seyn full selde
ᵃ Nat oonly this Grisildis thurgh hire witte
Kowthe all the feet of wifly humblenesse
But eke whan that the cas required itte
The cōmmune ꝓprofite couthe she redresse
Ther nas discorde rancour ne heuynesse
In alle the lande that she ne couthe apese
And wisely bryng hem alle in reste ⁊and ese
ᵃ Though that hire housbond absent were a noon
Of gentell men or other of hire cuntre
Were wrooth she wolde bryng hem a toon
So wise ⁊and ripe wordes hadde shee
And Iugementz of so greet equite
That she from heuen sent was as men wende
Peple to saue / ⁊and eủery wrong tamende
ᵃ Nat longe tyme aftir that . this Grisilde
Was weddid she a doughter hath y bore
Al had hire leuer haue born a knaue childe
Glad was the Markys and the folke therfore
For though a maide com all byfore
She may vnto a knaue childe atteyne
By liklihede sith she is not bareyne
Explicit Secunda ꝑpars . Incipit tercia pars
Ther felle as it befallith tymes mo
Whan that this childe had sowked but a throwe
This Markis in his herte longeth so
To tempte his wife her sadnes for to knowe
That he ne myght out of his herte throwe
This merueillous desire his wife tassay
Nedeles god woot. he thought her for taffray
ᵃ He had assaied hire ynow byfore
And fond hire eủer good what nedith itt
Hire for to tempte ⁊and alway more ⁊and more
Though som men preise it for a subtil witt
But as for me I seye that I uele it sitt
To Assaille a wif whan it is no nede
And putten hire in anguysshe ⁊and in drede
ᵃ For whiche this Markis wrought in þˢthis manere
He come allone a nyght ther as she lay
With sterne face ⁊and with trouble chere
And saide thus Grisilde qdquod he that day
That I yow took out of youre poore array
And put yow in estaat of heigh noblesse
Ye haue nat that forgeten as I gesse
ᵃ I sey Grisilde this p̉resent dignite
In whiche that I haue put yow as I trowe
Maketh yow nat foryetfull for to be
That I yow took in pore estat ful lowe
For any wele ye mote youre seluen knowe
Take hede of eủery word / that I yow seye
Ther is no wight that hureth it . but we tweye
ᵃ Ye woot youre selfe wele / how that ye come here
In to this hous it is not longe a goo
And though to me that ye be leef ⁊and dere
Vnto my gentils. ye ben no thyng soo
They seyn to hem it is greet shame ⁊and woo
For to be subgit ⁊and to ben in seruage
To the that born art of smalle village
ᵃ And namely sith thy doughter was ybore
These wordes han they spoken douteles
But I desire as I haue don byfore
But lyue my life in rest ⁊and pees
. I may not in this cas be recheles
. I moot doon with thy doughter for the beste
Nat as I wolde but as my peple leste
ᵃ And yet god woot this is full looth to me
But natheles wᵗwith oute youre wityng
I wole not don but this wele I qdquod he
That ye to me assente as in this thyng
Shewe now youre pacience in youre wirkyng
That ye me hight ⁊and swore in youre village
That day that maked was oure mariage
ᵃ Whan she had herd all this she she nought ameued
Neither in word. or chere. or contenaunce
For as it semed she was nat agreued
She seide lorde all lith in youre plesaunce
Mi childe and I with hertely obeissaunce
Ben youres alle. ⁊and ye mowe saue or spille
Youre owne thyng. wirketh aftir youre wille
ᵃ Ther may no thyng . god so my soule saue
Liken to yow that may displese me
Ne I ne desire no thyng for to haue
Ne drede for to lese saue oonly the . // vlye
This wille is in myn hert ⁊and ay shall be
No lengthe of . tyme or deeth may this deface
Ne chaunge my cherecorage to other place
ᵃ Glad was this Markis of here answeryng
But yet he feyned as he were nat so
Al dreri was his chere and his lokyng
Whānn that he sholde oute of the chambre go
Sone aftir this a forlong wey or two
He pryuely hath tolde al his entent
Vn to a man. ⁊and to his wife hym sent
ᵃ A maner sergeaunt. was this pryue man
The whiche that feithfull ofte. founden hadde
In thynges grete ⁊and eke suche folkes wele kan
Doon execucouıı̄un on thynges badde
The lorde knewe wele that he hym loued ⁊and dradde
And whan this sergeaunt wist this lordis wille
In to the chambre he stalked hym full stille
ᵃ Madame he seide ye mote foryeue it me
Though I do thyng to whiche I am constreyned
Ye ben so wys that full wele knowe ye
That lordes hestes mow nat ben yfeyned
They mow wele ben y wailed or compleyned
But men mote nede vnto her luste obeye
And so wole I ther is nomore to seye
ᵃ This child I am cōmmaunded for to take
And spak nomore but out the child he hente
Dispetously ⁊and gan a chere make
As thow he wolde han slayn it. ere he went
Grysildes mote all soffre ⁊and consente
And as lambe she sittith meke ⁊and stille
And leet this cruel sergeaunt don his wille
ᵃ Suspecious was the diffame of this man
Suspecte his face suspecte his word also
Suspecte the tyme in whiche he this bygan
Allas hir doughter that she loued so
She wende he wolde han slawen it right tho
But natheles she neither weep̄e ne siked
Cōnformyng hire to that the Markis liked
ᵃ But at the laste speken she began
And mekely she to the sergeaunt preide
So as he was a worthy gentil man
That she most kisse her childe . er that it deide
And in her barme this litel child she leyde
With full sadde face ⁊and bygan the child to blysse
And lulled it ⁊and after gan it kysse
ᵃ And thus she saide in hire benygne voys
Fare wele my childe I shall the neủer se
But sith I the haue marked with þᵉthe croys
Of thilke fader blissed mote he be
That for vs deyde vppon a croys of tre
Thy soule litel child I hym bytake
For this nyght shalt thow dye for my sake
ᵃ I trowe that to a norse in this cas
Yt had ben harde. this reuthe for to se
Wele myght a Moder than cried allas
But natheles. so sad stedefast was she
That she endured all adủersite
And to the sergeaunt mekely she saide
Haue here agayn youre yonge litel maide
ᵃ Gooth now qdquod she ⁊and do my lordes heeste
But o thyng wole I pᵃray yow of youre grace
That but my lord forbade yow at þᵉthe leste
Burieth this litel body on som place
That beestes ne no briddes hit to rase
But he no word wil to the pᵘurpos seye
But took the child ⁊and went on his weye
ᵃ This sergeaunt coom vnto his lord agayn
And of Grisildes wordes ⁊and hire chere
He tolde hym in shortpoint for poynt in short ⁊and playn
And hym p̉resenteth wᵗwith his doughter dere
Somwhat this lorde hath routhe in this manere
But natheles his pᵘurpos helde he stille
As lordes doon whan they wolle han her wille
ᵃ And bade this sergeaunt that he pryuelye
Sholde this childe softe wynde ⁊and wrappe
With alle circūmstaunces tendrelye
And carie it in a cofre or in a lappe
But vppon peyne his heed for to swappe
That no man sholde knowe of this entent
Ne whens he come. ne whether that he went
ᵃ But at Boloigne he to his suster dere
That thilke tyme of Pauyk was countesse
He sholde it take ⁊and shewe hire this matere
Bisikyng hire to doon hire bysynesse
This childe to fostre in all gentillesse
And whoos child that it was he bade hire hide
From eủery wight. for ought that may bytyde
ᵃ The sergeaunt goth ⁊and hath fulfild thys thyng
But to thys Markys now retourne we
For now gooth he fulfast ymagenyng
If by his wifes chere. he myght se
Or be hire word aꝑperceyue that she
Were chaunged / but he couthe her neủer fynde
But eủer in oon y lyke sad and kynde
ᵃ As glad as humble as besy in seruyse
And eke in loue as she was wont to be
Was she to hym in eủery man̉er wise
Ne of hir doughter nought a word spake she
Non accident for non adủersite
Was sayn in hire. ne neủer hire doughter name
Ne nempned she in ernest ne in game
Explicit tercia pars . Incipit quarta pars
.In this estate there passed ben foure yere
Er she with child was but as god wolde
A knaue childe she bare by this walter
Full gracious ⁊and faire for to byholde
And whan that folke it to his fader tolde
Nat oonly he but all his cuntre mery
Was for this childe ⁊and god they thanke ⁊and hery
ᵃ Whan it was twoo yere olde ⁊and fro the breste
Deꝑparted of his Novice on a day
Thys Markis caught yet a nother lest
To tempte his wyfe. yet ofter if he may
O nedeles was she tempted in assay
But wedded men ne knowen no mesure
Whan that thay fynde a pacient creature
ᵃ Wyfe qdquod this Markis ye han herde or thys
Mi peple sikly berth oure mariage
And namely sith my sone born is
Now is it worse. than eủer in alle oure age
The murmᵘur sleth myn hert ⁊and my corage
For to myn eris cometh the soulevois so smerte
That it wel nyegh. destroied hath myn herte
ᵃ Now sey they thus whan walter is a gon
Than shal the blood of Ianicle succede
And ben oure lord for other haue we noon
Suche wordes seith my peple oute of drede
Wele ought I of suche murmᵘur taken hede
For certeynly I drede suche sentence
Though they nought pleyn speke in myn audience
ᵃ I wolde lyue in pees. yf that I myght
Wherfore I am disposed yef that I may outrely
As I his suster serued be nyght
Ryght so thynke I to serue hym pryuely
This warne I yow that ye nat sodeynly
Oute of youre selfe for no woo shold outraye
Both pacient ⁊and ther of I yow pᵃraye
ᵃ I haue qdquod she seide thus ⁊and eủer shall
I wol no thyng ne nyl no thyng certeyn
But as yow lyst nought greuyth me at al
Though that myn doughter ⁊and my sone be sleyn
At youre cōmmaundement this is to seyn
I haue noght had no part of children tweyne
But first siknesse and aftir woo ⁊and peyne
ᵃ Ye ben oure lorde. doth with youre owne thyng
Ryght as yow lyst. axeth no reed at me
For as I lefte at home all my clothyng
When I first come to yow right so qdquod she
Lefte I my wille ⁊and all my liberte
And took youre clothyng wherfore I yow preye
Doth youre plesaunce I wil youre luste obeye
ᵃ And certes if I had prescience
Youre wille to knowe or ye youre lust me tolde
I wolde it doon with outen necligence
But now I woot youre luste ⁊and what ye wolde
All youre plesaunce. ferme ⁊and stable I holde
For wist I that myn deth wold don yow ese
Right gladly wold I dien yow to plese
ᵃ Deth may noght make no cōmparisoıı̄un
Vn to youre loue ⁊and whan this Markis say
The constaunce of his wife he caste a doıı̄un
His eyen two / and wondreth that she may
In pacience suffre all this array
And forth he goth with drery cuntenaunce
But to his herte it was full grete plesaunce
ᵃ This vggely sergeaunt in the same wise
That he hir doughter caughte right so he
Or worse if men kan worse deuyse
Hath hent here sone. that ful was of beaute
And eủer in oon so pacient was she
That she no chere made of heuynesse
But kyste hire sone. and aftir gan it blesse
ᵃ Saue this she praide hym. that if he myght
Hire litle sone. he wolde in erthe graue
His tendre lymes delicat to sight
Fro foweles ⁊andfro bestes it to saue
But she non answere of hym myght haue
He wente his wey. as hym no thyng ne rought
But to Boloigne he tendrely it brought
ᵃ This Markis wondrith eủer lenger the more
Vpon hire pacience ⁊and if that he
Ne hadde sothly knowen. therfore
That ꝑperfitly here children loued she
He wolde haue wende that of som subtilite
And of malice. or for cruel corage
That she had suffred this wᵗwith sad visage
ᵃ But wele he knewe that next hym selfe certayn
She loued hire children best in eủery wyse
But now of wommen wolde I axen fayn
Yf these assaies myght nat suffise
What couthe a sturdy housbond more dyuyse
To proue hire wifhod and hire stedfastnesse
And he contynuyng eủer in sturdynesse
ᵃ But ther ben folke of suche condicoıı̄un
That when they haue a certeyn pᵘurpos take
They kan not stynte. of hire entencioıı̄un
But right as they were bounden to that stake
They will noght of that first pᵘurpos slake
Right so this Markys fulliche hath pᵘurposed
To tempte his wife as he was first disposed
ᵃ He waiteth if be worde or contenaunce
That she to hym / was chaunged of corage
But neủere kouthe he fynde variaunce
She was ay on in hert ⁊and in visage
And ay the ferther that she was in age
The more trewe. if that it were possible
She was to hym in loue. ⁊and more penyble
ᵃ For whiche it semed thus. that of hem two
Ther nas but o wille. for as walter leste
The same luste was hire plesaunce also
And god be thanked alle fille for the beste
She shewed wele. for no. worldly vnreste

l.hi: A wife as of hire selfe no thynge ne sholde
Wille (in effecte) but as hire housbond wolde

div.l: ᵃ The sklaunder of walter. ofte ⁊and wide spradde
That of cruel herte. he wickedly
For he a pore woman wedded hadde
Hath morthered both his children pⁱriuely
Whiche murmᵘur was a mong hem comunly
No wondre is for to the peples ere
There cam no worde. but that they mordred were
ᵃ For whiche . where as this peple there byfore
Had loued hym wele . the sklaunder of his diffame
Made hem . that thay hym hated therfore /
To ben a murdrer . is an hatefulle name
But natheles for ernest ne for game
He of his cruel pᵘurpos nolde not stynte
To tempte his wyf . was sette alel // his entent
ᵃ Whan that this doughter xij . yere was of age
He to the court of Rome in subtil wise
Enformed of his wille sent his message
Cōmmaundyng hem suche bulles to deuyse
As to his cruelle pᵘurpos may suffice
How that the pope (as for his peples reste)
Bade hym to wede a nother if hym leste
ᵃ I sey he bad . they sholde counterfete
The popes bulles makyng mencioıı̄un
That he hath leue his first wife to lete
As by the popes dispensacoıı̄un
To stynte rancour ⁊and dissencoıı̄un
Bitwix his peple ⁊and hym thus seyde the bulle
The whiche they han publisshed at the fulle
ᵃ The rude peple as it no wonder is
Wenden fulle wele that it had ben right soo
But whan these tydynges cam to Grisildis
I deme that hire hert was full woo
But she ylyke sad for eủer mo
Disposed was this humble creature
Thadủresite of fortune. al tendure
ᵃ Abydyng eủere his lust and his plesaunce
To whom that she was yeuen hert ⁊and al
As to hire verrey worldly suffisaunce
But shortly if this storie I tellen shal
This Markis wretyn hath in special
A lettre in whiche he sheweth his entente
And secrely . he to Boloigne it sente
ᵃ To the Erle of Pauyk whiche that hadde tho
Wedded his suster . praide he specially
To bryngen hoom a gayn his children two
In honurable estate alle openly
But o thyng he hym praide outrely
That he to no wight. though men wolde enquere
Sholde nat telle . whoos children that they were
ᵃ But sey the maide shulde I wedded be
Vn to the Markis of Saluce a noon
And as this Erle was praide so did he
For at day y set he on his wey is goon
Toward Saluce ⁊and lordes many / on
In riche array this maiden for to gide
Hire yonge brother rydyng by hir side
ᵃ Arraied was toward hir mariage
This freisshe maide fulle of gēmmes clere
Hire brother whiche that seuen yere was of age
Arraied eke ful freisshe in his manere
And thus in grete noblesse. ⁊and with glad chere
Toward Saluce shapyng hir iourney
Fro day to day . they riden in her wey
Explicit quarta pars / . Incipit prima pars quinta
Among alle this aftir his wikke vsage
This Markis yet his wife to tempte more
To the outerest pref . of hire corage
Fully to han exꝑperience ⁊and lore
Yf that she were as stedefast as bifore
He on a day in open audience
Fulle boistously hath seide hire this sentence
ᵃ Certes Grisilde . I had I nogh plesaunce
To han yow to my wife for youre goodnesse
As for youre trouth . ⁊and for youre obeissaunce
Nought for youre lynage . ne for youre richesse
But nowe knowe I in verray sothfastnesse
That in grete lordshep̄e . if I wele auyse
Ther is grete seruytute in sundry wyse
ᵃ I may noght doo as eủery plowman may
My peple me constreyneth for to take
A nother wife ⁊and crien day be day
And eke the pope . rancour for to slake
Consenteth it that dar I vndirtake
And trewely thus moche I wole yow seye
My newe wyfe is comyng by the weye
ᵃ Be stronge of herte ⁊and voide a non hir place
And thilke dower that ye broghten me
Take it a gayn I graunte it of my grace
Retourneth to youre fadres hous qdquod he
Nou man may alway hane prosꝑperite
With euene herte I rede yow to endure
The strook of fortune or of aventure
ᵃ And she a gayn answerde in pacience
My lorde qdquod she I wote ⁊and wiste alway
How that bitwixe youre magnificence
And my poủerte no wight kan ne may
Maken comparysoıı̄un it is no nay
I ne helde me neủer digne in no manere
To be youre wife . no . ne youre chambrere
ᵃ And in this hous there ye me lady made
The high god take I for my witnesse
And also wisly he my soule glade
I neủer helde me lady . ne maistresse
But humble seruant to youre worthynesse
And eủer shalle while that my lyfe may endure
A bouen eủery wordly creature
ᵃ That ye so longe of youre benygnyte
Han holden me in honoᵘur and nobleye
Where as I was noght worthy for to be
That thonke I god ⁊and yow to whom I preye
Foryeld it yow ther is nomore to seye
Vnto my fader gladly wol I wende
And with hym dwelle vn to my lyfes ende
ᵃ Ther I was fostred of a child fulle smal
Til I be deed my lyfe there wole I lede
A widewe clene in body herte ⁊and al
For sith I yaf to yow myn maydenhede
And am youre trewe wyfe it is no drede
God childe suche a lordes wife to take
A nother man to housbond or to make
ᵃ And of youre newe wyfe . god of his grace
So graunt yow wele ⁊andꝓprosꝑperite
For I wol gladly yelden hire my place
In whiche that I was blysfulle forwont to be
For sith it lyketh yow my lord qdquod she
That whilom were alle myn hertys reste
That I shalle goon . I wole whan yow leste
ᵃ But there as ye me ꝓprofre suche dowaire
As I first brought . it is wele in my mynde
Yt were my wrecched clothes . no thyng faire
The whiche to me . were hard now for to fynde
O good god how gentil ⁊and how kynde
Ye semed by youre speche . and youre visage
The day that maked was oure mariage
ᵃ But sooth is seide algate I fynde it trewe
For in effecte it proued is on me

l.hi: Loue is noght olde as whan that it is newe

div.l: But certes lord for noon adủersite
To deyen in the cas . it shal noght be
That eủer in word or werke I shalle repente
That I yow yaf myn herte in hole entente
ᵃ My lorde ye woot that in my fadres place
Ye dide me stripe . oute of my pore weede
And richely me cladden of youre grace
To yow broght I noght elles oute of drede
But feith ⁊and nakednesse ⁊and maydenhede
And here a gayn my clothyng I restore
And eke my weddyng ryng . for eủermore
ᵃ The remenaıı̄unt of youre Iewels redy be
With Inne youre chambre . dar I safly sayn
Naked oute of my fadres hous qdquod she
I cam / and naked I turne agayn
Al youre plesaunce wole I folwen fayn
But yet I hope it be not youre entent
That I smokles theout of youre paleys went
ᵃ Ye kowde nat don . so dishonest a thyng
That thilke wombe . in whiche youre children leye
Shold byforn the peple . in my walkyng
Be seyn albare . wherfore I yow preye
Lat noght me like a worme go by the weye
Remembre yow . myn owne lorde so dere
I was youre wife though I vnworthy were
ᵃ Wherfore in gerdon of my maydenhede
Whiche that I broght . ⁊and noght agayn I bere
As voucheth safe to yeue me to my mede
But suche a smokke as I was wont to were
That I there with may wrie the wombe of here
That was youre wyfe . ⁊ here take I my leue
Of yow myn owen lord lest I yow greue
ᵃ The smokke qdquod he that thow hast on thy bakke
Late it be stille . and bere it forth with the
But wele vnethes . thilke worde he spakke
But wente his way for routhe ⁊andfor pite
Byforn the folke hir seluen stripeth she
And in hire smokke with heued ⁊and feet albare
Towarde hire . fader hous . forth is she fare
ᵃ The folke hire folwen wepyng in hire weye
And fortune ay thay cursen . as they goon
But shee fre wepyng kept hire eyen dreye
Ne in this tyme word ne spake she noon
Hire fader that this tydynge herde a non
Curseth the day ⁊and tyme . that nature
Shoop hym to ben a lyues creature
ᵃ For oute of doute . this olde pore man
Was eủer in suspecte of hire mariage
For eủer he demed sith that it bygan
That whan the lord fulfillid had his corage
Hym wolde thynke it were a disꝑparage
To his estate so lowe talyght
And voiden hire as sone as eủer he myght
ᵃ A gayns his doughter hastely goth he
For he by noyse of folke knewe her comyng
And with hire olde cote . as it myght be
He coủered hire ful sorowefully wepyng
But on hire body myght he it not bryng
For rude was the cloth ⁊and more of age
By daies fele than was hire mariage
ᵃ Thus with hire fader for a certeyn space
Dwellith this floure of wifly pacience
That neither by hire wordes ne hir face
Be forn the folke ne eke in hire absence
Ne shewed she that hire was doon offence
Ne of hire high estate . no remembraunce
Ne had she as by hire contenaunce
ᵃ No wondir is for in hire gret estate
Hire goost was eủer in pleyn humilite
No tendre mouth . non hert dilicat
No pompe no semblaunt of realte
But ful of pacient benygnyte
Discreet ⁊and prideles . ay honurable
And to hire housbond eủer meke ⁊and stable
ᵃ Men speke of Iob . ⁊and most for his humblesse
As clerkys . whan hem lyst . kan wele endite
Namely of men but as in sothfastnesse
Though clerkes preyse . wōmmen but a lite
Ther kan no man in humblesse hym acquite
As wōmmen kan . ne kan be halfe so trewe
As wōmmen ben . but it be falle of newe
ᵃ Fro Boloigne is this Erle of Pauyk come
Of whiche the fame vp sprang . to moore ⁊and lesse
And to the peples eres alle ⁊and some
Was couthe eke . that a newe Markisesse
He with hym brought in suche pompe ⁊and richesse
That neủer was there seyn with mānnes eye
So noble array in al west lombardeye
ᵃ The Markis whiche that shoop ⁊and knewe all this
Er that this Erle was come sent his message
For thilke syly pore Grysildis
And she with humble herte ⁊and glad visage
Nat with no swollen thought in hire corage
Cam at his heest . and on her knees hir sette
And reủerently and wisely she hym grette
ᵃ Grysilde qdquod he my wille is outrely
This maiden that shal wedded ben to me
Reseyued ben to morwe as really
As it possible is . in myn hous to be
And eke that eủery wight in his degre
Haue his estate in sittyng and seruyse
And high plesaunce as I kan best deuyse
ᵃ I haue no wommen suffisaunt certayn
The chambres for tarray in ordynaunce
Aftir my luste ⁊and therfore wolde I fayn
That thyn were alle suche man̉er goủernaunce
Thow knowest eke of olde all my plesaunce
Though thyn array be badde . ⁊and yuel byseye
Do thow thy deuoir . at the leste weye
ᵃ Nat oonly lord that I am glad qdquod she
To doon yow luste but I desire also
Yow for to serue ⁊and plese in my degre
With outen feyntyng . ⁊and shal eủer mo
Ne neủer for no wele ne for no wo
Ne shall the goste with Inne myn herte styente
To loue yow best with all my trewe entent
ᵃ And with that word she gan the hous to dight
And tables for to sette . ⁊and beddes make
And payned hire . to don all that she myght
And pᵃrayēmdg the chambreres for goddis sake
To hasten hem ⁊and faste swepe ⁊and shake
And she the moste seruysable of alle
Hath eủery chambir arraied ⁊and his halle
ᵃ A Bouten vndron gan this Erle a light
That with hym broughten his noble children twey
For whiche the peple ranne to see the sight
Of hire array so richely bysey
And than at erst a monges hem they sey
That walter was no fole though that hym leste
To chaunge his wife for it was for his beste
ᵃ For she is fairer . as they demen alle
Than is Grisilde ⁊and more tendre of age
And fairer fruyt bitwene hem sholde falle
And more plesaunt for hire highe lynage
Hire brother eke so faire was of visage
That hem to sen the peple hath caught plesaunce
Cōmmendyng now the Markys goủernaunce

l.hi: O stormy peple . vnsad ⁊and eủer vntrewe
Ay vndiscreet and chaungyng as a vane
Delytyng eủer in rumbil that is newe
For like the mone . ay waxe ye ⁊and wane
Ay fusl of clappyng . dere ynogh a Iane
Youre doom is fals . youre constaunce yuel preueth
A full greet fole is he . that on yow leueth

div.l: ᵃ Thus seyden allsad folke in that Cite
Whan that the peple . gazed vp ⁊and doun
For they were glad right for the nouelte
To haue a newe lady of hire toun
Namore of this now make I mencioun
But to Grisilde agayn wole I me dresse
And telle hire constaunce . ⁊and hire bysynesse
ᵃ Ful bysy was Grisilde in eủery thyng
That to the feste was aꝑpertynent
Right noght was she a basshed of hire clothyng
Though it were rude ⁊and eke somdele to rent
But with glad chere to the yate is went
With other folke to grete the Markisesse
And aftir that . doth forth hire bysynesse
ᵃ With so glad chere . hise gestes she resseyueth
And so konnyngly eủeryche in his degre
That no defaute noman aꝑperceyueth
But ay thay wondren what she myght be
That in so pore array was for to se
And koude suche honour ⁊and reủer>ence
And worthily they preysen here prudence
ᵃ In alle this meene while she ne stente
This maide ⁊and eke hire brother to cōmmende
With alle here herte . in full benygne entente
So wele that noman couthe hir prys amende
But at the laste whan that these lordes wende
To sitten doun to mete he gan to calle
Grisilde as she was besy in halle
ᵃ Grisilde qdquod he as it were in his pley
How liketh the my wife . and hire beaute
Ryght wele qdquod she my lord for in good fey
A fairer saugh I neủer noon than she
I pray to god yeue yow ꝓprosꝑperite
And so hope I that he wole to yow sende
Plesaunce I nough vnto youre lyues ende
ᵃ O thynge byseke I yow ⁊and warne also
That ye ne prike with no turmentynge
This tendre maiden as ye han do mo
For she is fostred in hire norisshyng
More tendrely ⁊and to my supposyng
She couthe nat adủersite endure
As coude a pore fostred creature
ᵃ And whan this walter saugh hire pacience
Hire glad chere . ⁊and no malice at alle
And so ofte hadde doon to here offense
And she ay sadde . ⁊and constant as a walle
Contynuynge euere hire Innocence oủer alle
This sturdy Markys gan his herte dresse
To rewen vppon hire wifly stedfastnesse
ᵃ This is ynogh Grisilde myn quod he
Be now nomore agast . ne yuele apayed
I haue thy feith . and thy benygnyte
As wele as eủer woman was assaied
In greet estate ⁊and poreliche arraied
Now know I dere wyfe thy stedfastnesse
And hire in armes took . and gan hire kesse
ᵃ And she for wonder took of it no keep̄e
She herde nat what thyng he to hire seide
She ferde as she hadde stirt oute of hire sleep̄e
Til she oute of hire mazednesse abreide
Grysylde qdquod he . by god that for vs deide
Thow art my wyfe . ne noon other I haue
Ne neủer hadde as god my soule saue
ᵃ This is thi doughter whiche thow haste supposed /
To be my wyfe . that other feithfully
Shal be myn eyre . as I haue ay pᵘurposed
Thow bare hym in thy body trewely
At Boloigne haue I kepte hym pryuely
Take hem agayn for now maistow not seye
That thow hast lorn noon of thi children tweye
ᵃ And folke that other weys han seide of me
I warne hem wele that I haue don this dede
For no malice ne for no cruelte
But for tassaie in the thy womanhede
And not to slen my children . god forbede
But for to kepen hem pryuely ⁊and stille
Til I thy pᵘurpos knewe . and alle thi wille
ᵃ Whan she this herde . a swowne doun she falleth
For pitous Ioye ⁊and aftir hir swownyng
She bothe hire yonge children into hire callith
And in hire armes . pitously wepyng
Embraseth hem . ⁊and tendrely kyssyng
Full like a moder . with hire salte teres
She batheth . both hire visage ⁊and here heres
ᵃ O. swiche a pitous thynge it was to se
Hire swownyng . ⁊and hire humble voys to here
Graunt mercy lorde . god thonke it yow qdquod he
That ye han saued me my children dere
Now rekke I neủer to ben deed right here
Sith I stonde in youre loue ⁊and in youre grace
No force of deth ne whan my spirit pace
ᵃ O tendre .o. dere .o. yonge children myne
Youre woofull moder . wende stedfastly
That cruel houndes or som foule vermyne
Hadde eten yow but god of his hie m̉ercy
And youre benyngne fader tendrely
Hath don yow kepte . ⁊and in that same stounde
Al sodenly she swapte a doun to grounde
ᵃ And in hire swow so sadly holdeth she
Hire children two . whan she gan hem tenbrace
That with grete sleight ⁊and grete difficulte
The children from hire arme they gonne arace
O many a tere o many a pitous face
Doun ranne of hem that stoden hire biside
Vnnethe abouten hire myght they abide
ᵃ Walter hire gladeth ⁊and hire sorwe slaketh
She riseth vp abaysed from hire traunce
And eủery wight hire Ioyse ⁊and feste maketh
Til she hath caught agayn hire cuntenaunce
Walter hire doth so feithfully plesaunce
That it was deynte for to sen the chere
Bitwix hem two now they ben mette in fere
ᵃ Thise ladies whan that they hire tyme say
Han taken hire . ⁊and in to chambre goon
And stripen hire oute of hire rude array
And in a cloth of golde that bright shon
With a crowne of many a riche ston
Vpon hire heed they in to halle hir broughte
And there she was honoᵘured . as hire oughte
ᵃ Thus hath this petous day a blisful ende
For eủery man ⁊and wōmman doth his myght
This day in murthe and reuel to dispende
Til on the welkne . shoon the sterris light
For more solempne in eủery mannys sight
This feste was ⁊and gretter of costage
Than was the reuel of hir mariage
ᵃ Full many a yere in heigh ꝓprosꝑperite
Lyuen these two in concord ⁊and in reste
And richely his doughter maried he
Vnto a lorde oon of the worthiest
Of alle Itaille . and thanne in pees ⁊and reste
His wyues fader in his court he kepeth
Til that the soule oute of his bodye crepeth
ᵃ His sone . succedith in his heritage
In reste and pees aftir his fadris day
And fortunat was eke in mariage
Al putte he nat his wife in gret assay
This world it is not so stronge it is no nay
As it hath ben in olde tymes yore
And herkeneth what this Auctoᵘur seith therfore
ᵃ This storie is seide nat for that wyues shulde
Folwen Grisilde as in humilitee
For it were importable . though they wolde
But for that eủery wight in his degree
Sholde be constant in adủersite
As was Grisild therfore Petrak writeth
This storie whiche he with hie stile enditeth
ᵃ For sith a woman was so pacient
Vnto a mortal man wele more vs oughte
Receyuen al in gree that god vs sent
For greet skile is . he proue that he wrought
But he ne tempteth noman that he bought
As seith seint Iame . if ye his pistel rede
He proueth folke alday . it is no drede
ᵃ And suffreth vs . as for oure excercise
With sharpe scourges of adủersite
Full ofte to be bete in sundry wise
Nought for to knowe oure wille for certes he
Er we were born . knewe al oure frelte
And for oure beste is al his goủernaunce
Lete vs thanne lyue in vertuous suffisaunce
ᵃ But o word lordynges herkeneth er I go
Þt were full harde to fynde now a dayes
In alle a toun Grisildis thre or two
For if that they were put . to swiche assaies
The gold of hem hath now so badde a layes
With bras that though the coyne be faire at Iye
Þtthat wolde rather breste a two . than plye
ᵃ For whiche here . for the wyues loue of Bathe
Whos lyfe ⁊and al hire secte . god mayntene
In heigh maistrie . ⁊and elles were it scathe
I wille wᵗwith lusty herte . fresshe ⁊and grene
Sey yow a songe . to glade yow I wene
And lete vs stynte of ernestfull matere
Herkeneth my songe that seith in this manere
Lenuoy de Chaucer . ~
GRisilde is ded . ⁊and eke hire pacience
And bothe at onys buried in Itaile
For whiche I crie in open audience
No wedded man so hardy be tassaile
His wyues pacience in trust to fynde
Grisildis , for in certeyn he shal faile /
ᵃ O noble wyues full of heigh prudence
Late noon humylyte youre tonge vaille
Ne late no clerke . haue cause or diligence
To write of yow a storie of suche meruaile
As of Grisildis pacient ⁊and kynde
Lest Chichiuache yowe swolwe . in hire entraille
ᵃ Folwith Eccko that holdith no silence
But eủer answereth . at the countretaille
Beth nat bydaffed for youre Innocence
But sharply take on yow the goủernaille
Empreenteth wele this lesson in youre mynde
For commune ꝓprofit / sith it may auaille /
ᵃ The Archywyues stondith at defense
ᵃ Syn ye be stronge . as is a grete camaille
Ne suffreth not that men do yow offense /
And sklendre wyues feble as in bataille
Beth egre as is a tigre yond in Inde
Ay clappeth as a Mylle / I yow counsaille /
ᵃ Ne dreed hem not . doth hem no reủerence
For though thyn housbond . armed be in maille
The arwes of thy crabbed eloquence
Shall ꝑperisshe his brest ⁊and eke his auentaille
In Ialowsy I rede eke thow hym bynde
And thow shalt make hym couche as doth a quaille
ᵃ If thow be faire there folke ben in p̉resence
Shewe thow thyn visage. ⁊andthyn apꝑperaile
Yf thow be foule be free of thy dispense
To gete the frendis ay do thy trauaile
Be ay of chere as light as leef on lynde
And late hym care ⁊and wepe . ⁊and wrynge ⁊and waile
This worthy clerke when ended was his tale
Oure oost seide . ⁊and swore by goddis bones
Me were leuer than a barel ale
My wyfe at hom at herde this legend ones
This is a gentel tale for the nones
As to my pᵘurpos . wiste ye my wille
But thyng that wol nat be . lat it be stille
Here endith the tale of the Clerke of Oxenford
Here bigynneth the Phisiciens tale
Ther was as telleth Titus liuius
A knyght that called was Virginius
Fulfild of honour . ⁊and of worthynesse
And strong of frendes . ⁊and of grete richesse
This knyght a doughter hadde by his wyfe
No children hadde mo in all his lyfe

div.l: Faire was this maide in excellent beaute
A bouen eủery wight that men may se
For nature hath with soủereigne diligence
Y formed hire in so grete excellence
As thow she wolde seyn lo I nature
Thus kan I forme . ⁊and peynte a creature
Whan that me lyst . who kan me countrefete
Pigmalion nought . though he ay . forge ⁊and bete
Or graue or poynt . for I dare wele seyn
Apelles zanzis . sholde werke in veyn
Other to graue or peynt or forge / or bete
Yf they p̉resumeden me to countrefete
For he that is the former pirincipal
Hath maked me his vicarie gen̉eral
To foorme ⁊and peynten erthely creatureys
Right as me lyst ⁊and iche thyng . in my cure is
Vnder the moone that may wane ⁊and waxe
And for my werke right noght wole I axe
My lord ⁊and I ben full of oon accorde
I made hire to the worsship of my lorde
So do I all myn other creatures
What colour that thay han . or what figures
Thus semeth me that nature wolde seye /
This maide of age xij yere was and tweye
In whiche that nature . had suche delit
For right as she kan peynte a lilie whit
And reed as roos / right with suche peynture
She peynted hath . this noble creature
Er she were borne vpon hire lymes fre
Wher as by right suche colours sholden be
And Phebz died hath . hire tresses grete
Like to the stremes . of his burned hete
And if that excellent . was hire beaute
A thousand fold more vertuous was she
In hire ne lakked no condicoıı̄un
That is to preise as be discrecoıı̄un
As wele in goost as body . chast was she
For whiche she floured in virginite
With all humilite and abstinence
With all attemꝑperaunce ⁊and pacience
Wtith Mesure eke . of beryng ⁊and array
Discreet she was . in answeryng alway
Thow she were wise Pallas dar I seyn
Hir facounde eke full womanly ⁊and pleyn

div.l: No countrefeted t̉ermes had she
To seme wise but aftir hire degre
She spak ⁊and alle hire wordis both more ⁊and lesse
Sownyng in vertue ⁊and in gentilesse
Shamefast she was . in maydens shamefastnesse
Constant in herte ⁊and eủer in besynesse
To dryve hire oute of slogardrie
Baccus had of hire mouth right no maistrie
For wyn ⁊and youthe . doth venus encresse

l.hi: As men in fir wol casten oile or gresse

div.l: And of hire owne vertue vnconstreyned
She hath full ofte tyme . sik hire feyned
For that she wolde fleen the companye
Where lykly was to treten of folye
As is at festes . reuels ⁊and at daunces
That ben occasions of daliaunces
Whiche thyng make children for to be
To soone ripe ⁊and boold as men may se
Whiche is full ꝑperilous . ⁊and hath ben yore
For alle to sone may thay lerne lore

l.hi: Of boldnesse whan she waxen is a wife

div.l: ¶ And ye maistresses in youre olde lyfe
That lordes doughters han in goủernaunce
Ne takith of my wordes . no displesaunce
Thynke that ye be sette in goủernynges
Of lordes doughtres . oonly for two thynges
Other for ye han kept youre honeste
Or elles ye han falle in frelete
And knowen wele I now the olde daunce
And han forsaken fully swiche myschaunce
For eủer mo . therfore for cristes sake
To teche hem vertue loke that ye nat slake /
A theef of venysoıı̄un that hat hath for lafte
His likerousnesse ⁊and all his olde crafte
Kan kepe a forest best of any man̄ /
Now kepeth wele for if ye wole ye can /
Loke wele that ye vnto no vices assente
Lest ye be dampned / for youre wikke entente
For who so doth a traitour is certeyn̄ /
And taketh kepe of that that I shall seyn̄ /

l.hi: Of alle tresoıı̄un soủereyn pestilence
Is whan a wight bitraiseth Innocence

div.l: ye fadres ⁊ ye modres eke also
Thow ye han̄ children be it oon̄ or mo
Youre is the charge of alle hire surueyaunce
Whil that they ben̄ vndir youre goủernaunce
Beth ware that by ensample of youre lyuynge
Or by youre negligence in chastysynge
That they perisshe for I dare wele seye
Yf that they doon ye shall ful dere abeye

l.hi: Vnder a shephurd . softe ⁊ necligent
The wolfe hath many a sheep ⁊ loomb to rent

div.l: Suffiseth now oon ensample as here
For I mote turne a yeyn to my matere
This maide of whiche I wol my tale expresse
So kept hire selfe hir nedid no maistresse
For in here lyuyng maidens myghten rede
As in a book . eủery good word ⁊and dede
That longeth to a maidēn vertuous
She was so prudent ⁊and so bounteuous
For whiche the fame oute spronge on eủery side
Bothe of hire beaute ⁊and hire bounte wyde
That thurgh that land they preysed hire echone
That loued vertue / saue enuye alone
AugustꝰusThat sory is of other mennes wele
And glad is of hys sorwe ⁊and his vnhele /
The doctour maketh this discripcoun /
This maide vpon a day wente in to þe toun
Toward a temple wtith hire moder dere
As is aof yonge maidens the manere /
Now was . there than a Iustice in that toun
That goủernour was of that regioun
And so bifel this Iuge his eyen caste
Vpon this maide / auysyng hym full faste /
As she come forthby ther as this Iuge stode /
A noon his hert chaunged ⁊and his mode /
So was he caught with beaute of this maide /
And to hym selfe full pryuely he saide
This maide shall be myn for any man /
A noon the fende in to his herte ran
And taught hym sodenly that he be slight
The maiden to his p̉erpos wynne myght /
For certes be no force ne be no mede
Hym thought he was not able for to spede
For she was stronge of frendes . ⁊and eke she
Confermed was in soủereigne bounte
That wele he wiste he myght hire neủer wynne
As forto maken hire with his body to synne
For whiche by grete delibacoıı̄un
He sente aftir a cherle was in the toun
Whiche that he knewe for subtil ⁊and for bolde
This Iuge vnto this cherle his tale hath tolde
In secre wise ⁊and made hym to ensure
He shuld telle it to no creature
And if he dede he shold lese his heed
Whan that assented was . this cursed reed
Glad was this Iuge . ⁊and maked hym gret chere
And yaf hym yeftes p̉recious ⁊and dere
Whan shapen was all hire conspiracie
From poynt to poynt how that his lecherie
ꝐPerformed shuld ben . full subtilly
As ye shull here it aftir opynly
Hoom gooth the Cherle þtat hight Claudius
This fals Iuge that hight Apius
So was his name for this is []nono fable
But knowe for historial thyng notable
The sentence of it . soth is oute of doute
This fals Iuge goth now faste aboute
To hasten all[]all his delite . al that he may
(base) And so bifell sone after on a day
(base) This fals Iuge as telleth vs þe storie
(base) As he was wonte sate in his consistorie
(base) And yaf his dome vpon sondry cas
(base) This fals cherle cam forth a full grete pas
(base) And seide lorde if it be youre wille
(base) As doth me right vpon this pitous bille
(base) In whiche I pleyne vpon Virginius

(base) I wole it preue ⁊ fynde good witnesse
(base) That soth is that my bille wolle expresse
(base) The Iuge answerde of this in his absence
(base) I may not yeue diffinitif sentence
(base) Lat do hym calle ⁊ I wole gladly here
(base) Thow shalt haue alright ⁊ no wronge here

(base) To my lorde sir Apius so dere

(base) How that a knyght callid Virginius

(base) Holdeth expꝰersse agayn the wille of me

(base) Whiche fro myn hous . was stole vpon a nyght
(base) While that she was full yonge . this wole I preue
(base) By witnesse lorde . so that it nat yow greue
She nys his doughter nat what so he seye
Wherfore to yow my lorde the Iuge I preye
Yelde me my thral yf that it be youre wille
Lo this was al the sentence of his bille
Virginius gan vpon the thral byholde
But hastely er he his tale tolde
And wolde haue preued it as shold a knyght
And eke by witnessyng of many a wight
That all was fals that saide his adủersarie
This cursid Iuge wold no thynge tarie
Ne here a word more of Virginius
But yaf his Iugement ⁊and saide thus
I deme a non this cherle his ꝸseruant haue
Thow shalt no lenger in thyn hous hire saue
Go bryng hire forth . ⁊and put hire in oure warde
The cherle shall han his thral this I a warde
And whan this worthy knyght Virginius
Thorogh sentence of this Iustice Apius
Moste by force his doughter yeuen
Vnto the Iustice in lecherie to lyuen
He gooth hym hoom ⁊and sette hym in his halle
And lete anon his dere doughter calle
And with a face deed as Asshen colde
Vpon hire humble face he gan byholde
With fadres pitee stikyng thurgh his herte
Al wolde he . from his prerpos not conủerte
Doughter qdquod he Virginia by thy name
Ther ben twoo weyes eyther deth or shame
That thow most soffre allas that I was bore
For neủer thow deseruedist wherfore
To deyen with a swerd or with a knyf
O dere doughter ender of my lyf
Whiche I haue fostred vp with swiche plesaunce
That thow were neủer out of my remembraunce
O doughter whiche that art my last woo
And in my lyfe my last Ioye alsoo
O gemme of chastite . in pacience
Take thow thi deth for this is my sentence
For loue ⁊and nat for hate thow most be deed
My pitous hand mote smyten of thyn heed
Allas that eủer Apius the say
Thus hath he falsly iugged the to day
And tolde hire all the cas . as ye bifore
Han herd nat nedith it . to telle it more
O mercy dere Fader . qdquod this maide
And with that word she both hire armes laide
A boute his necke as she was wont to do
The teris borste oute of hire eyen two
And seide gode fader shall I dye 
Ys there no grace is there no remedye 
No certes dere doughter myn̄ qdquod he /
Than yef me leyser fader myn qdquod she
Mi deth for to compleyne a litel space
For parde Iepte yaf his doughter grace
For to compleyne er he hir slowe allas
And god it wote no thyng was hire trespas
But for she ranne hir fader first to see
To welcome hym with grete solempnyte
And with that word she fil a swowne anoon
And aftir whan hire swownyng is a goon
She riseth vp . ⁊and to hire fader saide
Blyssed be god that I shall dey a maide
Yef me my deth er that I haue a shame
Doth with youre child . youre wille a goddis name /
And with that worde she parayeth hym full ofte
That with his swerd he sholde smyte softe
And with that worde a swowne doun she fille
Hire fader with full sorowfull herte ⁊and wille
Hire heed of smote / and bi the top it hente
And to the Iuge he gan it to p̉resente
As he sat yet in doom in Consistorie /
And whan the Iuge it sawe as seith the storie
He badde to take hym . and an honge hym faste
But right a non a thowsand peple in thraste
To saue the knyght for routh ⁊and[]forfor pite /
For knowen was this fals iniquite /
The peple a noon had suspecte in this thyng
By man̉er of the cherlis chalēmsgyng
That it was bi thassent of Apius
They wisten wele that he was lecherous
For whiche vnto this Apius they gon
And caste hym in a prison right a non
(base) Where as he slough hym selfe ⁊ Claudius
That ꝸseruant was vnto this Apius
Was demed for to hange vpon a tre
But that Virginius of his pite
So preied for hym that he was exiled
And ellis certis had he ben bigiled
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: The remenaunt were an hanged both more ⁊and lesse
That were consentat of this cursednesse
Here men may sen . how synne hath his merite /
Beth ware / for noman woot . whom god wol smyte
In no degre / ne in whiche man̉er
The worme of conscience may agrise
Of wicked lyfe though it so pryue be
That noman woot ther of but god ⁊and he
For be he lewed man or ellis lered
He noot how sone he shal ben afered
Therfore I rede yow this counseille take

l.hi: Forsaketh synne or synne yow forsake

div.l: Here endith the Phisiciens tale
The ꝓprohemye of the pardoners tale
Oure oost gan to swere as he were wood
Harrow qdquod he by nailles ⁊and by blood /
This was a fals cherle . a fals Iustise
As shamefull deth as herte can dyuyse
Come to thise Iuges . and hire Aduocatz
Algate this sely maide is slayn allas
Allas to dere bought she beaute
Wherfore I say alday that men may se
That yeftes of fortune ⁊and of nature
Ben cause of deth to many a creature
Of bothe yeftes that I speke of now
Men han full ofte more for harm than for prow
But trewely myn owen maister dere
This is a pitous tale for to here
But natheles passe oủer is no fors
I paray to god so saue thi gentil cors
And eke thyn ?vrinals? . and Iurdones
Thyn Ipocras ⁊and eke thi Galiones
And eủery boiste full of thi letuarie
God blisse hem ⁊ oure lady seinte Marie
So mote I then thow art a ꝓpropre man̄
And like a p̉re late . by seint Ronyan̄
Seide I not wele I kan̄ nat speke in terme
But wele I woot thow doost ?myn? herte to erme
That I almoost haue caughte a Cardynacle
By corpus bones but if I haue triacle
Or ellys a draught of moiste ⁊and corny ale
div.note: Text on this page supplied initially from the base text. Delete this note when revised against the manuscript image.
div.l: Or but I here a noon a mery tale
Myn herte is loste for pite of this maide
Thow bele amy thow ꝑpardoner he saide
Telle vs som myrth or Iapes right anon̄
Yt shall by done qdquod he . by seint Ronyo?n?
But first qdquod he here at this ale stake
I wole bothe drynke ⁊and eten̄ of a Cake
But right ano?n? these gentils bygon to crye
Nay lat hym telle vs . of no ribaudie
Telle vs som moral thyng that we may lere
Som witte ⁊and than wolle we gladly
I graunte I wys qdquod he . but I mote thynke
Vpon som honest thyng while that I drynke
Radix omnium maloꝝrum est cupiditas
Here bygynneth the Pardoners tale
LOrdynges qdquod he in chirche whan I preche
I peyne me to haue an hauteyn̄ speche
And ryng oute . as round / as goth a belle
For I kan all by rote . that I telle
First I ꝓpronounce whens that I come
And thanne shewe I my bulles al ⁊and some
Oure lige lordes sele on my patent
Shewe first my body to warent
That no man̄ be so bolde ne preste ne clerke
Me to distorbe of cristis holy werke
And aftir that than telle I forth my tales
Bulles of popes ⁊and of Cardinales
Of Patriarkes ⁊and of bisshops I shewe
And in latyn̄ speke I wordes fewe
To sauffroıı̄un with my p̉erdicacoun
In eủery village ⁊ in eủery toun
This is my teme ⁊and shal ⁊and eủer was
Radix malorum est cupiditas
Than shewe I forth my longe crestal stones
I crāmmed full of cloutes ⁊and of bones
Relikes ben they as wenen they echon
Than haue I in a latoıı̄un a sholder bon
Whiche that was of an holy iewis sheepe
Good men I sey take of my wordes kepe
If that this bon be wasshe in any welle
If Cowe or calfe or Oxe swelle
That any worme hath ete or worme y stonge
Take water of that welle ⁊ wasshe his tonge
And it is hoole anon̄ ⁊and forther moore
Of pokkes ⁊and of scabbe . and eủery sore
Shall eủery sheep by hole / that of this welle
Drynketh a draught take kepe eke what I telle
Yf that the good man̄ / that the beestes owith
Wil eủery weke er that the cok hym crowith
Fastynge drynken of this welle a draughte
As thilke holy iewe oure eldres taught
His beestes ⁊and his stoor shall multiplie
And ꝸser?r? also it helith Ialousie
For though a man̄ be falle in Ielous rage
Late maken with this water his potage
And neủer shall he more his wife mystriste
Though he the sothe of hire defaute wiste
Alle hadde she taken prestes two or three
¶ Here is a meteyn eke that ye may se
He that his honde wolle putte in this myteyne
He shall haue multiplyeng of his greyne
Whan he hath sowen / be it whete or otes
So that he offre pens . or elles grotes
Gode men o thyng warne I yow
Yf any wight be in this chirche nowe
That hath doon synne horrible that he
Dar not for shame of it y shryuen be
Or ony woman̄ be she yonge or olde
That hath maked hire housbond kokewolde
Swiche folke haue non̄ power ne no grace
To offren to my relikes in this place
And who so fyndith hym oute of suche blame
They wole come ⁊and offre vp a goddis name
And I assoille hym by the Auctorite
Whiche that by bulle garaunted was to me
¶ By this gaude haue I wonne yere by yere
An hundred marke sith I was ꝑpardonere
I stonde like a Clerke in my pulpet
And whan the lewed peple is doun y sette
I preche so as ye han herd byfore
And telle an hundred fals Iapes more
Thanne peyne I me . to strecche forth the nekke
And este ⁊and weste vpon the peple I bekke
As doth a dowue sittyng vpon a berne
Myn handes ⁊and my tunge gon so yerne
That it is ioye to sen my besynesse
Of auarice ⁊and of suche cursidnesse
Ys all my prechyng for to make hem fre
To yeue her pens ⁊and namely vn to me
For myn entente is not but for to wynne
And no thyng for correccioıı̄un of synne
I rekke neủer whan that thay ben buried
Though that hire soules gon a blakberied
For certes many a p̉redicacioun
Cometh ofte of euyl entencioun
Som for plesaunce of folke ⁊and of flaterie
To ben avaunsed be ypocrysye
And som for veyn glorie ⁊and som for hate
For whan I dar non other weyes debate
Than wolle I stynge hym with my tunge smerte
In prechyng so that he shal nat a sterte
To ben defamed falsly if that he
Hath trespased to my brethern or to me
For though I telle nought his ꝓpropre name
Men shall wele knowe / that it is the same
By signes ⁊and by other circūmstaunces
Thus quyte I folke that don vs displesaunces
Thus spute I oute my venym vndir hewe
Of holynesse to semen holy ⁊and trewe
But shortly myn entent I wole deuyse
I preche of no thyng but for couetyse
Therfore my tyme is yet ⁊and eủer was
Radix malorꝝrum est cupiditas
Thus kan I preche a gayn that same vice
Whiche that I vse . and that is Auaryce
But though my selfe be gilti in that synne
Yet kan I make other folke to wynne
From Auarice ⁊and sore to repent
But that is nat my principal entent
I preche no thyng but for couetise
Of this matere it ought ynow suffise
¶ Thanne telle I hem ensamples many oon̄
Of oolde stories longe tyme a goon
For lewed peple louen tales olde
Swiche thynges / kan they wele report ⁊and holde
What trowe ye / that whiles I may preche
And wynne golde ⁊and siluer for I teche
That I wole leue in poủerte wilfully
Nay nay ; I thought it neủer trewely
For I wole preche ⁊and begge in sondry londes
I will nat do no labour with myn hondes
Ne make basketes and lyue therby
By cause I wol nat beggen Idelly
I wole noon of the Aposteles cuntrefete
I wolle haue money . wolle . chese . ⁊and whete
Al were it yeuen of the pourest page
Or of the pourest widwe / in a village
Alle shulde hire children sterue for famyne
Nay I wole drynke licour of the vyne
And haue a Ioly wenche in eủery toun
But herkeneth lordynges in conclusioun
Youre likyng is that I shalle telle a tale
Now haue I dronke a draught of corny ale
By god I hope I shall yow telle a thynge
That shall by resoun ben at youre lykynge
For though my selfe be a full vicious man
A moral tale / yet I yow telle kan
Whiche I am wonte to preche for to wynne
Now hoold youre pees my tale I wolle begynne
IN Flaundres whilom was a companye
Of yonge folke that haunteden folie
As ryot . hasard . stewes . ⁊and tauernes
Where as with harpes lutes and gyternes
They daunce ⁊and pleyen atte dees both day ⁊and nyght
And ete also ⁊and drynke oủer her myght
Thurgh whiche they don the deuel sacrifise
With Inne that deueles temple in cursed wise
By suꝑperfluite abhominable
Hire othes ben so grete ⁊and\so/dampnable
That it is grysly for to here hem swere
Oure blissed lordes body for to tere
Hem thought that Iewes rend hym noght y now
And eche of hem at otheres synne low
And right a noon than comen Tombesteris
Fetys ⁊and smale ⁊and yonge frutesterys
Syngeris with harpes . Baudes wafereris
Whiche ben / the verrey deuels officeris
To kyndle ⁊ blowe the fire of leccherie
That is annexed vn to glotonye
The holy writte take I to my witnesse
That luxurie is in wyn ⁊and dronkenesse
¶ Lo how that dronken loth vnkyndely
Lay by his doughtres two vnwityngly
So dronke he was / he nyst what he wrought
Herodes / who so wele the stories sought
Whan he of wyn replet was at his feste
Ryght at his owne table / he yaf his heste
To slee the baptiste Iohn ful gilteles
Senek seith a good worde douteles
He seith he kan no difference kan fynde
Bitwix a man that is oute of \his/ mynde
And a man / whiche that is dronkelewe
But that woodnesse / y fallen in a shrewe
Perseuerith lenger than doth dronkenesse
O glotonye full of cursidnesse
O cause first of oure confusioun
O original of oure dampnacoun
Til Crist had bought vs with his blood a geyn̄
Lo how dere shortly forto seyn
A bought was thilke cursed vilenye
Corrupt was al this world for glotonye
Adam oure fader ⁊and his wife alsoo
Fro paradyse to labour ⁊and to woo
Were dryuen for that vice it is no drede
For while that Adam fasted as I rede
He was in ꝑparadyse . ⁊and whan that hee
Ete of the frute defended on a tree
Anoon he was out caste to woo ⁊and peyne
O glotonye on the wele oughte vs pleyne
O wiste a man how many maladies
Folwen of excesse and of glotonyes
He wolde ben the more mesurable
Of his diete sittyng atte his table
Allas the short throte the tendre mouth
Maketh / that Est / ⁊and west / ⁊and North / ⁊and south
In erthe / in eyre / in water man to swynke
To gete a glotoun / deynte mete ⁊and drynke
Of this matere . o Paule wele kanstowe trete
Mete vnto wombe / ⁊and wombe eke vn to mete
Shal god destroyen bothe as Paulus seith
Allas a foule thynge it is by my feith
To sey this worde . and fouler is the dede
Whan̄ man̄ so drynketh of the white ⁊and rede
That of his throte he maketh his pryuee
Thurgh thilke cursed / suꝑperfluyte
The Apostle wepyng seith full pitously
Ad Philipenses . c . z .Ther walken many of whiche yow tolde haue I
I say it now wepyng with pitous voys
Ther ben ennemys of cristis Croys
Of whiche the ende is deth / wombe is her god
O wombe O bely O stynkyng Cod
Fulfild of donge ⁊ of corrupcioun
At eyther ende of the foule is the soun
How grete labour and cost is the to fynde
These Cokys / how they stampe / ⁊ streyne ⁊ grynde
To tornen substaunce in to accident
To fulfille alle thi likerous talent
Oute of the harde bones knokke they
The mary / for they caste nought a wey
That may goo thorow þe golet softe ⁊ swote
Of spicerie of leef ⁊ barke ⁊ rote
Shal ben his sause y maked by delyt
To makyn hym yet a newer appetit
But certes / he that haunteth swiche delices
Is deed / while that he lyueth in tho vices
A lecherous thynge is wyn / ⁊ dronkenesse
Ys full of stryuyng ⁊ of wrecchidnesse
O dronke man disfigured is thy face
Sour is thy breeth foule art thow to embrace
And thurgh thy dronke nose / semeth the soun
As thow thow seydest ay / Sampsou Sampsou
And god wote Sampson dranke neuꝰer no wyn
Thow fallest as it were a stiked swyn
Thy tonge is loste ⁊ alle thyn honest cure
For drunkenesse is verrey sepulture
Of mann9 wit ⁊ his discrecioun
In whom that drynke hath dominacioun
He kan no counseille kepe / it is no drede
Now kepe yow fro the white ⁊ fro the rede
And namely from the white wyne of lepe
That is to selle / in Fisshestrete or in Chepe
This wyne of Spayne crepith subtilly
In othere wynes growyng faste by
Of whiche ther riseth suche fumosite
That whan a man hath dronken draughtes thre
And weneth that he be at home in chepe
He is in Spayne right at the toune of lepe
Nat at the Rochel ne at the Burdeux toun
And than wole he sey . Sampsoıı̄un Sampsoun
But herkeneth lordynges / o worde I yow preye
That alle the souꝰereyn actes / dar I seye
Of victories in the olde testament
Thurgh verrey god that is omipotent
Were doon in abstynence ⁊ in parayere
Loketh the bible . and there ye may it lere
Loke Attilla / the grete conquerour
Deide in his sleep / wtith shame ⁊ dishonorur
Bledyng ay at his nose in dronkenesse
A Capitayne sholde lyue in sobrenesse
And ouꝰer alle this aviseth yow riȝt wele
What was comaunded vnto lamwele
Nat samuel but lamwel sey I
Redith the bible ⁊ fynde it expresly
Of wyn yeuyng to hem that han Iustice
Namore of this / for it may suffice
¶ And now that I haue spoken of glotonye
Now wole I yow defenden hasardrie
Hasard is verrey moder of lesynges
And of deceyte / ⁊ cursed forswerynges
Blasphemyng of crist / manslaughter ⁊ wast also
Of catel ⁊ of tyme ⁊ forther mo
It is reproue / ⁊ contrarie of honour
For to ben holde / a comoun hasardour
And euꝰer the hier he is of estate
The more is he holden desolat
Yf that a prynce vseth hasardrye
In alle gouꝰernaunce . ⁊ palicie
He is / as by comune opynyoun
I holde the lasse in reputacioun
¶ Stilbon that was a wise embassatour
Was sent to Corynthe / in ful grete honour
Fro lacedomye / to maken hire alliaunce
And whan he cam hym happed ꝑperchaunce
That alle the gretteste / that were of that lond
Pleyng at hasard he hem fond
For whiche / as sone as it myght be
He stale hym hom a gayn to his cuntre
And seide there wole I not lese my name
Ny wol not take on me so grete defame
Yow forto allie / vnto none hasardours
Sendeth other wise embassadours
For by my trouthe me were leuer dye
Than I yow shulde to hasardours allie
For ye that ben so glorious in honours
Shalle nat allie yow with hasardours
As by my wille / ne as by my trete
This wise Philosophre / thus saide he
¶ Loke eke that to the kyng demetrius
The kynge of Parthes . at the book seith vs
Sent hym a peyre of dees of golde in scorn
For he had vsed hasard ther byforn
For whiche he helde his glorie / or his renoun
At no value or reputacioun
Lordes may fynden other manꝰer play
Honest y now / to dryue the day a way
¶ Now wole I speke of othes fals ⁊ grete
A worde or two . as olde bokes trete
Greet sweryng is a thynge abhomynable
And fals sweryng is yet more repreuable
The heighe god forbad sweryng at al
Witnesse of Mathewe but in special
Of sweryng seith the holy Ieremye
Thow shalt swere sooth thyn othes ⁊ not lye
And swere in doom ⁊ eke in rightwysnesse
But idelle sweryng is a cursednesse
Biholde ⁊ see / that in the first table
Of hie goddes hestes honurable
How that the secund of hym / is this
Take nat my name in ydel or amys
Lo rather / he forbedith suche sweryng
Than homycide / or many a cursed thyng
I seye that as by ordre / thus it stondeth
This knowen / that his hestes vndirstondeth
How that the secund heste of god is that
And forther ouꝰer I wole the telle al plat
That vengeaunce shalle not ꝑperten from his hous
That of his othes . is so outrageous
By goddis pꝰercious hert ⁊ by his nailes
And by the blood of criste that is in hailes
Seuene is my chaunce . ⁊ thyn is cynke ⁊ treye
By goddis Armys / if thow falsly pley
This dagger shalle thorogh oute thyn herte go
This fruyt cometh / of the bicched bones two
For sweryng Ire / falsnesse / homycyde
Now for the loue of Crist that for vs deyde
Lete youre othes / bothe grete ⁊ smale
But sires / now wolle I telle forth my tale
¶ These riotours iij . of whiche I telle
Longe erste or prime ronge of ony belle
Were sette hem in a tauerne to drynke
And as they satte they herde a belle knyllke klynke
By forn a cors / was caried to his graue
That oon of hem gan callen to his knaue
Go bette qᵈuod he ⁊ axe redily
What cors is this / that passeth here forth by
And loke that thow report his name wele
¶ Sire qᵈuod this boy it nedeth neuꝰer a dele
Yt was me tolde er ye cam here twey oures
He was parde an olde felawe of youres
And sodenly he was y slayn to nyght
For dronke as he satte on his benche vpright
Ther cam a pryue thef / men clepeth deth
That in this cuntre / alle the puple sleeth
And with his spere he smote his herte a two
And wente his wey with oute wordes mo
He hath a thousand slayn this pestilence
And maister er ye come in his presence
Me thynketh that it were necessarie
For to be ware of swyche an aduꝰersarye
Beth redy for to mete hym euꝰer more
Thus taught me my dame / I sey nomore
¶ By Seint Marie seide this tauernere
The childe seith soth for he hath slayn this yere
Henne ouꝰer a myle with inne a grete village
Bothe man ⁊ woman / childe ⁊ hyne / ⁊ page
I trowe his habitacioun be there
To ben avised grete wisdom it were
Er that he did a man a dishonour
¶ Ye goddis armes qᵈuod this reatour
Ys it suche a ꝑperil for to mete
I shalle hym seke / by wey ⁊ eke by strete
I make a vow / to goddis digne bones
Herkeneth felawes / we . iij . ben al ones
Late eche of vs / holde vp his hand til other
And eche of vs / bycome otheres brother
And welle sleen this fals traitour deth
He shalle be slayn that so many sleeth
By goddis dignyte er it be nyght
To gidres han thise three hire trewthes plight
To lyuen ⁊ dyen eche of hem for other
As theigh he were his owen born brother
And vp they sterte ⁊ dronken in this rage
And forth thay gon towardis that village
Of whiche that tauerner had spoken byforn
And many a grysly ooth / than han they sworn
And cristes blissed body they to rente
Deeth shalle be deed / if that they may hym hente
Whan they han gon nat fully half a myle
Right as they wolde / han treden ouꝰer a stile
An olde man ⁊ a pore . with hem mette
This olde man fulle mekely hem grette
And seide thus . now lordis god yow se
The proudest of these reatours thre
Answerde a gayn what carle wtith sory grace
Why artow alle for wrapped saue thy face
Why lyuest ow so longe in so grete age
¶ This olde man gan loke in his visage
And seide thus / for I ne can nat fynde
A man though that I walked in to Inde
Neither in Cite ne in no village
That wolde chaunge his youthe for myn age
And therfore mote I han myn age stille
As longe tyme / as it is goddis wille
Ne deeth allas / ne wolle nat han my lyf
Thus walke I like a reccheles caitif
And on the grounde whiche is my modres gate
I knokke with my staffe bothe erly ⁊ late
And sey leue moder lete me Inne
Lo how vanysshe . flesshe . ⁊ blood . ⁊ skynne
Allas / whan shulle my bones ben at reste
Moder with yow wolde I chaunge my cheste
That in my chambre longe tyme hath be
Ye for an heire cloute / to wrappe me
But yet to me / she wol nat do that grace
For whiche ful pale / and welked is my face
But sires / to yow / it is no curteisie
To speken to an olde man villenye
But he trespasse in worde or ellys in dede
In holy writte / ye may youre selfe wele rede
A gayns an olde man / hoor vppon his heede
Ye sholde a ryse / wherfore I yeue yow rede
Ne dooth to an olde man noon harme nowe
Nomore than that ye wolde man dide to yowe
In age if that ye so longe a bide
And god be with yow where ye goo ⁊ or ride
I mote goo theder as I haue to goo
¶ Nay olde cherle by god thow shalt nat so
Seide this other hasardour a noon
Thow partist not so lightly / by seynt Iohn
Thow speke right now / of thilke traitour deth
That in the cuntre alle oure frendes sleeth
Haue here my treuthe / as thow art his espie
Telle where he is or thow shalt a bie
By god ⁊ by the holy sacrament
For shortly thow art oon of his assent
To sleen vs yonge folke / thow fals thefe
¶ Now sires qᵈuod he / if that ye be so lefe
To fynde deth turne vp this croked wey
For in that groue I lafte hym be my fey
Vnder a tree ⁊ ther he wole abide
Not for youre boost he wole hym nothyng hyde
Se ye that ooke . right there ye shal hym fynde
God saue yow that bought a gayn mankynde
And yow amende thus seide this olde man
And euꝰeryche of these reatours ran
Til he come to that tree / ⁊ ther they founde
Of floryns fyve of golde / y coyned rounde
