his herte gan enclyne to þᵉ wille of his wife · cōn
siderynge hire trewe entente

enforsed hym anoon** ⁊and assented fully
to werken aftir hire counseile ·

and thonked god of whom ꝓprocedeth /
alle vertue and alle goodnesse / that hym sente a wyfe of so gretee
discrecioun /

And whan the day cam that hise adủersaries sholde apper̉er
in his p̉resence 
he spake vnto hem full goodly ⁊and seyde in this wise

Alle be it so · that of youre pride ⁊and hie p̉ersumpcoıı̄un⁊and folie · ⁊and of youre
necligence ⁊and vnkonnynge ·

ye haue mysborne yow ⁊and trespased vnto
me 
yet for as mychel as I se ⁊and byholde youre greet humylyte ·

and
that ye ben sory ⁊and repentaunt of youre giltes

it constreyneth
me to do yow grace ⁊and mercye //
Wherfore I receyue yow to my gᵃrace

⁊and foryeue yow outrely alle þᵉ offenses · Iniuries ⁊and wronges þᵗat ye haue
doon a gayne me ⁊and myne ·

to this effecte · ⁊and to this ende þᵗat god of his
endles mercy

wole at the tyme of oure deiynge · foryeue vs oure
giltes that wee han trespassed to hym in this wrecched worlde /

For douteles if we be sory ⁊and repentaunt of the synnes ⁊and giltes ·
whiche we han trespassed / in the sight of oure lorde god 

he is
so fre ⁊and so merciable ·
that he wole foryeuen vs oure giltes

and
brynge vs to the blysse that neủer hath ende ·/·
Here is ended Chaucers tale of Melibee

div.l: Chaucer de casibz viror illustriıı̄un
Whan ended was the tale of Melibe
And of Prudence ⁊and hire benyygnyte
Oure ooste seyde · as I am feithful man
And by þᵗat p̉recious corpus Madrian
I hadde leuer thanne a barel ale
That goodlef my wife hadde herde this tale
She nys nothynge of suche pacience
As was this Melibeus wife Prudence .
By goddes bones · whan I bete my knaues .
She brengeth me the greet clobbed staues
And crieth . slee the dogges eủerychoıı̄un .
And breke hem bothe bakke ⁊and eủery boıı̄un .
And if that any neighebore of myne .
Wole nat in chirche to my wife enclyne .
Or be so hardi to hire to hire to trespace
Whan she cometh she raumpeth in my face
And crieth / fals to wards / wreke thy wife
By corpus bones I wole haue thy knyfe
And þᵘ shalt haue my distaf ⁊and goo spynne
Fro day to nyght · right thus she wole begynne
Allas she seith · þᵗat eủer þᵗat I was shape
To wedde a Melksoppe · or a cowarde ape
That wole ben** oủer ladde / wᵗith eủery wight
Thow darste nat stonden by þⁱ wyues right
This is my · lyfe · but if that I wole fight
And oute atte dore a noon** I moot me dight
Or ellys I am but loste · but if that I
Be like a wilde leou** / fool hardy
I woot wele she wole do me slee som day
Som neighebore · and thanne go my way
For I am ꝑperilous with knyfe in honde
Al be it that I dare nat hire withstonde
For she is bigg in armes by my feith
That shalle he fynde · þᵗat hire mysdooth or seith
But late vs passe a way · fro this matere
¶ My lorde the Monke qduod he be mery of chere
For ye shulle telle a tale trewely
Loo Rouchestre stont here fast by
Ride forth myn** owen lorde breke nat oure game
But by my trouthe I knowe nat youre name
Wheþ̉er shal I calle yow my lorde dame Iohn**
Or daun** Thomas · or elles Daun Albon
Of what hous be ye · be youre fader kyn
I vowe to god  þᵘ haste a full faire skyn
Yt is a gentil pasture · ther thow goost
Thow arte nat lyke a penaunt or a goost
Vppon** my feith · thow arte som** officer
Som worthy sextein · or som Celerer
For by my faders soule as to my dome
Thow arte a maister whan þᵘ arte at home
No pore Cloistrer · ne no Novys
But a goủernoure witti ⁊and wys
And ther with al of brawnes ⁊and of bones
A wele faryng ꝑpersone for the nones
I preye to god yeue hym confusioıı̄un
That firste the brought vnto religion
Thow woldest han bene a tredefoule aright
Haddest þᵘ as greet a leue as þᵘ haste myght
To ꝑperfourme all thy luste in engendrure
Thow haddest bygeten full many a creature
Allas why werestow so wide a cope
God yeue me sorwe · but ⁊and I were a pope
Nat oonly þᵘ · but eủery myghty man
Though he were shore full hye vppon** his pan
Sholde haue a wife / for al the werlde is lorn** /
Religioun** hath take vp alle the corn**
Of tredynge · ⁊and we borel men ben shrympes
Of feble trees  there come wrecched Impes
This maketh that oure eires beth so sklender
And feble that thay may nat wele engender
This maketh that oure wyues wole assay
Religious folke · for ye mowe bettre pay
Of venus paiementz than may we
God woot no lussheburgh payen ye
But be nat wrooth my lorde though that I pleye
Full ofte in game a sooth I haue herde seye
¶ This worthy Monke toke all in paceince
And seide I wole doon** al my diligence
As fer as sowneth in to honestee
To telle yow a tale / or twoo or three
And if þᵘ lyste to herkne hiderwarde
I wole yow sey the lyfe of seint Edwarde
Or ellys first tragedies wole I telle
Of whiche I haue an hundred in my selle
Tragedye is to seyn a certeyn storie
As olde bokes maken vs memorie
Of hym stood in greet ꝓprosꝑperite
And is y fallen oute of heigh degre
In to miserie** ⁊and endeth wrecchedly
And they ben v̉ercified comonly
Of vj · feet · whiche men clepen** exametron
In prose eke ben endited many oon
And eke in metre in many a sondry wise
Loo this declarynge oughte ynow suffise
Now herkeneth if yow lyke for to here
But first I yow beseke in this matere
Though I be ordre telle nat these thynges
Be it of Popes Emꝑperours or kynges
Aftir hire ages as men writen fynde
But telle hem som byfore ⁊and som byhynde
As it now cometh / vnto my remembraunce
Haue me excused / of myn** ignoraunce

l.hi: Explicit ꝓprohemiıı̄unm
⁊and Incipit Fabula

div.l: I wole by waile in man̉ere of tregedye
The harme of hem þtat stood in heigh degre
And fellen so that ther nas no remedie
To brynge hem oute of hire adủersite
For certeyn̄ whan þᵗat fortune lyste to flee
Be ware be these ensamples trewe ⁊and olde
¶ At lucifer though he an Aungel were lucifer
And nat a man̄ . at hym I wole begynne
For though fortune may non̄ Aungel dere
From heighe degre · yet felle he for his synne
Doun in to helle where as he yet is ynne
O lucifer brightest of Aungels alle
Now art thow Sathanas · þᵗat maist nat twynne
Oute of miserie · in whiche þᵗat þᵘ art falle
Adam
¶ Lo Adam in the felde of Damyssene Adam
With goddis owne fynger wrought was he
And not bygoten of mannes sparme vnclene
And welth all Paradis sauyng oo tree
Had neủer wordly man so highe degree
As Adam till he for mysgoủernaunce
Was dryue oute of his hie ꝓpropsꝑperite
To labour ⁊and to helle and myschaunce
¶ Sampsoıı̄un
Loo Sampsoıı̄un whiche þᵗat was anıı̄unciat Sampsoıı̄un
By þᵉ Aungel longe or his natiuite
And was to god almyghti consecrat
And stood in noblesse while he myght se
Was neủer swiche a nother as was he
To speke of strengthe ⁊and ther wᵗith hardynesse
But to his wyues tolde he his secre
Thurgh whiche he slow hym selfe for wrecchednesse
// Sampsoıı̄un þˢ noble and myghti champioun
With outen wepne saue his hondes tweye
He slow ⁊and all to rente þᵉ leoun
Towarde his weddyng walkyng by þᵉ weye
His fals wife coude hym so plese ⁊and preye
Til she his counseile knewe / ⁊and she vntrewe
Vnto his foos bygan to wreye
And hym forsook ⁊and tooke a nother newe
¶ The hundred foxes toke Sampsoıı̄un for yre
And alle hire tailles to gidre bonde
And sette þᵉ foxes tailles alle on fire
For he on eủery taille · hadde knytte a broonde
And they brende alle þᵉ Cornes in that londe
And alle hire Olyues ⁊and vynes eke
A thousand men he slough wᵗat his hoonde
⁊and hadde no wepne but an asses cheke
¶ Whan they were slayn** / so thursted hy** þᵗat he
Was welle nyghe lorne / for whiche he gan to preye
That god wolde on his peyne han som pite
And sende hym som drynke · or ellys moste he deye
And of þˢ asses cheke / that was dreye
Oute of a wange tooth · sprange a noon** a welle
Of whiche he dranke y now · shortly to seye
Thus heelpe hym god · as Iudicum kan telle
¶ By verrey force at Gazon on a nyght
Maugre Philistiens of þᵗat Citee
The gates of þᵉ toun he hath vp plight
And on his bakke y karied hem hath he
Highe on an hille / where as men myght hem se
O noble tl myghti sampson leef ⁊and dere
Hadde þᵘ not tolde to wōmmen thy secre
In alle this worlde ne hadde ben thy pere
¶ This Sampson neủer Cider dranke ne wyn
Ne on his heed com** rasour noon** ne shere
By p̉ercepte of the messenger dyuyn
For alle his strengthes in his heres were
And fully xxᵗⁱri · wynter yere by yere
He hadde of Israel þᵉ goủernaunce
But soone shall he wepe many a tere
For wōmmen shulle hym brynge to myschaunce
¶ Vnto his lēmman dalida he tolde
That in heeris alle his streyngthe lay
And falsly to his foomen / he hym solde
And slepyng in hire barme vpon** a day
She made to clippe / or sheer his heer a way
And made his fomen all þˢ crafte espien
And whan that thay hym fonde in þˢ array
They bounden hym faste · ⁊and putte oute his eyen
¶ But eer his heer was clipped or y shaue
Ther was noo bonde · wᵗith whiche men myght hym bynde
But now is he in prisoun** in a Caue
Where as they made hym at þᵉ querne grynde
O noble Sampsoıı̄un strengest of mankynde
O whilom Iuge / in glorie ⁊and in richesse
Now maistow wepen** wᵗith thyn eyen blynde
Sith þᵘ froo wele arte falle in wrecchednesse
¶ The ende of þˢ caitife · was as I shal sey
His foomen made a feste vpon a day
And made hym as hire fole / byfore hem pleye
And þˢ was in a temple of gret array
But at þᵉ laste he made a foule a fray
For he twoo pilers shoke ⁊and made hem falle
And doun** felle temple ⁊and alle / ⁊and ther it lay
And slowe hym selfe ⁊and eke his fomen alle
¶ This is to seyn** þᵉ princes eủerychoıı̄un
And eke three thousand bodies were there sleyn
Wᵗith fallyng of the greet temple of stoon
Of Sampson now wole I nomore seyn
Beth ware / by this ensample olde ⁊and pleyn**
That no men telle here counsel til hire wyues
Of swiche thynge as they wole han secre fayn**
Yf that it touche hire lymes or hir lyues
** ¶ hercules
**¶ Of hercules the soủereyn conqueroure
Syngen hise werkes  laude ⁊and heigh renoun**
For in his tyme of strengthe he bare þᵉ floure
He slough ⁊and rafte þᵉ skyn fro the leoun
He of Centauros · leyde þᵉ boost a doun**
He Arpies slough · the cruel briddes felle
He golden Apples / rafte of the dragoun
He drough oute Cerberus / the hounde of helle
¶ He slough the cruel tyraunt Busirus
And made his hors to frete hym flesshe ⁊and boon**
He slow þᵉ firy serpent venymus
Of Achilles twoo hornes he brake oon
And he slowe Kakus in a Caue of stoon
He slowe the geaunt Antheuꝰus þᵉ stronge
He slough þᵉ grysly boor · ⁊and þᵗat a noon
And bare the hede  on his nekke longe
¶ Was neủer wight sith that þˢ worlde bigan
That slow many monstres as did he
Thurgh oute þˢ wilde worlde his name ran
What for hise strengthe / ⁊and for heigh bounte
And eủery reaume went he for to se
He was so stronge that noman myght hym lette
At bothe the worldes endes / seith Trophee
In stide of boundes he a piler sette
A leman hadde this noble champion
That highte dianra fresshe as may
And as these Clerkes · maken mencoıı̄un
She hath hym sente a sherte fresshe ⁊and gay
Allas þˢ sherte · allas ⁊and weile a way
Enuenemed was so subtily wᵗith alle
That er that he hadde werid it halfe a day
It made his fleisshe alle from his bones falle
¶ But nartheles som** clerkes hire excusen
By oon that hight Nessus that it maked
Be it as be may I wole nat hire accusen
But on his bakke he wered the sherte al naked
Til that his fleisshe was for the venym blaked
And whan he say non** other remedye
In hote coles · he hath hym selfen raked
For with noo venym / deigned hym to dye
¶ Thus starfe þˢ worthy myghty hercules
Lo whoo may truste on fortune any throwe
For hym þᵗat folweth all þˢ worlde of prees
Er he beware is ofte y leide full lowe
Full wys is he · that kan hym siluen knowe
Beth ware / for whan** fortune lyste to glose
Than waiteth she hir man to oủer throwe
By swiche a wey / as he wole leest suppose
¶ The myghty trone / the precious tresor
¶ The glorious ceptre / ⁊and roial maieste
That hadde þᵉ kyng · Nabugodonosor
With tunge vnnethe · may discryued be
He twies wan̄ Ierusalem the Cite
The vessel of the temple he wᵗith hym ladde
At Babiloyne / was his soủereyne see
In whiche / his glorie ⁊and his delyte he hadde
¶ The fairest children of the blood roial
Of Israel he leet / do gelde anon
And maked iche of hem to ben his thral
Amonges othere Danyel was oon
That was the wisest childe of eủerychoıı̄un
For he the dremes of þᵉ kyng expowned
Where as in chaldey / Clerke ne was ther noon
That wiste to what fyne · his dremes sowned
¶ This proude kyng / leet make a statue of golde
Sixti cubitis longe ⁊and seuene in brede
To whiche ymage / he bothe yonge ⁊and olde
Cōmmaunded to loute / ⁊and haue in drede
Or in a Furneys · ful of flambes rede
He shall be bronde þᵗat wolde nought obeye
But neủer wolde assente to that dede
Danyel · ne his yonge felawes tweye
¶ This kynge of kynges proude was ⁊and elate
He wende that god that sitte in maieste
Ne myght hym nat byreue of his estate
But sodeynly he leste his dignyte
And like a beest hym semed for to be
And eet hey as an oxe · ⁊and lay ther oute
In rayn with wilde bestes walked he
Til certeyn̄ tyme was I come a boute
¶ And like an Egles fetheris waxe his heeris
His nailes like a briddes clawes were
Til god relessed hym a certeyn yeris
And yaf hym witte ⁊and than̄ wᵗith many a tere
He thonked god ⁊and euer his life in fere
Was he to doon̄ amys · or more trespace
And til that tyme he leyde was on his bere
He knewe that god was full of myght ⁊and grace
¶ Balthasar
¶ His sone whiche that hight Baltasar
That helde the reigne aftir his fader day
¶ By ~ his Fader koude nat be ware
For proude he was / of herte ⁊and of a ray
And eke an Idolastre was he ay
His highe estate assured hym in pride
But fortune caste hym doun / ⁊and ther he lay
And sodeīngly his reigne gan dyuyde
¶ A feeste he made vnto his lordes alle
Vpon a tyme ⁊and made hem blithe be
And thanne his officers gan he calle
Gooth bryngeth foorth the vessels qduod he
Whiche that my fader in his ꝓprosꝑperite
Oute of the temple of Ierlm̄ byrafte
And to oure highe goddis thanke we
Of honour that oure eldres wᵗith vs laste
¶ His wyfe / his lordes ⁊and his concubynes
Ay dronken while þᵗat hire Appetytes lafte
Oute of these vessels sondry wynes
And on a walle this kynge his eyen caste
And say an hande armles . that wroot ful faste
For feer of whiche he quook ⁊and siked sore
This hand that made baltasar so soore a gaste
Wroot Mane techel phares . ⁊and namore
¶ In alle that lande Magicien was ther noon
That coude expounde / what þˢ lettre mente
But Danyel / expounde it a noon
And seide kynge god thy fader lente
Glorie / ⁊and honour / regne / tresour / rente
And he was proude · ⁊and nothyng god ne dradde
And therfore god grete wreche vpon hym sente
And hym byrefte the reigne that he hadde
¶ He was oute caste of mannꝰus companye
With asses was hise habitacoıı̄un
And eet hey as a beste in weet ⁊and drye
Til that he knewe by grace ⁊and by resoıı̄un
That god of heuene hath dominacioıı̄un
Oủer eủery reigne / ⁊and euery creature
Than hadde godde of hym compassion
And hym restored / his reigne ⁊and his figure
¶ Eke thow þᵗat arte his sone art proude also
And knowest alle these thynges verrayly
And arte rebel to god / ⁊and art his foo
Thow dranke eke of þᵉ vessel boldely
Thy wife eke ⁊and thy wenches synfully
Dronke of thoo same vessels sondry wynes
And heriest fals goddis cursedly
Therfore to þᵉ y shapen / full grete peyne is
¶ This hande was sente from god / þᵗat on þᵉ walle
Wroot Mane techel phares . truste me
Thy reigne is doon̄ þᵘ weiest nought at alle
Dyuyded is thy regne . ⁊and it shal be
To Mede ⁊and to ꝐPerses · yeuen qduod he
And thilke same nyght . this kynge was slawe
And Darius occupieth his degree
Though he therto · hadde neither right ne lawe
¶ Lordynges ensample herby may ye take
How that in lordshep̄e is no sikernesse
For whanne Fortune wole a man forsake
She berith a wey his reigne ⁊and his richesse
And eke his frendes booth more ⁊and lesse
For what man that hath frendes thorow fortune
Mishap wole make hem enemys I gesse
This ꝓprouerbe is soth ⁊and full comune
¶ Cenobia
¶ Cenobia of Palymere quene
As writen ꝐPersiens / of hire noblesse
**So worthy []sheshe was / in armes ⁊and so kene
That no wight passed hire / in hardynesse
Ne in lynage / ne other gentellesse
Of kynges blood of ꝐPerce / is she descended
I sey nat that she hadde moost fairnesse
But of hire shappe she myght nat ben amended
¶ From hire childhede I fynde that she fledde
Office of wōmmen · ⁊and to wode she wente
And many a wilde hertes blood she shedde
With arwes brood that she to hem sente
She was so swifte that shee a noon hem hente
And whan that she was elder . she wolde kille
Lyons leopardes · and beres alto rente
And in here Armes welde hem at hire wille
¶ She dorste / wilde beestes dennes seke
And rennen in þᵉ Mounteyns al the nyght
And slepen vndir the busshe · ⁊and she coude eke
Wrastlen by verrey force · ⁊and by verrey myght
With a yonge man were he neủer so wight
Ther myght no thynge in hire armes stonde
She kepte hire maidenhede from eủery wight
To no man̄ deigned hire to be bonde
¶ But at the laste hire frendes haue hire maried
To Onedake a prince of that cuntre
Alle were it soo þᵗat shee hem longe taried
And ye shalle vnderstonde . how that he
Hadde swiche fantasies · as hadde she
But natheles / when they were knyt in fere**
They lyued in Ioye · ⁊and in felicite
For iche of hem hadde other liefe ⁊and dere
¶ Saue oo thynge þᵗat she wolde neủer assente
By no wey that he sholde by hir lye
But oones for it was hire pleyne entent
To haue a childe the world to multiplie
And also sone · as þᵗat she myght espye
That she was nat with childe with that dede
Thanne wolde she suffren hym don his fantasye
Eft sones · ⁊and nought but ones oute of drede
¶ And if she were wᵗith childe at thilke caste
Nomore sholde he pleien thilke game
Til fully xl daies · weren paste
Than̄ wolde she oones soffre hym do the same
Al were this Onedake · wilde or tame
He gate nomore of hire / for thus she seide
It was to wyues leccherie ⁊and shame
In oother caas / if that men wᵗith hem pleide
¶ Two sones by thys Onedake · hadde she
The whiche she kepte · in v̉ertue ⁊and lettrure
But now vnto oure tale turne we
I seye so worshepfull a creature
And wys ther with · ⁊and large wᵗith mesure
So peyneble in the werre · ⁊and curteys eke
Ne more labore myght in werre endure
Was noon̄ / thow al this world men sholde seke
¶ Hire riche array · ne myght nat be tolde
As wele in vessel as in hire clothynge
She was alle cladde in perre ⁊and in golde
And eke she lafte nought for non huntynge
To haue of sundry tonges ful knowynge
Whan that she leyser hadde / ⁊and for to entende
To lerne bokes was alle hire lykyng
How she in vertue myght here lyfe despende
¶ And shortly of this storie for to trete
So doughty was hire housbonde ⁊and eke she
That they conquered many reignes grete
In Thorient with many a faire Cite
Aꝑpertenᵃaunt vnto the maieste
Of Rome ⁊and wᵗith stronge honde helde hem ful faste
Ne neủere myght her fomen doon hem flee
Ay while that Onydakes daies laste
¶ Hire batailles who so lyste hem for to rede
Agayn Sapor þᵉ kyng ⁊and other moo
And how that alle this ꝓprocesse fille in dede
Whi she conquered ⁊and what title ther too
And aftir of hire myschyef ⁊and hire woo
How that she was biseged ⁊and y take
Late hym / vnto my maister Petrak goo
That writ I now of this I vndir take
¶ Whan Onedake was deed / she myghttely
The regnes helde · ⁊and wᵗith hire ꝓpropre honde
Agayns hire foos / she faught so cruelly
That ther nas kynge ne prince in al that londe
That he nas glad if he that grace fonde
That she ne wolde · vppon his londe werreye
With hire they made alliaunce by boond
To ben in pees · ⁊and lete hire ride ⁊and pleye
¶ The Emꝑperoure of Rome Claudius
Ne hym byforn the Romayn Galyen
Ne dursten neủer ben so corageus
Ne noon Ermyn̄ ne non̄ Egipcien
Ne Surrien ne noon Arabien
Wᵗith Inne þᵉ feldes þᵗat durste wᵗith hire · fight
Leste that she wolde hem wᵗith hire handes slen
Or with hire meyne puttēn hem to flyght
¶ In kynges habit wenten hire sones two
As heires of hire fadres regnes alle
And heramanno · and Thymalao
Hire names were · as Persiens hem calle
But ay fortune hath in hire hony galle
This myghty quene may no while endure
Fortune oute of hire reigne made hire falle
To wrecchidnesse ⁊and to mysauenture
¶ Aurelian whan that þᵉ goủernaunce
Of Rome come in to his handes tweye
He shooꝑper vppon̄ this quene to doon vengeaunce
And wᵗith his legions he toke his weye
Towarde Cenobie · ⁊and shortly for to seye
He made hire flee / and atte þᵉ laste hir hente
And fettrid hire ⁊and eke hire children tweye
And wanne the lande ⁊and hoome to Rome he went
¶ Amonges other thynges that he wan
Here chare that was wᵗith golde wroght ⁊and perre
This grete Romayn̄ this Aurelian
Hath with hym ladde / for that men sholde it se
Byforne his tryumphe walketh she
With gilte cheynes on hir nekke hangynge
Crowned was she / as aftir hire degre
And full of perre · charged hire clothynge
¶ Allas fortune she that whilom was
Dredfull to kynges · ⁊and to Emꝑperoures
Now gawreth all the peple on hire allas
And she that helmed was · in starke stoures
And wanne by force townes stronge ⁊and towres
Shall on hyre heed  now were a vitremyte
And she that baar the sceptre full of floures
She bare a distafe hir coste for to quyte
¶ De Nerone
¶ Al though that Nero were vicious
As any fende that lith full low a doun
Yet he · as tellith vs swetonius
This wide worlde hadde in subieccioun
Booth este ⁊and weste / North · ⁊and Septemptrion
Of Rubies Saphires · ⁊and of pierles white
Were alle hire clothes broudid vp ⁊and doun
For he in gēmmes gretly gan delite
¶ More dilicat more pompous of aray
More proude was neủer emꝑperour than he
That ilke clooth · that he hadde werid o day
Aftir that tyme he wolde it neủer see
Nettes of golde threed hadde he greet plente
To fisshe in Tybre water whan hym lyst pleye
Hise lustes were al lawe in his decree
For fortune as his frende hym wolde obeye
¶ He Rome brende for hise delicacie
The Senatours he slowe vpon a day
To here how that men wolde wepe ⁊and crye
And slough his brother ⁊and by his suster lay
His moder he made in pitous array
For he hire wombe slytte to byholde
Where he conseyued so weylaway
That he so litel / of his moder tolde
¶ No tere oute of his eighen · for that sight
Ne cam / but seide a faire woman was she
Greet wondir is / how that he coude or myght
Be domesman / of hire dede beaute
The wyn to bryngen hym cōmmaunded he
And dranke a noon / noon̄ other woo he made
Whan myght is ioyned vnto cruelte
Allas to depe wole the venym wade
¶ In youthe / a maister hadde this Emꝑperoure
To teche hym lettrure ⁊and curtesie
For of Moralite he was the floure
As in his tyme but if bokes lye
And while this maister hadde of hym maistrie
He maked hym · so louyng ⁊and so souple
That longe tyme it was / er tirannye
Or ony vice durste in hym vncouple
¶ This Seneca of whiche þᵗat I deuyse
Bi cause Nero / hadde of hym swiche drede
For he fro vices · wolde hym ay chastice
Discretly as by worde / ⁊and nat by dede
Sire wolde he seyn̄ / an Emꝑperour moot nede
By vertuouse ⁊and hate Tirannye
For whiche he in a bath made hym to blede
On bothe hys armes · til he most deye
¶ This Nero hadde eke · a custumance
In youthe agayns his maister forto rise
Whiche aftirwarde · hym thought a greet greuᵃaunce
Ther for he maden hym deyen in this wise
But Natheles this Seneca the wise
Chees in a bath · to die in this man̉ere
Rather thanne han · a nother tormentrise
And thus hath Nero / slayn his maister dere
¶ Now felle it so · that Fortune lyste no lengere
The hie pride of Nero · to cherise
For though that he was stronge · yet was she strenger
She thought thus · by god I am to nyce
To sette a man that is fulfilde of vice
In hie degree / ⁊and Emꝑperour hym calle
By god oute of his sete I wole hym trice
Whan he leest weneth / sonnest shalle he falle
¶ The puple roos vppon̄ hym / on a nyght
For his defaute / ⁊and whan̄ he is espied
Oute of his dores a noon̄ / he hath hym dight
Allone ⁊and there he wende han ben allied
He knokked faste / ⁊and ay the more he cried
The faster shette they the doores alle
Tho wiste he wele he hadde hym selfe mysgyed
And wente his wey · no lenger durste he calle
¶ The peple cride / and rombled vp ⁊and doun
That wᵗith his eeris · herde how they seide
Where is this fals Tiraunt this Neroin
For fere Almoost oute of his witte he breyde
And to his goddis pitously he preide
For socour but it myght be tyde
For drede of this hym thought þᵗat he dede
And ranne in to a gardeyn hym to hyde
¶ And in this gardyn · fonde he cherles twey
That seten by a fuyr grete ⁊and reed
And to these cherles two he gan prey
To slen hym · ⁊and to gerden of his heed
That to his body · whan that he were deed
Were no despit ydoon / for his defame
Hym selfe he slough he coude no bettre reed
Of whiche fortune · loughe ⁊and hadde a game
¶ De Oliferno
¶ Was neủer Capitayn · vndir a kynge
That reignes moo put in subieccoıı̄un
Ne strenger was in felde · of alle thynge
As in his tyme ne gretter of renoun
Ne more pompous in heigh p̉ersumpcoıı̄un
Thanne Olyferne · whiche fortune ay kyste
So lykerously · and ladde hym vp ⁊and doun
Til that his heed was of er that he wiste
¶ Nat oonly that þˢ world hadde hym in awe
For lesynge of richesse / or liberte
But made eủery man reney his lawe
Nabugodonosor / was god seide he
Noon̄ other god · sholde adoured be
Agayns this heste / no wighte durste trespace
Saue in Bethulia / a stronge Cite
Where Eliachym / a preest was of that place
¶ But take kepe of the deeth of Oliferne
Amydde his ooste he dronke lay a nyght
Wᵗith ynne his tente · large as is a berne
And yet for alle his pompe ⁊and al his myght
Iudith a wōmman as he lay vp right
Slepyng his heed of smote ⁊and from his tente
Full pryuely she stale from eủery wight
And with his heed vnto hire toıı̄un she wente
De Anthiocho illustri
¶ What nedeth it of kyng Anthiochus
To telle / his hie roial mageste
His hie pride his werkys venymus
For swiche a nother was ther noon as he
Reed whiche þᵗat he was in Machabee
And reed þᵉ proude wordes that he seyde
And why he felle from hye ꝓprosꝑperite
And in an hille how wrecchidly he deyde
¶ Fortune hym hadde enchaunted so in pride
That verreily he wende he myght Atteyne
Vn to the sterres / vpon eủery side
And in balaunce weyen eche mountayne
And alle the floodes of the see restrayne
And goddes peple hadde he moost in hate
He wolde he slen̄ / in turment ⁊and in peyne
Wenyng that god ne myght his pride abate
¶ And for that Nichanore / and Thymothee
With Iewes weren venquysshed myghtely
Vnto the Iewys / swiche an hate hadde he
That he bad greithe his chare ful hastely
And swore ⁊and seyde ful dispitously
Vnto Ierlm he wolde Efte soone
¶ God for his manace · hym so soore smot
With inuisible wounde ay incurable
That in his guttes / carfe it so ⁊and boot
That hise peynes weren importable
And certeynly / the wreche was resonable
For many a mannes guttes ded he peyne
But fro his purpos cursed ⁊and dampnable
For alle his smert he wolde hym nat restreyne
¶ But bade a noon̄ apparaillen his hoste
And sodeynly er he were of it ware
God daunted al his pride / ⁊and alle his booste
For he so sore / fil out of his chare
That it his lymes / and his skyn to tare**
So that he neither myght goo ne ride
But in a chaier / men aboute hym bare
Al forbrosed bothe bakke ⁊and side
¶ The wreche of god hym smote · so cruelly
That thourgh his bodye · wikked wormes crepte
And ther withal he stanke so horribly
That noon of alle his meyne that hym kepte
Whether so he woke · or elles slepte
Ne myght not the stynke of hym endure
In this mescheef he wailed ⁊and eke wepte
And knewe god lorde of eủery creature
¶ To alle his ooste · ⁊and to hym selfe also
Ful wlatsom was the stynke of his careyne
No man ne myght hym bere / to ne fro
And in this stynke · and this horrible peyne
He starfe full wrecchedly in a mounteyne
Thus hath this robbour / and this homycyde
That many a man̄ / made to wepe ⁊and pleyne
Swiche gerdon / as bylongeth vnto pride
¶ De Alexandro
¶ The storie of Alisaunder is so comune
That eủery wight that hath discrecioıı̄un
Hath herde somwhat / or alle of his fortune
This wide worlde / as in conclusioıı̄un
He wanne by strengthe . or for his hie renon
They were gladde / for pees vnto hym sende
The pride of man and beest he leyde a doun
Where so he cam / vnto the worldes ende
¶ Comꝑperison / myght neủer yet ben maked
Bitwixe hym and another conquerour
For alle this worlde / for drede of hym hath quaked
He of knyghthode ⁊and of fredom floure
Fortune hym made the heire of honoure
Saue wyn ⁊and wȳmmen · no thynge myght a swage
His hie entente in armes ⁊and labour
So was he ful / of leonyn corage
¶ What pris were it to hym though I yow tolde
Of Darius ⁊and of an hundred thowsand moo
Of kynges · Pⁱrinces · Dukes · Erles bolde ·
Whiche he conquered · ⁊and broght hem in to woo
I sey as fer as a man may ride ⁊and goo
The worlde was hise what sholde I more deuyse
For though I write · or tolde yow eủer moo
Of his knyghthode / it myght nat suffise
¶ Twelfe yere he reigned as seith Machabe
Philippus sone of Macedoyne he was
That firste was kynge / in grece the cuntre
O worthy gentil Alisaunder allas
That eủer sholden falle swiche a cas
Enpoysened / of thyn̄ owne folke þᵘ were
Thy sys · fortune · hath turned in to aas
And for the / ne wepe she neủer a tere
¶ Who shalle me yeue teeris to compleyne
The deeth of gentilesse / ⁊and of fraunchise
That alle the worlde welded in his demeyne
And yet hym thought · it myght not suffise
So full was his corage · of heigh emprise
Allas whoo shall me helpe to endite
Fals fortune / ⁊and poysoıı̄un to despise
The whiche two / of alle this woo I wite
¶ De Julis Cesar͗e
¶ By wisdom manhede ⁊and by greet labour
Fram humble bedde to Roial mageste
Vp roos · he Iulius the conquerour
That wanne alle the Occidente by lande ⁊and see
By strength of honde or ellys by trete
And vnto Rome made hem tributarie
And sith of Rome the Emꝑperour was he
Til that fortune waxe his adủersarie
¶ O myghti Cesar that in Thessalie
Agayn Pompeus Fader thyn in lawe
That of Thorient hadde alle the Chiualrie
As fer as that the day bygynneth dawe
Though thurgh thy knyghthode . haste hem take ⁊ slawe
Saue fewe folke that . with Pompeus fledde
Thurgh whiche thow puttest alle Thorient in awe
Thanke fortune that so wele the spedde
But now a litel while . I wole by wayle
This Pompeus . this noble gouꝰernour
Of Rome whiche that sleigh at this bataille
I sey oon of his men / a fals traitour
His heed of smote to wynne hym fauour
Of Iulius ⁊ hym the heed he brought
Allas Pompeie . of Thorient Conquerour
That fortune vnto swyche a fyn the brought
To Rome Agayn / repaireth Iulius
Wtith his triumphe laureat full hye
But on a tyme Brutus Cassius
That euꝰer hadde of his heigh estate enuye
Full piriuely hath made conspiracie
Agayns this Iulius . in subtil wise
And caste the place in whiche he sholde dye
With boydekyns . as I shall yow deuyse
This Iulius to the Capitolie wente
Vpon a day as he was wonte to goon
And in the Capitolie a noon hym hente
This false Brutus . and his other foon
And stiked hym wtith boydekyns a noon
With many a wounde and thus they lete hym lye
But neuꝰer grunte he at noo strook but oon
Or ellys at two / but if his storie lye
So manly was this Iulius of herte
And so wele loued / estatly honeste
That though his deedly woundes so sore smerte
Hise mantel ouꝰer his hipes caste he
For noman sholde sen his pryuete
And as he lay / of dyeng in a traunce
And wiste verely that deed was he
Of honeste yet hadde he remembraunce .
Lucan to the this storie I recomende
And to sweton ⁊ to valerius alsoo
That of the storie / writen worde ⁊ ende
How that these greet Conquerours twoo
Fortune was firste frende ⁊and sith a foo
Noman ne truste vpon hire fauour longe
But haue hire in a waite for eủer moo
Witnesse on alle these conquerours stronge
Cresus
¶ This riche Cresus · whilom kyng of lyde
Of whiche Cresus · Cirus soore hym dradde
Yet was he caught amyddes alle his pride
And to be brende men to the fire hym ladde
But swiche a rayn̄ doun fro the welken shadde
That slow the fuyr · ⁊and made hym to escape
But to be ware · no grace yet he hadde
Til fortune · on the galwes made hym gape
¶ Whan he eschaped was / he kan nat stente
Forto bygynne a newe werre a gayn̄
He wende wele for that fortune hym sente
Swiche happe that he escaped thurgh the rayn̄
That of his foos he myght nat be slayn
And eke a sweuen vpon̄ a nyght / he mette
Of whiche he was // proude ⁊and eke so fayn
That in vengeaunce he alle his herte sette
¶ Vpon̄ a tree he was as that hym thoughte
Ther Iuppit̉er hym wesshe bothe bakke ⁊and side
And Phebꝫus eke a faire to wail hym broughte
To drye hym with / and therfore waxe his pride
And to his doughter þᵗat stood hym byside
Whiche that he knewe · in heigh sentence habounde
He bade hire telle hym what it signified
And she his dreem / bygan right thus expounde
¶ The tree qduod shee / the galwes is to mene
And Iuppiter bitokeneth snow ⁊and reyn
And Phebꝫus wit his towail so clene
Tho ben the sonnes stremes for to seyn
Thow shalte an honged be fader certeyn
Rayn̄ shall the waisshe · ⁊and sonne shall the drie
Thus warned hym · full plat ⁊and full pleyn
His doughter · whiche that was Phanye
¶ An · hanged was Cresus the proude kynge
His Roial trone myght hym nat auaile
Tragedies noon oother maner thynge
Ne kan in syngyng crie ne bywaile
But that fortune alway wole assaille
With vnwar strook the regnes that ben proude
For whan men trusteth hire · than̄ wole she faile
And kouere hire bright face with a clowde
De Petro Ispaun̉er
¶ O noble o worthy Petro / glorie of Spaigne
Whom fortune helde so heigh in mageste
Wele oughten men thy pitous deth complayne
Oute of thy lande thy brother made the flee
And aftir that a sige by subtilite
Thow were bitraised ⁊and ladde vnto his tente
Where as he with his owen honde . slow the
Succedynge in thyn reigne ⁊and in thyn rente
¶ The feeld of snowe / wtith thegle of blak ther Inne
Caught . wtith the lymrod / coloured as the glede
He brewe this cursidnesse / ⁊and alle this synne
The wikked neste / was werkere of this nede
Nought Charles . Olyuere that toke ay hede
Of trouthe ⁊and honour but Armoryke
Genylon . Olyuere . corrupte for mede
Brought this worthy kynge in swiche a brike
De Petro de Cipre
¶ O worthy Petro . kynge of Cipre also
That Alisaunder wan by hie maistrye
Full many an hethen . wroughtest þu ful woo
Of whiche thyn owen liges hadde enuye
And for no thynge / but for thy chiualrie
They in thy bedde / han slayn the by the morwe
Thus kan fortune hire whele gouerne ⁊and gye
And oute of Ioye brynge men to sorwe
De Barnabo
¶ Of Melan / grete Barnabo viscounte
God of delyt ⁊and scourge of lumbardie
Why sholde I not thyn Infortune acounte
Sith in estaat thow clombe were so hye
Thy brother sone . that was thy double allie
For he thy nevewe was ⁊and sone in lawe
With Inne his prison made the to die
But why ne how / noot I . þtat þu were slawe
¶ Of the Erle hugelyn of Pize the langoure
Ther may no tunge tellen for pite
But litel oute of Pize stant a toure
In whiche toure in prison putte was hee
And with hym ben his litel children three
The eldeste scarsly fyve yere was of age
Allas fortune it was grete Cruelte
Swiche briddes to putte in swiche a cage
¶ Dampned was he to deye in that prisoun
For Roger whiche that bisshop was of pize
Hadde on hym made a fals suggestion
Thurgh whiche the peple gan vpon hym ryse
And putten hym / to Prisoun in swiche wise
As ye han herde · ⁊and mete ⁊and drynke he hadde
So smal · that wele vnneth it may suffise
And ther withal / it was ful pore ⁊and badde
¶ And on a day byfel / that in that houre
Whan that his mete wonte was to be brought
The Gailler shette the dores of the toure
He herde it wele · but he spake right nought
And in his herte anon̄ ther felle a thought
That they for hunger · wolde doon hym deyen
Allas qduod he · allas that I was wrought
Ther with the teeris fillen from his eighen
¶ Hise yonge sone that three yere was of age
Vnto hym seide · Fader · Fader · why do ye wepe
Whan̄ wole the Gailler brynge oure potage
Ys there no mosel brede that yee do kepe
I am so hungry that I may not slepe
Now wolde god that I myghte slepe euere
Thann̄e shulde not hunger in my wombe crepe
Ther is no thynge but breed that me were leuere
¶ Thus day by day the childe bygan to crie
Til on his Fadres barme · a doun it lay
And seide fare wele Fader I moot dye
And kiste his Fader · ⁊and deyde the same day
And whan the woofull Fader deed it say
For woo his armes two he gan to bite
And seide allas fortune ⁊and weylaway
Thy fals whele · my woo al may I wite
¶ His children wende that it for hunger was
That he hise armes gnowe ⁊and nat for woo
And seiden Fader · do nat so allas
But rather ete the fleisshe vpon vs twoo
Oure fleisshe thow yafe · take oure fleisshe vs froo
And eete ynow / right thus they to hym seyde
And aftir that with ynne a day or twoo
They leyde hem in his lappe a doun ⁊and deyde
¶ Hym selfe despeyred eke for hunger starfe
Thus ended is this myghty Erle of Pize
From heigh estaat fortune a way hym carfe
Of this tragedie it oughte ynough suffise
Who so wole here it in a lenger wyse
Redeth the grete Poet of Itaille
That hight Dant for he kan it all deuyse
Fro poynt to poynt · nat o worde wole he faile

l.hi: Here the knyght stynteth the Monke of his tale
Here the knyght stynteth the Monke of his tale

div.l: HO qduod oure oste good sire nomore of this
That ye han seide is right ynow I wys
And more for litel heuynesse
Is right ynow to moche folke I gesse
I say for me it is a greet disease
Where as men han ben in greet welthe ⁊and ease
To here of hire sodeyn falle allas
And the contrarie is ioye ⁊and grete solace
As whan a man hath ben in poure astate
And clymbeth vp ⁊and wexeth fortunate
And there abideth in prosꝑperite
Soche thynge is gladsom as thynketh me
And of soche thynge were goodly for to telle
I se qduod oure ooste by seint Poules belle
Ye sey right soth / this Monke he crieth loude
He spake how fortune coủered with a cloude
I note neủer what ⁊and also of tregedie
Right now ye herde and parde no remedie
Yt is for to be waillen / ne compleyne
That þᵗat is doon / and also it is a peyne
As ye haue seide to here of heuynesse
Sir Monke nomore of this so god yow blesse
Youre tale anoieth al this cōmpanye
Soche thynge is nat worth a boter flye
For there in there is disporte ne game
Where fore sire Monke ·O· daun Piers by youre name
I prey yow hertely telle vs somwhat ellys
For sikirly ne clynkynge of youre bellys
That on youre bridel hange · on eủery syde
By heuene kynge · that for vs alle deyde
I shulde er this · haue fallen doun for slepe
Al though the slowe / hadde neủer ben so deepe
Thanne hadde youre tale / al be tolde in veyne
For certeynly as that these clerkis seyne
Where as a man may haue non audience
Nought helpeth it · to tellen his sentence
And wele I woot the substaunce is in me
Yf any thynge shall wele reported be
Sire sey somwhat of huntynge I yow preye
¶ Nay qduod this Monke · I haue no luste to pleye
Now late a nother telle as I haue tolde
Than spake oure hoost · with rude speche ⁊and bolde
And seide vnto the Nonnes preest anoon
Com neer thow preest · come hider þᵘ sir Iohn
Telle vs swiche thynge · as may oure hertes glade
Be blithe · thow þᵘ ride vpon a Iade
What thow thyn hors · be bothe foule ⁊and lene
Yf he wole serue the · rekke nat a bene
Loke þᵗat thyn herte be merie eủer moo
Yis sir qduod he yis so mote I goo
But I be merie · I wole be blamed
And right a noon his tale he hath attamed
And thus he seide · vnto vs eủerychon
This swete preest this goodly man sir Iohn

hi.hi: Here bygynneth the Nonnes prestes tale

div.l: A Pore widowe somdele stape in age
Was whilom dwellyng in a narwe a cotage
Bysyde a groue stondynge in a dale
This widwe of whiche I telle yow my tale
Syn thilke day that she was laste a wyfe
In pacience ladde a full sympul lyfe
For litel was hire catel / ⁊and here rente
By housbondrye / of whiche as god hire sente
Shee fonde hire selfe ⁊and eke hire doughtren twoo
Thre large sowes hadde she ⁊and nomoo
Thre kyne ⁊and eke a sheep that hight Malle
Full sooty was hire boure · ⁊and eke hire halle
In whiche she eete full many a sklender mele
Of poynaunt sawce · hire neded neủer a dele
Noo deynte Morsel · passed thurgh hire throte
Hire diete was accordaunt to hire cote
Repleccion ne made hire neủer syke
A tempre diete was al hire Phisike
And excercise / and hertes suffisaunce
The gowte lette hire no thynge for to daunce
Napoplexie · shent nat hire heed
No wyn̄ ne dranke she neither white ne reed
Hire boord was serued moste with white ⁊and blakke
Melke ⁊and broun breed in whiche she foond no lakke
Seynd bacoun ⁊and somtyme an ey or tweye
For she was as it were a maner deye
A yerde she hadde enclosed al aboute
With stikkes . and a drie diche with oute
In whiche she hadde a Cokke heet Chauntecleere
In alle the londe . of crowyng nas his pere
His voys was Mirier than the myrye orgon
On Masse dayes / that in chirche goon
Wele sikerer was his crowyng in his logge
Thanne is a clokke . or any Abbey Orlogge
By nature he crewe eche assencioun
Of the equinoxial in thilke toun
For whan degrees xv . were ascended
Than crewe he / that it myght nat ben amended
His Combe was redder . than the fyn coralle
And batailled as it were a castel walle
His bile was blakke . and as þe Ieet it shoon
Lyke Asure were his legges . and his toon
His nailles whiter than þe lilie floure
And like the burned golde was his coloure
This gentil cok hadde in his goủernaunce
Seuene hennes for to doon all his plesaunce

¶ Oon of the grettest Auctor that men rede

And so byfel · that longe er it were day

And seide allas · for in an Oxes stalle

¶ And certes in the same boke I rede

Madame ꝐPertelote · my worldis blys

¶ And so bifel as he caste his eye
A monge the wortes / on a Boterflye

For naturelly · a beest desireth flee
Fro his contrarie if he may it see

This Chauntecleer · whan he gan hym espye
