So hidous was the noyse / a benedicite
Certes he Iakke strawe . ⁊and his meynee
Ne made neuꝰer showtes halfe so shrille
Whan that they wolden any flemyng kylle
As thilke day / was made vpon the Foxe
Of bras they broughten bemys / ⁊and of boxe
Of horn of boon in whiche they blewe ⁊and powped
And ther with al . they skryked ⁊and they houped
Yt semed as that heuen sholde falle
Now good men I pray yow herkeneth alle
Lo how fortune torneth sodeynly
The hope ⁊and pride eke of hir Enemy
This Cok that lay vpon the foxes bak
In alle his drede . vnto the fox he spak
And seide sire if that I were as ye
Yet wolde I seyn as wis god helpe me
Turneth a gayn . ye proude cherles alle
A verrey pestilence vpon yow falle
Now am I come vnto the wodes syde
Maugre youre heed / þe cok shal here abide
I wole hym ete I feith ⁊and that a noon
¶ The Foxe answered I feith it shall be doon
And as he spak that worde / al sodeynly
This Cokke brake from his mouthe delyuerly
And hye vpon a tree he flye a noon
And whan the Fox sey that he was goon
Allas qduod he · o · Chaunteclere allas
I haue to yow qduod he / y doon trespas
In as myche as I maked yow a ferde
Whan I yow hente ⁊and brought in to þˢ yerde
But sire I dede it · in no wicke entente
Come doun ⁊and I shalle telle yow what I mente
I shall sey sooth to yow / god helpe me so
¶ Nay thanne qduod he I shrewe vs bothe two
And firste I shrewe my selfe booth blood ⁊and bones
If þᵘ bygyle me / any ofter than** ones
Thow shalte namore / thorugh thy flaterie
Do me so synge / ⁊and wynke wᵗith myn ye
For he that wynketh whan** he sholde y see
Al wylfully god lete hym neủer y thee
Nay qduod the Foxe · but god yef hym myschaunce
That is so vndiscrete of gouernaunce
That Iangleth whan he sholde holde his pees
Lo swiche it is for to be recchelees
And necligent ⁊and truste on flaterye
But ye that helden this tale a folye
As of a Foxe or of a Cok / or hen
Taketh the moralite good men
For seint Poule seith · that al that writen is
To oure doctryne · it is y write y wys
Taketh the fruyt · ⁊and late the chafe be stille
Now good god if that it be thy wille
As seith my lorde so make vs alle good men
And brynge vs to his blysse amen
¶ Sire nonnes preest oure hoost seyde a none
Y blessed be thy breth ⁊and eủery stoone
This was a mery tale of Chaunteclere
But be my trouthe if þᵘ were seculere
Thow woldeste bene a tredefoul a right
For if thow haue corage as þᵘ haste myght
The were nede of hennes as I wene
Ye moo than** ·vij· tymes seventene
See whiche braunnes hath þˢ gentel preeste
So grete a nekke ⁊and so large a breeste
He loketh as a Sparhauke with his yen
Hym nedeth nat his colour for to dyen
With Brasile ne with Greyne of Portyngale /
Now sire faire falle yow for youre tale
And aftir he with full mery chere
Saide vnto a nother as ye shulle here
Here is ended the Nonnes prestes tale
And folowith the ꝓprologe of the Maunciples tale
W Oot ye nat where ther stante a litel toun
Whiche that cleped is · Bobbe vp ⁊and down
Vnder the blee · in Caunterbury weye
There gan oure ooste for to Iape ⁊and pleye
And seide sires / what don is in þᵉ Myre
Is there no man · for preiere ne for hire
That wole a wake oure felawe al byhynde
A theef myght hym · ful lightly robbe ⁊and bynde
See how he nappeth · se how for cokkys bones
That he wole falle / fro his hors atones
Is that a Cook of london / with meschaunce
Do hym come forth he knowith his penaunce
For he shalle telle a tale be myfeye
Al though it be nat woorth a botel heye
A wake thow Cook qduod he · god yeue the sorwe
What eyleth the to slepe by the morwe
Hastow hadde fleen al nyght / or artow dronke
Or hastow with som quene al nyght y swonke
So that thow maiste nat holden vp thyn heed
¶ This Cooke that was full pale ⁊and no thynge reed
Seide to oure ooste · so godde my soule blesse
As ther is falle on me swyche heuynesse
Noot I nat why · that me were leuer slepe
Than the beste galon wyn in chepe
Wele qduod the Maunciple if it may don** eese
To the sire Cook · ⁊and to no wight displese
Whiche that here rideth in þˢ companye
And that oure ooste wole of his curtesie
I wole as nowe excuse the of thy tale
For in good feith thy visage is full Pale
Thyn eyen daswen eke · as that me thynketh
(base) And wele I woot thy breeth ful soure stynketh
(base) That sheweth wele . thow art nat wele disposed
(base) Of me certeyne thow shalt nat ben y glosed
(base) Se how he ganeth . lo this dronken wighte
(base) As thow he wolde swolwe vs a noon righte
(base) Hoold cloos thy mouth man . by thy fader kyn
(base) The deuel of helle / sette foot ther yn
(base) Thy cursed breeth / infecte wole vs alle
(base) Fy stykynge swyn / fy foule mote the falle
(base) A taketh hede sires of this lusty man
(base) Now swete sere wole ye Iusten atte fan
(base) Ther to me thenketh ye ben wele y shape
(base) I trow yt ye dronken han wyn ape
(base) And that is whan men pleyen with a strawe
(base) And with his speche . the Cook waxe wrooth ⁊ wrawe
(base) And on the Manciple . he gan nodde faste
(base) For lakke of speche / ⁊ doun the hors hym caste
(base) Where as he lay / til that men vp hym tooke
(base) This was a faire chiuache of a cooke
(base) Allas he nad holde hym by his ladel
(base) And er that he agayn were in his sadel
(base) Ther was grete showuynge bothe two ⁊ froo
(base) To lyfte hym vp . and mychel care ⁊ woo
(base) So vnweldy was this sory palled goost
(base) And to the Manciple than spake oure oost
(base) ¶ By cause drynke hath dominacion
(base) Vpon this man / by my sauacion
(base) I trowe he lewedly telle wole his tale
(base) For were it wyn or olde mosty ale
(base) That he hath dronke / he speketh in his nose
(base) And fnesith faste / ⁊ eke he hath the pose
(base) He hath also to do / more than I nowe
(base) To kepe hym and hys capul owte of the slowe
(base) And if he falle from his capul efte sone
(base) Thanne shalle we alle haue ynow to done
(base) In lyftynge vp his heuy dronken corps
(base) Telle on thi tale / of hym make I no fors
But yet Manciple in feith thow arte to nyce
Thus openly reproue hym of his vice
A nother day he wole ꝑperauenture
Reclayme the ⁊and brynge þᵉ to lure
I mene he speke wole of smale thynges
As for to pynchen / at thy rekenynges
That were nat honeste if it cam to preef
¶ Noo qduod the Manciple that were a greet meschief
So myght he lightly brynge me in the snare
Yet hadde I lefere payen for the Mare
Whiche that he rit on / thanne he sholde wᵗith me stryue
I wole nat wratthe hym · also mote I thryue
That þᵗat I spake · I seide it in my bourde
And wyte ye what I haue here in a gourde
A draught of wyn / ye of a ripe grape
And right anoon / ye shuln seen right a good Iape
This Cook shall drynke ther of if I may
Vppeyne of deeth · he wole nat sey me nay
And certeynly to tellen as it was
Of this vessel / the Cook dranke faste allas
What neded it he dranke ynowh byforn
And whan he hadde powped in this horn
To the Maunciple he toke the gourde agayn
And of that drynke the Cook was wonder fayn
And thanked hym swiche wise as he coude
Than gan oure ooste to lawhen wonder lowde
And seyde I see wele · it is necessarie
Where that we goon / good drynke we wᵗith vs carye
For that wole torne rancour ⁊and disese
To acoord ⁊and loue · ⁊and many a wronge apese
O bachus y blissed be thy name
That so kanste turnen ernest in to game
Worshep ⁊and thanke be to thy deite
Of that matere ye gete nomore for me
Telle on thy tale / Manciple I the prey
Wele sire qduod he / now herkeneth what I sey
Explicit ꝓprophemiūm
Here bygynnyth the manciples / tale of the Crowe
Whan Phebus dwelled here in this erthe adown
As olde bokes maken mencioun
He was the moost lusty bachilere
In alle this worlde · ⁊ eke the beste Archere
He slowe Phyton the serpent as he lay
Slepynge a gayn the sonne . vpon a day
And many a nother noble worthy dede
He with his bowe wrought . as men may rede
Pley en he cowde . on eủery mynstralcye
And syngen / that it was a melodye
To heren / of his clere voys the soun
Certes the kynge / of thebes Amphyoun
That with hys syngyng walled that Cite
Koude neủer syngen / halfe so wele as he
Ther to he was the semelyest man
That is or was / sith that the worlde bygan
What nedeth it his fetures to descryue
For in this worlde was noon so faire on lyue
He was ther with fulfilled of gentilesse
Of honoure ⁊ of ꝑperfite worthynesse
This Phebus that was floure of bachilrye
As wele in fredom / as in cheualrye
For his disporte in signe of victorie
Of Phiton so as telleth vs the storie
Was wonte to beren in his hande a bowe
Now hadde this Phebꝫus in his hows a crowe
Whiche in a Cage he fostred many a day
And taughte it speke · as men teche a Iay
White was this crowe · as is a snowe whit swan
And countre feted the speche of eủery man
He coude whenne he sholde telle a tale
Therwith / in al this worlde no nyghtyngale
Ne koude by an hundred thousand dele
Syngen so wonder muryly ⁊ wele
Now hadde this Phebꝫus in his hous a wyf
Whiche that he loued more than his lyf
And nyght ⁊ day dide eủer his diligence
Hire for to plese . ⁊ doon hire reủerence
Safe only / this is the soth that I shall sayn
Ialous he was / ⁊ wolde haue kepte hire fayn
For hym were looth / byiaped for to be
And so is eủery wight in swiche degre
But al fornought for it availleth nought
A good wife that is clene / in werke ⁊ thought
Shulde nat ben kepte in noon a waite certayn
And trewely / the labour is in veayn
To kepe a shrewe / For it wole noght be
This holde I for a verry nycete
To spille labour for to kepe wyues
Thus writen / olde Clerkys in hire lyues
But now to purpos as I firste began
This worthy Phebz dooth al that he kan
To plesen hire wenynge for swiche plesaunce
And for his manhode ⁊ for his goủernaunce
That noman / sholde han put hym from hire grace
But god it wote · ther may no man enbrace
As to destreyne a thynge whiche that natur͗e
Hath naturelly sette in a creature
Take any bridde · ⁊ put it in a cage
And do al thyn entente · and thy corage
To fostre it tendrely with mete ⁊ drynke
Of alle deyntees that thow canste bythynke
And kepe it also clenly as thow may
Al thow his cage of golde / be neủer so gay
Yet hath this bridde / by twenty thowsand folde
Leuer in a foreste that is rude ⁊ colde
Goon ete wormes ⁊ swiche wrecchednesse /
For eủere this bridde wole doon his besynesse
To eschapen oute of his cage if he may
His liberte / this bridde desireth ay
Late take a Catte · ⁊ fostre hym wele with melke
And tendre fleisshe · ⁊ make his couche of selke
And late hym seen a Mous / goo by the walle
A noon he weyueth / melke fleisshe ⁊ alle
And eủery deynte that is in that hous
Swiche appetite hath he / to ete a Mous
Loo here hath luste his dominacion
And Appetite flemeth discrecion
A she wolfe hath also a vyleyns kynde
The lewediste wolfe / that she may fynde
Or leest of reputacioun / that wole she take
In tyme whan hire luste to haue a make
Alle these emsamples / speke I by these men
That ben vntrewe / but nothynge by wȳmmen
For men han eủere a likerous appetite
On lower thynge to ꝑperfourme her delyte
Than on hire wyues be they neủer so faire
Ne neủer so trewe / ne so debonaire
Fleisshe is so newefangel / wᵗith meschaunce
That we ne konne in no thynge han plesaunce
That sowneth in to vertue any while
This Phebus whiche that thoughte · vpon no gyle
Deceyued was / for alle his Iolytee
For vndir hym another hadde shee
A man of litel reputacioun
Nought worth to Phebus in comꝑperison
Ne more harme is / it happeth ofte so
Of whiche ther cometh mychel harme ⁊ woo
And so byfel whan Phebus was absent
His wife a noon / hath for hire leman sent
Hire leman ; certes this is a knauysshe speche
Foryeueth it me . and that I yow beseche
The wise Plato seith . as ye may rede
The worde moot nede acorde wᵗith þᵉ dede
If men shalle telle / ꝓproprely a thynge
The worde mote Cosyn be / to the werkynge
I am a boystous man right thus sey I
Ther nys no difference trewely
Bitwixe a wife that is of high degre
Yf of hire body dishonest she be
And a poure wenche oother than this
If it so be · they werke bothe amys
But that the gentile / in estate aboue
She shalle be clepid / his lady / as in loue
And for that other / is a pore woman
She shall be cleped his wenche or his leman
And god it woot myn owne dere brother
Men leyn that oon · as lowe as lith that other
Ryght so bytwixe a titlelees tiraunt
And an outlawe · or a theef erraunt
The same I seye · ther is no difference
To Alisaundre was tolde this sentence
That for the Tiraunt is of gretter myght
By force of meyne for to sleen doun right
And brennen hous ⁊ hoom / ⁊ make all pleyn
Loo therfore he is I cleped a capeteyn
And for the outlawe hath but smale meyne
And may nat doon so grete an harme as he
Ne brynge a cuntre to so grete myschiefe
Men clepen hym an outlawe or a thefe /
But for I am a man nought textuele
I wole not telle of textes neủer adele
I wile goo to my tale as I began
Whan Phebz wyfe hadde sent for her leman
A noon they wrought al her luste volage
The white Crowe / that henge ay in the cage
Bihelde her werke ⁊ seide neủer a worde
And whan that hoom was come Phebus the lorde
This Crowe songe Cokkowe Cokkow e Cokkowe
What bridde qᵈuod Phebus / what songe syngestowe
Ne were thow wonte so murely to synge
That to myn herte it was a reioysynge
To here thy voys / allas what songe is this
By god qᵈuod he I synge not amys
Phebus qᵈuod he . for all thy worthynesse
And for all thy beaute ⁊ gentillesse
For all thy songe ⁊ all thy mynstralcie
For all thy waytyng blered is thyn ye
With oon of litel reputacoıı̄un
Nought worth to the in comꝑperison
The mountaunce of a gnat so mote I thryue
For on thy bedde · I seigh hym · ⁊cꝰer
What wole ye more / the crowe anoon hym tolde
By sadde tokenys / and by wordes bolde
How that his wyfe / had doon hire lecherie
Hym to grete shame / ⁊ to grete vyleynye
And tolde hym how / ofte / he sey it with his eyen
This Phebus gan a waywarde for to wreyen
And thought his soroufull herte barste a two
His bowe he bente ⁊and sette ther in a floo
And in his Ire / his wyfe than hath he slayn
This is theffecte / ther is nomore to sayn
For sorwe of whiche · he brakke his mynstralcye
Bothe harpe ⁊and lute ⁊and gyterne ⁊and sautrye
And eke he brake his arwes ⁊and his bowe
And aftir that thus spake he to the crowe
¶ Traitour qduod he · with tunge of Scorpion
Thow haste me brought to my confusion
Allas that I was wrought / why nere I deed
O dere wyfe ·o· gemme of lustyhede
That were to me so sadde ⁊and eke so trewe
Now lystow deed · wᵗith face pale of hewe
Full gilteles that shdurst I swere I wys
O rakel hande / to doon so foule amys
O trouble witte ·o· Ire reccheles
That vn auysed / smytest gilteles
O whan truste full of fals suspecion
Where was thy witte ⁊andthi discrecion
O eủery man be ware of rakelnesse
Ne trowe no thynge wᵗith oute stronge witnesse
Smyte nat to sone / er that ye wyten why
And beth auysed wele ⁊and sobrely
Er ye doon any execucoıı̄un
Vpon youre Ire / for suspecioıı̄un
Allas a thowsand folke hath rakel Ire
Fully fordoon / or brought hem in the myre
Allas for sorwe / I wole my seluen slee
And to the crowe / o fals thefe seide he
I wole the quyte a noon thy fals tale /
Thow songe whilom / lyke a nyghtyngale
Now shaltow fals theef · thy songe forgoon
And eke thy white fetheris eủerychon
Ne neủere in alle thy lyfe ne shaltow speke /
Thus shall men on a traitour ben a wreke
Thow ⁊and thyn osprynge eủer shulle be blake
Ne neủer swete noyse shull ye make
But eủer crye / agayn tempeste ⁊and rayn
In tokenyng that thurgh the . my wyfe is slayn
And to the crowe he stirte / ⁊ that anoon
And pulled his white fetherys eủerychon
And made hym blakke ⁊ rafte hym alle hys songe
And eke his speche ⁊ oute atte dore hym slonge
Vnto the deuel whiche I hym betake
And for this cas ben al crowes blake /
¶ Lordynges be this ensample I yow prey
Beth ware ⁊ taketh kepe what that ye sey
Ne telleth neủer · noman in youre lyfe
How that a nother man hath dight his wife
He wole yow haten mortelly certeyn
Daun Salomon / as wise clerkes seyn
Techeth a man / to kepe his tunge wele
But as I seyde I nam nought textuele
But natheles / thus taught me my dame
My sone thynke on the Crowe · a goddis name
My sone kepe wele thy tonge · ⁊ kepe thy frende
A wikked tunge · is wors than a fende
My sone from a fende · men may hem blesse
My sone god of his endeles goodnesse

l.hi: Walleth a tunge / with teeth ⁊ lyppes eke
For man sholde hym auyse what he speke

div.l: My sone full ofte / for to moche speche
Hath many a man ben spilte · as clerkes teche
But for lytel speche auysely
Is noman shente to speke generally
My sone thy tunge sholdestow restreyne
At alle tymes / but whan þᵘ doost thy peyne
To speke of god / in honour ⁊ praiere
The first vertue sone / if thow wolt lere
Is to restreyne ⁊ kepe wele thy tunge
Thus lernen children / whan that they ben yonge
My sone of mochel spekyng yuele auysed
Ther lasse spekyng hadde y nough suffised
Cometh mochel harme / thus was me tolde ⁊ taught
In mochel speche / synne wanteth naught
Wostow where of / a rakel tunge serueth
Right as a swerde · forkutteth ⁊ forkerueth
An arme a two · my dere sone right so
A tunge kniteth frendshepe 'al a two
A Iangler is to god abhomynable
Reed Salomon so wise ⁊ honurable
Reede Dauid in his psalmes / rede Senek
My sone speke not but wᵗith thyn heed þᵘ bek
Dissimule as thow were deef yf that thow here
A Ianglere speke / of perilous matere /
The Flemyng seith / (⁊and lerne it if the leste)
That litel Ianglyng causeth mochel reste
My sone if thow no wikked worde haste seyde
The dar nat drede / forto be by wreyde
But he that hath mysseyde I dar wele seyn
He may be no wey clepen his worde a geyn
Thynge that is seyde · is seide / ⁊and forth it goth
Thow hym repente / or be hym leef or looth
He is his thral to whom that he hath sayde
A tale of whiche / he is now yuele apayde
My sone by ware / ⁊and be noon auctor newe
Of tydynges / wheither they ben fals or trewe

l.hi: Where so þᵘ come · amonges heyghe or lowe
Kepe wele thy tunge / and thynke vpon the crowe /

div.l: Here endeth the manciplis tale of the Crowe
Here bygynnyth the ꝓprologe of the Frankeleyn
Thise oolde gentil Britons · in hire dayes
Of dyuers auentures . maden laies
Rymeyed in hire firste Briton tunge
Whiche layes / wᵗith hire Instrumentz they sunge
Or elles redden hem . for hire plesaunce
And oon of hem haue I in remembraunce
Whiche I shall seyn with good wille as I kan
But sires by cause I am a burel man
At my bygynnyng first I yow beseke
Haue me excused of my rude speche
I lerned neủere . Rethorike certeyn
Thynge that I speke it moot be bare ⁊and pleyn
I slepe neủere in the Mounte of ꝐParnaso
Ne lerned neủer Marcus Tullius Sithero vn ꝐPerisiꝰus
Coloures ne knowe I none wᵗith outen drede
But swiche coloures as growen in the mede
Or ellys swiche as men dye or peynte
Coloures of Rethorik ben to queynte
My spirit feelith nat of swiche matere
But if yow lyste my tale shall ye here
Here bygynnyth the Frankeleyns tale
IN Armoryk that called is Bretayne
Ther was a knyght þᵗat loued ⁊and dede his payne
To serue a lady · in his beste wyse
As many a labour · many a greet emprise
He for his lady wrought · ere she were wonne
For she was the faireste vnder sonne
And eke therto · come of so hye kynrede
That wele vnnethe · dorste this knyghte for drede
Telle hire his woo · his peyne ⁊and his distresse
But at the laste · she for his worthynesse
And namely for his meke obeisaunce
Hath swiche a pite caught of his penaunce
That pⁱriuely · she felle of his accorde
To takin hym for hire housbande ⁊and hire lorde
Of swiche lordshep** · as men han of hire wyues
And for to lede the more in blisse · hire lyues
Of his fre wille he swoor hire as a knyght
That neủer in alle his lyue he day ne nyght
Ne sholde vppon hym take no maistrye
Agayn her wille ne kythe hire Ialousye
But hire obeye · ⁊and folwe here wille in alle
As any louer to his lady shalle
Saue that the name of soueraynte
That wolde he haue for shame of his degre
¶ She thonked hym · ⁊and with full grete humblesse
She seyde · sire · sith of youre gentillesse
Ye ꝓprofre me to haue so large areyne
Ne wolde neủer god · bitwix vs tweyne
As in my gilte · were outher werre or stryfe
Sire I wole be youre humble trewe wyfe
Haue here my trouthe / til that myn herte breste
Thus ben they bothe / in quyete ⁊and in reste
¶ For o thynge sires saufly dar I seyēn
That frendes / eủeryche other mote obeyēn
Yf they wole longe holden compaignye /
Loue wole nat be constrayned · by maistrie
Whan maistrie cometh · the god of loue anoon
Betith hise wynges · ⁊and farewele he is goon /
Loue is a thynge · as any spirit free
Wȳmmen of kynde desiren libertee
And nat to be constreyned as a thral
And so doon men yf I soth seyn shal
Loke who that moste is pacient in loue
He is at his auᵃntage al aboue
Pacience is an heighe v̉ertu certeyn
For it venquysseth · as these clerkys seyne
Thynges that rigour sholde neủer atteyne
For eủery worde · men may nat chide or pleyne
Lerneth to suffre · or elles so mote I goon
Ye shalle it lerne · where so ye wole or noon
For in this worlde · certeyn ther no wight is
That he ne dooth or seith som tyme amys
Ire / siknesse / or confusion
Wyn woo ·/ or chaungyng of compleccion
Causeth full ofte to doon amys or speken
On eủery wronge · a man may nat be wreken
After the tyme moste be temꝑperaunce
To eủery wight that can on goủernaunce
And therfore hath this wise worthy knyght
To lyue in eese · suffraunce hire behight
And she to hym · ful wisly gan to swere
That neủer sholde ther be · defaute in here
¶ Here may men seen · an humble wyse accorde
Thus hath she take hire ʆseruᵃnt ⁊and hire lorde
Seruᵃnt in loue · ⁊and lorde in mariage
Than was he bothe · in lordshepe ⁊and seruage
Seruage nay but in lordshepe al aboue
Sith he hath bothe his lady ⁊and his loue
His lady certes / and his wife also
To whiche that lawe of loue accordeth too
And whan he was in his ꝓprosꝑperite
Hoom with his wyfe he goth to his cuntre
Nought fer fro Pedmarke / ther his dwellyng was
Where as he lyueth in blisse ⁊and in solas /
Who coude telle but he hadde wedded be
The ioye theese · ⁊and the ꝓprosꝑperite
That is bitwixe hym · ⁊and hys wyfe
A yere ⁊and more lasteth this blysfull lyfe
Til that the knyght of whiche I speke of thus
That of kairrud · was cleped Arueragus
Shoop hym to goon · ⁊and dwelle aȝere or tweyne
In Engelond / that cleped was eke bretayne
To seke in armys worshepe ⁊and honour turne iiii lefes a bak to thys sygne there is a sign here
For alle his luste · he sette in swiche labour
And dwelle there twoo yere · the book seith thus there is a sign in the right margin
Now wole I stynten / of this Arueragus
And speke I wole of Dorigen hise wyf
That loueth hire housbonde / as hire hertes lyfe
For hise absence · wepeth she ⁊and siketh
As doon these noble wyues · whan hem lyketh
She mourneth / waketh / wailleth / fasteth / pleyneth
Desire of his p̉resence · hire so distreyneth
That al this wyde worlde / she sette at nought
Hire frendes whiche that knowe · hire heuy thought
Conforten hire · in all that eủer they may
They prechen hire · they telle hire nyght ⁊and day
That causeles she sleeth hir selfe allas
And eủery comfort possible in this cas
They doon to hire · with alle hire besynesse
Al for to make hire leue hire heuynesse
¶ By proces as ye knowen eủerychone
Men may so longe · grauen in a stoon
Til some figure · ther ynne empreynted be
So longe han they conforted hire til she
Receyued hath · by hope ⁊and by reson
The empryntynge / of hir consolacion
Thurgh whiche hire grete sorwe gan a swage
She may nat alway duren in swiche rage
¶ And eke Arueragus in alle this care
Hath sente hire łletres hom . of hise welfare
And that he wole come hastily agayn
Or ellys hadde this sorwe / hire herte slayn
¶ Hir frendes sawe · hire sorwe gan to slake
¶ And preide hire on knees . for goddes sake
To come ⁊and romen hire in companye
A way to dryue / hire derke fantasye
And fynally she grᵃunted that requeste
For wele she sawe that it was for the beste
¶ Now stode hire faste by the see
And often with here frendes walketh she
Hire to disporte · vpon the banke an heigh
Where as she . many a shippe ⁊and barge seigh
Seillyng hire cours / where as hem lyste to goo
But than was that a ꝑparcel of hire woo
For to hire selfe full ofte allas seith shee
Is there no shippe · of so many as I see
Wol bryngen hom my lorde / than were myn herte
Al warisshed · of hise bittre peynes smerte
A nother tyme · ther wolde she sitte ⁊and thynke
And caste hire eighen dounwarde fro the brynke
But whan she sey the grissely rokkes blake
For verray fere · so wolde hire herte quake
That on hire feet · she myght hire noght sustene
Than wolde she sitte a doun vpon the grene
And pitously in to the see byholde
And seyn right thus . wᵗith sorweful sikes coolde
¶ Eterne god that thurgh thy purueaunce
Ledest the worlde · by eterne goủernaunce
In ydel as men seyn · ye no thynge make
But lorde these grisly / feendly rokkes blake
That semen rather · a foule confusioıı̄un
Of werke · than any faire creacoıı̄un
Of swiche a ꝑparfite wyse god · ⁊and astable
Why han ye wrought · this werke vnresonable
For by this werke / South / North / ne Weste / ne Este /
Ther nys y fostred . ne man / ne bridde / ne beeste
It dooth no good to my witte but anoieth
Se ye nat lorde · how mankynde hit destroieth
An hundred thousand bodies of mankynde
Han rokkes slayn / al be they noght in mynde
Whiche mankynde is so faire a parte of thy werke
That thow it madest . lyke thyn owen merke
Than semed it · ye hadde a grete chierte
Towarde mankynde / but how than may it be
That ye swiche menes make · it to destroien
Whiche menes do no good but eủere anoyen
I wote wele clerkes wole seyn as hem lyste
By argumentz that al is for the beste
Thow I ne kan · the causes noght y knowe
But thilke god that made wynde to blowe
As kepe my lorde · this my conclusion
To clerkys lete I al disputison
But wolde god · that alle these rokkes blake
Weren sonken in to helle · for his sake
These Rokkes slen myn herte · for the fere
Thus she seith with many a pitous tere
Hire frendes saugh that it was no disport
To romen by the see · but discomfort
And shopen for to pleien · som where elles
They ledden hire by ryuers ⁊and by welles
And eke in othere places delitables
They dauncen / ⁊and they pleien at chesse ⁊and tables
So on a day · right in the morwe tyde
Vnto a gardeyn that was there bysyde
In whiche they hadde maoe theire ordenaunce
Of vitaille · ⁊and of other purueaunce
They goon ⁊and pley hem alle the longe day
And this was on the sixte morwe of may
Whiche may hadde peynted with his softe shoures
This gardyn full of leues ⁊and of floures
And crafte of mannys honde so coriously
Arraied hadde this gardyn trewely
That neủer was there gardyn of swiche pris
But if it were / the verrey paradys
The oudre of floures · ⁊and the freisshe sight
Wolde han maked any herte lyght
That euer was born but if to grete sikenesse
Or to grete sorwe helde it in distresse
So full it was of Beaute · with plesaunce
At aftir dyner · gonne they to daunce
And synge also / saue · Dorigen . allone
Whiche made alwey · hir compleynt . ⁊and hire mone
For she ne saugh hym · on daunce goo
That was hire housband ⁊and hire loue also
But natheles . she moste a tyme abyde
And with good hope · late hire sorwe slyde /
Vpon this daunce (· a monges other men)
Daunced a squier bifore Dorigen
That fressher was . ⁊and Iolyer of array
(As to my dome) than is the Monthe of May /
He syngeth / daunceth / passyng any man
That is . or was . sith the worlde bygan /
Ther with he was . if men shold / hym discryue
Oon of the beste / faryng man on lyue /
Yonge / stronge / right v̉ertuous . ⁊and riche ⁊and wys
And wele byloued · ⁊and holden in greet pris /
And shortly · if the soth I tellen shalle
Vnwitynge of this Dorigen · at al
This lusty squyer · seruᵃaunt vnto Venus
Whiche that y cleped was · Aurelyus
Hadde loued hire beste of any creature
Two yere ⁊and more · as was his auenture /
But neủer durste he tellen hire his greuᵃaunce
With outen coppe · he dranke all his penᵃaunce
He was dispeired · nothyng dorste he seye
Saue in his songes . somwhat wolde he wreye
His woo · as in a gentel compleynyng
He seyde he loued · ⁊and was biloued no thyng
Of whiche matere · made he many layes
Songes / compleyntes / roundels / virelaies /
How that he dorste nat his sorwe telle
But languyssheth · as a Fuyre doth in helle /
And deye he moste he seyde as dide Ekkoo
For Narcisus / that durst nat telle hire woo
In other manere than ye hure me seye
Ne durste he nat to hire his woo by wreye /
Saue that ꝑparauenture somtyme at daunces /
There yonge folke kepen hire obseruᵃaunces
It may wele be · he loked on hire face
In swyche awise · as man that asketh grace /
But nothyng wiste she · of his entente /
Natheles it happed · er they thennes wente
By cause that he was hire neghebour
And was a man of worshep ⁊and honour
And hadde y knowen hym · of tyme yore
They fille in speche ⁊and forth more ⁊and more
Vnto this pᵘurpos · drow Aurelius
And whan he saugh hys tyme he seide thus /
¶ Madame qduod he / by god that this worlde made
So that I wiste it myght youre herte glade
I wolde that day · that youre Arueragus
Wente oủer the see · that I Aurelius
Hadde went · ther neủer I shulde han come agayn /
For wele I woot my ʆseruyce is in vayn
My gerdon is · but brestynge of myn herte / turne ouer iiij lefes to thys sygne there is a sign here
Madame reweth vpon my paynes smerte
For with a worde · ye may me sleu or saue
Here at youre feet · god wolde that I were graue
I ne haue as now no leyser more to seye there is a sign in the right margin
Haue mercy swete or ye wol do me deye /
She gan to loke · vpon Aurelius /
Is this youre wille · qduod she ⁊and sey ye thus
Neủer erste qduod she / ne wiste I what ye mente /
But now Aurelie · I knowe youre entente /
Be thilke god that yaf me soule ⁊and lyfe
Ne shall I neủer be vntrewe a wyfe
In worde ne werke · as fer as I haue wit
I wole ben his to whom I am knyt
Take this for final answere · as of me /
But aftir that . in pleye · thus seyde she
¶ Aurelie qduod she · by heigh god aboue
Yet wolde I graunt yow to ben youre loue /
Syn I yow se so pitously complayne /
Loke what day · endelonge Brytayne
Ye remoue alle the Rokkes stoon by stoon
That they ne lette ship · ne boot to goon /
I sey whan ye / han made . the coste so clene
Of Rokkes that ther nys no stoon y sene /
Than wole I loue yow beste of any man /
Haue here my trouthe · in al that eủer I kan /
Is there noon other grace in yow qduod he 
No be that lorde qduod she · that maked me
For wele I woot that it shal neủer bitide /
Late swiche folies · oute of youre herte slyde
What deynte shulde a man han · in his lyfe
For to goo loue a nother mannys wyfe
That hath hire body · whan so that hym lyketh 
¶ Aurelius full ofte sore siketh
Wo was Aurelius whan that he this herde /
And with a sorwefull herte he thus answerde
Madame qduod he this were an Impossible /
Thanne mote I deye · of sodeyn deeth possible /
And with that worde · he turned hym anoon /
Tho comen hire other frendes many oon
And in the Aleys romeden vp ⁊and doun
And nothyng wiste of this conclusioun /
But sodenly begonne reuel newe
Til that the bright sonne · loste his hewe
For thorisonte · hath refte the sonne his lyght
This is as myche to sey · as it was nyght /
And hom̄ they goon in Ioy ⁊and in solas
Saue oonly · wrecched Aurelius . allas
He to his hous is goon sorwefull herte /
He seeth he may nat from his deeth asterte
He semed that he felte his herte colde /
Vp to the heuene / his hondes he gan holde
And on his knowes bare · he sette hym doun
And in his rauyng seide his orisoun
For verrey woo · oute of his witte he breide /
He nyste what he spake but thus he seyde /
With pitous herte · his pleynte hath he begonne
Vnto the goddys · ⁊and firste vnto the sonne /
¶ He seide Appollo god ⁊and gouernour
Of eủery plante / herbe / tre / ⁊and flour
That yeueth aftir thy declynacoıı̄un
To eche of hem his tyme / ⁊and his seson
As thyn herberwe chaungeth · lowe or heighe
Lorde Phebus caste thy m̉erciable eyghe
On wrecche Aurelie · whiche that am but lorn
Loo lorde my lady hath my deth y sworn
With outen gilte · but thy benygnyte
Vpon my dedly herte haue som pite /
For wele I woot lorde Phebus . if yow leste
Ye may me helpen (saue my lady) beste /
Now souche saufe · that I may yow deuyse
How that I may be holpen ⁊and in what wyse
Youre blissefull . Suster** lucina the shene
That of the see is chief goddesse ⁊and quene
Though Neptunus hath deite in the see
Yet Emꝑperour abouen hym is she
Ye knowen wele lorde · þᵗat right as hire desire
Is to be quyked ⁊and lyghted of youre fire
For whiche she folweth yow full bysely
Right soo the see · desireth naturely
To folwen hire · as she that is goddesse
Bothe in the see · ⁊and Ryuers more ⁊and lesse /
Wherfore lorde Phebus · this is my requeste
Do this miracle or do myn herte berste
That nowe nexte · at this opposicion
Whiche in the signe shal be of the leon
As prieth hire · so greet a flood to brynge
That fyf fadme · at the leste it oủer sprynge
The hyest rokke in Armorik Britayne
An late this flood endure yeris twayne
Than certes to my lady · may I seye
Holdeth youre heest . the rokkes ben a weye
Lorde Phebus · do this miracle for me .
Pray hire · shee goo . no faster cours than ye
I sey · preyeth youre Sister that she goo
No faster cours than ye · thise yeris two
Than shall ye ben euene at the fulle alway
And sprynge flood lasten · both nyght ⁊and day
And but she souche saufe · in swiche manere
To graunt me my souereyn lady dere
Pray hire to synken eủery rokke a doun
In to hire owne dirke regioun
Vnder the grounde · ther Pluto dwelleth ynne
Or neủer moo · shalle I my lady wynne
Thy temple in delphos wole I barefoot seke
Lorde Phebus se the teeres on my cheke
And of my peyne haue som̄ compassion
And with that in sorwe he fel adoun
And longe tyme he lay forth in a traunce /
His brother whiche that knewe of his penᵃaunce
Vp caught hym · ⁊and to bedde he hath hym brought
Dispeired in his turment . ⁊and this thought
Late I this wofull creature lye
Chese he for me wher͗e he wole lyue or dye /
¶ Arueragus with hele . ⁊and grete honour
As he that was . of Chiualrie the flour
Is comen hoom ⁊and other worthy men /
O blysful art thow now . thow Dorigen
That haste thy lusty husbond in thyn armes
That fresshe knyght that worthy man of armes
That loueth the . as his owne hertes lyf
No thynge lyste hym to ben ymaginatif
If any wight hadde spoke while he was oute
To hire of loue · he ne hadde of it no doute
He nought entendeth · to no swiche matere
But daunceth · Iusteth · maketh hire good chere
And thus in Ioye ⁊and blisse I lete hem dwelle
And of the sike Aurelius · wole I telle
In langour ⁊and in turment furyus
Twoo yere ⁊and more · lay wrecche Aurelius
Er any foot he myghte · on erthe goon
Ne comforte in this tyme hadde he noon
Saue of his brother · whiche that was a clerke
He knewe of all this woo · ⁊and al this werke
For to noon other creature certayn
Of this matere / he durste no thynge sayn
Vnder his breest he bare it more secre
Than eủer dide Panfilus for Galathe
His breest was hole wᵗatoute for to sene
But in his herte · ay was the arwe kene
And wele ye knowe · that of asursanure

l.hi: In surgerie is ꝑperilous the cure

div.l: But men myght touche the arwe or come therby
His brother weep · ⁊and wailed pryuely
Til atte laste he fille in remembraunce
That whiles he was at Orlyens in Fraunce
As yonge clerkes · that ben likerous
Seken in eủery halke · and eủery herne
Particuler sciences for to lerne
He hym remembred that vpon a day
At Orliens in stodie a book he say
Of magike naturel . whiche his felawe
That was that tyme · a bacheler of lawe
Al were he there to lerne a nother crafte
Hadde pⁱriuely vppon his daske y lafte
Whiche book spake myche . of the oꝑperacions
Towchyng the ·xxviii· mansions
That longeth to the Mone . ⁊and swiche folye
As in oure dayes is nat worth a flye
For holy chirche feith · in oure beleue turne iiii lefes bakward to thys sygnethere is a sign beside the marginalia
Ne suffreth noon illusion . vs to greue
And whan this book was in his remembraunce
Anon for Ioye his herte gan to daunce There is a sign in the right margin
And to hym selfe he seide pryuely
My brother shall be warisshed hastely
For I am siker that ther be sciences
By whiche men make · dyủerse apꝑparences
Swhiche as these subtile tregetours pley
For ofte at festes · haue I wele herd sey
That tregetours with ynne an halle large
Haue made come in . a water ⁊and a barge
And in the halle rowen vp ⁊and doun
Somtyme hath semed come · a Grym leoun
And somtyme floures · sprynge as in a mede
Somtyme a vyne · ⁊and grapes white ⁊and rede
Somtyme a castel . al of lyme ⁊and stoon
And whan hym lyked voided it anoon
Thus semed it to eủery mannꝭes sight
Now than conclude I thus · þᵗat if I myght
At Orliens . som olde felawe fynde
That hadde · this Mones mansions in mynde
Or other magik naturel aboue
He sholde wele make my brother hane his loue
For with an apꝑparence · a clerke may . make
To mannꝭes sight . that alle the rokkes blake
Of Britayne . were y voided eủerychone
And shippes bi the brynke come ⁊and gone
And in swiche fourme endure a day or two
Than were my brother warisshed of his woo
Thanne moste she nedes . holden hire byheste
Or ellys he shall shame hire at þᵉ leste /
What sholde I make a lenger tale of thys
Vnto his brotherꝭes bedde he comen is
And swiche comfort he yaf hym for to goon
To Orliens . that he vp sterte anoon
And on his way forthwarde · thanne is he fare
In hope for to been lissed of his care /
Whan they were comen almost to that Cite
But if it were · a twoo furlonge or three
A yonge clerke romyng by hym selfe they mette
Whiche that in latyn · thriftely hem grette
And aftir that he seyde a wonder thynge
I knowe qduod** he · the cause of youre cōmmynge
And er͗e they ferther · any foot wente
He toolde hem · al that was in hire entente /
This Briton Clerke hym asked of felawes
The whiche that he hadde knowe in olde dawes /
And he answerde hym · that they deed were
For whiche he weep full ofte many a tere /
Doun of his hors . Aurelius light a noon
And with this Magicien forth he is goon
Hoom to his hous · ⁊and maden hem wele at teese
Hem lakked no vitaille · that myght hem pleese
So wele arraied hous · as there was oon
Aurelius in his lyfe · saugh . neủer noon
He shewed hym · er he wente to sopere
Forestes / Parkes / full of wilde dere
Ther sawe he hertis with hire hornes hye
The gretteste that eủer were seyn wyth ye
He sawe of hem · an hundred y slayn with houndes
And some with arwes blede · of bitter woundes
¶ He saugh when voided were · the wilde deer
Thise Fauconer**s vpon a faire ryuer
That with hire haukes · han the heyron slayn /
Tho saughe he knyghtes Iustynge in a playn
And aftir this he dide hym swiche plesaunce
That hs hym shewed his lady on a daunce
On whiche hym selfe he daunsed as hym thought
And whan this maister · that this magik wrought
Saugh it was tyme · he clapte his handes two
And fare wele . al oure reuel was a goo
And remoued they neủere **oute of the hous
Til they saugh · at this sight m̉erueillous
But in his studie · ther as his bokes be
They seten stille · ⁊and no wight thay thre
To hym this maister · called his squyer
And seide hym thus · is redy oure soper 
Almoste an houre it is I vndirtake
Sith I yow bade · oure soper for to make
Whan that thise worthy men · wenten with me
In to my studie · there as my bokes be /
Sire qduod this squyer whan that it liketh yow
It is all redy · thogh ye wole right nowe /
Gowe thanne soupe qduod he · as for the beste /
Thise Amorouse folke somtyme · mote hane reste /
At aftir soper fille they in trete
What sōmme · sholde this maistres gerdon be
To remouen alle these Rokkes of Britayne
And eke from Gerounde · to the Mouth of Sayne /
He made hitte straunge · ⁊and swoor so god hym saue
Lasse than a thousand pounde · wolde he nat haue /
Ne gladly for that som he wolde nat goon /
Aurelius with blisful herte anoon
Answerde thus · fy on a thousand pounde
This wide worlde · whiche that men sey is rounde
I wolde it yeue . if I were lorde of it /
This bargayn is full dryue · for we bēn knyt
Ye shall be paied trewely · by my trouthe
But loketh now for no necligence or slouthe
Ye tarie vs here no lenger than to morwe /
Nay qduod this clerk · haue here my feith to borwe /
To bedde is goon Aurelius · whan hym leste
And wele al that nyght he hadde his reste
What for his labour · ⁊and his hope of blysse
His wofull herte of penᵃaunce hadde a lisse /
Vpon the morwe · whan that it was day
To Britayne toke they the right way
Aurelius · and this Magicen biside
And ben descended ther they wolde abyde
And this was . as these bokes me remembre
The colde frosty seson of Decembre /
Phebus waxe olde · and hewid like laton
That in his hoot declinacion
Shoon as the burned gold wᵗith stremes bright
But now in Capricorn . a doun he lyght
Where as he shoon full Pale I dar wele seyn /
The bittre frostes . with the sleet ⁊and reyn
Destruyed han · the grene in eủery yerde **
Ianus sytte by the fyr · with double berde
And drynketh of his bugle horn the wyn /
Byforn hym stante brawen / of the tusked swyn /
And nowel crieth eủery lusty man /
Aurelius in all that eủer he kan
Dooth to his maister · chere ⁊and reuerence
And preieth hym to doon his diligence
To bryngen hym · oute of his peynes smerte /
Or with a swerde that he wolde slitte his herte
¶ This subtil clerke · swiche routhe hadde of this man
That nyght ⁊and day he sped hym that he kan
To wayte a tyme · of his conclusioıı̄un
This is to seyn · to make illusioıı̄un
By swiche an apꝑparence · or Iogelrye /
(I ne kan no termes of Astrologye)
That she and eủery wight sholde wende ⁊and sey
That of Britayne · the Rokkes were a wey
Or elles they were sonken vnder grounde /
Soo at the laste · he hath his tyme y founde
To maken his Iapes · and his wrecchidnesse
Of swiche a suꝑpersticious corsidnesse
Hise tables tolletanes forth he broght
Full wele corrected · ne ther lakked noght
Neither his collect . ne his expans yeris
Ne hise rootes · ne hise other geres
As ben hise centres · and hise argumentz
And hise ꝓproporcionels conuenientz
For hise equacions · and eủery thynge
And by hise ·8· speere in his werkynge
He knewe full wele · how fer · Alnath was shoue
Froo the heed of thilke fixe Aries aboue
That in the .9. spere considered is /
Full subtilly he kalculed al this /
Whan he hadde founde his firste mancion
He knewe the remenᵃaunt be ꝓproporcoıı̄un
And knewe the arysynge of his Moone wele
And in whoos ⁊and terme / and eueridele
And knewe full wele · þᵉ Moones mansioun
Acordaunt to his oparacioun turne ouer ii lefes to thys sygnethere is a sign beside the marginalia
And knewe also his othere obseruaunces there is a sign in the margin
For swiche illusions ⁊and swyche myschaunces
As hethen folke · vseden in thilke dayes
For swyche no lenger maketh he no delaies
But thurgh his magik for a wike or tweye
Yt semed that alle the rokkes were a weye /
Aurelius whiche that yet despeired of thys
Where he shall · han his loue . or fare amys
A waiteth nyght ⁊and day on** this miracle
And whan he knewe · that ther was non obstacle
That voided were these rokkes eủerychon
Doun to his maistres feet · he fel a noon
And seide · I woofull wrecche Aurelius
Thonke yow lorde ⁊and lady myn Venus
That me han holpen fro my cares colde
And to the temple · his wey forth hath he holde
Where as he knewe · he sholde his lady see
And whanne he saugh his tyme · a noon right he
With dredfull herte ⁊and with humble chere
Salewed hath · his souereyn lady dere /
My right lady · qduod this woofull man
Whan I moost drede ⁊and loue · as I best can
And lothest were · of all this world displese
Nere it that I for yow haue swiche disese
That I moste deyen here · at youre foot anoon
Noght wolde I telle · how me is woo bigoon
But certes outher moste I deye or pleyne
Ye slee me gilteles for verray payne
But of my deth · though that ye haue noo routhe
Auyseth yow · er that ye breke youre trouthe
Repenteth yow for thilke god a boue
Er ye me sleen . by cause that I yow loue
For madame wele yow woot what ye han hight
Nat that I chalenge any thynge of right
Of yow my soủereigne lady · but youre grace
But in gardyn · but in a gardyn · yond at siche a place
Ye woot right wele · what ye behighten me
And myn honde youre treuthe plighten ye
To louen me beste · god woot ye seide so
Al be that I . vnworthy am ther to
Madame I speke it for the honour of yow
More thanne to saue myn hertis lyfe right now
I haue do so as ye cōmmaunded me
And if ye vouche safe ye may goo see
Dooth as yow lyste haue youre heste in mynde
For quyk or deed · right there ye shall me fynde
In yow lieth alle to do me lyue or dey
But wele I woot the rokkes ben a weye /
He taketh his leue · ⁊and she astoned stood
In alle hire face nas a drope of blood
She wende neủer haue come in swiche a trappe /
Allas qduod she · that eủer this sholde happe
For I wende neủer be possibilite
That swiche a monstre or meruaille myght be
It is agayns the ꝓprocesse of nature
And hoom she she gooth · a sorwefull creature
For verrey fere vnnethe may she goo
She wepeth wailleth · al day or two
And swowneth · that it routh was to see
But why it was · to no wight tolde shee
For oute of towne was goon̄ Arueragus
But to hire selfe / she spake ⁊and seide thus
With face pale · ⁊and with ful soroweful chere
In hire compleint · as ye shull aftir here /
Allas qduod she · on the fortune I pleyne
That vnware haste me wrapped in thy cheyne
Fro whiche tescape · woot I no socour
Saue only deth · or elles dishonour
Oone of these two · behoueth me to chese
But natheles · yet haue I leuer to lese
My life than of my body haue a shame
Or knowe my seluen fals · or lese my name
And with my deth may I be quytte I wys /
Hath ther nat many a noble wyfe or this
And many a maide · y slayn her selue allas
Rather than with hire body / doon trespas 
Yis certes . loo these stories beren witnesse
Whan̄ thritty tirauntes ful of cursednesse
Hadde slayn Phidon . in Athenes at the feste
They cōmmaunded his doughtren fortareste
And bryngen hem byforn hem in despite
All naked to fulfille her foule delite
And in her fadres blood they made hem daunce
Vpon the pauement god yeue hem myschaunce
For whiche these woofull maidens full of drede
Rather than they wolde lese hire maidenhede
They pⁱriuely ben sterte into a welle
And dreynte hem seluen as the bokes telle /
¶ They of Mecene . leet enquere ⁊and seke
Of lacedomye · fifty maydons eke
On whiche they · wolden doon hire leccherie
But was ther noon · of all that compaignye
That she nas slayn · and with a good entente
Chese rather for to dey than assente
To ben oppressed · of hire maidenhede /
Why sholde I thanne / to deyen ben in drede 
¶ Loo eke the tiraunt . Aristoclides
That loued a maiden · heet Stymphalides
Whan that hire fader · slayn was on a nyght
Vnto Dyanes temple . goth she right
And hente the Image in hire hondes two
Fro whiche ymage wolde she neủer goo /
No wight ne myght hire hondes of it arrace
Til she was slayn . right in the selue place /
Now sith that maidons · hadden swiche despite
To ben defouled · with mannys foule delyte /
Wele oughte a wyfe rather hire seluen slee /
Than ben defouled /· as it thynketh me /
¶ What shall I sayn · of hasdrubales wyfe
That at Cartage · birafte hire selue hire lyfe 
For whan she sawe · that Romayns wan the town
She tooke hire children alle · ⁊and skipte a down
In to the fuyre ⁊and chees rather to dye
Than any Romayn dede hire vyleynye
¶ Hath nat lucresse · y slayn hire selfe allas
At Rome whan she oppressed was
Of Tarquyn  for hire thought it was a shame
To lyuen whan she hadde loste hire name /
The ·vij· maidons of Milesie also
Han slayn hem selue · for verrey drede ⁊and wo
Rather than̄ folke of Gawle · hem shulde oppresse /
Moo than̄ a thowsand stories . as I gesse /
Koude I now telle as touchyng this matere
¶ Whan habradace was slayn his wife so dere
Hire siluen slow · and leet hire blood to glyde

(base) Wel rather than they wolde defouled be
(base) I wol conclude that it is bet for me
(base) To sleen myself than ben defouled thus
(base) I wol be trewe vnto Arueragus
(base) Or rather sle myself in som manere
(base) As dide Democienis doghter deere
(base) By cause that she wolde nat defouled be
(base) O Cedasus it is ful gret pitee
(base) To reden how thy doghtren deyde allas
(base) That slowe hemself for swich maner cas
(base) As greet a pitee was it or wel moore
(base) The Theban mayden that for Nychanore
(base) Hirseluen slow right for swich manere wo
(base) Another Theban mayden dide right so
(base) For oon of Macedonye hadde hire oppressed

(base) How trewe eek was to Alcebiades
(base) His loue that rather for to dyen chees

(base) What Omer of goode Penolopee
(base) Al Grece knoweth of hir chastitee
(base) Pardee of Laodomya is writen thus
(base) That whan at Troye was slayn Protheselaus
(base) No lenger wolde she lyue after his day
(base) The same of noble Porcia telle I may
(base) Withoute Brutus koude she nat lyue
(base) To whom she hadde al hool hir herte yeue
(base) The parfit wifhod of Arthemesye
(base) Honoured is thurgh al the Barbarye

(base) Thus pleyned Dorigene a day or tweye
(base) Purposynge euere that she wolde deye
But natheles vpon̄ the thridde nyght
Hoom cam Arueragus · this worthy knyght
And asked hire · why that she weep so sore /
And she gan wepe eủer lenger the more /
Allas qduod she that eủer I was born
Thus haue I seide qduod she · thus haue I sworn
And tolde hym alle · as ye han herde bifore /
Yt nedeth nat reherce it yow namore /
¶ This housbande with glad chere · in frendly wise
Answerde ⁊and seide · as I shall yow deuyse
Is ther ought ellys · Dorigene but this 
Nay nay qduod she · god helpe me so as wis
This is to moche · and it were goddis wille /
¶ Ye wife qduod he · late slepen that is stille
Yt may be wele ꝑparauenture · yet to day
Ye shulle youre treuthe holden by my fay
For god so wisly haue mercy vpon me
I hadde wele leuer · y stiked for to be
For verrey loue · whiche that I to yow haue
But ye shulde · youre trouthe kepe ⁊and saue
Trouthe is the hyest thynge · that man may kepe
And with that worde · he braste a noon to wepe
And seide · I yow forbede · vpon peyne of deth
That neủer while the lasteth lyfe or breth
To no wight telle thow of this auenture
As I may beste I wole my woo endure
Ne make no contenᵃaunce . of heuynesse
That folke of yow may demen harme or gesse /
And forth he clepeth · a squyer ⁊and a maide
Go forth a noon with Dorigene he seide
And bryngeth hire to swiche a place a noon /
They take hire leue . ⁊and on hir wey they gon
But they ne wiste why she theder wente
He nolde no wight tellen hise entente /
¶ This squyer whiche that hight Aurelius
On Dorigene · that was so amorous
Of Auenture happid hire to mete
A mydde the town · right in the quykkest strete
As she was boon to go the wey forth right
Toward the gardyn · ther as she had hight
And he was to the gardyn warde also
For wele he spied . whan she wolde go
Oute of hire hous · to any maner place
But thus they meete · of auenture or grace
And he salueth hire with good entente
And asked of hire · whiderwarde she wente
And she answerde · halfe as she were madde
Vnto the gardyn · as myn housbond badde
My trouth for to holde / allas / allas /
¶ Aurelius gan wondren on this cas
And in his herte hadde grete compassion
Of hire ⁊and · of hire lamentacion
And of Arueragus the worthy knyght
That bade hire holden · al that she hadde hight
So looth hym was · his wife sholde breke hire treuth /
And in his herte · he caught of it grete reuthe
Consideryng the beste · on eủery syde
That fro hise luste · yet were hym leủer abyde
Than doon so heigh a cherlis wrecchednesse
A gayns Fraunchise ⁊and alle gentillesse
For whiche · in fewe wordes . seide he thus /
Madame / seith to youre lorde Arueragus
That sith I see hise greet gentilesse
To yow · ⁊and eke I se wele youre greet distresse
That hym were leuer han shame · ⁊and þᵗat were routhe
Than ye to me · sholde breke thus youre trouthe
I haue wele leuer · eủer to suffre woo
Thanne I departe the loue bitwixe yow two
I yow relese Madame · Into youre honde
Quite eủery surement . and eủery bonde
That ye han made to me . as here byforne
Sith thilke tyme . whiche that ye were born
Mi trouthe I plight . I shall yow neủer rep̉reue
Of no biheste · ⁊and here I take my leue
As of the treweste ⁊and the beste wyfe
That eủer yet I knewe in al my lyfe /
But eủery wife biware of hire byheste
Of Dorigene · remembreth at the leste
Thus kan a squyer · doon a gentel dede
As wele as kan a knyght · with outen drede
¶ She thonketh hym vpon hire knees albare
And home vnto hire housbonde · is she fare
And tolde hym alle · as ye han herde me sayd
And be ye siker he was so wele apayd
That it were impossible me it to write /
What sholde I lenger of this cas endite
¶ Arueragus ⁊and Dorigene his wif
In souereyn blisse ledden forth hire lyf
Neủer Eft ne was ther · anger hem bytwene
He cherissheth hire · right as she were a quene
And she was to hym trewe for eủerimoore
Of these twoo folke . ye gete of me nomore
Aurelius that his coste hath al forlorn
Curseth the tyme · that eủer he was born /
Allas qduod he allas · that I bihighte
Of pured golde a thowsande pounde of wight
Vnto this Philosophre · how shall I doo
I se nomore · but that I am for doo
Myn heritage mote I nedes selle
And ben a begger · here may I nat dwelle
And shamen al my kynrede in this place
But I of hym may gete bettre grace
But natheles · I wole of hym assaye
At certeyn dayes yere by yere to paye
And thonken hym of hise grete curtesye
My trouth wole I kepe I wole not lye
With herte sore · he goth vnto his cofre
And brought golde · vnto this Philosophre
The valewe of fyue hundred pounde y gesse
And bisicheth of his gentilesse
To graunte hym dayes of the remenᵃaunt
And seyde maister I dar wele make auᵃaunt
I failed neủer as yet of my trouthe as yette
For sikerly my dette shal be quette
Towarde yow · how eủer that I fare
To goon a begged in my cirtel bare
But wolde ye vouche safe vpon sirete
Twoo yer or thre · for to respiten me
Than were I wele · for ellys mote I selle
Myn heritage · ther is nomore to telle
This Philosophre sobrely answerde
And seyde thus · whan he these wordes herde
Haue I not holden couenᵃaunt vnto the 
Yes certes wele ⁊and trewely qduod he /
Hastow nat hadde thy lady · as the lyketh 
No no qduod he · and sorwefully he syketh /
What was the cause · telle me if thow kan 
Aurelius hys tale a noon bygan
And tolde hym alle . as ye han herde byfore /
It nedeth nat to yow · reherce it moore /
He seide Arueragus of gentilesse
Hadde leuer dye · in sorwe ⁊and distresse
Than his wife were of hir treuthe fals /
The sorwe of Dorigene · he toolde hym als
How looth hire was to ben a wikked wyfe
And that she loste had leủer · that day hire lyfe
And that hire treuthe · she swore of Innocence
She neủer erste hadde herde speke of apꝑparence
That made hym haue of hire so grete pite
And right as frely · as he sente hir me
As frely sente I here to hym a gayn
This al ⁊and som ther · ther nys nomore to sayn /
¶ This Philosophre answerde · leue brother /
Eủeriche of yow dide genteliche to other
Thow art a squyer · ⁊and he is a knyght
But god forbede for his blysfull myght
But if a clerke koude doon a gentel dede
As wele as any of yow · it is no drede /
¶ Sire I relese the thy thowsand pounde
As thow right now were crope oute of the grounde
Ne neủer er now · ne haddest knowen me /
For sire I wole nat take a peny of the
For alle my crafte · ne noght for my trauaile /
Thow haste I paied wele for my vitaille
It is ynogh and fare wele haue good day
And toke his hors ⁊and forth he gooth his way /
Lordynges this question · than wole I axe yowe
Whiche was the moost fre · as thynketh yow
Now telleth me er that ye ferther wende /
I kan nomore my tale is at an ende /

The ꝒProheme of the tale of the man
lawe of Custaunce
Ovre ooste saugh wele · that the brighte sonne
The arke of his artificial day / hath ronne
The ferthe parte ⁊and halfe an houre ⁊and more
And though he were nat depe / y sterte in lore
He wiste it was the eght and twenty day
Of Aprill that is Messynger to may
I sawe wele that the shadwe of eủery tree
Was as in lenghthe / the same quantite
That was the body erecte that caused it
And therfore bithe shadwe he toke his wit
That Phebꝰus which that shoon so clere ⁊and bright
Degrees was fyue and fourty / clombe on hight
And for that day / as in that latitude
It was ten of the clokke / he gan conclude
And sodeynly he plight his hors a boute
Lordynges qduod he . I warne yow alle this route
The ferthe partie of this day is goon
Now for the loue of god ⁊and of seynt Iohn
Lesith no tyme / as ferforth as ye may
Lordynges the tyme it wasteth nyght ⁊and day
And stelith from vs / what piriuely slepynge
And what thourgh necligence in oure wakynge
As dooth the streem that turneth neủer a gayn
Descendynge fro the Mountayne in to playn
Wele kan Senek and many a Philosophre
Be waillen tyme . more than golde in cofre
For los of catel . may rekeued be
But los of tyme · shendith vs qduod he
It wole nat come agayne · with outen drede
Namore than wole Malkyns Maidenhede
Whan she hath loste it in hire wantownesse
Late vs nat mowlen thus in ydelnesse
Sire man of lawe qduod he · so haue ye blisse
Tel vs a tale a noon as forward ysse
Ye ben submytted thourgh youre free assente
To stonden in this caas . at my Iuggemente
Acquiteth yow now of youre byheste
Thanne haue ye don youre deuoyre atte leste
¶ Hoost qduod he · deꝑperdeux iche assent
To breke forwarde / is nat myn entente
Biheste is dette . ⁊and I wole holde fayn
Al my byheste I kan no bettre sayn
For swiche lawe · as a man yeueth a nother wight
He sholde hym selfe vsen it be right
Thus wole oure texte · but natheles certeyn
I kan right now no thrifti tale seyn
That Chaucer thow he kan / but lewedly
On metres / or on rymyng craftyly
Hath seide hem in swiche englisshe as he kan
Of olde tyme / as knoweth many a man
And if he haue noght / seyde hem leue brother
In oo book he hath seyde hem in a nother
For he hath tolde of louers vp ⁊and doun
Mo than Ouyde made of mencoun
I hise epistelis that ben olde
What sholde I tellen hem / syn they ben tolde
In youthe he made of Ceys / ⁊and Alcione
And sithen hath he spoke of eủerychone
These noble wifes / ⁊and these louers eke
Who so that wole / his large volume seke
Cleped the seintes legende of Cupide
Ther may he seen . the large woundes wide
Of lucresse ⁊and of Babilan Tesbe
The swerde of Dido / for the fals Ene
The tree of Phillis for hire Demophon
The pleinte of Dyane / ⁊and of hermyon
Of Adryane / and of Isiphile
The barayne Ile stondynge in the see
The dreynte leandre · for hi erro
The teeris of Eleyne ⁊and eke the wo
Of Brixseide / and of the ladomia
The cruelte of the quene Medea
Thi litel Children hangyng by the hals
For thi Iason that was of loue so fals
Oyꝑpermystra · Penalope / Alceste
Youre wifhood / he cōmmendeth wᵗith the beste
But certeinly no worde writeth he
Of thilke ensample of Canace
That loued hire owne brother synfully
Of swiche cursed stories I sey fy
Or ellis of Tiro Appollonius
How that the cursed kynge · Antiochus
Birafte his doughter · of hire maidenhede
That is to horrible a tale for to rede
Whan he hire threwe vpon the pauement
And therfore he of full auysement
Nolde neủer write / in noon of hise sermons
Of swiche vnkynde abhomynacoıı̄uns
Ne I wole noon reherce · if that I may
But of my tale · how shall I doon this day
Me were looth be likened douteles
To Muses / that men clepe Pierides
Methamorphosios / woot what I mene
But natheles I recche nought a bene
Though I come aftir hym / with hawe bake
I speke in prose / and late hym rymes make
And with that word · he with a sobre chere
Bygan his tale / as ye shall aftir here
Here bigynneth the tale of Custaunce
O hateful harm condicioun of pouerte
With thurste · with colde · wᵗith honger so confounded
To asken helpe the shameth in thyn herte
If thow noon aske · so sore artow ꝓpro / wounded
That verray nede / vnwrappeth al thy wounde hed
Maugre thyn heed / thow most for Indigence
Or stele / or begge / or borwe thi dispence
¶ Thow blamest criste / ⁊and seist ful bitterlie
He mysdeꝑperteth richesse temporal
Thi neghebor / thow witeste synfully
And seist thow haste to lyte · ⁊and he hath al
ꝐPerfay seist thow · somtyme he rekene shal
Whan that his taille shalle brennen in the gleede
For he noght helpeth nedful in hire nede
¶ Herke what is the sentence of the wise
Bette to dien than haue indigence
Thy selfe neghebore wole the despise
Yf thow be pore / farewele thy reuerence /
Yet of the wise man / take this sentence
Alle the dayes of pore men ben wycke
Beware therfore or þᵘ come to that prikke
¶ If þᵘ be pore · thy brother hateth the
And alle thy frendes flen from the allas)
O Riche merchauntz ful of wele ben ye
O noble o prudente folke as in this cas
Youre bagges ben nought fild wᵗith Ambes aas
But with sys synke / that renneth for youre chaunce / Odd form of virgule, resembling a modern comma
At Cristemasse · murie may ye daunce /
¶ Ye seken londe ⁊and see · for youre wynnynges
As wise folke ye knowen al thestate
Of reignes / ye ben Fadres of tydynges
And tales / booth of pees / ⁊and of debate /
I were right now / of talis desolat
Nere that a Merchaunt / goon is many a yere
Me taughte a tale · whiche that ye shal here /
IN Surrye whilom dwelte a companye
Of Chapmen riche ⁊and therto sadde ⁊and trewe
That wide where senten here spicerye
Clothis of golde · and Satyns riche of hewe
Here Chaffare was so thrifty ⁊and so newe
That eủery wight hath deynte to chaffare
With hem ⁊and eke to sellen hem hire ware /
¶ Now fille it that the maistres of that sorte
Han shapen hem to Rome for to wende
Were it for chapmanhode or for disporte
Noon other Message . wolde they theder sende
But comen hym selfe to Rome / this is thende
And in swiche place · as thoughte hem auᵃauntage
For hire eate / they taken here herbergage /
¶ Soiourned han these Merchauntes in that toune
A certeyn tyme as fel to hire plesuᵃaunce
And so byfel the excelent renoun
Of Themꝑperoures doughter dame Custaunce
Reported was with eủery circumstaunce
Vnto thise Surreyn Merchuᵃauntz in swiche wise
From day to day as I shall yow deuyse
¶ This was the cōmmune voys of eủery man
Oure Emꝑperoure of Rome god hym see
A doughter hath that sith the world bygan
To rekne as wele / hire goodnesse as beaute
Nas neủere swiche a nother / as is she /
I preye to god in honour hir sustene
And wolde she were / of alle Europe the quene /
¶ In hire is highe beaute / wᵗith outen pride
Youthe with outen grenhede / or folye
To alle here werkes . vertue is here gide
Humblesse hath slayn in hire / al tirannye
She is myrrour / of alle curtesye
Hire herte is verrey chambre / of holynesse
Hire hand Mynystre of Fredome for almesse /
¶ And alle this voys was soth / as god is trewe
But now to pᵃrapos / late vs turne agayn
Thise Merchauntz han doon fraught / hire shippes newe
And whan they han / this blisful Maiden sayn
Hom to Surry ben they wente ful fayn
And doon hire nedes · as they han doon yore
And lyuen in wele · I kan sey yow nomore /
¶ Now fille** it that these Merchuᵃauntz . stode in grace
Of hym that was the Sowdon of Surrye
For whan they come fro any straunge place
He wolde / of his benyngne curtesye
Make hem good chere · and bysily espie
Tidynges / of sundry regnes / for to lere
The wondres that they myght sen or here
¶ Amonges other thynges / specially
These Merchuᵃauntz han hym tolde · of dame Custaunce
So grete noblesse · in ernest seriously there is a sign beside the added text between the linesceriose
That this Sowdon hath caught so grete plesaunce
To han hire figure / in hise remembraunce
And alle his luste . ⁊and alle his besy cure
Was for to loue hire · while his lyfe may dure
¶ ꝐPerauenture in thilke large book
Whiche that men clepe / the heuene y wreten was
With sterres / whan that he his birthe tooke
That he for loue sholde han his deeth allas
For in the sterres · clerer than is glass
Is writen god wote · who so coude it rede
The deth of eủery man . with outen drede
¶ In sterris many a wynter · ther byforn
Was writen the deth of Ector ⁊and Achilles
Of Pompey Iulius . er they were born
The stryfe of Thebes · ⁊and of Ercules
Of Sampson Turnus ⁊and of Socrates
The deeth / but mennꝰus wittes ben so dulle
That no wight kan wele rede it at the fulle /
¶ This Sowdan for his pⁱriuey counseile sente
And shortly of this matere for to pace
He hath to hem / declared his entente
And seide hem certeyn / but if he myght haue gᵃrace
To haue Custᵃraunce · with Inne a litel space
He nas but deed · ⁊and charged hem in hye
To shapen for his lyfe som remedye /
¶ Dyuerse men · dyủerse thynges seyden
They Argumenten / casten vp ⁊and doun
Many a subtil resoun forth they leyden
They speken of Magik / and Abusion
But finaly as in conclusion
They kan nat sen in that non auᵃauntage
Ne in noon other weye saue in mariage /
¶ Thanne saugh ther Inne swiche difficulte
Be way of resoun for to speke al playn
By cause that ther was swiche dyuersite
Bitwene hire bothe lawes / that thay sayn
They trowe / that no cristen Prince wolde fayn
Wedden his childe / vnder oure lawes swete
That vs was yeuen be Mahoun oure ꝓprophete
¶ And he answered · rather than I lese
Custaunce · I wole be Cristened douteles
I moot ben hires · I may non other chese
I paray yow · holdeth youre Argumentz in pees
Saueth my lyfe ⁊and beth nat recchelees
To geten hire / that hath my lyfe in Cure
For in thys woo · I may not longe endure
¶ What nedeth gretter dilatacioun
I seye be treteys . ⁊and embassadrye
And by the popes mediacioun
And alle the chirche ⁊and alle the Chiualrie
That in destruccoıı̄un of Mawmetrye
And in encrees / of Cristes lawe dere
They ben accorded · so as ye shal here
¶ How that the Sowdan / and hise baronage
And alle hise lieges · sholde y cristned be
And he shall han Custaunce in Mariage
And certeyn golde · I noot what quᵃautite
And herto founden sufficient surete
This same accorde was sworn / on either side
Now faire Custaunce / almyghti god the gyde
¶ Now wolde som moen wayten / as I gesse
That I sholde tellen alle the puruyaunce
That the Emꝑperour of his grete noblesse
Hath shapen for his doughter dame Custaunce
Wele may men knowen that so grete ordenᵃaunce
May noman tellen in a litel clause
As was arraied / for so heigh a cause
¶ Bisshopes ben shapen with hire for to wende
Lordes ladies . knyghtes of renoun
And other folke I nowe / this is the ende
And notefied is thourgh oute the toun
That eủery wight with grete deuocioun
Sholde preien criste · that he this mariage
Receyue in gree ⁊and spede this viage
¶ The day is come / of hire deꝑpertynge
I seye the woofull day fatal is come
That ther may be no lenger tariynge
But forthwarde they hem dressen alle ⁊and some
Custaunce that was with sorwe al oủercome
Ful pale aryst · ⁊and dresseth hire to wende
For wele she seeth · ther nys non other ende
¶ Allas what wonder is it thow she wepte
That shal be sente · to straunge nacion
Fro frendes that kepte hire so tenderly
And to be bounde vnder subieccion
Of oon she knoweth nat his condicion
Housbandes ben alle good and han be yore
That knowen wyfes . I dar sey yow nomore
¶ Fader she seide / thy wrecched childe Custaunce
Thy yonge doughter fostred vp so softe
And ye my Modre · my soủereyn plesaunce
Ouer alle thynge / outaken crist on lofte
Custaunce youre childe / hire recomendeth ofte
Vnto youre grace / for I shall to Surrye
Ne shal I neủer se yow more with · ye
¶ Allas vnto the Barbre nacion
I most goon / syn that it is youre wille
But criste that starfe for oure redempcion
So yeue me grace his hestes to fulfille
I wrecche woman no force thow I spille
Women er born / to thraldom ⁊and penaunce
And to bebenbeng vnder mannys gouernaunce
¶ I trowe at Troye whan Pirrus brak the wal
Or ylyon . brende Thebes the Cite
Nat Rome thurgh the harme of hanybal
That Romaynes / hath venquyssed tymes three
Nas herde swiche tendre wepyng for pite
As in the chambre was for hire departynge
But forth she moot . wher so she wepe or synge
O first meuyng cruel firmament
With thy diurnal sweigh / that crowdest ay
And hurlest al froo este / til occident
That naturelly wold holde another way
Thy crowdynge set the heuene in swiche array
At the begynnynge of this fiers viage
That cruel Mars hath slayn this mariage
¶ Infortunat ascendent tortuous
Of whiche the lorde is helpeles falle allas
Oute of his Ancle in to the derkeste hous
O Mars .o· atazir as in this cas
O feble Mone vnhappy ben thy paas
Thow knyttest the / ther þᵘ nart nat receyued
Ther thow were wele fro thens artow weyued
¶ Imprudent Empoure of Rome Allas
Was ther no Philosophre in all thy toun
Is no tyme bette than other / in swiche cas
Of viage / is ther noon eleccion
Namely to folke / of heigh condicion
Nat whan a rote is of a burthe y knowe
Allas we ben to lewed / or to slowe
¶ To shippe is brought · this wofull faire maide
Solempuely with eủery circumstaunce
Now IħuIhesu Criste be with yow alle / she saide
Ther nys nomore / but farewele faire Custaunce
She payneth hire to make good countenaunce
And forth I late hire saille in this manere
IAnd turne I wole agayn to my matere
¶ The Moder of the Sowdan (welle of vices)
Espied hath / hire sones pleyn* entente
How he wole lete / his olde sacrifices /
And right a noon · she for hire counseile sente
And they ben come to knowe · what she mente /
And whan assembled was this folke in fere
She sette hire doun · and seide as ye shal here
¶ Lordes she seide ye knowen eủerychone
How that my sone · in poynt is for to lete
The holy lawes of oure · alkaron
Yeuen by goddes Massage Macomete
But oon avow to grete god I hete
The lyfe shall rather oute of my body sterte
Than Macometes lawe / oute of myn herte
¶ What sholde vs tyden / of this newe lawe
But thraldom to oure bodies and penᵃaunce
And aftirwarde in helle to be drawe
For we reneyed Mahoun oure creaunce
but lordynges wyl ye make assuraunce**
As I shall seyn Assentyng to my lore
And I shal maken vs sauf for eủermore
¶ They sworen ⁊and assenten eủerychone
To lyue with hire ⁊and dyen / ⁊and by hire stonde
And eủeryche in the beste wise he kan
To strenghthen hire / shal alle his frendes fonde
And she hath take this Emprice on honde
Whiche ye shal heren / that I shal deuyse
And to hem alle · she spake right in this wyse
¶ We shulle firste feyne vs cristendome to take
Coolde water shall nat greue vs but a lite
And I shall swiche a feste and reuel make
That as I trowe I shall the Sowdan quyte
For thogh his wyfe be cristened neủer so white
She shall haue nede · to waisshe a way the rede
Though she a fonte ful water with hire lede
¶ O Sawdanesse roote of Iniquite
Virago · thow Semyrame the secunde
O serpent vnder femynynytee
Lyke to the serpent depe in helle y bounde
O feyned woman · al that may confounde
Vertue ⁊and Innocence thurgh thy malice
Is bred in the · as neste of eủery vice
¶ O Sathan enuyous / syn thilke day
That þᵘ were chaced from oure heritage
Wele knoestow to wȳmmen tholde way
Thow madest Eua / brynge vs in seruage
Thow wolte fordoon this cristen mariage /
Thyn Instrument . (so weileway the while)
Makestowe of hem / whan thow wolte begyle
¶ Thys Soudanesse / whom I thus blame ⁊and warye
Lete pⁱriuely hire counseile goon hir way
What sholde I in this tale lenger tarye
She rideth to the Sowdan on a day
And seide hym that she wolde reneye hire lay
And cristendome of Prestes hondes fonge
Repentynge hire · she hethen was so longe
¶ Bisichyng hym / to doon hir that honour
That she moste han the cristen folke to feste
To plesen hem . I wole doo my labour
The Sowdan seith · I wole doon at youre heste
And knelyng thankyng here / of that requeste
So glad he was he nyste what to seye
She kyste hire sone / and hoom she gooth hire weye
¶ Arryued ben this cristen folke to londe
Iⁿ Surrye with a grete solempne route
And hasteliche this Soudan sent his sonde
First to his moder / and al the regne a boute
And seyde his wyfe was comen oute of doute
And preide hire / for to ride / agayn the quene
The honour of his reigne / to sustene
¶ Grete was the prees · and riche / was tharray
Of Surryens · and Romayns met y fere
The Moder of the Sowdan riche ⁊and gay
Receyueth hire · with also glad a chere
As any Moder myghte hire doughter dere
And to the nexte Cite ther bysyde
A softe paas /· solempnely they ryde
¶ Naght trowe I the / tryumphe of Iulius
Of whiche that lucas maketh swiche a boost
Was roialler / or more curyus
Than was thassemble / of this blisfull ooste /
But this scorpion / this wicked goost
The Sowdonesse / for alle hire flaterynge
Caste vnder this · full mortaly to stynge
¶ The Sowdam comth hym selfe sone after this
So roially that wonder is to telle
He welcometh hire with all Ioye ⁊and blisses
And thus in myrthe and Ioye · I late hem dwelle
The fruyt of this matere is that I telle /
When tyme cam / men thought it for the beste
That reuel stynte · ⁊and men goo to hire reste /
¶ The tyme come · this olde Sowedanesse
Ordeyned hath / this feste of whiche I tolde
And to the feste / cristen folke hem dresse
In gen̉eral . ye bothe yonge ⁊and olde
Heer may men feste / and roialte biholde
And deyntees moo · than I kan yowe deuyse
But alto dere · they bought it er they ryse
¶ O sodeyn woo · that euer arte successour
To worldly blysse spreind wᵗith bittrenesse
The ende of the Ioye / of oure worldly labour
Woo occupieth the / fyn of oure gladnesse
Herke this counseile / for thy sikirnesse

l.hi: Vpon thy glade day · haue in thy mynde
The vnwar woo / or harme that cometh byhynde

div.l: ¶ For shortly for to tellen / it a worde
The Soudan · ⁊and the Cristen euerichon
Ben alto hewe ⁊and stiked at the borde
But if it were oonly dame Custaunce allone
This olde Soudanesse / kursed krone
Hath with hire frendes doon this cursed dede
For she hire selfe / wolde al the cuntre lede
¶ Ne was Surrien noon · that was conủerted
That of the counseile · of the Soudan woot
That he nas al to hewe or he a sterted
And Custaunce han they take anoon foot hoot
And in a Sheppe al stereles god woot
They han hire sette ⁊and biddeth hire lerne saile
Oute of Surry · agaynward to Itaille
¶ A Certeyn tresour that she thider ladde
And soth to sayn vitaile grete plente
They han hire yeuen ⁊ clothes⁊and clothes eke she hadde
And forth she sailleth · in the salte see /
O my Custaunce ful of Benyngnyte
O Emꝑperoures yonge doughter dere
He that is lorde of Fortune / be thy stere
¶ She blisseth hire ⁊and with ful pitous voys
Vnto the crois of Criste thus seide she
O clere o welful auter / holy croys
Reed of the lambes blood / ful of pite
That waisshe the world fro the olde iniquite
Me fro the fende · and fro his clawes kepe
That day that I shal drenchen in the depe
¶ Victorious tree · ꝓproteccion of trewe
That oonly worthy were · for to bere
The kynge of heuene · with his woundes newe
The white lambe · that hurte was with the spere
Flemer of fendis / oute of hym / ⁊and here
On whiche thy lymes · feithfully extenden
Me kepe ⁊and yeue me myght my lyfe tamenden
¶ Yeris ⁊and daies Fleet this creature
Thurgh oute the see of Grece / vnto the strayte
Of Marrok / as it was / hir auenture
On many a sory mele now may she baite
Aftir hire deeth · ful ofte may she wayte
Or that the wilde wawes / wole hire dryue
Vnto the place · ther she shalle arryue
¶ Men myghten asken why she was nat slayn
Eke at the feste / who myght hire body saue 
And I answere to that demaunde agayn
Who saued SDaniel in the hoorible Caue
Ther eủery wight saue he / maister or knaue
Was with the leoun frete / er he a sterte 
No wight but god · that he bare in his herte /
¶ God lyste to shewe his wonderfull miracle
In hire / for we shulde seen / his myghti werkys /
Criste whiche that is / to eủery harme triacle
By certeyn menes ofte (as knowen Clerkys)
Dooth thynge for certeyn ende / that ful derke is
To mānnes witte · that for oure ignoraunce
Ye kūnne nat knowe his prudent purueaunce
¶ Now sith she was nat . / at the feste y slawe
Whoo kepte hire / from the drenchyng in the see
Who kepte Ionas / in the fisshes mawe
Til he was spouted vp at Nynyue
Wele may men knowe / it was no wight but he
That kepte peple hebrayk fro her drenchynge
With drie feet thurgh oute · the see passynge
¶ Who bade the foure spirites of tempeste
That power han tanoyen lond ⁊and see
Bothe North ⁊and South · ⁊and also // Est ⁊and // West
Anoieth nother see ne land ne tree
Soothly the cōmmaunder of that was he
That fro the tempest ay this woman kepte
As wele whan she wook / as whan she slepte
¶ Wher myghte this woman mete ⁊and drynke haue
Thre yere ⁊and more / how lasteth hire vitaille
Who fedde the Egipcian marie in the Caue
Or in / deserte · no wight but criste suᵃaunz faile
Fyfe thowsand folke it was as gret meruaille
With looues fyve · and fisshes two to fede
God sente hise foyson / at hire grete nede
¶ She dryueth forth in to oure Occian
Thurgh oute oure wilde see / til at the laste
Vnder an holde that nempnen I ne kan
Fer in Northumberland · the wawe hir caste
And in the sande · hire shippe stiked so faste
That thennes wolde it nat of alle a tyde
The wille of criste was . that she sholde abyde
¶ The Constable of the Castel · doun is fare
To sen his wrak / and alle the shippe he sought
And fonde this wery woman full of Care
He fonde also the tresour . that she brought /
In hire langage · mercy she besought
The lyfe oute of hire body to twynne
Hire to delyủer of woo that she was ynne /
¶ A man̉er latyn corrupt was hire speche
But algate therby · was she vnderstonde
This constable · whan hym lyste no lenger seche
This wofull woman / broughte he to the londe
She kneleth doun / and thanketh goddis sonde
But what she was she wolde noman seye
For foule ne faire / thow that she sholde deye
¶ She saide she was so mased in the see
That she forgate hir mynde by hire trouthe /
The Constable hath of hire / so grete pitee
And eke his wife that they wepen for routhe
She was so diligent with owten sloughthe
To serue ⁊and please eueriche in that place
That alle hir louen / that loken in hire face
¶ This Constable / and dame hermengild his wyf
Were paiens / and that cuntre / eủery where
But hermengild loued hire / right as hire lyfe
And Custance hath so longe soiourned there
In Orisons / with many a bitter tere
Til IħuIhesu hath conuerted thurgh his grace
Dame hermengilde / Constablesse of that place
¶ In al that londe no cristen dorste route
Alle cristene folke ben fledde fro that cuntre
Thurgh payens that conquereden al a boute
The plages of the North · by land ⁊and se
To Walys fledde · the cristianyte
Of olde Britons dwellyng in this Ile
Ther was hire refute for the mene while
¶ But yet nere cristen Britons · so exiled
That there nere sōmme · that in hire pⁱriuetee
Honoured criste ⁊and hethen folke bigiled
And neigh the Castel · swiche there dwelten three
That oon of hem was blynde · ⁊and myght . nat see
But it were of thilke yen of his mynde
With whiche men see whan that they be blynde
¶ Bright was the sonne · as in that someris day
For whiche the Constable and his wife also
And Custaunce · han take the right way
Toward the see · a furlong wey or two
To pleyen ⁊and to romen too ⁊and fro
And in hire walke · this blynde man they mette
Croked ⁊and olde with faste y shette
¶ In name of criste · cride this blynde Britoun
Dame hermengilde · yef me my sight agayn
This lady waxe a fraied of the soun
Leste that hire housbonde / shortly for to sayn
Wolde hire for IħuIhesu Cristes loue han slayn
Til Custaunce made hire bolde · ⁊and bade hire werche
The wille of Criste · a doughter of his chirche
¶ The Constable wexe a basshed / of that sight
And seide what amounteth al this fare 
Custaunce answered · sire it is cristes myght
That helpeth folke oute of the fendes snare
And so ferforth she gan oure lay declare
That she the Constable / er it was eue
Conuerteth · ⁊and on crist maketh hym byleue /
