¶ This Constable was nothynge lord of thys place
Of whiche I speke ther he Custaraunce fonde
But kepte it strongely many wyntres space
Vnder Alla kyng of all Northumberlond
That was ful wis ⁊and worthy of his honde
Agayn the Scottes · as men may wele here
But turne I wole agayn / to my matere
¶ Sathan that eủer vs waiteth to begile
Saugh of Custaraunce al hire ꝑperfeccioun
And caste a noon how he myght quyte her while
And made a yonge knyght · that dwelt in that toun
Loue hire so hote · of foule affeccioun
That verreyly hym thought he sholde spille
But he of hire myght ones haue his wille
¶ He wowith hire / but it auailleth noght
She wolde do no synne by no weye
And for despite he compaseth in his thought
To maken hire on shameful deth to deye
He waiteth whan the Constable was a weye
And pⁱriuely on a nyght he crepte
In hermengildes Chambre while she slepte
¶ Wery for waked in hire orisons
Slepeth Custaraunce · and hermengille also
This knyght thorow Sathans temptacoıı̄uns
Al softely is to the bedde y goo
And kitte the throte of hermengild a two
And leyde the blody knyfe by dame Custaunce
And wente his weye · ther god yef hym myschaunce
¶ Sone aftir / cometh this Constable hoom a gayn
And eke Alla / that kyng was of that londe
And saugh his wyfe disputously y slayn
For whiche full ofte he wepe · ⁊and wronge his honde
And in the bedde the blody knyfe he fonde
By Dame Custaunce Allas what myght she seye
For verrey woo hir witte was al awey
¶ To kynge Alla was tolde alle this meschaunce
And eke the tyme · ⁊and where · ⁊and in what wise
That in a shippe was founden this Custaunce
As here byforn / that ye han herde deuyse /
The kynges herte of pite gan agrise
Whan he sey so benyngne a creature
Falle in disese ⁊and in mysauenture
¶ For as the lambe / toward his deth is brought
So stant this Innocent byfore the kyng /
This fals knyght · that hath this treson wrought
Berith hire on honde that she hath doon this thyng
But natheles ther was grete moornyng /
Amonge the peple / ⁊and seyn they can nat gesse
That shee had doon · so greet a wikkednesse
¶ For they han seyn hir eủer so vertuous
And louyng hermyngilde · right as hire lyfe /
Of this bare witnesse eủeryche in that hous
Saue he that hermyngild slowe with his knyfe /
This gentel kynge / hath caught a greet motyfe
Of this witnesse ⁊and thoughte he wolde enquere
Depper in this a trouthe for to lere /
¶ Allas Custaunce / thow haste no champion
Ne fight kanstow nought / so weillaway
But that starfe for oure redempcion
And bonde Sathan / and yet lieth ther he lay
So be thy stronge champion this day
For but if criste / open miracle kythe
With outen gilte · thow shalt be slayn as swythe
¶ She sitte hire doun on knees · and thus she sayde
Inmortal god / that saued Susanne
Fro fals blame / and thow mercifull maide
Marie I meene · doughter of seint Anne
Byfore whoos childe · Aungels synge Osanne
If I be gilteles · of this felonye
My socour be for / ellys shal I dye
¶ Haue ye nat seyn · somtyme a pale face
A monge a prees / of hym that hath by lad
Toward his deeth where as hym gate no grace
And swiche a colour in his face hath hadde
Men myght knowe his face that was bystad
Amonges alle the faces in that route 
So stante Custaunce ⁊and loketh hire aboute
¶ O quenes lyuyng in prosꝑperite
Duchesses and ye ladies euerichone
Haueth som routhe on hire adủersite
An Emꝑperours doughter / stant allone
She hath no wight to whom to make her mone
O blood Roial / that stondist in this drede
Fer ben thy frendes at thy grete nede
¶ This Alla kyng / hath swiche compassion
(As gentil herte / is fulfilde of pite)
That from his eyen ranne the water doun /
Now hastely doo fecche a book qduod he
And if this knyght . wol sweren how that she
This wōmman slowe · yet wol we vs auyse
Whom that we wole that shal be oure Iustise
¶ A Briton Book writen with euᵃaungiles
Was fette and on this booke he swore a noon
She giltise was · ⁊and in the mene whiles
An honde hym smote vpon the nekke bon
That doun he fel at ones · as a stoon
And bothe his eyen / broste oute of his face
In sighte of eủery body in that place
¶ A voys was herde · in general audience
And seide thow haste disclaundred glilteles
The doughter of holy chirche · in heigh presence
Thus hast thow doon · and yet holde I my pes /
Of this meruaille . agaste was alle the pres
As mazed folke · they stonden eủerychone
For drede of wreche · saue Custaunce alone
¶ Grete was the drede · ⁊and eke the repentaunce
Of hem that hadde wronge suspeccion
Vpon this sely Innocent Custaunce
And for this miracle in conclucion
And by Custaunce mediacion
The kynge ⁊and many a nother in that place
Conủerted was thanked by goddes grace
¶ This fals knyght was slayn for his vntrouth
By Iuggement of Alla hastysly
And yet Custaunce hadde of his deth grete routhe
And aftir this . IħuIhesus of his mercie
Made Alla wedden ful solempnely
This holy woman that is so bright ⁊and shene
And thus hath Criste made Custaunce a quene
¶ But who was woful · yf I shal not lye
Of this weddynge but Donegild ⁊and namo
The kynges Moder full of Tyrannye
Hir thought hire cursed herte barste a two
She wolde nought hire sone hadde do so
Hire thought a despite that he sholde take
So straunge a creature vnto his make
¶ Me lyst nat of the chaffe / or of the stree
Maken so longe a tale / as of the korn
What sholde I tellen of the roialte
At mariages / or whiche cours gooth byforn
Who bloweth in the trumpe or in an horne
The fruyt of eủery tale is for to seye
They ete · ⁊and drynke · ⁊and daunce · ⁊and synge ⁊and pleye
¶ They goon to bedde as it was skille ⁊and right
For thow that wyues be ful holy thynges
They moste take in pacience / at nyght
Swiche man̉er necessaries / as ben plesynges
To folke that han I wedded hem · with rynges
And leye a lite / her holynesse a side
As for the tyme / it may no bette betide
¶ On hire he gate / a knaue childe a noon
And to a bisshope ⁊and his Constable eke
He toke his wife to kepe · whan he is gon
To Scotlond warde his foomen for to seke
Now faire Custaunce / that is so humble ⁊and meke
So longe is goon with childe / til that stille
She halte hire chamber / abydyng Cristis wille
¶ The tyme is come · a knaue childe she beer
Mauricius at the fonte stoone / they hym calle
This Constable doth com forth a messynger
And wroot vnto his kynge · that cleped was Alle
How that this blysful tydyng is befalle
And other tydynges / spedfull forto seye
He tath the lettre · ⁊and forth he goth his weye
¶ This Messynger to doon his auᵃauntage
Vnto the kynges Moder · rideth swithe
And salueth full faire in his langage
Madame qduod he / ye may be glad ⁊and blithe
And thanketh god / an hundred thousand sithe
My lady quene hath childe with outen doute
To ioye ⁊and blysse to alle this regne aboute
¶ Loo here the lettres / selid of this thyng
That I mote bere / wᵗith al the haste I may
If ye wole aught · vnto youre sone the kynge
I am youre ʆseruᵃaunt / both nyght ⁊and day /
Donegilde answerde / as now at this tyme nay
But here alnyght I wole thow take thy reste
To morwe wole I sey the what me leste /
¶ This messager dranke sadly ale ⁊and wyn
And stolen were his lettres pⁱriuely
Oute of his boxe · while he sleep as a swyn
And countrefeted was / full softellysotillysoftellysotilly
A nother lrēm wrought full synfully
Vnto the kynge directe of this matere
Fro his Constable / as ye shulle after here
¶ The lrēm spake the quene deliủered was
Of so horrible / a fendlyche creature
That in the Castel noon so hardy was
That any while durste there endure
The Moder was an Elfe by auenture
I comen by charmes or by Sorcerie
And eủeryche hatieth hir cōmpanye
¶ Woo was this kyng whan he þˢ lrēm hadde seyn
But to no wight he tolde his sorwes sore
But of his owene hoond he wroot agayn
Welcome the sonde of Criste for eủer moore
To me that am now lerned in his lore
Lorde welcome be thy luste · and thy plesuᵃaunce
My luste I putte alin thyn ordenᵃaunce
¶ Kepeth this childe · al be it foule or faire
And eke my wyfe vnto my home cōmmynge
Criste whan hym luste / may sende me an eir
Moore agreable than this / to my lykynge
This lettre he seleth pⁱriuely wepynge
Whiche to the Messenger was take sone
And forth he gooth / ther is nomore to done
¶ O Messager fulfilde of dronkenesse
Stronge is thy breth / thy lym̄mes faltren ay
And thow be wreyest al secrenesse
Thy mynde is lorn / thow Ianglest as a Iay
Thy face is turned in a newe array

l.hi: There dronkenesse reigneth in any route
Ther is no counsel hidde / . wᵗith outen doute

div.l: ¶ O Donegild I ne haue non englyssh digne
Vnto thy malice ⁊and thy tirannye
And therfore to the fende · I the resigne
Lete hym enditen of thi traitorye
Fy mannyssh fy / o nay by god I lye
Fy fendelich spirit for I dare wele telle
Thogh thow here walke / thi spirit is in helle
¶ This messager cometh fro the kynge a gayn
And at the kynges Modres Court he lyght /
And she was of this Messager full fayn
And plesed hym in al that eủer she myght /
He dranke · ⁊and wele his girdel vnder pight /*
He slepeth · ⁊and he fnorteth . in his gyse
Al nyght /* til the sonne gan aryse /
¶ Eft were his lrēms / stolen eủerychone
And countrefeted lrēms in this wyse /
The kyng cōmmaundeth his Constable anone
Vp peyne of hangyng on on heigh Iewyse
That he ne shulde suffren in no wyse
Custaunce Inwith his reigne for to abide
Thre dayes / ⁊and a quarter of a tyde
¶ But in the shmesameshame shippe · as he hir fonde
Hire ⁊and hire yonge sone / ⁊and al hire gere
He sholde putte · ⁊and crowde hir fro the londe
And charge hire / that she neủer efte come there /
O my Custaunce / wele may thy goost haue fere
And slepyng in thy dreem ben in penaunce
Whan Donegild caste all this ordenaunce
¶ This Messager on morwe whan that he wooke
Vnto the Castel halte the nexte way
And to the Constable he the lrēm toke
And that he this Pitous lrēm say
Full ofte he seide allas ⁊and weillaway
Lord Crist qduod he how may this world endure
So full of synne · is many a creature /
¶ O myghti god · if that it be thi wille
Sith thow art rightful Iuge / how may it be
That þᵘ wolt suffren Innocentz to spille
And wicked folke regnen in ꝓprosꝑperite
O good Custaunce / allas so wo is me
That I moot be thy tormentour / or dey
On shames deth · ther is non other wey
¶ Wepen bothe yonge ⁊and olde / in al that place
Whan that the kynge this cursed lrēm sente
And Custaunce · with a dedly pale face
The ferthe day toward hir shippe she wente
But natheles / she taketh in good entente
The wille of Criste / ⁊and knelynge on the stronde
She seide lorde / ay welcome be thy sonde /
¶ He that me kepte from the fals blame
While I was on the londe amonges yow
He kan me kepe · fro harme ⁊and eke fro shame
In salte see · al thow I see nat how
As stronge as eủer he was · he is yet now
In hym triste I /* ⁊and in his Moder dere
That is to me / my saile / ⁊and eke my stere /
¶ Hir litel childe lay wepyng in hire arme /
Pees litel sone I wol do the non harme
With that hir couerchir of hire heed she breyde
And oủer his litel eyen she it leyde
And in hir arme / she lulleth it full faste
And in to heuene · hir eyen vp she kaste /
¶ Moder qduod she / and maide bright marie
Sooth is that thurgh wōmmans eggemente
Mankynde was lorn / and dampned ay to dye /
For whiche thi childe was / on a croys I rente
Thy blysfull eyghen / saugh al his turmente /
Than is there no comꝑperison betwene
Thy woo · ⁊and any woo man may sustene
¶ Thow saugh thi childe y slayn · byfore thyn eyen
And yet now leueth my litel childe ꝑperfay
Now lady bright / to whom alle wooful crien
Thow glorie of womanhode · thow faire may
Thow hauen of refute · bright sterre of day
Rewe on my childe / that of thi gentillesse
Rewest on eủery rewfull in distresse /
¶ O litel childe allas / what is thi gilt
That neủer wroghtest synne as yet ꝑperde
Why wole thyn herde fader / han the spilt /
O mercy dere Constable qduod she
As late my litel childe · dwelle here with the
And if thow darst nat / sauen hym for blame
So kysse hym oones in his fadres name
¶ Ther with she loked a bakwarde to the londe
And seide farewele housband routheles
And vp she riste ⁊and walketh doun the stronde
Toward the shippe · hir folewith al the prees
And eủer she preieth hire childe · to holden his pees
And taketh hire leue / ⁊and with an holy entente
She blisseth hire · and into shippe she wente /
¶ Vitailled was the shippe · it is no drede
Habundantly for hire full longe space
And oother necessaries / that sholde nede
She hath y now / heried by goddis grace
For wynde ⁊and weder / al myghti god purchace
And brynge hir hoom / I kan no better sey
But in the see / she dryueth forth hir wey /
¶ Alla the kynge · cometh home sone after this
Vnto his Castel of the whiche I tolde
And asketh where his wife · ⁊and his childe is
The Constable gan aboute his herte colde
And pleynly al the man̉er he hym tolde
As ye han herde I kan telle it no bettre
And sheweth the kynges seel · ⁊and his lettre
¶ And seide lorde as ye cōmmaunded me
Vppeyne of deth /* so haue I doo certeyn /
This Messanger tormented was til he
Moste be knowe / ⁊and tellen plat ⁊and pleyn
Fro nyght · in what place he had leyn
And thus by witte ⁊ subtil enquerynge
Ymagened was by whom this harme gan sprynge
¶ The honde was knowe / that the lre wroot
And all the venym of this cursed dede
But in what wise / certeynly I noot
Theffecte is this / that Alla oute of drede
His moder slough / that may men pleynly rede
For that she traitour was / to hire ligeaunce
Thus endeth olde Donagild with myschaunce /
¶ The sorwe that this Alla nyght ⁊ day
Maketh for his wife . ⁊ for his childe also
Ther is no tunge that it telle may /
But now wole I vnto Custaunce goo
That flateth in the / see / in peyne ⁊ wo
Fyue yere ⁊ more / as liked cristes sonde
Er that hire shippe / approched to the londe
¶ Vnder an hethen Castel / at the laste
Of whiche the name in my texte noght I fynde
Custaunce ⁊ eke hir childe / the see vp caste
Al myghty god that saued al mankynde
Haue on Custaunce ⁊ on hire childe som mynde
That fallen is in hethen hand eft sone
In poynt to spille / as I shalle telle yow sone
¶ Doun fro the Castel cometh ther many a wight
To gauren on this shippe / and on Custaunce
But shortly from the Castel on anyght
The lordes stywarde / god yeue hym myschaunce
A theef that hadde reneied oure creaunce
Cam in to shippe allone. and seide he sholde
Hir leman be / wher she wolde or nolde
¶ Woo was this wrecched woman thoo bygoon
Hir childe cride / ⁊ she cride petously
But blisfull marie heelpe / hire right anoon
For with hire strogelyng wele ⁊ myghtely
The theef fel oủer borde al sodeinly
And inthe see he dreynte for vengeaunce
And thus hath criste / vnwēmmed kept Custaunce
¶ O foule luste of luxurie. loo thyn ende
Nat oonly that / thow fayntest mann̉er mynde
But verely thow wolt his body shende
Thende of thy werke. or of thy lustes blynde
Is cōmpleynyng how many oon may men fynde
That nat for werke somtyme / but for thentente
To doon this synne / ben other slayn or shent
¶ How may this wayke wōmman han this strengthe
Hir to defende . agayn this renegat
O golias vnmesurable of lengthe
How myght Dauy make the so maat
So yonge ⁊ of armure . so desolaat
How dorste he loke . vpon thy dredfull face
Wele may men seen it was but goddis grace
¶ Who yaf Iudith corage . or hardynesse
To slen hym Olyfern in his tente
And to delyủeren. oute of wrecchednesse
The peple of god I sey for this entente
That right as god / spirit of vigour sente
To hem ⁊ saued hem oute of meschaunce
So sente he myght ⁊ vigour to Custaunce
¶ Forth gooth hir shippe . thurgh oute the narwe mouth
Of Iubaltare . and Septe / dryuyng alway
Somtyme weste . and somtyme North ⁊ South
And somtyme Est / full many a wery day
Til Cristes moder . blessed be she ay
Hath shapen thourgh her endeles goodnesse
To make an ende of all hir heuynesse
¶ Now late vs stynte of Custaunce butt a throwe
And speke we of the Romayn Emꝑperour
That oute of Surrye hath by lres knowe
The slaughter of Cristen folke ⁊ dishonour
Doon to his doughter by a fals traitour
I mene the cursed wikked Soudanesse
That at the feest leet slee both more ⁊ lesse
¶ For whiche this Emꝑperour / hath sente a non
His Senatour with roial ordenᵃaunce
And oother lordes / god woot many oon
On Surriens / to take heigh vengeaunce
They brennen / sleen / ⁊ brynge hem to meschaunce
Ful many aday / but shortly this is thende
Homward to Rome . they shapen hem to wende
¶ This Senatour repaireth with victorie
To Roome warde seillyng / full Roially
And mette the shippe . dryuynge . as seith ye storie
In whiche Custaunce / sit ful Pitously
No thynge knewe he / what she was ne why
She was in swiche array / ne she nel seye
Of hire estate though she sholde deye
¶ He bryngeth hire to Rome / and to his wyfe
He yafe hire / and hire yonge sone alsoo
And with the Senatour / she ladde hir lyfe
Thus kan oure lady . bryngen oute of woo
Woofull Custaunce ⁊ many a nother moo
And longe tyme dwelled she in that place
In holy werkes eủer as was hir grace
¶ The Senatours wyfe hir Aunte was
But for al that . she knewe here neủer the more
I wole no lenger tarien in this caas
But to kyng Alla . whiche I spake of yore
That wepeth for his wyfe and siketh sore
I wole retourne / ⁊ lete I wole Custaunce
Vnder the Senatours gouernaunce
¶ Kyng Alla . whiche that hadde his moder slayn
Vpon a day felle in swiche repentaunce
That if I shortly tellen shall ⁊ playn
To Rome he cometh to resceyue his penaunce
And putten hym in the popes ordenaunce
In heigh ⁊ lowe / and iħuihesu criste bysought
Foryeue hise wicked werkys / that he wrought
¶ The fame a noon thurgh oute the toun is born
How Alla kynge . shall comen on pilgrymage
By herbergeours . that wenten hym byforn
For whiche the Senatour as was vsage
Rood hym agayns / ⁊ many of his lynage
As wele to shewen his heigh magnificence
As to doon any kyng a reuerence
¶ Greet chere doth this noble Senatour
To kyng Alla . ⁊ he to hym also
Eueriche of hem . dooth oother greet honour
And so bifel that in a day or twoo
This Senatour is to kyng Alla goo
To feeste ⁊ shortly if I shal not lye
Custaunces sone wente in his companye /
¶ Somm̄ men wolde seyn at requeste of Custaunce
This Senatour hath ladde this childe to feste
I may nat tellen . eủery circumstaunce
Be as he may ther was he at the leste
But sooth is this / that at his moders heste
Biforn Alla . duryng the metys space
The childe stood lokyng in the kynges face
¶ This Alla kyng hath of this childe grete wonder
And to the Senatour he seyde a noon
Whos is that faire childe . that stondeth yonder
I noot qᵈuod he by god ⁊ by seint Iohn̄
A moder he hath . but fader hath he noon
That I of woot . but shortly in a stounde
He tolde Alla . how that this childe was founde
¶ But god woot n̄ this Senatour also
So vertuous a lyfer in my lyfe
Ne saugh I neủer as she / ne herde of mo
Of wordly wȳmmen / maide ne of wyfe
I dar wele sayn / hir hadde leuer a knyfe
Thorow oute hir breste / than be a woman wykke
Ther is no man koude brynge hir to that prikke
¶ Now was this childe . as lyke vnto Custaunce
As possible is a creature to be /
This Alla hath the face / in remembraunce
Of dame Custaunce ⁊ ther on mused he
If that the childes moder were aught she
That is his wife . and pryuely he sight
And sped hym fro the table . that he myght /
¶ ꝐPersay thought he . fantome is myn heed
I ought deme of skilfull Iuggement
That in the salte see / my wife is deed /
And aftirwarde he made his argument
What woot I if criste haue hider senteysenteysente
My wife be see . as wele as he hir sente
To my cuntre fro thennes that she wente /
¶ And aftir noon . hoom with the Senatour
Gooth Alla for to sen this wonder chaunce /
This Senatour doth Alla greet honour
And hastely he sente . aftir Custaunce
But trusteth wele . hir luste nat to daunce
Whan that she wiste wherfore was that sonde
Vnnethe vpon hire feet . she myght stoonde /
¶ Whan Alla saugh his wyfe . faire he hir grette
And wepe that it was routhe for to see
For at the first looke . he on hire sette
He knewe wele verrailly that it was she
And she for sorwe . as dom stant as a tre
So was hir herte shette in hire distresse
Whan she remembred his vnkyndenesse
¶ Twies she swowneth in his owne sight
He weep / ⁊ hym excuseth pitously
Now god qᵈuod he / ⁊ his Aalwes bright
So wissely on my soule / as haue mercy
That of youre harme / as gilteles am I
As is Maurice my sone / so like youre face
Elles the fende me fecche / oute of this place
¶ Longe was the sobbyng and the bitter peyne
Er that hir wooful hertes myght ceesse /
Grete was the pite for to hirre hem pleyne
Thurgh whiche pleintes . gan her woo encresse
I pray yow alle my labour to relesse
I may nat telle hir woo / vnto til te morwe
I am so wery for to speke of sorwe
¶ But fynally whan that the sooth is wiste
That Alla . giltles was of hir woo
I trowe an hundred tymes han they kyste
And swiche a blysse is ther bitwixe hem twoo
That saue the Ioye that lasteth eủer moo
Ther nys noon lyke that any creature
Hath seyn . or shall while that the world may dure
¶ Tho preide she hir housband mekely
In relyef of hir longe pitous pyne
That he wolde pray hir Fader specially
That of his mageste he wolde enclyne
To vouche saufe som day with hym to dyne
She preide hym eke that he sholde be no weye
Vnto hir Fader no worde of hir seye
¶ Som men wolde seyn / how that the childe Maurice
Dooth this message vnto this Emꝑperour
But as I gesse Alla was nat so nyce
To hym that was / of so soủereyne honour
As he that is of Cristen folke the flour
Sent any childe / but it is bette to deme
He wente hym selfe / ⁊ so it may wele seme
¶ This Emꝑperour hath graunted gentilly
To come to Dyner / as he hym besought
And wele rede I . he loked bysyly
Vpon this childe . ⁊ on his Doughter thought /
Alla gooth to his Inne / and as hym ought
Arraide for the feste / in eủery wise
As ferforth / as his konnynge may suffise
¶ The morwe kam / ⁊ Alla gan hym dresse
And eke his wyfe this Emꝑperour to mete
And forth they ryde in Ioye ⁊ in gladnesse
And whan she saw; hir Fader in the strete
She lyght doun / and falleth hym to fete
Fader qᵈuod she youre yonge childe Custaunce
Is now full clene / oute of youre remembraunce /
¶ I am youre doughter / Custance qᵈuod she
That whilom ye han sente vnto Surrye
It am I Fader / that in the salte see
Was putte allone . ⁊ dampned forto dye
Now good Fader mercy I yow crye
Sende me nomore vnto non hethenesse
But thonketh my lorde / here of his kyndenesse /
¶ Who kan the petous Ioye tellen alle
Betwix hem three / syn they ben thus I / mette
But of my tale make an ende I shalle /
The day gooth faste . I wole no lenger lette
Thys glade folke to dyner they hem sette
In ioye ⁊ blysse / at mete I lete hem dwelle
A thowsand folde welmore than I kan telle /
¶ This childe Maurice / was sithen Emꝑperour
Made by the pope . ⁊ lyued cristenly
To cristes chirche / he dide grete honour
But I lete all this storie passen by /
Of Custaunce is my tale specially
In the oolde Romayn gestes / may men fynde
Maurices lyfe I bere it nat in mynde /
¶ This kyng Alla whan he his tyme say
With his Custaunce his holy wyfe so swete
To Engelond ben they come the right wey
Where as they lyue / in Ioye ⁊ in quyete
But litel while it lasteth I yow hete
Ioye of this world For tyme wol not abyde
Fro day to nyght it chaungeth as the tyde
¶ Whoo lyued eủer in swiche delyte o day

l.hi: That hym ne meued outher Conscience
Or Ire or talent . or som kynnes affray
Enuye or pride / or passion / or offence ;

div.l: I ne sey but for this ende / this sentence
That litel while / in Ioye or in plesaunce
Lesteth the blisse of Alla / with Custaunce
¶ For deeth that taketh of heigh ⁊ lowe his rente
Whan passed was a yere euene / as I gesse
Oute of this worlde / this kyng Alla he hent
For wham Custaunce hath full greet heuynesse /
Now late vs pray god / his soule blesse
And Dame Custaunce (Finally to seye)
Toward the toun of Rome gooth hir weye
¶ To Rome is come this holy creature
And fyndeth here frendes hole ⁊ sounde
Now is she scaped / al hir auenture
And whan that she hir Fader hath y founde
Doun on hire knees falleth she to grounde
Wepynge for tendernesse / in herte blithe
She herieth god an hundred thowsand sithe
¶ In vertue ⁊ holy almesdede
They leuen alle ⁊ neủer a sonder wend
Til dethe deꝑperted hem / this lyfe they lede
And fareth now wele / my tale is at an ende
Now iħuihesu Criste that of hys myght may sende
Ioye aftir woo . gouerne vs in his grace
And kepe vs alle . that ben in this place . Amen .
Here endeth the tale of the man̄ of lawe
The Marchᵃuntez tale of Ianuarⁱ
WEpyng ⁊and waylynge care ⁊and other sorwe
I know I nough / on eue ⁊and morwe
Quod the Marchaunt ⁊and so dooth other moo
That wedded ben I trowe that hit be so
Ful wele I woot it fareth so be me
I haue a wyfe the werst that may be
For though the fende to here I coupled were
She wolde hym oủer macche I dar wele swere
What sholde I reherce in special
Hire hie malice she is a shrewe with al
Ther is a longe ⁊and a large Difference
Be twix Grisildes grete pacience
And of my wyfe . the passynge cruelte /
Were I vnbounden as I mote y thee
I wolde neủer efte come in the snare
We wedded men lyuen in sorwe ⁊and care
Assaye who wille ⁊and he shall fynde
That I sey soth by seint Thomas of Inde
And for the more part I sey not alle
God shilde that it shulde falle /
A good ʆsir hoost I haue wedded be
Thies Monthes twoo ⁊and more nat parde
And yet I trowe that he that hath alle hys lyve
Wifeles haue ben / thaught þᵗat men wolde hym ryve
Vnto the herte ne coude in no man̉ere
Tellen so moche sorow as I now here
Coude telle of my wyfes cursednesse
Non Marchᵃunt qᵈuod oure oost so god yow blesse
Sen ye so moche knowe of that arte
Full hertely I pᵃray yow telle vs parte /
Gladly qᵈuod he but of myn owen sore
For sory herte I telle may nomore
Whilom ther was dwellyng in lumbardye
A worthy knyght þᵗat born was of Pauye
div.note: Narrac̄io
div.l: In whiche he lyuede / in grete ꝓprosꝑperite
And sixti yere . a wifles man was he
And folewed ay his bodely delyte
On wȳmmen ther as was his Appetyte
As doon these foles that ben seculer
And whan that he was passed sexti yere
Were it for holynesse or dotage
I kan nat sey / but swiche a grete corage
Hadde this knyght / to ben a wedded man
That day ⁊ nyght . he doth that he kan
Thespyen where he myght wedded be
Preyng oure lorde . to gᵃraunte hym that he
Mighte ones knowe / of that blysful lyfe
That is betwixe an housbonde ⁊ his wyfe
And for to lyue vnder that holy bonde
With whiche that god man ⁊ woman bonde
Noon other lyfe seide he is woorth a bene
For wedlokke is so esy ⁊ so clene
That in this worlde it is a paradys
Thus seide this olde knyght that was so wys
And certeynly as soth as god is kynge
To take a wife it is a glorious thynge
And namely whan a man is olde ⁊ hoor
Than is a wife the fruyt of his tresoor
Than sholde he take a yonge wyfe ⁊ a feire
On whiche he myght engendren hym an eyre
And lede his lyfe in Ioye ⁊ in solas
Where as these bachelers syngen allas
Whan that they fynden any adủersite
In loue whiche that nys but childisshe vanyte
And trewely it sitte wele to be soo
That bachilers han ofte peyne ⁊ woo
On brotil grounde they buylde / and brottelnesse
They fynde whan they wene to fynde sikernesse
They lyue but as a bridde . or as a beste
In liberte ⁊ vnder noon arreste
Ther as a wedded man in his estate
Lyueth a lyfe blysful ⁊ ordynat
Vnder this yokke of mariage y bounde
Wele may his herte in Ioye ⁊ blisse habounde
For whoo kan be so buxum as a wyfe
Whoo is so trewe ⁊ eke soo ententyfe
To kepe hym sike ⁊ hole / as is his make
For wele or woo / shee wole hym nat forsake
She nys nat wery hym to loue ⁊ serue
Thow that he lye bedrede til he sterue
And yet som Clerkys seyn . it is nat soo
Of whiche he Theofraste . is oon of thoo
What force thogh Theofastre lyste lye
Ne take no wyfe qᵈuod he for housbondrie
As for to spare in housolde . thy despense
A trewe ʆseruᵃaunt dooth more diligence
Thi good to kepe than thyn owne wyfe
For she wole clayme halfe parte al hire lyfe
And if that thow be sike / so god me saue /
Thy verrey frendes / or a trewe knaue
Wole kepe the bette / than she that waiteth ay
Aftir thi good ⁊ hath don̄ many a day
And if thow take a wife of highe lynage
She shall be hauten ⁊ of grete costage
This sentence and an hundred thynges worse
Writeth this man / ther god his bones curse /
But take no kepe of alle swiche vanyte
Deffye Theofastre / ⁊ herkēm me /
A wife is goddis yefte verreyly
Alle other man̉er yeftes hardely
As londes / rentes / pasture / or cōmmune
Or meobles alle ben yeftes of fortune
That passen as a shadowe on a wal
But drede (if pleynly speke I shal)
A wife wole laste / ⁊ in thyn hous endure
Wele lenger than the leste / ꝑperauenture
Mariage is a full grete sacrament
He whiche that hath no wyfe I holde hym shent
He lyueth helpeles . and alle desolate
I speke of folke in seculer estate
And herke why . I sey nat this for noght
That wōmman is for mannys helpe I wroght /
The heigh god whan he hadde Adam maked
And seigh hym a lone bely naked
God of his greet goodnesse seide than
Late vs now make an helpe vnto this man
Lyke hym selfe . and thanne he made hym Eue /
Here may ye see . and here by may ye preue
That wyfe is mannꝰus helpe / ⁊ his comforte
His Paradys terrestre . and his disporte
So buxom ⁊ so vertuous is she
They moste nedys leue in vnyte
O fleisshe they ben / and o fleisshe as I gesse
Hath but oon herte in wele ⁊ in distresse /
A wyfe a seinte Marie benedicite
How myght a man han any adủersite
That hath a wife / certes I kan nat seye
The blisse whiche that is bitwixe hem tweye
Ther may no tunge telle / or herte thenke
If he be pore / she helpeth hym to swenke
She kepeth his good / ⁊ wasteth neủer a dele
Al that hire husbond luste hire lyketh wele
She seith nat oones nay . whan that he seith ye
Doth this seith he . al redy sire seith she
O blisful ordre / of wedlok precious
Thow arte so murie ⁊ so vertuous
And so cōmmended / and appreued eke
That any man . that halt hym worth a leeke
Vpon hire bare knees / oght al his lyfe
Thanken his god . that hym hath sente a wyfe
Or elles preye to god hym for to sende
A wyfe to laste . vnto his lyues ende /
For thanne his lyfe is sette in sikirnesse
¶ He may nat be desseyued (as I gesse)
So that he werke after hise wyues reed
Than may he boldely beren vp his heed
They ben so trewe ⁊ ther withal so wyse
For whiche if thow wolte / werken as the wyse
Do alwey so as wȳmmen wole the rede /
Lo how that Iacob . as these Clerkes rede
By good counseil / of his Moder Rebekke
Bonde the kydes skyn a boute his nekke
For whiche his Fadres benyson he wan /
¶ Lo Iudith as the storie eke telle kan
By wys counseile . she goddes peple kepte
And slow hym Olofernus while he slepte /
Lo Abigail . by good counseile how she
Saued hire housbonde Nabal . whan that he
Sholde han ben slayn . ⁊ loke Ester also
By good counseille delyủered oute of woo
The peple of . god . ⁊ made hym Mardoche
Of Assuer / enhaunsed for to be /
Ther is no thynge in gree suꝑperlatyfe
As seith Senek . a boue an humble wyfe /
Suffre thy wyfes tunge . as Caton bitte
She shall cōmmaunde ⁊ thow shalt suffren it
And yet she wole obeye of curtesye /
A wife is keper of thyn housbondrye
Wele may the seke man be waille ⁊ wepe
Ther as ther nys no wyfe the hous to kepe /
I warne the . if wysely thow wolte werche
Loue wele thy wyfe . as crist loued his cherche
If thow louest thy selfe . thow louest thy wyfe
Noman hateth his fleisshe but in his lyfe
He fostreth it . and therfore bidde I thee

l.hi: Cherisshe thy wyfe or thow shalt neủer thee /

div.l: Housbonde ⁊ wyfe . what so men Iape or pleye
Of worldly folke holde the syker weye /
They ben so knytte . ther may noon harm betyde
And namely vpon the wyues syde /
For whiche / this Ianuarie of whiche I tolde
Considered hath . Inwith his daies olde
The lusty lyfe . the vertuouse quiete
That is in mariage hony swete
And for his frendes on a day he sente
To tellen hem theffette of his entente
With face sadde . this tale he hath hem tolde
He seide frendes . I am hoore ⁊ olde
And almoste god wote on my pittes brynke
Vpon my soule sōmwhat moste I thynke
I haue my body folyly dispended
Blessed be god / that it shal be amended
For I wole certeyn a wedded man
And that a noon in all the haste I kan
Vnto som maide / faire ⁊ tendre of age
I pray yow shapeth for my mariage
Al sodenly for I wole nat abide
And I wole fonde / tespien on my syde
To whom I may be wedded hastily /
But for as moche . as ye beth mo than I
Ye shullen rather swiche a thyng espyen
Whanne ⁊ where me beste were to allien /
¶ But on thynge warne I yow . my frendes dere
I wole noon olde wyfe / han / in no manere
She shal nat passe .lx. yere certayn
Olde Fysshe / ⁊ yonge fleissh wold I haue full fayn
Bet is qᵈuod he a pik than a pikerel
And bette than olde beef is the tendre veel
I wole no woman .xxx. yere of age
It is but benestrawe ⁊ greet forage
And eke these olde widewes / god it woot
They konne so moche crafte . on wades boot
So mochel brooken harme whan hem leste
That with hem / shuld I neủer leue in reste
For sondry scoles / maketh subtil Clerkis
Wōmmen of many scoles halfe a clerke is /
But certeynly . a yong thyng may men gye
Right as men may . warm wexe / wtith handes plie
Wherfore I sey yow / pleynly in a clause
I wole noon olde wyfe hau / right for this cause
For if so were I hadde swiche meschaunce
That I in here . ne koude haue no plesaunce
Thanne sholde I lede my lyfe in a vowtrie
And streyght to the deuel . whan I dye /
Ne children sholde I noon vppon . hire geten
Yet were me leuer houndes hadde me eten
Than that myn heritage sholde falle
In straunge honde / and this I telle yow alle
I dote nat / . I wote the cause why
Men sholde wedde / ⁊ ferthermore wote I
Ther speketh many a man of mariage
That woot nomore of it . than wote my page
For whiche causes . man sholde take a wife /
If he ne may nat leue chaste hys lyfe
Take hym a wyfe with grete deuocion
By cause of leful procreacoūn
Of children / to honour of god a boue
And nat oonly for ꝑperamour ofr loue
And for they sholde leccherie eschue
And yelde hir dette whan that it is dewe
Or for that eche of hem / sholde helpen other
In myschief as a suster shall the brother
And lyue in chastite full hollyly /
But sires by youre leue / that am nat I
For god be thanked / I dar make asaunt
I fele my lemes sterke / ⁊ suffissaunt
To doo al that a man bylongeth to
I woot my seluen beste what that I may do
Thow I be hore . I fare as dooth a tree
That blosmeth . er that fruyt y woxen be
And blosmy tree / nys neyther drie ne dede
I fele me now heer hoor / but on my hede /
Myn herte ⁊ all my lymes ben as grene
As laurer thourgh the yere / is for to sene
And syn that ye han herde / al myn entente
I pray yow to my wille / ye wole assente /
¶ Dyuers men . dyuersely hym tolde
Of mariage many ensamples olde
Som blamed it . som preised it certeyn /
But at laste shortely for to seyn
As alday falleth altercacion
Bitwix frendis / ⁊ disputison
Ther fell a stryfe be twix his brethern too
Of whiche that oon was cleped placebo
Iustinus soothly called was that other
Placebo seyde / o Ianuarie brother
Ful litel nede / hadde ye my lord so dere
Counseile to axe . of any that is here
But that ye ben so full of sapience
That yow ne liketh / for youre hye prudence
To weyuen fro the word of Salomon
This worde seide he / vnto vs eủerychon
Wirke all thynge be counseile / thus seide he
And than shalt thow . nat repente the /
But thow that Salomon / spak swiche a word
Myn owene dere brother . ⁊ my lorde
So wisly god my soule brynge at reste
I holde youre owen counseile is the beste
For brother myne of me take this motyf
I haue now ben a court man al my lyf
And god it woot / thogh I vnworthi be
I haue stonden in full degree
A bouten lordes of full greet estate
Yet hadde I neủere with noon of hem debate
I neủere hem contraried trewely
I woot wele that my lorde kan more than I
What that he seith . I holde it ferme ⁊ stable
I sey the same / or elles thynge semblable
A full greet fole / is any counseillour
That serueth any lorde of heigh honour
That dare presume or elles thenke it
That his counseile shold passe his lordes wit
Nay lordes ben no fooles / by my say
Ye han youre seluen / heer to day
So heigh sentence so holyly ⁊ wele
That I consente ⁊ conferme eủerydel
Youre wordes alle . and youre opynyoun
By god ther nys no man . in al this toun
Ne in Itaile . couthe bette han I sayde /
Crist halt hym of this counseil . ful wele apayd
And trewely it is an heigh corage
Of any man / that stapen is in age
To take a yonge wyfe / by my fader kyn
Youre herte hongeth on a Ioly pyn
Doth now in this matere right as yow lest
For finally I holde it for the best /
¶ Iustinus that ay stille sate and herde /
Right in this wise he to Placebo answerde /
Now brother myn be pacient I preye
Syn ye han seide , ⁊ herkeneth what I seye
Senek a monges other wordes wise
Seith that a man ought hym riȝt wele auyse
To whom he yeueth his londe or his catele
And syn I oughte . auysen me right wele
To whom I yeue my good a way fro me
Wele moche more . I ought auysen me
To whom I yeue my body , for alwey
I warne yow wele it is no childes pley
To take a wyfe with outen auysement
Men moste enquere this is myn assente
Wher she be wys ⁊ sobre . or dronkelewe
Or proude / or elles other weyes a shrewe
A chidestere . or wastour of thi good
Or riche or pore . or mannyssh wood
Al be it so / that no man fynden shal
Noon in this world / that trotteth hool in al
Ne man ne beste . swiche as men coude deuyse,
But natheles . it ought I now suffise
With any wyfe / if so were that she hadde
Moo good thewes / than hire vices badde
And alle this axeth leyser tenquere /
For god it woot / I haue wepte many a tere
Ful pⁱriuely syn that I hadde a wyfe
Preise who so wole a wedded mannꝰus lyfe
Certeyn I fynde in it . but coste ⁊ care
And obʆseruaunces . of alle blisses bare
And yet god woot . my neighebors aboute
And namely of wȳmmen many a route
Seyn that I haue the most stedefast wyf
And eke the mekest oon that bereth lyf
Bote I woot beste / where wryngeth me my shoo
Ye mowe for me right as yow liketh doo
Auyseth yow . ye ben a man of age
How that ye entren into mariage
And namely with a yonge wyfe ⁊ a fair
By hym that made water erthe ⁊ ayr
The yongest man that is in al this route
Is besy I now to bryngen it a boute
To han his wyfe allone tristeth me
Ye shulle nat pleasen hire fully yeris thre
This to seyn to doon hire ful plesaunce
A wife axeth ful many an obꝸseruaunce
I prey yow that ye be nat yuel apaid /
Wele qd this Ianuarie / and hastow y sayd ;
Strawe for thy Senek and for thy ꝓprouerbes
I counte nat a panyer ful of herbes
Of scole termes / wiser men than thow
As thow haste herde assentedyn right now
To my pupos / Placebo what say ye
I sey it is a cursed man / qd he
That letteth Matrymoigne sikerly
And with that worde . they risen sodeynly
And ben assented fully that he sholde
Be wedded whan hym luste ⁊ where he wolde
¶ Heigh fantasye / and curious besynesse
Fro day to day / gan in the soule impresse
Of Ianuarie / a boute his mariage
Many faire shap . ⁊ many a faire visage
Ther passeth thurgh his herte nyght be nyght
As who so toke a Myrrour polisshed bright
And sette it in a comune Market place
Than shulde he see ful many a figure pace
By his myrrour . and in the same wyse
Gan Ianuarie / in with his thoght deuyse
Of Maidens whiche that dwelten hym bysyde right
He wiste nat where that he myght abyde
For if that oon haue beaute in hire face
Another stant so in the peples grace
For hir sadnesse ⁊ hir benygnyte
That of the peple . grettest voys hath she
And sōmme were riche . ⁊ hadden badde name
But natheles bitwix ernest ⁊ game
He atte laste / apoynted hym oon
And lete alle other from his herte goon
And chees hire of his owne auctorite
For loue is blynde alday ⁊ may nat see /
And whan that he was in his bedde y brought
He purtreide in his herte and in his thought
Hire freisshe beaute . and hire age tendre
Hire Middel smal . here armes longe ⁊ sclendre
Hire wise gouꝰernaunce . hire gentilesse
Hire womanly beryng ⁊ hir sadnesse
And whan that he on hire . was condescended
Hym thought his choys myght noght ben amended /
For whan that he hym selfe . concluded hadde
Hym thought eche other mannys witte so badde
That impossible / it were to replie
Agayn his choys . this was his fantasye /
His frendes sente he too / at his instaunce
And praied hym to doon hym that plesaunce
That hastely . they wolden to hym come
He wolde abregge her labour alle ⁊ some
Nedeth nomore for hym to goo ne ride
He was apoynted ther he wolde abyde
¶ Placebo cam ⁊ eke his frendes sone
And Alderfirst he bade hem alle a bone
That noon of hem / non argumentz make
A gayn the purpos . whiche that he hath take
Whiche purpos was plesaunt to god seyde he
And verrey ground of his ꝓprosꝑperite /
He seyde ther was a maide in the toun
Whiche of beaute hadde grete renoun
Al were it so . she were of smal degre
Suffiseth hym her youthe ⁊ hire beaute
Whiche maide he seide / he wolde han to his wife
To lede in ese ⁊ holynesse his lyfe
And thanked god that he myght han hir al
That no wight his blisse parten shal
And preied hem to labour in this nede
And shapen that he faile nat to spede
For thanne he seyde . his spirit was at ese
Than is qd he . nothyng may me displese
Saue o thynge priketh in my conscience
The whiche I wole reherce in youre pꝰersence
I haue qd he herde seyde . ful yore a goo
Ther may no man han ꝑperfit blisses twoo
This is to seye . in erthe ⁊ eke in heuene
For though he kepe hym fro the synnes seuene
And eke from euꝰery braunche of thilke tree
Yet is there so ꝑperfite felicite
And so grete eese ⁊ luste in mariage
That euꝰer I am a gaste now in myn / age
That I shal lede now / so mury a lyfe
So delicate with oute woo or stryfe
That I shal han my / heuene in erthe here
For sith that verrey heuene is bought so dere
With tribulacoūn ⁊ grete penaunce
How sholde I thanne leuen in in swiche plesaunce
As alle wedded men . do with hire wyues
Come to the blysse . ther criste eterne on lyue is
This is my drede . ⁊ ye my bretheren twey
Assoilleth me this question I prey /
Iustinus whiche that hated his folie
Answerde a noon right in his Iaperye
And for he wolde his longe tale a bregge
He wolde non auctorite allegge
But seide sire . so ther be non obstacle
Other than this / god of his hye myracle
And of his mercy may so for yow wirche
That er ye han . youre right of holy chirche
Ye may repente of wedded mann9 lyfe
In whiche ye seyn / ther nys no woo ne stryfe
And elles god forbede but he sente
A wedded man / hym grace to repente
Wele ofte rather . than a sengle man
And therfore sire the beste rede I kan
Dispeire yow noght but haue in youre memorie
ꝐPeraunter she may be youre purgatorie
She may be goddys mene . and goddis whippe
Than shal youre soule vp to heuene skippe
Swifter than doth an arwe . oute of a bowe
I hope to god . her after shul ye knowe
That ther nys non so grete felicite
In mariage ne neuꝰer mo shal be
That yow shal lette . of youre sauacion
So that ye vse as skile is ⁊ reson
The lustes of youre wife attemprely
And that ye plese hir nat to amorously
And that ye kepe yow eke from other synne
My tale is doon for my witte is thynne
Beth nat agaste her of my brother dere
But late vs waden oute of this matere
The wyfe of Bathe . yf ye han vndirstonde
Of mariage whiche we han on honde
Declared hath ful wele in litel space /
Fareth now wele god haue yow in his grace /
And with this worde . Iustyn ⁊ his brother
Han take hir leue . ⁊ eche of hem of other /
For whan they sawe . that it most nedes be
They wroughten so / be sly ⁊ wys trete
That she this maiden . whiche that Mayus hight
As hastely . as euꝰer that she myght
Shal wedded be vnto this Ianuarie /
I trowe it were so longe yow to tarie
Yf I yow tolde of euꝰery scripte ⁊ bonde
By whiche that she was feffed in his honde
Or for to herknen . of hire riche array
But finally . y comen is that day
That to the chirche / bothe be they wente
For to resceyue / the holy sacrament
Forth cometh the preest . with stole a boute his nekke
And bade hir bylyke . Sarra . ⁊ Rebekke
In wisdom ⁊ in trouth of mariage
And seide his orisons . as is vsage
And crowched hem . ⁊ bade god sholde hem blesse
And made al siker y nowe . with holynesse
Thus ben they wedded with solempnite
And at the feste sitteth he ⁊ she
With other worthy folke vpon the deys
Al ful of Ioye ⁊ blisse is the paleys
And ful of Instrumentz ⁊ of vitaille
The moste deynteuous of alle Itaille
Byforn hem stood swiche instrumentz of swiche soun
That Orpheus . nof Thebes Amphyon
Ne maden neuꝰer swiche a melodie
At euꝰery cours than cam loud mynstralcie
That neuꝰer trumped Ioab for to here
Ne he Therdomas yet halfe so clere
At Thebes whan the Cite was in doute
Bachus the wyn hem shynketh al aboute
And venus laugheth vpon euꝰery wight
For Ianuarie was bicome her knyght
And wolde bothe assaie his corage
In liberte ⁊ eke in mariage
And with hire firbrond in hir hand a boute
Daunceth byforn the bride / and alle þe route
And certeynly I dar right wele sey this
Imeneus that god of weddyng is
Say neuꝰer his lyfe . so mury a wedded man /
Holde thow thi pees . thow Poet Marcian
That writest vs . that ilke weddynge murye
Of hire Philologie . and hym Mercurie
And of the songes that the muses songe /
To smal is bothe thy penne . ⁊ eke thy tonge
For to descryuen of this mariage
Whan tendre youthe . hath wedded stoupyng age
Ther is swiche merthe . that it may nat be writen
Assaieth it youre selfe / than may ye witen
If that I lye or noon in this matere /
Mayus that sitte . with so benygne a chere
Hir to byholde . it semed fairye
Quene . Ester loked neuꝰer with swiche an ye
On Assuer so meke a look hath she /
I may yow nat deuyse al hir beaute /
But thus moche of hire beaute telle I may /
That she was like the bright morwe of May
Fulfilled of alle beaute ⁊ plesaunce /
This Ianuarie is rauysshed in a traunce /
At euꝰery tyme he loked on hire face
But in his herte he gan hir to manace
That he that nyght in armes wolde hir streyne
Harder than euꝰer Parys dide Eleyne /
But natheles / yet hadde he grete pite /
That thilke nyght offenden hire moste he /
And thoughte allas / o tendre creature
Now wold god / ye myght wele endure
Al my corage . it is so sharpe ⁊ kene /
I am a gaste . ye shul nat it sustene /
But god forbede I dede al my myght
Now wolde god . that it were waxen nyght
And that the nyght wole lasten euꝰer mo /
I wolde that al this peple were a go
And finally he doth alle his labour
As he beste myght / sauyng his honour
To haste hem fro the mete in sotil wise /
The tyme kam that reson was to rise /
And aftir that men daunce ⁊ drynke faste
And spices al a boute the hous they caste
And ful of Ioye ⁊ blisse is euꝰery man /
Al but a Squier hight Damyan
Whiche karfe byfore the knyght many a day /
He was so rauysshed on that lady May
That for the verrey peyne / he was nyz wood
Almoste he swelte . and swowned as he stood /
So sore hath venus . hurte hym with hir brond
As that she bare it / daunsynge in hire hond
And to his bedde he went hym hastyly /
Nomore of hym / at this tyme speke I /
But there I lete hym wepe ynow and pleyne
Til freisshe May . wol rewen on his peyne
O perilous fire . that in the bedstrawe bredeth /
O famulier foe that his seruise bedith
O ꝸseruant traitour . false homly hewe
Lyke to the Neddre in bosom / sly vntrewe
God shilde vs alle . from youre acqueintaunce /
O Ianuarie . dronken in plesaunce
In Mariage se how thy Damyan
Thyn owne Squyer . and thy born man
Entendeth for to do the vylenye /
God graunt the thy homly foo espie

l.hi: For in this world . nys worse pestilence

div.l: Than homly foo / alday in thy pꝰersence /
ꝐPerfourmed hath the sonne . this Ark diurne
No lenger may the body of hym soiourne
On thorisonte / as in that / latitude
Right with his mantel . that is derke ⁊ rude
Gan ouꝰer sprede / themysperie aboute /
For whiche deꝑperted is . this lusty route
Fro Ianuarie . with thanke on euꝰery syde
Hoom to hire houses / lustely they ryde
Where as they doon hem thynges as hem lyste
And whan they sey her tyme go to reste /
Sone aftir that . this hasty Ianuarie
Wole go to bedde he wole no lenger tarie
He drynketh ypocras . clarre ⁊ vernage
Of spices hote . tencrescen his corage
And many a letuarie hadde he ful fyn
Swiche as the Cursed Monke . Daun Constantyn
Hath writen in his book de coitu
To eten hem alle . he nas no thynge eschewe
And to hise piriue frendes . thus seide he
For goddis loue as sone as it may be
Late voiden al this hous . in curteys wise /
And they han doon . right as he wole deuyse /
Men drynken / and the trauers drawe anoon
The bride was brought a bedde . as stille as stoon
And whan the bedde was with the preest y blessed
Oute of the chaumbre hath euꝰery wight hym dressed
And Ianuarie hath / faste in armes take
His freisshe May / his paradys / his make
He lulleth hire . he kysseth hire ful ofte
With thilke bristles / of his berde vnsofte
Lyke to the skyn of houndfisshe sharpe as brere
For he was shaue al newe . in his manere
He rubbeth hire . a boute hire tendre face
And seide thus . Allas / I mote trespace
To yow my spouse / and yow gretly offende
Er tyme come . that I wole / doun descende
But natheles considereth this qd he
Ther nys no werkman . (what so euꝰer he be)
That may both werke wele ⁊ hastely
This wole be do at leyser ꝑperfitly .
It is no fors how longe that we pleye
In trewe wedlok coupled be we tweye
And blissed be the yokke that we ben Inne
For in actes . we mow do no synne
A man may do no synne with his wyfe
Ne hurte hym seluen with his owen knyfe
For we haue leue for to pleye as by the lawe /
Thus lauboreth . til that the day gan dawe
And thanne he taketh a soppe in fyn clarre
And vpright in his bedde than sitteth he
And aftir that he songe ful loude ⁊ clere
And kyste his wyfe . ⁊ made wantown chere
He was al Coltisshe ful of ragerye
And ful of Iargoūn . as a flekked pye /
The slak skyn a boute his nekke shaketh
While that he songe . so chaunteth he ⁊ craketh /
But god woot what that may thought in hire herte
Whan she hym sawe vp sittynge in his sherte
In his nyght cappe . and with his nekke lene
She preiseth nat his pleiyng worth a bene /
Than seide he thus my reste wole I take
Now day is come I may no lenger wake
And doun he leide his heed / ⁊ sleep / til prime
And aftirward whan he sawe his tyme
Vp riseth Ianuarie / but freisshe May
Helde hir chambre vnto the ferthe day
As vsage is of wyues . for the beste
For euꝰery labour somtyme moot haue reste
Or elles / longe may he nat endure /
This is to seyn / no lyues creature
Be it of fisshe / or brid / or beest / or man /
¶ Now wole I speke of woful Damyan
That langwissheth for loue . as ye shul here /
Therfore I speke to hym in this manere
I sey / o sely Damyan allas
Answere to my demaunde as in this cas
How shaltow to thy lady freisshe May
Telle thy wo . she wole alwey sey nay /
Eke if thow speke / she wol thy woo be wreye
God be thyn helpe I kan no bettre seye /
This sike Damyan . in venus fire
So brenneth / that he dieth for desire /
For whiche / put his lyfe in aventure
No lenger myght he in this wise endure
But piriuely a penner gan he borwe
And in a lettre wroot he al his sorwe
In manꝰer of a compleynt or a lay
Vnto his faire freisshe lady May
And in a purs of selke henge on his sherte
He hath it putte / ⁊ leyde it at his herte
¶ The mone that at noon was thilke day
Þat Ianuarie hath wedded freissh May
In two of Taure / was in to Cancre gliden
So longe hath Maius in hire chambre abiden
As custume is / vnto this nobles alle /
A bride / shal nat eten in the halle
Til daies foure . or thre daies . atte leeste
I passed ben / than late hire goo to feste /
The fourth day complete / from noon to noon
Whan that the heigh masse was y doon
In halle sitte this Ianuarie ⁊ May
As freissh as is the bright someris day
And so byfel how that this good man
Remembred hym . vpon thys Damyan
And seide seynt marie how may it be
That Damyan entendeth nat to me
Is he ay sike . or how may this bitide ;
His squyers whiche that stoden ther bysyde
Excused hym / by cause of hys sikenesse
Whiche letted hym to do his besynes
Noon other cause . myght make hym tarie /
That me forthynketh / qd this Ianuarie
He is a gentel squier / by my treuthe
If that he deied . it were harme ⁊ reuthe
He is as wys / discreet ⁊ secre
As any man I woot of his degree
And therto manly ⁊ eke seruysable
And for to be a thrifty man right able /
But after mete as sone as euꝰer I may
I wole my selfe visite hym ⁊ eke May
To do hym al the comfort that I kan
And for that worde hym blyssed euꝰery man
That of his bounte ⁊ his gentillesse
He wolde so conforten in sikenesse
His squyer for it was a gentel dede /
Dame qd this Ianuarie take good hede
At aftir mete ye with youre wymen alle
Whan ye han ben in youre chambre oute of this halle
That alle ye goo to see this Damyan
Dooth hym disport . he is a gentil man
And telleth hym / that I wole hym visite /
Haue I no thynge but redded me a lyte
And spede yow faste . for I wole a byde
Til that ye slepe faste be my syde
And with that worde he gan to hym to calle
A squyer that was Marchal of his halle
And tolde hym certeyn thynges what he wolde /
This freisshe May hath streight hir wey y holde
With alle hir wymen vnto Damyan /
Doun by his beddes side / sit she than
Confortynge hym . as goodly as she may /
This Damyan whan that his tyme he say
In secre wise / his purs ⁊ eke his bille
In whiche that he y writen hadde his wille
Hath put in to hir hande with outen more /
Saue that he siketh wonder depe ⁊ sore
And softely to hire . right thus seide he
Mercy . and that ye nat discouꝰere me
For I am deed . if that this thynge be kyd /
This pors hath she / in with hir bosom hid /
And wente hire wey ye gete nomore of me /
But vnto Ianuarie y comen is she /
That on his beddys syde sitte ful softe
And taketh hire / ⁊ kisseth hire ful ofte /
And leide hym doun to slepe / And that a noon /
She feyned hire . as that she most goon
Ther as ye woot / . that euꝰery wight mote nede /
And whan she of this bille . hath taken hede
She rente it al to cloutes / atte laste /
And in the piriue . softely it caste
¶ Whoo studieth now . but faire fressh May /
A doun by olde Ianuary she lay
That sleept / til that the cough hath hym a waked
A non he preide hire . strepen hire al naked
He wolde of hire he seide . han som plesaunce /
He seide hir clothes / dide hym encombraunce
And she obeieth . be / hee lief or loth
But lest that pꝰercious folke be with me wrooth
How that he wrought . I dar nat to yow telle
Or whether that hir thought it . Paradys or helle /
But here I lete hem werken in hir wise
Til euesonge range / and that they most aryse /
Were it be destynee / or by auenture
Were it by influence or be nature
Or constellacoūn / that in swiche estate
The heuene stood that tyme fortunate
As for to putte a bille of venus werkys /
(For al thynge hath tyme . as seyn these clerkys)
To any woman for to gete hir loue
I kan not sey / but grete god aboue
That knowith / that noon acte / is causeles
He deme of alle / for I wole holde my pees /
But sooth is this / how that this freisshe May
Hath taken . swiche impression that day
Of pite on this sike Damyan
That from hire herte she ne dryue kan
The remembraunce / for doon hym ese
Certeyn thoght she / whom that this thyng displese
I rekke nat . for here I hym assure
To loue hym beste of any creature
Thogh he nomore hadde than his sherte /
Lo pitee renneth sone in gentel herte /
¶ Here may ye see . how excellent fraunchise
In wōmman is whan they hem narwe auyse /
Some tiraunt is / as . ther be many oon
That hath an herte . as harde as is a stoon
Whiche wolde han late hym steruen in the place
Wele rather than han graunted hym hire grace
And hem reioysen / in hir cruel pride
And rekke nat to ben / an homycyde
This gentil May . fulfilled of pite
Right of hire honde a lettre maked she
In whiche she graunteth hym hir verrey grace
Ther lakketh nat oonly but day ⁊ place
Where that she myght vnto his luste suffise /
For it shal be right as he wole deuyse /
And whan she sawe hir tyme vpon a day
To visite this Damyan goth May
And subtilly this lettre doun she threste
Vndir his pilwe rede it if hym leste /
She taketh hym by the hande . ⁊ harde hym twiste
So secrely that no wight it wiste
And bad hym be al hool . ⁊ forth she wente
To Ianuarie . whan that he for hire sente /
¶ Vp riseth . Damyan the nexte morwe /
Al passed was his sikenesse ⁊ his sorwe /
He kembeth hym / he preyneth hym ⁊ pyketh /
He doth al that his lady luste ⁊ lyketh /
And eke to Ianuarie he gooth as lowe
As euꝰer dide a dogge for the bowe /
He is so plesaunt vnto euꝰery man /
(For crafte is al . who so that do it kan)
That euꝰery wight is fayn to speke hym good
And fully in his ladies grace he stood /
Thus late I Damyan / aboute his nede
And in my tale . forth I wole ꝓprocede .
¶ Som Clerkes holden that felicite
Stant in delyte . ⁊ therfore certeyn he
This noble Ianuarie . with al his myght
In honest wise as longeth to a knyght
Shoop hym to lyue ful deliciously
His housyng / his array / as honestly
To his degre was maked as a kynges .
Amonges other / of hise honest thynges
He made a gardyn walled al with stoon
So faire a gardyn wote I nowher noon
For oute of doute I verrely suppose
That he that wroot the romaunce of the rose
Ne koude of it the beaute wele deuyse /
Ne priapus / ne myght nat suffise
(Thow he by god of gardyns) for to telle
The beaute of the gardyn / of the welle
That stood vnder a laurer alwey grene
Ful ofte tyme / he pluto ⁊ his quene
Proserpina . and al hire fairie
Desporten hem / and maken melodie
Aboute that welle / and daunced as men tolde /
This noble knyght / . this Ianuarie the olde
Swiche deynte hath in it to walke ⁊ pleye
That he wole no wight soffre bere the keye
Saue he hym selfe for of the smale wiket
He bare alwey / of syluer a Clykket
With whiche / whan that hym lyst / he it vnshet /
And whan that he wolde pay his wife hir dette
In somer sesoun theder wolde he goo /
And May his wyf and no wight but they two /
And thynges whiche that were nat doon abedde
He in the gardyn / ꝑperfourmed hem ⁊ spedde
And in this wise many a mery day
Lyued this Ianuarie / ⁊ this freisshe May /
But wordly Ioy may nat alway dure
To Ianuarie ne to no creature /
O. sodeyn hap .o. thow fortune vnstable
Lyke to the Scorpion . so deceyuable
That flaterist with thyn heed . whan þu wolt stynge
Thy taille is deth . thurgh thyn enūnemynge /
O. brotel Ioye / o swete venym queynte
O. Monstre . that so subtily kanst peynte
Thy yeftes vnder hewe of stedenastnesse
That thow deceyuest both more ⁊ lesse ;
Why hast thow Ianuarie thus deceyued ;
That haddest hym for thy fulle frend receyued
And now thow haste byrafte hym both his eyen ;
For sorwe of whiche desireth he to deyen
Allas this noble Ianuarie free
A Midde his luste ⁊ his ꝓprosꝑperite
Is woxen blynde / And that al sodeynly /
He wepeth ⁊ he wailleth pitously
And ther with al . the fire of Ialousye
Leste that his wife . shulde falle in som folye
So brente his herte / that he wolde fayn
That som man . bothe hire ⁊ hym hadde slayn /
For neither aftir his deth ne in his lyfe
Ne wolde he . that she . were loue ne wyfe /
But euꝰer lyue as widwe . in clothes blake
Soul as the turtle . that loste hath hir make /
But atte laste . aftir a Monthe or twey
His sorwe gan a swage . soth to seye /
For whan he wiste . it may non other be
He paciently toke his aduꝰersite /
Saue oute of doute . he may nat forgon
That he nas Ialous . euꝰer more in oon /
Whiche Ialowsie . it was so outrageous
That neither in halle . ne in noon other hous
Ne in noon other place . neuꝰer the moo
He nolde suffre hire . for to ride or goo
But if that he had hond . on hire alway /
For whiche ful ofte wepeth freissh May
That loueth Damyan . so benignely
That she moot other deyen sodenly
Or elles she moot han hym as hir leste
She waiteth whan hire herte wolde berste /
¶ Vpon that other syde eke Damyan
Bicomen is the sorwefullest man
That euꝰer was . for nouther nyght ne day
Ne myght he speke a word to Freissh May
As to his pupos . of no swiche matere /
But if that Ianuarie moste it here
That hadde an hande vpon hir euꝰer mo /
But natheles . by writyng to ⁊ fro
And pryue signes . wiste he what she mente
And she knewe eke the fyn of his entent /
¶ O Ianuarie / what myght it the availe
Thow myghtest see / as fer as shippes saile
For as good is blynde deceyued be
As to be deceyued whan a man may se /
Lo Argus . whiche that hadde an hundred eighen
For al that euꝰer he coude poure or pryen
Yet was he blent . ⁊ god woot so be moo
That weneth wisly . that it be nat soo /
Passe ouꝰer is an ese / I sey namore /
This freisshe May . that I spake of so yore
In warm wex . hath emprented the Cliket
That Ianuarie bare of that smale wyket
By whiche in to his gardy ofte he wente /
And Damyan that knewe al his entente
The Clyket countrefeted piriuely
Ther nys nomore to sey but hastyly
Som wonder of this Cliket shal betyde
Whiche ye shul heren . if ye wole abyde /
¶ O. noble Ouyde . ful soth seith thow god woot
That sleyght is it . though it be longe ⁊ hoot
That he nel fynde it oute . in som manere /
By Piram9 And Tesbe / may men lere
Thogh they were kepte ful longe streit ouꝰeralle
They ben accorded rownyng thorow a walle
Ther no wight coude han founde out swiche a sleyghte /
But now to prrapos . er that daies eighte
Were passed er the Monthe of Iuyl byfylle
That Ianuarie hath . caught so grete a wylle
Thurgh eggyng of his wyfe / hym to pleye
In his gardyn ⁊ no wight but they tweye
That in a morwe vnto the May seith hee
Rys vp my wyfe . my loue my lady free
The Turtles voys is herd . my lady swete
The wynter is goon . wtith . reynes wete
Com forth now / with thyn eighen Columbyn
How fairer ben thy breestis than is wyn
The gardyn is enclosed al aboute
Com forth . my swete spouse oute of doute
Thow hast me wounded in my hert / o wyfe
No spot of the ne knewe I al my lyfe
Comforth ⁊ late vs takēm oure disport
I chees the for my wyfe . ⁊ my confort /
Sweche olde lewed wordes . vsed he /
On Damyan a signe made she
That he shold goo byforn . wtith his Clyket /
This Damyan than opened the wyket
And In he sterte . and that in swiche manere
That no wight myght it see . neyther y here
And stille he sitte vnder a buyssh / a noon
This Ianuarie as blynde as is a stoon
With Mayus in his honde ⁊ no wight moo
In to his freisshe gardyn is a goo
And clapte to the wiket sodenly
¶ Now wif qd he . here nys but thow ⁊ .I
Thow arte the creature that I beste loue
For by that lorde that sitte in heuene a boue
Leuer iche hadde to deyen on a knyfe
Than the offende trewe dere wyfe
For goddes sake / thynke how I the chees
Nought for no couetise douteles
But oonly for the loue I hadde to thee
And though that I be olde ⁊ may nat see /
Beth to me trewe / ⁊ I wole telle yow why /
Thre thynges certes shal ye wynne ther by
First loue of criste . and to youre selfe honoure
And al myn heritage toun ⁊ toure
I yeue it yow . maketh chartours as ye leste
This shal be doon to morwe or sonne reste /
So wisly . god my soule brynge in blisse
I pray yow first in couenant ye me kysse /
And though that I be Ialous . wyte me nought
Ye ben so depe prynted in my thought
That whan that I considere youre beaute
And ther withal . the vnlykly elde of me /
I may nat certes (though I sholde dye)
Forbere to ben oute of youre companye
For verrey loue / this is with outen doute /
Now kysse me wyfe . and late vs rome aboute /
This freissh May . whan she thise wordes herde
Benyngnely / to Ianuarie answerde
But first ⁊ forward she bygan to wepe /
I haue qd she a soule for to kepe
As wele as ye . and also myn honour
And of my wyfhode thilke tendre flour
Whiche that I haue assured in youre honde
Whan that the preest to yow my body bonde /
Wherfore I wole answere in this manere
By the leue of yow my lord so dere /
I pray to god / that neuꝰer dawe the day
That I ne sterue / as foule as woman may
If euꝰer I do vnto my kyn that shame
Or ellys I empeire so my name
That I be fals . and if I do that lakke
Do stripe me / ⁊ put me in a sakke
And in the next ryuer do me drenche /
I am a gentel woman ⁊ no wenche /
Why speke ye thus ; but men ben euꝰer vntrewe
And women haue repreue of yow ay newe
Ye han non other contenance I leue
But speke to vs of vntrust ⁊ repreue /
And with that worde . she sawe where Damyan
Sate in the busshe / ⁊ coughen she be gan
And with hire fynger . signes made shee
That Damyan / sholde clymbe vpon a tree
That charged . was with fruyt / ⁊ vp he wente
For verreylly he knewe al hire entent
And euꝰery signe / that she kowde make
Wele bette than Ianuarie hir owne make
For in a lettre she hadde tolde hym alle
Of this matere how he werchen shalle /
And thus I lete hym sitte vppon the pirie
And Ianuarie ⁊ May . romyng merye /
¶ Bright was the day . ⁊ blewe the firmament
Phebus hath of golde his stremys doun y sent
To gladen euꝰery floure . with his warmnesse
He was that tyme . in Gemynis as I gesse
But litel fro this declinacoūn
Of Cancer . Iouis exaltacoūn
And so bifel that bright morwe tyde
That in that gardeyn / in the ferther side
Pluto that is kyng of farie
And many a lady in his companye
Folwyng his wife the quene Preserpyne
Eche aftir other . right as a lyne
While that she gaderid floures in the mede
(In Claudian / ye may the storie rede)
How in his grysly Carte he hir sette
¶ Thys kynge of Fairie / than a doun hym sette
Vppon a benche of turues . fresshe ⁊ grene
And right a non thus seide he to his quene /
My wife qd he / ther may no wight say nay
Thexꝑperience so preueth euꝰery day
The treson whiche that woman doth to man
Tenhundred thousand tellen I kan
Notable / of youre vntrouth ⁊ brotelnesse
O Salomon / wys . and richest of richesse
Fulfild of sapience . and of worldly glorie
Ful worthy be thy wordys to memorie
To euꝰery wight that witte ⁊ reson kan
Thus preiseth he yet . the bounte of man /
A monges a thowsand men . yet fond I oon
But of wymen alle fonde I noon
Thus seith the kyng / . that knoweth youre wikkednesse
And Ihc filius Sirak as I gesse
Ne speketh of yow but seeld reuꝰerence
A wild fuyr and corrupte pestilence
So falle vppon youre bodies yet to nyght
Ne se ye nat this honurable knyght
By cause Allas . that he is blynde ⁊ olde
His owne man / shal make hym cokewolde
Loo where he sitte . the lecchour in the tree
Now wole I graunten of my mageste
Vnto this olde blynde worthy knyght
That he shal haue ayeyn . his eyen syght
Whan that his wife wolde doon hym vyleynye /
Than shal he knowen al this harlotrie
Bothe in repreue of here . and other moo /
¶ Ye shal . (qd Proserpyne.) / wole ye so ;
Now be my moders sires soule I swere
That I shal yeue hire suffissaunt answere
And alle wymen aftir / for hire sake /
That (though they be in any gilt I take)
With face bolde . they shul hem selfe excuse
And bere hem doun . that wolde hem accuse /
For lakke of answere . non of hem shal dyen
Al had men seyn a thyng with bothe his yen /
Yet shal we wymen visage it hardily
And wepe ⁊ swere / ⁊ chide subtily
So that ye men . shul ben as lewed as gees /
What rekketh me of youre Auctorites ;
¶ I wote wele that this Iewe / this Salomon
Fande of vs wōmmen foles many oon /
But thogh that he . ne fande . no good wōmman
Yet hath ther founde / many a nother man
Wymen ful trewe / ful good ⁊ vertuous
Witnesse on hem . that dwelle in cristes hous
With Martirdom they ꝓproued hire constaunce
The Romain gestes eke maken remembraunce
Of many a varray trewe wife also /
But sir ne be nat wrooth al be it so
Though that he seide . he foond no good wōmman /
I pray yow take the sentence of the man /
He mente thus . that in souereyn bounte
Nis noon but god that syttes in trinite
Ey for verrey god / that nys but oon /
What make ye so moche of Salomon ;
What thogh he made a temple goddis hous
What thogh he were riche ⁊ glorious ;
So made he eke a temple . of fals goddis /
How myght he do a thyng that more forbode is ;
Parde as faire . as ye his name emplastre
He was a lechour . ⁊ an ydolastre
And in his elde / he verrey god forsoke
And if god ne hadde . as seith the booke
I spared hym for his fadres sake / he sholde
Haue lest his regne . rather than he wolde /
I sette right noght of the vyleynye
That ye of wymen write . a Boterflye /
I am a woman . nedes mote I speke
Or ellys swelle / til my herte breke /
For sythen he seide . that we ben Iangleresses
As euer hool I mote broke my tresses
I shal not spare / for no curtesie
To speke hym harme . that wolde vs vilenye
¶ Dame qd this Pluto . be no lenger wrooth

That I wolde garaunte hym his sight a gayn
My worde shal stonde / I warne yow certayn
I am a kyng it sit me nat to lye /
¶ And I qd she a quene of Fayrye /
Hire answere shal she haue I vndertake /
Late vs nomore wordes here of make /
For soth I wol no lenger yow contrarie /
Now late vs turne a gayn to Ianuarie
That in the gardyn . with his faire May

Yow loue I beste ⁊ shal ⁊ other noon /
So longe a boute the Alies is he goon

Where as this Damyan . sitteth ful merie

This freisshe May . that is so bryght ⁊ shene
Gan forto sike ⁊ seyde Allas my syde
Now sire qd she / for ought that may betyde

Or I mote dye / so sore longeth me
To eten of the smale perys grene

I telle yow wele . a woman in my plyt
May han to fruyt . so grete an appetyt
That she may dyen . but she of it haue /
Allas qd he . that I ne hadde here a knaue
That koude clyme . allas allas qd he
For I am blynde . ye sir no force qd she
But wolde ye fouche safe . for goddis sake
The pirie inwith youre armes to take
(For wele I woot / that ye mystruste me)
Thanne sholde I clymbe wele I now qd she
So I my footb myght sette vppon youre bakke /
Certes qd he ther on shal be no lakke /
Myght I yow helpen with myn herte blood /
He stouped doun . ⁊ on his bakke she stood
And caught hire by a twyste . ⁊ vp she gooth /
Ladies I prey yow . that ye be nat wrooth
I kan no glose . I am a rude man
And sodeynly a noon this Damyan
Gan pullen vp the smokke . ⁊ in he thronge /
¶ And whan that Pluto saugh this grete wronge /
To Ianuarie he yaf agayn his sight
And made hym see . as wele as euꝰer he myght /
And whan that he hadde caught his sight a gayn /
Ne was ther neuꝰer man . of thynge more fayn /
But on his wife his thought was euꝰer moo
Vp to the tree he caste his eyghen two
And say that Damyan his wyfe had dressed
In swiche manere it may nat ben expressed
But if I wolde speke vncurtesly /
And vp he yaf a roryng ⁊ a cry
As doth the moder whan the child shal dye
Oute helpe Allas . harrowe he gan to crye
O stronge lady store what dostow ;
¶ And she answered / sir what eyleth yow
Haue pacience ⁊ resoun in youre mynde
I haue yow holpe . on bothe youre eyen blynde
Vp paril of my soule . I shal not lyen
As me was taught . to hele with youre yen
Was no thynge bette to make yow to see
Thanne strugle with a man vpon a tree
God woot I dede it . in ful good entente /
¶ Strugled qd he ; ye algate In it wente
God yef yow bothe on shames deth to dyen
He swyued the . I say it with myn yen
And ellys be I hanged by the hals /
Thanne is qd she my medycyn fals /
For certeynly if that ye myght see
Ye wolde nat seyn these wordes vnto me /
Ye han som glymsynge and no ꝑperfit ꝑperfit sight /
I see qd he . as wele as euꝰer I myght
Thonked be god . with both myn eyen twoo /
And by my trouthe . me thought . he dide the soo
¶ Ye maze . maze . good sire qd she
Thys thanke haue I . for I haue made yow se /
Allas qd she . that euꝰer I was so kynde /
Now dame qd he . late alle passe oute of mynde
Come doun my leef . and if I haue myssaide
God helpe me soo . as I am yuele apaide /
But be my Fadres soule . I wende haue seyn
How that this Damyan hadde by the leyn
And that thy smokke . hadde leyn vppon thy breste
Ye sir qd she . ye may wene as ye leste /
But sire a man that waketh oute of his sleep
He may nat sodenly wele taken keep
Vpon a thynge . ne sen it ꝑperfitly
Tyl that he be dawed verrayly
Ryght so a man that longe hath blynde I be
Ne may nat sodenly / so wele y see
Firste whan his sight . is newe come agayn
As he that hath . a day or twoo y sayn
Til that youre sight y satled be a while
Ther may ful many a sight / yow bygyle
Beth ware I prey yow . for by heuen kynge
Ful many a man . weneth to sen athynge
And it is al a nother than it semeth
He that mysconceyueth . he mysdemeth
And with that worde . she lepte doun fro the tree
¶ This Ianuarie who is glad but he
He kysseth hire . he clyppeth hire ful ofte
And on hire wombe he stroked hire ful softe
And to his Paleys . hoom he hath hir lad
Now good men I pray yow to be glad
Thus endeth my tale of Ianuarie
God blisse vs / ⁊ his Moder Seint Marie . Amen

¶ Here endith the Marchauntis
tale of Ianuar
Here endith the M ꝰerchauntz tale of Ianuar
Ey goddys mercy qd oure oste thoo
Now soche []a wifea wife I pray god kepe me froo
Loo suche sleightes / ⁊ soteltees
In wymen been for ay as besy as bees
Ben they vs sely men for to disceyue
And from the soth alwey wole they weyue /
By this Marchauntes tale it preueth wele /
But douteles as trewe as ony stele
haue a wyfe though that she poure be
But of hir tunge of labbyng shrewe is she
And yet she hath an hepe of wiles moo
Ther of no force lete alle suche thynges goo
But wote ye what ; in counseille be it seyde
Me rueth sore I am vnto hire teyde
For and I shulde rekke euꝰery vice
Whiche that she hath I wys I were to nyce
And cause why it shulde reported be
And tolde to hire of som of thys meyne
Of whom it nedeth not forto declare
Sen wymen can oute suche chafare
And eke my witte suffiseth nat thertoo
To tellen alle / wherfore my witte is doo
Squyer come neer . if it youre wille be
And sey somwhat of / certes ye
Can there on as moche as ony man /
Nay sir qd he / but sothe thyng as I can
With hertely wille / for I wil not rebelle
A yenst youre luste / a tale wole I telle
Haue me excuse yf I speke amys /
My wille is good ⁊ so my wille is this
