div.l: (base) Agayn the swerde of wynter kene ⁊ colde
(base) This Cambyuskan . of whiche I haue yow tolde
(base) In Roial vestiment sit on his deys
(base) With diademe full hie in his paleys
(base) And halte his feste solempne ⁊ so riche
(base) That in this worlde / ne was ther noon it liche
(base) Of whiche / if I shall tellen all the array
(base) Thanne wolde it occupie a someris day
(base) And eke it nedeth nat to deuyse
(base) At euꝰery cours . the ordre of her seruyse
(base) I wole nat tellen . of here straunge sewys
(base) Ne of hire swannes / ne of hire heronsewys
(base) Eke in that lande . men recche of it but smal
(base) Ther nys no man . that may reporten alle
(base) I wole nat tarien / . yow for it is pryme
(base) And for it is no fruyt . but losse of tyme
(base) Vnto my firste I wole haue . my recours
(base) And so bifel that aftir the thridde cours
(base) While that this kynge / sitte thus in his nobleye
(base) Herkyng hys mynstrals her thynges pleye
(base) Byforn hym at the borde deliciously
(base) In at the halle dore al sodeynly
(base) Ther come a knyght vpon a stede of bras
(base) And in his honde a brood myrrour of of glas
(base) Vpon his thombe . he hadde of golde a rynge
(base) And by his side a naked swerde hangynge
(base) And vp he rideth to the hye borde
(base) In alle the halle ne was there spoke a worde
(base) For merueille of that / knyght hym to be holde
(base) Full bisely they waiten yonge ⁊ olde
(base) ¶ This straunge knyght . that cam thus sodeynly
(base) Al armed saue his heed []fulful richely
(base) Salewith kyng ⁊ quene . and lordis alle
(base) By ordre as they seten in the halle
(base) With so heigh reuerence . and obeisaunce
(base) As wele in speche as in countenaunce
(base) That Gawayn with his olde curtesie
(base) Though he were come agayn . out of Fairie
(base) Ne coude hym nat amende with a worde
(base) And aftir this byforn the heigh borde
He with a manly voys seide his message
After the forme vsed in his langage
With outen vice . of Silable or of lettre
And for his tale sholde seme the bettre
Accordaunt to hise wordes . was his chere
As techeth arte of speche / hem that it lere
Al be that I kan nat . sowne his stile
Ne kan clemben ouer so heigh a stile
Yet sey I this . that as to comune entente
Thus myche amounteth . al that eủer he mente
If so be that I haue it in mynde
He seide the kynge of Arabe ⁊and of Inde
My lorde on this solempne day
Salewith yow . as he best kan ⁊and may
And sendeth yow in honour of youre feste
By me that am al redy at youre heste
This steed of bras . that esely ⁊and wel
Kan in the space of a day naturel
This is to seyn . in .xxiiij. hourys
Wher so yow lyste . in droughte or ellys shourys
Beren youre body . in to eủery place
To whiche youre herte wylneth for to pace
With outen wem of yow . thurgh foule or fair͗e
Or yf yow lyste to flee as high in the ai͗e
As doth an Egle . whan hym lyste to soore
This same stede shall bere yow eủer more
With outen harm til ye ben there yow leste
Thogh that ye slepen on his bakke or reste
And turne a gayn with writhyng of a pynne
He that it wrought . cowde many a gynne
He waited many a constillacoūnn
Er he hadde doon this aꝑperacioun
An knewe full many a seel . ⁊and many a bond
This myrrour eke that I haue in myn hond
Hath swiche a myght / that men may in it se
Whan ther shall fallen / any adủersyte
Vnto youre regne . or to youre selfe alsoo
And openly who is youre frende or foo
And oủer al this . if any lady bright
Hath sette hir herte . on any maner wight
Yf he be fals . she shal his treson see
His newe loue ⁊and all his subtilite
So openly that he shall no thynge hide
Wherfore a gayn this lusty someris tyde
This mirrour and this rynge that ye may se
He hath sente to my lady Canace
Youre excellent doughter that is here
Þᵉ vertue of the rynge if ye wole here
Is this . that if hire lyste it forto bere
Vpon hire thombe / or in hir purse it bere
Ther nys no foule that fleith vnder the heuene
That she ne shall / wele vnderstonde his steuene
And knowe his menyng openly ⁊and playn
And answere hym in his langage a gayn
And eủery gras that groweth vpon rote
She shal ek knowe . ⁊and whom it wole do bote
Al be hise woundes neủer so depe and wide
¶ This naked swerde / that hangith by my syde
Swiche vertue hath / that what man so ye smyte
Thurgh oute his armure / it wole kerue ⁊and byte
Were it as thikke / as is a braunched oke
And what man that is wounded with the strooke
Shall neủer be hole . til that yow lyst of grace
To stroke hym with the plat in thilke place
Ther he is hurt / this is as myche to seyn
Ye mote . with the plat swerde ageyn
Stroke hym on the wounde . and it wole close
This is a verrey soth . with outen glose
It failleth nat . whiles it is in youre holde
¶ And whan this knyght hath thus his tale y tolde
He rideth oute of halle . and doun he light
His steede whiche that shoon as sonne bright
Stant in the Courte . stille as any stoone
This knyght is to his chambre ladde a noon
And is vnarmed . ⁊and to the mete y sette
The p̉resentez ben full rialliche y fette
This is to seyn . the swerde ⁊and the myrroure
And borne anoon into the highe toure
With certeyn officers ordeyned therfore
And vnto Canace . the rynge is bore
Solempnely . ther she sitte atte table
But sikerly with outen any fable
The hors of bras that may nat ben remewyd
It stante as it were to the ground y glewyd
Ther may no man . oute of the place it dryue
For non engyne / of wyndes / or polyue
And cause why / For they kan nat the crafte
And therfore in the place they han it lafte
Til that the knyght hath taught hem the manere
To voyden hym . as ye shall aftir here
¶ Greet was the prees . that swarmeth to ⁊and froo
To gauren on this hors . that stondeth soo
For it so hy was . and so brood / and longe
So wele ꝓproporcioned . for to be stronge
Ryght as it were / a stede of lumbardye
Ther with soo horsly . ⁊and so quyk of ye
As it a gentel . Poyleys . courser were
For certis / fro his taille vnto his ere
Nature ne arte ne koude hym nat amende
In noo degree as al the peple wende
But eủer more / hir mooste wonder was
How that it koude goon . and was of bras
It was a fayrie / as the peple semed
Dyuerse folke dyuersly demed
As many heuedes / as many wittes ter ben
They murmured / as dooth a swarme of ben
And maden skyles . aftir hir fantasies
Rehersynge of these olde Poetries
And seyden it was lyke the . Pegasee % equs pegaseus
The hors that hadde wynges for to fle
Or ellis it was / the Grekys hors Synon
That brought Troye to destruccion
As men in these olde geestes rede
Myn herte qdquod oon is eủer more in drede
I trowe som men of armes ben ther Inne
That shapen hem this cite for to wynne
It were right good . that all swiche thynge were knowe
A nother rowned / to his felawe lowe
And seide he lieth . for it is rather lyke
In apparence . y made by som Magygyke
As Iogelours pleyen at these festes grete
Of sondry doutes thus they Iangle ⁊and trete
As lewde peple demeth comunlly
Of thynges that ben made more subtilly
Than they kan in her lewednesse comp̉rehende
They demen gladly . to the badder ende
¶ And sōmme of hem wondren on the mirrour
That born was vp into the maistre tour
How men myght in it . swiche thynges see
¶ A nother answered ⁊and seyde /. it myght wele be
Naturelly by composicouıı̄uns
Of Anglis . and of sly refleccouıı̄uns
And seide that in Rome was swiche oon
They speke of Alocen and vitulon
And Aristotel . that writen in here lyues
Of queynt Mirrours . ⁊and of ꝑperspectyues
As knowen they that han hire bokes herde
¶ And oother folke han wondred on the swerde
That wolde ꝑpercen . thurgh out eủery thynge
And fille in speche of Thelophus the kynge
And of Achilles . for his queynte spere
For he coude with it . bothe hele ⁊and dere
Right in swiche wise / as men may with the swerd
Of whiche right now ye han youre seluen herd
¶ They speke of sondry hardyng of metal
And speke of Medicynes ther with xx
And how ⁊and whan it sholde y harded be
Whiche is vnknowe . algatis vnto me
¶ Tho speke they of Canaces rynge
And seiden alle that swiche a wonder thynge
Of crafte of rynges herde they neủer non
Saue that he Moyses ⁊and kyng Salomon
Hadde a name of kuıı̄unnyng in swiche art
Thus seyn the peple . and drawen hem a part
But natheles . sōmme seyden that it was
Wonder to maken of Fern Asshen glas
And is glas / nat lyke asshen of Fern
But for they han knowen it so fern
Therfore cesseth hir ianglyng ⁊and hir wonder
As sore wondren sōmme / on cause of thonder
On ebbe / ⁊and flood on gossomer / ⁊and on Myst
And alle thynge til that the cause is wyst
Thus Ianglen they . ⁊and demen ⁊and deuyse
Til that the kyng gan fro his borde aryse
¶ Phebus hath lafte the Angle Meridional
And yet ascendyng was the beest roial
The gentel leon . with his Aldiran
Whan that / this tartre kynge Cambyuskan
Roos fro his borde / ther as he sate ful hye
Byforn hym gooth . the lowde Mynstralcye
Til he cam to his chambre of Parementz
Ther as ther sownen dyủerse Instrumentz
That it is lyke an heuene for to here
Now dauncen / lusty venus / children dere
For in the Fysshe / hir lady sat full hye
And loketh on hem with a frendly ye
¶ This noble kynge / is set vpon his trone
This straunge knyght . is fet to hym ful sone
And on the daunce . he gooth with Canace
Here is the reuel . and the Iolite
That is nat able a dul man to deuyse
He moste han knowe loue . and his seruyse
As ben a Feestlich man . as freissh as May
That sholde yow deuysen swiche array

l.hi: He cowde telle yow the forme of daunces

div.l: So vncouth ⁊and swich freisshe countenᵃnces
Swich subtil lokynge . and dissymulynges
For drede of Ielous mennes aꝑperceyuynges
No man but launcelot / ⁊and he is deed
Therfore I passe of al this lustyheed
I seye nomore / but in this Iolyfnesse
I lete hem / til men to the soper dresse
¶ The Stiward bit spices for to hie
And eke the wyn / in al this melodye
The vsshers and the squyers ben y goon
The spices / and the wyn . is come a noon
They ete ⁊and drynke / and whan this hadde an ende
Vnto the temple as reson was they wende
The seruyce doon / they soupen al by day
What nedith yow rehersen hir array
Eche man woot wele . that at a kynges feste
Is plente to the meste and to the leest
And deyntes moo than ben in my knowyng
Ac aftir soper gooth this noble kyng
To sen this hors of bras / with al a route
Of lordis ⁊and of ladys hym a bounte
Swiche wondrynge was ther . on this hors of bras
That syn the grete sege of Troye was
Ther as men wondriden . on an hors also
Ne was ther swiche a wondrynge as was therthoo
But fynally . the kynge axeth this knyght
The vertue of this Courser . and the myght
And preide hym to telle his goủernaunce
¶ This hors a non gan to trippe ⁊and daunce
Whan that this knyght leyde hande vppon his reyne
And seide sire ther nys nomore to seyne
But whan yow lyste to riden any where
Ye moten trille a pyn stant in his ere
Whiche I shall yow telle . bytwixe vs two
Ye moten nempne hym to what place also
Or to what cuntre . that yow luste to ryde
And when ye come / ther as yow luste abide
Bidde hym descende . ⁊and trille a nother pyn
For ther in lyeth . theffecte / of al that gyn
And he wole doun descende / and doon youre wille
And in that place / he wole abiden stille
Thow al the world the contrarie hadde y swore
He shal nat thenn̉er . ben y drawe nor y bore
Or if yow lyste bydde hym thennes goon
Trille this pynne . and he wole vanysshe anoon
Oute of the sight . of eủery man̉er wight
And come a gayn be it day or nyght
Whan that yow lyste . to clepen hym a geyn
In swiche agyse . as I shall to yow seyn
Betwixe yow ⁊and me . ⁊and that full sone
Ride whan yow lyste . ther is nomore to done
Enformed / whan the kynge was of that knyght
And hath conceyued in his witte aright
The maner and the forme / of all this thynge
Ful glad ⁊and blithe / this noble doughti kynge
Repaireth to his reuel . as byforne
The bridel is vnto the toure y borne
And kepte amonge his Iewels lefe ⁊and dere
The hors vanysshed I note in whiche manere
Oute of here sight / ye gete nomore for me
But thus I lete in luste ⁊and Iolyte
This Cambyuskan / hise lordes festeyynge
Til wel ny / the day / bygan to sprynge
Explicit prima pars /. Incipit pars / secunda
The Norce of digestioun / the sleepe
Gan on hem wynke . and bade hem take kepe
That myche drynke ⁊and labour . wole haue reste
And with a galpyng mouth . hem alle he keste
And seide that it was tyme . to lye a doun
For blood was in his domynacioun
Cheriseth blood natures frend quod he
They thanken hym galpyng by two by thre
And eủery wight gan drawe hym to his reste
As sleep hem badde / they toke it for the beste
Hyre dremes shull nat mowen be toold for me
Ful were hir heuedes of fumosite
That causeth dreem of whiche ther nys no charge
They slepen til that it was pryme large
The mooste parte . but it were Canace
She was full mesurable as wȳmmen be
For of hir Fader hadde she taken leue
To goon to reste / sone aftir it was eue
Hir lyste nat appalled for to be
Nor on the morwe / vnfestlych for to se
And slepte hir firste sleep and wook
For swiche a ioye she in herte took
Bothe of hir queynte rynge . and hir myrrour
That twenty tyme . she chaunged hir colour
And in hir sleep right for imp̉ressioun
Of hire myrrour . she hadde a visioun
Wherfore ar the sonne gan vp glyde
She cleped vp on hire maistresse hire biside
And seyde / that hire lyste for to ryse
¶ These olde wȳmmen / that ben gladly wyse
As is hir Maistresse / answerde hire a noon
Ne saugh I neủer er now . no bridde ne beest
That ferde with hym selfe so petously
Ye slen me with youre sorwe vereyly
I haue of yow grete compassioun .
For goddis loue . come fro the tree adoun
And as I am a kynges doughter trewe
If that I veraily the cause knewe
Of youre disese . if it lay in my myght
I wolde amende it ere it . were nyght
As wisly helpe me / grete god of kynde
And herbes shal I right y nowe fynde
To hele with youre hurtes hastily
Thoo shright this Faukon yet more pitously
Than eủer she dide / and fille to grounde a noon
And lieth a swowne deed / and lyke a stoon
Til Canace hath in hir lappe hir take
Vnto that tyme she gan of swow wake
And after that she of swow gan abraide
Right in hir hawkes ledene . thus she seide
¶ That pite renneth sone in gentil herte
Felyng his symylitude / in peynes smerte
Is preued al day . as men may it see
As wele by werke . as by auctorite
For gentel herte kitheth gentilesse
I se wele that ye haue of my distresse
Compassion / my faire Canace
Of verray womanly benygnyte
That nature in hire pⁱrinciples hath set
But for noon hope to fare the bette
But for to obey vnto youre herte free
And for to make other y ware by me
As by the whelpe chasted is the leoun
Right for that cause . and for that conclusioun
While that I haue a leyser and a space
Myn harme I wole confessen er I pace
And eủer while that oon . hir sorwe tolde
That oother weep̄e . as she to water wolde
Til that the fawkon bade . hire to be stille
And with a sike . right thus she seide hir wille
And with her beke hir seluen so she prighte
That ther nys tigre ne so cruel beste
That dwelleth . outher in wood or in foreste
That nolde han wepte . if that he wepe kowde
For sorwe of hire / she shright alwey so lowde
For ther nas neủer man . yet on lyue
If that I koude / a fawkon wele discryue
That herde of swiche a nother of fairnesse
As wele of Plumage . as of gentilesse
Of shappe . of al that myght y rekned be
A Fawkon ꝑperegryn . than semed she
Of fremde lande / and eủer more as she stood
She swowned now ⁊and now for lakke of blood
Til wele nygh . is she fallen fro that tree
This faire kynges doghter Canace
That on hir fynger bare the queynte ryng
Thurgh whiche she vnderstood wele eủer y thyng
That any foule may in his ledene sayn
And cowde answere hym in his ledene agayn
Hath vnderstonde what this fawkon seyde
And wel nygh for the routhe almost she deyde
And to the tree she gooth ful hastely
And on this Fawkon loketh pitously
And helde hir lappe a brood . for wele she wiste
The Fawkon moste fallen fro the twyste
Whan that it swownyth / for lakke of blood
A longe while to wayten hire she stood
Til at the laste / she spak in this manere
Vnto the hawke as ye shall aftir here
¶ What is the cause . if it be for to telle
That ye ben this furyal peyne of helle
Quod Canace . vnto this hauke a boue
Is this for sorwe of deth / or losse of loue
For as I trowe / thise ben causes twoo
That causen moste a gentil herte woo
Of other harm it nedeth nat to speke
For ye youre selfe / vpon youre self doth wreke
Whiche preueth wele that outher Ire or drede
Moot ben encheson of youre cruel dede
Syn that I se non other wight yow chace
For loue of god doth youre seluen grace
Or what may be youre helpe / for weste / nor Este
Ne saugh I neủer er now . no bridde ne beest
That ferde with hym selfe so petously
Ye slen me with youre sorwe vereyly
I haue of yow grete compassioun .
For goddis loue . come fro the tree adoun
And as I am a kynges doughter trewe
If that I veraily the cause knewe
Of youre disese . if it lay in my myght
I wolde amende it ere it . were nyght
As wisly helpe me / grete god of kynde
And herbes shal I right y nowe fynde
To hele with youre hurtes hastily
Thoo shright this Faukon yet more pitously
Than eủer she dide / and fille to grounde a noon
And lieth a swowne deed / and lyke a stoon
Til Canace hath in hir lappe hir take
Vnto that tyme she gan of swow wake
And after that she of swow gan abraide
Right in hir hawkes ledene . thus she seide
¶ That pite renneth sone in gentil herte
Felyng his symylitude / in peynes smerte
Is preued al day . as men may it see
As wele by werke . as by auctorite
For gentel herte kitheth gentilesse
I se wele that ye haue of my distresse
Compassion / my faire Canace
Of verray womanly benygnyte
That nature in hire pⁱrinciples hath set
But for noon hope to fare the bette
But for to obey vnto youre herte free
And for to make other y ware by me
As by the whelpe chasted is the leoun
Right for that cause . and for that conclusioun
While that I haue a leyser and a space
Myn harme I wole confessen er I pace
And eủer while that oon . hir sorwe tolde
That oother weep̄e . as she to water wolde
Til that the fawkon bade . hire to be stille
And with a sike . right thus she seide hir wille
¶ That I was bredde / allas that ilke day
And fostred in a roche / of Marbul gray
So tendrely that noon thyng eyled me
I nyste nat what was adủersite
Til I coude fly full hye vnder the sky
Tho dwelte a Tercelet me fast by
That semed welle of alle gentilesse
Al were he full of traison ⁊and falsnesse
It was so wrapped vnder humble chere
And vnder hewe of trewthe / in swiche manere
Vnder plesaunce ⁊and vnder besy peyne
That no wight wolde han wende he koude feyne
So depe in greyne he died hise colours
Right as a serpent . hid hym vnder flours
Til he may se his tyme for to bite
Right so this god of loues Ipocrite
Dooth so his Cerymonijs /. and obeisaunces
And kepeth in semblaunt alle hise obseruᵃnces
That sownen in to gentilesse of loue
As on a towmbe i al the faire a boue
And vnder is the corp̄es / swiche as ye woot
Swiche was this ypocrite booth colde ⁊and hoot
And in this wise . he seruede his entente
That saue the fende noon wiste what he mente
Til he so longe / hadde wopen ⁊and compleyned
A many a yer / his seruyce to me feyned
Til that myn herte . to pitous ⁊and to nyce
Al Innocent . of his crowned malice
For fered of his deeth / as thoughte me
Vpon his oothes . and his surete
Graunted hym loue vpon this condicioun
That eủer moo my honour ⁊and renoun
Were saued / bothe pryue ⁊and aperte
This is to sayn . that after his deserte
I yafe hym all myn herte . ⁊and al myn thought
God woot ⁊and he / that other wise noght
And toke his herte in chaunge of myn for ay
But sooth is seide / goon sithen many a day

l.hi: A trewe wight and a theef thenken nat oon

div.l: And whan he saugh the thynge so fer y goon
That I hadde graunted hym fully my loue
In swiche agyse as I haue seide a boue
And yeuen hym my trewe herte as free
As he swore he yaf his herte to me
¶ A noon this Tygre . full of doublenesse
Fil on his knees with so deuoute humblenesse
With so heigh reủerence / and as by his chere
So lyke a gentil louere / of manere
So rauysshed . as it semed for the ioye
That neủer Iason / ne Parys of Troye
Iason certes / ne noon other man
Syn lameth was / that alderfirste bygan
To louen twoo / as writen folke byforn
Ne neủer syn / the firste man was born
Ne koude man / be twenti thowsand parte
Countrefete the sophymes of his arte
Ne were worthy vnbokel hise galoche
Ther dowblenesse . for Feynynge sholde approche
Ne so koude thanke a wight / as he dide me
His manere was an heuene for to see
Til any wōmman / were she neủer so wys
So peynted he and kembde at poynt deuys
As wele hise wordes as his countenᵃnce
And I so loued hym / for his obeisᵃunce
And for the treuth I demed in his herte
That if so were . that any thynge hym smerte
Al were it neủer so lite / and I it wiste
Me thought I felte deth . myn herte twyste
And shortly so ferforth this thynge is wente
That my wille was his willes Instrumente
This is to seyn . my wille obeide his wille
In all thynge as fer as reson fille
Kepynge the boundes of my worshep euer
Ne neủere hadde I thynge so leef ne leuer
As hym god woot . ne neủere shal namoo /
This laste lenger than a yer or twoo
That I supposed of hym nought but good
But finally thus atte laste it stood /
That fortune wolde that he moste twynne
Oute of that place . whiche that he was ynne
Where me was woo / that is no questioun
I kan noght make of it discripcioun
For o thynge dar I telle boldely
I knowe what is the peyne therby
Whiche harme I felte . for he ne myght bileue /
Soo on a day . of me he toke his leue
So sorwefully eke . that I wende vereily
That he hadde feeled as myche harme as I
Whan that I herde hym speke ⁊and sawe his hewe
But natheles . I thought he was so trewe
And eke that he repaire sholde agayn
With Inne a litel while soth to sayn
And reson wolde eke that he moste goo
For his honour / as ofte happeth soo
That I made vertue of necessite
And toke it wele . syn that it most be
As I beste myght / I hidde from hym my sorwe
And toke hym by the hond . seint Iohn to borwe
And seide thus . lo I am yours alle
Beth swiche / as I to yow haue ben ⁊and shalle
¶ What he answerde it nedeth nat reherse
Whoo kan seyn bette than he / whoo kan don werse ?
Whan he hath alwel seyd / than hath he doon
Therfore byhoueth hire a full longe spoon
That shall ete with a fende thus herde I seye
So atte laste he most forth his weye
And forth he fleeth / til he cam ther hym leste
¶ Whan it cam hym to purpos for to reste
I trowe he hadde thilke texte in mynde
That all thyng repairyng to his kynde Reditu suo singula gaudent
Gladeth hym selfe / thus seyn men as I gesse
Men louen of ꝓpropre kynde newefangelnesse
As briddes doon . that men in cage fede
For though thow nyght ⁊and day take of hem hede
And strawe hir Cage faire ⁊and softe as selke
And yeue hem sugre / hony / breed / ⁊and Melke
Yet right a noon . as that his dore is vppe
He with his feet wolle sporne a doun his cuppe
And to the wood he wole ⁊and wormes ete
So newefongel ben they of hir mete
And louen Nouelries . of propre kynde
No gentilesse of blood may hem bynde
So ferde this Tercelet / allas this day
Though he were gentel born ⁊and freissh ⁊and gay
And goodliche for to sen / ⁊and humble ⁊and free
He sawh vp a tyme / a kyte flee
And sodeynly he loued this kyte soo
That al his loue is clene fro me goo
And hath his trouthe / falsed in this wyse
Thus hath the kyte / my loue in hir seruyse
And I am lorne with outen remedie
And with that worde this faukon gan to crye
And swowned efte . in Canacees barm /
Greet was the sorwe . for the hawkes harm
That Canacee / and alle hir wȳmmen made /
They nyste how that they myght the fawkon glade /
But Canace hoom bereth hir . in hir lappe
And softely in plastres gan hir wrappe
There as she with here beek hadde hurte hir selue
Now kan nat Canace but herbes delue
Oute of the grounde / and make salues newe
Of herbes preciouse . ⁊and fyne of hewe
To helen with this hawke . from day to nyght
She doth hir besynesse / and al her myght /
And by her beddes heed . she made a mewe
And koủered it with felewetis blewe
In signe of trouthe . that is in wȳmmen sene
And alle with oute the Mewe / is paynted grene
In whiche were paynted . alle these fals fowles
As ben these tydyues . Tercelettes and owles
Right for despit were peynted hem bysyde
And pies on hem for to crye ⁊and chide /
Thus late I Canace . hir hawke kepyng
I wole namore as now speke of hir ryng
Til it come efte to pᵘurpos for to seyn
How that this fawkon . gate hir loue agayn
Repentaunt as the storie telleth vs
By mediacoıı̄un of Cambalus
The kynges sone . of whiche I to yow tolde /
But hennes forth I wole my ꝓproces holde
To speken of auentures / ⁊and of batailles
That neủere yet nere herde so grete m̉eruailles
Firste wole I telle yow of Cambyuskan
That in his tyme many a cite wan
And aftir wole I speke of Algarsyf
How that he wan Theodora to his wyf
For whom ful ofte in grete perel he was
Ne hadde he ben holpen . by the stede of bras /
And aftir wole I speke of Cambalo
That faught in lystes with the bretheren twoo
For Canace / er that he myght hir wynne /
And ther I lefte I wole / agayn begynne /
Explicit secunda pars /.
Incipit tercia pars /
Appollo whirleth vp his Chaar so hye
Til that the god Mercuries hous the slye
¶ The ꝓprologe of the Ploughman
¶ As the Pylgrymys Forth ded ryde
Owr͗ehost be gan to loke a boute
And seyd Felawys we most ꝓprouyde
Hoo that best of alle thys route
Kan telle hys tale as let comyth aboute
Ploughman Tylyer drawe the nere
And telle thy tale and we wyl here
¶ Syr͗e he seyde y shalle telle as y can
A tale of Crystys modyr dere
Mary that bare bothe god and man
How to a monk she ded a pere
That eủerry day seyde here santere
And heuene blysse had to hys mede
Hoo seruyth Owr͗e lady the bett̉er shalle spede
¶ Here be gynnyth the tale

Of erthely luste / ⁊and fals affeccion
O hauen .o. refute. o sauacion
Of hem that ben in sorwe ⁊and in distresse
Now helpe . for to my werke I wole me dresse
¶ Yet pray iche yow . that reden that I write
Foryeue me that I do no diligence
This ilke storie subtilly tendite
For bothe haue I. the wordes ⁊and sentence
Of hym that at the seyntes reuerence
The storie wroot . ⁊and folwen here legende
And prey yow . that ye wole my werke amende
¶ Incpt aco uois Cecilie ꝙquod pouit Frat̉er Iacob Iaxxxx in legenda aurea ¶ Firste wolde I yow the name of Seint Cicilie
Expoune . as men may in hire storie see
It is to seyn on Englyssh heuenes lylye
For pure chastnes / of virgynyte
Or for she witnesse hadde of honeste
And grene of conscience or of good fame
The swote sauour lilie . was hir name
¶ Or Cecile is to seyn / the wey to blynde
For she ensample was by good techyng
Or ellys Cecile / as I writen fynde
Is ioyned by a man̉er conioynyng
Of heuen ⁊and lya / ⁊and here in figuryng
The heuene is sette for thoght of holynesse
And lia for hire lastynge besynesse
¶ Cecile may eke be seyde / in this manere
Wantyng of blyndnesse / for hire greet lyght
Of sapience / ⁊and for hire thewes clere
Or elles loo / thys maidens name bright
Men Mighte hire wele / the heuene of peple calle
Ensample of good / ⁊and wyse werkes alle
¶ For leos puple is in englyssh is to seye
And right as men may in the heuen se
The sonne ⁊and Mone ⁊and sterris eủery weye
Right so men goostly . in this maiden fre
Saien of of feith . the magnanymyte
And eke the clerenes hool of sapience
And sondry werkes / bright of excellence
¶ And right soo . as these Philosofres write
That heuen is swifte ⁊and rounde / ⁊and eke brennyng
Right so was feyre Cecile the white
Full swifte ⁊and besy . euer in good werkyng
And rounde ⁊and hool / in good ꝑperseueryng
And brennyng eủer in charite ful bright
Now haue I yow declared what she hight
¶ This maiden bright Cecile . as hire lyfe seith
Was come of Romayns . and of noble kynde
And from hire cradell vp fostred in the feith
Of Criste ⁊and bare his gospel in hire mynde
She neủer cessed . as I writen fynde
Of hire pᵃrayere . ⁊and god to loue ⁊and drede
Bysykynge hym . to kepe her maydenhede
¶ And whan this maiden / sholde vntil aman
I wedded be / that was full yonge of age
Whiche that cleped was Valerian
And day was comen of hire mariage
She full deuout ⁊and humble in hire corage
Vnder hir robe of gold / that sate ful faire
Hadde nexte hire fleisshe y cladde hire in an haire
¶ And while that the orgnes made melodie
To god alone in hire herte this songe shee
O lorde my soule ⁊and eke my body gye
Vnwēmmed lest that I counfounded bee
And for his loue . that deide vpon the tree
Eủery secound ⁊and thrid day she faste
Ay biddyng in hire orisons full faste
¶ The nyght come . ⁊and to bedde mote she goon
With hire housbond / as ofte is the manere
And pryuely to hym she seyde anoon
O swete ⁊and welbyloued spouse dere
Ther is a counseile / ⁊and ye wolde it here
Whiche that right fayn . I wolde vnto yow seye
So that ye swere . ye sholle it nat by wreye
¶ Valerian gan faste vnto hire swere
That for no caas ne thynge that myght be
He sholde neủer moo bewryen here
And thanne at erste to hym seyde she
I haue an Aungel . whiche that loueth me
That with grete loue . where so I wake or slepe
Is redy ay my body for to kepe
¶ And if that he may / felen oute of drede
That ye me touche or loue in vylenye
He right a noon . wille slen yow with the dede
And in youre youthe . thus ye shulden dye
And if that ye in clene loue me gye
He wole yow loue as me . for youre clennesse
And shewe to yow his ioy . ⁊and his brightnesse
¶ This Valerian corrected as god wolde
Answerde agayn . if I shalle trusten thee
Late me that Aungel seen and hym byholde
And if that it a verrey Aungel be
Thanne wole I doon . as thow hast praied me
And if thow loue a nother man forsothe
Right with this swerde . than wole I slee yow bothe
¶ Cecile answerde a non right in this wise
If that yow leste the Aungel shulle ye se
So that ye trowe on criste and yow baptise
Gooth forth to via apia qdquod she
That fro this toun . ne stant but Miles thre
And to the pore folkes that there dwellen
Sey hem right . as that I shal yow tellen
¶ Telle hem that I Cecile / yow to hem sente
To shewen yow the good vrban the olde
For secre nedes / ⁊and for good entente
And whan that ye seint vrban han byholde
Telle hym thoo wordes . whiche I to yow tolde
And whan that he hath purged yow from synne
Thanne shall ye sen that Aungel er we twynne
¶ This Valerian . is to the place goon
And right as he was taught by his lernynge
He fonde this holy vrban a noon
Amonge the seintes buriels lotynge
And he a noon with outen tariynge
Dide his message . ⁊and whan that he it tolde
Vrban for ioye his handes gan vp holde
¶ The teeris from his eyen . leet he falle
Al myghty god o IhūIhesu crist qdquod he
So were of chaste counseile . hierde of vs alle
The fruet of thilke seed of chastite
That thow haste sowe in Cecile take to the
So lyke a besy bee . with oute gyle
The serueth ay . thyn owne thralle Cecile
¶ For thilke spouse . that she tooke but now
Ful lyke a fiers lyon / she sendeth here
As meke as euer was any lambe to yow
And with that worde . a noon ther gan appere
An olde man cladde . in white clothes clere
That hadde a boke wᵗith lettre of golde in honde
And gan biforn .Valerian to stonde
¶ Valerian as deed fille doun for drede
Whan he hym sey / and he vp hente hym thoo
And on his book right thus he gan to rede
O lord . o feith . o god with oute moo
O cristendom . ⁊and fader of alle also
A bouen alle . ⁊and oủer al eủery where
These wordes alle with golde y wreten were
Whan this was radde . than seide this olde man
Leuest thow his thynge / or no / sey ye or nay
I leue alle this thynge . quod Valerian
For sother thynge than this I dar wele say
Vnder the heuen no wight may
Tho vanysshed this olde man he nyst where
And pope Vrban / hym cristned right there
¶ Valerian goth hoom . And fynt Cecilie
In with his chambre . with an Aungel stonde
This Aungel hadde of rooses ⁊and of lilie
Crownes twoo . the whiche he baar in honde
And first to Cecilie / as I vnderstonde
He yaf that oon / ⁊and aftir gan he take
That oother to Valerian hir make
¶ With body clene ⁊and vnwēmmed thought
Kepeth ay wele / these Corones qdquod he
Fro paradys / to yow haue I hem brought
Ne neủer moo ne shalle they roten be
Ne lese hire swote sauour trusteth me
Ne neuere wight shalle sen hem wᵗith his eye
But he be chaaste . ⁊and hate vylenye
¶ And thow Valerian for thou so sone
Assentedest to good counseile also
Sey what the leste . ⁊and thow shalt han thy bone
I haue a brother qdquod Valerian tho
That in this worlde . I loue no man so
I pray yow that my brother may haue grace
To knowe the trouth . as I do in this place /
¶ The Aungel seide . god lyketh thy requeste
And bothe with the palme of martirdome
Ye shullen come / vnto his blysfull place /
And with that worde Tiburce his brother coom /
And whan that he / the sauour vndernom
Whiche that the roses ⁊and the lilies caste .
With Inne his herte he gan to wondre faste /
¶ And seide . I wondre this tyme of the yere
Whennes that swote sauour cometh soo
Of Rose ⁊and lilies that I smelle here /
For though I hadde hem . in myn hondes twoo
The sauour myght in me no depper goo
The swete smelle that in myn herte I fynde
Hath chaunged me all in a nother kynde /
¶ Valerian seide . twoo corounes han we
Snowe white ⁊and rose reed that shynen clere
Whiche that thyn eyen . ha no myght to se
And as thow smellest hem . thurgh my praiere
So shalt thow seen hem . leue brother dere
If it so be . thow wolte with outen slouth
Byleue aright ⁊and knowen verrey trouth
¶ Tiburce answerde seistow this to me
In soothnes or in dreem . I herkne this /
In dremys qdquod valerian haue we be
Vnto this tyme brother myne I wis
But now at erste in trouthe oure dwellyng is
How wostow this / qdquod Tiburce in what wise ?
Quod Valerian that I the deuyse /
¶ The Aungel of god hath me the trouthe y taught
Whiche thow shalte seen . if that thow wolt reneye
The ydols ⁊and be clene . ⁊and elles naught /
And of the myracle of thise Corones twey
Seint Ambrose in his p̉reface lyste to sey
Solempnely this noble doctour dere
Cōmmendeth it ⁊and seith in this manere /
¶ The palme of martirdome for to receyue
Seynt Cecile . fulfilde of goddis yifte
The worlde ⁊and eke hir chambre . gan she weyue
Witnesse Tiburces . ⁊and Cecilies shrefte
To whiche god of his bounte wolde shefte
Corownes two . of floures wele smellyng
And made his corounesAungel . hem the corounes / bryng
¶ The maide hath brought hem to blysse a boue
The worlde hath wiste . what it is worth certeyn
Deuocioun of chastite to loue /
Tho shewid hym Cecile . al open ⁊and pleyn
That alle ydols . nys but a thynge in veyn

l.hi: For they ben dombe . ⁊and therto they ben deffe
And charged hym his ydols for to leue

div.l: ¶ Who so that troweth nat this / a beest he is /
Quod thoo Tiburce / if that I shal nat lye /
And she gan kysse his breest that herde this
And was full glad he coude trouth espye /
This day I take the for myn allye
Seide this blysfull faire maide dere
And aftir that she seide / as ye may here
¶ Lo right as the loue . of criste qdquod she
Made me thy brother wyfe right in that wyse
A noon for myn allye . heer take I the
Syn that thow wolt thyn ydols despise
Go with thy brother now . ⁊and thee baptise
And make the clene . so that thow mowe byholde
The Aungels face / of whiche thy brother tolde /
¶ Tiburce answerde . ⁊and seide brother dere
Firste telle me whider that I shal . ⁊and to what man
To whoom qdquod he / com forth with right good chere
I wole the lede / vnto the pope Vrban
Til Vrban / brother myn Valerian
Qdquod thoo Tiburce . wolt thow me thider lede
Me thynketh that it were a wonder dede
¶ Ne menestow nat Vrban qdquod he tho
That is so ofte dampned for to be dede
And woneth alwey in halkes to . ⁊and fro
And dar nat ones put forth his hede
Men shulde hym brene in a fuyr so rede
If he were founde or that men myght hym spye
And wele also to bere hym companye
¶ And whil we siken thilke diuinitte

l.hi: That I hidde in heuen pryuely
Algate y brend in this worlde shul we be /

div.l: To whom Cecile answerde boldely
Men myghten dreden wele ⁊and skylfully
This lyfe to lese myn owen dere brother
If this were lyuynge only ⁊and noon oother
¶ But ther is bettre lyfe . in oother place
That neủer shal be loste ne drede the noght
Whiche goddis sone / vs tolde thurgh his grace
That Fadres sone / hath alle thynges wrought
And alle that wroght is . with a skylfull thought
The goost that fro the fader gan procede
Hath sowled hem wᵗith outen any drede
¶ By worde ⁊andand by myracle / he goddis sone
Whan he was in this worlde declared here
That ther was oother lyfe / ther͗e men may wone /
To whom answerde Tyburce / o suster dere
Ne seidestow right now in this manere
Ther nys but o god . lorde in sothfastnesse
And now of three . how maistow bere witnesse ?
¶ That shalle I telle qdquod she er I goo
Right as a man hath . sapiences .iij.
Memorie . engenyn . and intellecte also /
So in obeyng of dyuyte
Thre ꝑpersones may there right wele be /
Thoo gan she hym ful besyly to preche
Of cristis sone . ⁊and of his peynes teche
¶ And many poyntes of his passion
How goddes sone in this worlde was with holde
To doon mankynde / pleyn remyssion
That was y bounde yn synne and kares colde /
Al this thynge . she vnto Tiburce tolde /
And after this Tiburce in good entente /
With Valeryan . to pope vrban he wente
¶ That thanked god / ⁊and with glad herte ⁊and lyght
He cristned hym . ⁊and made hym in that place
ꝐPerfite in his lernyng goddes knyght
And aftir this Tiburce gate swiche grace
That eủery day . he say in tyme ⁊and space
The Aungel of god . ⁊and eủery man̉er bone
That he god asked / it was sped ful sone /
¶ It were full herde / by ordre forto seyn
How many wondres IħuIhesu christ for hem wroght
But at the laste . to telle short ⁊and pleyn
The sergeauntz of the toun of Rome hem soght
And hem biforn Almache the ꝓprỏrefect broght
Whiche hem opposed . ⁊and knewe alle hire entente
And to the ymage of Iubiter hem sente
¶ And seide / who so wole noght sacrifise
Swap of his heed / this my sentence here /
A noon thise Martirs . that I yow deuyse
Oon maximꝰus that was an officere
Of the p̉refectes / and his Corniculer
Hem hente ⁊and whan he forth the seintes ladde
Hym selfe he wepe for pite that he hadde
¶ Whan Maximꝰus had herde . the seintes loore
He gate hym of the tormentours leue
And ladde hem to his hous wᵗith more
And with here prechyng . er that it were eue
The gonnen from the tormentours to reue
And fro Maxime / ⁊and fro his folke echone
The fals feith / to trow in god allone
¶ Cecilie cam . whan that it was woxen nyght
With Preestes that hem cristened al yfere
And aftirwarde whan day was woxen light
Cecilie hym seide / wᵗith a ful stedenaste chere
Now Crystes owen knyghtes / leef ⁊and dere
Caste al a way . the werkes of derkenesse
And Armeth yow in armes of brightnesse
¶ Ye han forsothe / y doon a greet bataille
Youre cours is doon / youre feith haue ye conʆserued
Gooth to the Corone of lyfe / that may nat faile
The rightfull Iuge whiche that ye han serued /
And whan this thynge was seyde as I deuyse
Men ledde hem forth to doon the sacrifise
¶ But whan they weren to the place brought
¶ To tellen shortly the conclusioun
They nolde encense . ne sacrifise right noght
But on here knees they setten hem a doun
With humble herte . ⁊and sadde deuocioun
And losten bothe hire heuedis in the place
Hire soules wenten to the kyng of grace
¶ This maximꝰus that say this thynge bitide
With pitous teeris toolde it anon right
That he hire soules sawe to heuene glide
With Aungels full of cleernes ⁊and of lyght
And with his word conủerted many a wight /
For whiche Almachius did hym so to bete
With whippe of leed . til he his lyfe gan lete
¶ Cecilie hym toke ⁊and buried hym a noon
By Tiburce ⁊and Valerian softely
With ynne hire buryeng place vnder the stoon /
And after this . Almachius hastily
Bade his mynystres fecchen openly
Cecilie so that she myght in his p̉resence
Doon sacrifise ⁊and Iubiter encence
¶ But they conuertyd . at hire wise lore
Wepten full sore ⁊and yauen ful credence
Vnto hir word . ⁊and criden more ⁊and more

l.hi: Criste goddis sone . with oute difference
Is verray god . ys al oure sentence

div.l: That hath so good a seruᵃnt hym to serue
This with o voys / we trowen thogh we sterue
¶ Almachius that harde of this doyng
Bade fecchen Cecilie . that he myght hire see
And alderfirst loo this was his axyng
What maner woman . art thow qdquod he ?
I am a gentel woman born qdquod she /
I aske the qdquod he / though it the greue
Of thy religion . ⁊and of thy byleue /
¶ Why thanne bygan . youre question folily
Quod she / that woldest two answeres conclude
And o demaunde ye axed lewedly /
Almache answerde . vnto that simitude
Of whennes cometh . thyn answeryng so rude ?
Of whennes qdquod she / whan that she was freyned
Of conscience / and of good feith vnfeyned /
¶ Almachius seyde . ne takestow non heed
Of my power ? ⁊and she answerde hym this
Youre myght qdquod she / ful litel is to drede /
For eủery mortal mannꝰes power nys
But lyke a bladder ful of wynde I wys
For with a nedles poynt . (whan it is blowe)
May all the booste of it be leyde full lowe
¶ Ful wrongfully bygonne thow qdquod he
And yet in wronge is all thy ꝑperseủeraunce
Wostow nat how . oure myghty princes fre
Ben thus cōmmaunded ⁊and maad ordenaunce
That eủery cristen wight . shal han penaunce
But if that he his cristendom with seye /
And goon al quyt . if he wole it reneye ?
¶ Youre princes erren . as youre nobley doth
Quod tho Cecile . ⁊and with a wood sentence
Ye make vs gilti ⁊and is nat soth
For ye that knowen wele oure Innocence
For as moche as we doon a reuerence
To criste ⁊and for we beren a cristen name
Ye put on vs . a cryme ⁊and eke a blame
¶ But we that knowen thilke name so
For v̉ertuous . we may it nat with seye /
Almache answerde . chees oon of this two
Do sacrifise or cristendom reney
That thow mow now . escapen by that wey /
At whiche this holy blysfull faire maide
Gan forto laughe ⁊and to the Iuge she saide
¶ O Iuge confus . in thy nycete
Woltow that I reneye Innocence
To maken me a wikked wight qdquod she ?
Lo he dissymuleth hire in audience
He stareth ⁊and wodeth / in his adủertence /
To whom Almachius / vnsely wrecche
Ne wostow nat . how fer my myght may strecche
¶ Han nat oure myghty princes to me yeuen
Ye bothe power . ⁊and auctorite
To maken folke to dyen . or to lyuen
Why spekestow so proudly than to me ?
I speke nat but stedefastly qdquod she
Nat proudly . for I sey as for my syde
We haten deedly thylk vice of pride /
¶ And if thow drede noght a sooth to here
Than wole I shewe al openly by right
That thow haste made a full greet lesynge here
Thow seist thy princes han yeuen the myght
Bothe for to slen . ⁊and for to quyken a wight
Thow that ne / mayst but only lyfe bireue
Thow haste non other power . ne no leue
¶ But thow maiste sayn . thyt princesthat princes han the maked
Mynystre of deth . of if thow speke of mo
Thow lyest . for thy power is full naked /
Do wey thy boldnesse . seide Almachius tho
And sacrifice to oure goddis er thow go /
I recche nat what wronge that þᵘou me profre
For I kan suffre it as a Philosofre
¶ But thilke wronges / may I nat endure
That thow spekest of oure goddes here qdquod he /
Cecilie answerde . o nyce creature
Thow seydest no word . syn thow spake to me
That I ne knewe ther with thy nycete
And that thow were . in eủery maner wyse
A lewed officer a veyn Iustice /
¶ Ther lakketh no thyn to thyn vtter eyen
That thow nart blynd . for thynke that we sen alle
That is a stoon . that men may wele espyen
That ilke a stoon / a god thow . wolte it calle
I rede the late thyn honde . vpon it falle
And taast it wele / and stoon thow shalt it fynde
Syn that thow seest nat . with thyn eyen blynde
¶ It is a shame . that the peple shalle
So scornen the . and laughe at thy folye
For comonly men wote it oủeral
That myghty god is in his heuenes hye
And these ymages . wele thow mayste espie
To the . ne to hem selfe . mowe nat ꝓprofite
For in effecte they ben nat worth a myte /
¶ These ⁊and swiche other / seide she /
And he wexe wrooth . and bade men sholde her lede
Hoom til hir hous / ⁊and in hire hous qdquod he
Brenne hire right in a bath of flames rede
And as he badde / right so was doon the dede
For in a bath . they gonne her faste shetten
And nyght ⁊and day . greet fuyr they vnder betten /
¶ The longe nyght ⁊and eke a day also
For alle the fuyr . ⁊and eke the bathes h
She sate al colde . ⁊and feled no woo
It made hire nat a drope for to swete /
But in that bath hire lyfe she moste lete ,/
For he Almachius . with a full wikke entente
To sleen hire in the bath his sonde sente /
¶ Thre strokes in the nekke he smote hire tho
The tormentour . but for no man̉er chaunce
He myghte nat smyte . alle hir nekke a two /
And for ther was þᵗat tyme an ordynaunce
That no man sholde don man swiche penaunce
The ferthe strook to smyte softe or sore
This tormentour ne durst do nomore /
¶ But halfe deed with hire nekke y coruen there
He lefte hire lye / and on his weye is wente /
The cristen folke whiche that a boute hire were
With shetis / han the blood full faire y hente /
Thre daies lyued she in this torment /
And neủer cessed / hem the feith to teche
That she hadde fostred hem / she gan to preche /
¶ And hem she yafe here meobles . and hir thynge /
And to the pope vrban bitoke hem thoo
And seide . I axe this of heuene kynge
To haue respite three dayes . and namoo
To recomende to yow er that I goo
Thise soules loo . ⁊and that I myght do werche
Here of myn hous . ꝑperpetuelly a cherche /
¶ Seynt vrban with his dekenes pryuely
The bodie fette ⁊and buried . it be nyght
Amonge hise other seintes honestly /
Hir hous the chirche of seint Cicelie hight /
Seynt Vrban halwed it . as he wele myght
In whiche in to this day in noble wyse
Men doon to criste . and to his seint seruyse
Here bygynneth the Chanons yemans ꝓprologe
Whan that tolde was þᵉe lyfe of seint Cecile
Er we fully hadde riden fyue Mile
At Boghtoun vnder blee / vs gan a take
A man that clothed was . in clothis blake
And vnder that he hadde . a white surplys
His hakeney that was al pomeles grys
So swette that it wonder was to see
It semed he hadde priked myles thre
A boute the Peitrel stood the foom full hye
He was of foom . as flekked as a pye
The hors eke that his yoman rood vpon
So swette that vnneth myght it goon
A male tweyfolde vpon his croper lay
It semed that he caried lite array
A light for somer . rood this worthy man
And in myn herte . wondren I began
What that he was . til I vndirstood
How that his clook sewed to his hood
For whiche whan I hadde longe auysed me
I demed hym som Chanon for to be
His hatte henge at his bakke doun by a laas
For he hadde riden . more thanne trotte or paas
He hadde ay priked . like as he were wood /
A Cloot leef he hadde . vnder his hood
For swoot . ⁊and for to kepe his heed from hete
But it was Ioye . for to seen hym swete
His forhed / dropped as a stillatorie
Were full of plantayne . and Paritorie
And whan that he was come . he gan to crie
God saue qdquod he this Ioly companye
His yeman eke was full of curtesye
And seide sires now in the morwe tyde
Oute of youre hostelrye . I saugh yow ryde
And warned here my lorde . ⁊and myn soủerayn
Whiche that to riden with yow . is ful fayn
For his desport . he loueth daliaunce

That is an yngot . yf I may han happe

Full of water . ⁊and ye shulle wele se thanne
How that oure besynesse shall thryue or preue
And yet for ye shul han no mysbeleue
Ne wronge conseite of me in youre absence
I wole nat ben oute of youre p̉ersence
But goo with yow ⁊and come with yow a gayn
The Chambre dore shortly for to sayn
They opened ⁊and shetten / ⁊and wenten hire weye
And forth with hem / they carieden the keye
And come a gayn . with outen any delay
What shulde I tarien alle the longe day
He toke the chalke ⁊and shoop it in the wyse
Of an Ingot . as I shall yow deuyse
I sey he toke oute / of his owne sleue
A teyne of syluer . euel mote he cheue
Whiche that ne was nat but a nounce of wight
And taketh heed now of his cursed slyght
He shoop his Ingot in lengthe ⁊and in brede
Of thys teyne with outen any drede
So slyly that the preest it nat espide
And in his sleue agayn / he gan it hide
And fro the fuyr / he toke vp his matere
And in thengot put it with mery chere
And in the water vessel . he it caste
Whan that hym lyste / ⁊and bade the preest as faste
Loke what ther is . put in thyn honde ⁊and grope
Thow fynde shalt there syluer as I hope
What deuell of helle sholde it elles be
Shauynge of syluer . syluer is parde
He putte his hande Inne . ⁊and toke vp a teyne
Of syluer fyn ⁊and glad in eủery veyne
Was this preest whan he sy that it was so
Goddys blyssynge and his moders also
And alle halwes . haue ye ʆser Chanon
Seyde the preest . and I hir malyson
But and ye fouchen saufe / to techen me
This noble crafte and this sotelte
I wole be youre in al that eủer I may
Quod the Chanon . yet wole I make assay
The secound tyme that ye may take hede
And ben expert of this / ⁊and in youre nede
A nother day . assay in myn absence
This disciplyne / and this crafty science
Late take a nother ounce ꝙquod he thoo
Of quyk siluer with outen wordes moo
And do ther with . as ye han don er this
With that oother . whiche that now siluer is
¶ This preest hym besieth / in al that he kan
To doon al this Chanon / this cursed man
Cōmmaunded hym / ⁊and faste blewe the fyre
For to come to theffecte / of his desire
¶ And this Chanon right in the mene while
Al redy was this ꝑperest efte to begile
And for a contenᵃra>nce in his honde bare
An holwen stikke take kepe ⁊and be ware
In thende of whiche an ounce ⁊and nomore
Of siluer lymail put was / as by fore
Was in his cole . ⁊and stopped with wexe wele
For to kepe in his lymail eủery dele
And while the preest was in his besynesse
This Chanoun with his stikke gan hym dresse
To hym a noon / ⁊and his poudre caste yn
As he dide er the deuel oute of his skyn
Hym terne / I prey to god / for his falshede
For he was euer fals / in thought ⁊and dede
And with his stikke a boue the Croslette
That was ordeyned with that fals gette
He stered the coles. til relente gan
The wexe agayn the fuyr / as eủery man
But it a fole be / woot wele it mote nede
And al that in the stikke was / oute yede
And in the Croslet hastely the fel
Now good sires / what wole ye bet than wel
¶ Whan that this preest / was thus bygyled agayn
Supposynge nat but trouthe / soth to seyn
He was so gladde / that I kan nat expresse
In no manere . his myrthe / and his gladnesse
And to the Chanoun / he ꝓprofred efte sone
Though pouere I be . crafty thow shalt me fynde
I warne the . yet is ther more byhynde
Is ther Any coper here Inne / seide he
¶ Ye ꝙquod the preest sire / I trowe wele ther be
Ellys go bye vs som / and that as swithe
Now good sire / go forth thy wey ⁊and hye the
He wente his wey / and with this coper cam
And this Chanon / it in his hondes nam
And of that Copir . weyde oute but an ounce
Al to symple is my tunge to ꝓpronounce
As Mynystre of my witte . the doublenesse
Of this Chanon / rote of alle Cursednesse
He semed frendly to hem that knewe hym noght
But he was feendly bothe in werke ⁊and thoght
It werieth me . to telle of his falsnesse
And natheles . yet wole I expresse
To thentente . that men may be ware therby
And for noon other cause trewely
¶ He putte this ounce of Coper in the Croslet
And on the fyre as swithe he hath it sette
And caste in poudre . ⁊and made the preest to blowe
And in his wirkynge for to stoupe lowe
As he dide er / and al nas but a Iape
Right as hym lyste / the preest he made his Ape
And aftirwarde in thyngot he it caste
And in the panne put it at laste
Of watir / ⁊and in he put his owen hande
And in his sleue . as ye byforenande
Herde me telle . he hadde a siluer teyne
He slyly took it oute . this cursed heyne
Vnwytynge this preest of this fals crafte
And in the pannes botme . he hath it lafte
And in the water rumbleth too ⁊and fro
And wonder pryuely toke vp also
The copur teyne / nat knowyng this preest
And hidde it / . and hym hente by the breest
And to hym spake . ⁊and thus seyde in his game
Stoupeth a doun . by god ye be to blame
Helpeth me now . as I dede yow whilere
Put in youre honde / and loketh what is there
¶ This preest toke vp . the syluer teyne a noon
And thanne seyde the Chanon late vs goon
With these three teynes . whiche that we han wroghte
To som goldsmyth . ⁊and wite if they ben oughte
For by my feith . I nolde for my hood
But if they were syluer fyn ⁊and good
And that as swithe preued it shal be
¶ Vnto the goldsmyth . with these teynes thre
They wente . ⁊and putte these teynes in assay
To fire ⁊and hamour . myght no man say nay
But that they were as hem oughte be
This sotted preest . who was gladder than he
Was neủer brid gladder agayn the day
Ne nyghtyngale in the seson of may
Was neuꝰer noon that lyste bette to synge
Ne lady lustyer in carolynge
Or for to speke of loue . ⁊and womanhede
Ne knyght in armes don an hardy dede
To standen in grace of his lady dere
Than hadde this preest this crafte for to lere
And to the Chanon thus he spak ⁊and seyde
For loue of god that for vs alle deyde
And as I may disserue it vnto yow
What shall this receyt coste tellith now
¶ By oure lady qd this Chanon it is dere
I warne yow wele / for sauf I ⁊and a frere
In Engelond / ther kan noman it make
¶ No fors qd he / now sire for goddis sake
What shall I paye telleth me I preye
I wys qd he it is full dere I seye
Sire at o worde . if that yow lyste it haue
Ye shull pay .xl līn. so god me saue
And ner the frendshep . that ye dide er thys
To me ye sholden paye more I wys
This preest the som of xl pound a noon
Of nobles fette / ⁊and toke hem euꝰerychoon
To this Chanoun / for this ilke receyt
Alle his werkyng nas but fraude ⁊and disceyt
¶ Sire preest he seide / I kepe han no loos
Of my crafte / for I wolde it kepte were cloos
And as ye loueth me . kepith it secre
For and men knewen . al my sotelte
By god they wolden han so gret enuye
To me by cause of my Philosofye
I shulde be deed ther were non other weye
¶ God it forbede qd the preest what sey ye seye
Yet hadde I leuer spenden alle the good
Whiche that I haue ⁊and ellys wexe I wood
Than that ye sholden / falle in suche myschef
¶ For youre good wille . sire haue ye right good prefy
Quod the Chanoūn⁊and fare wele garaunt mercy
He wente his wey / ⁊and neuꝰer the preest hym sy
Aftir that day ⁊and whan that this preest sholde
Maken assay at swiche tyme . as he wolde
Of this receyt fare wele . it wolde nat be
Lo thus byiaped / ⁊and bygyled was he
Thus maketh he his introduccoūn
To brynge folke to hire distruccouıı̄un
¶ Considerith sirs / how that in eche estate
By twixe men ⁊and gold / . ther is debate
So ferforth / that vnnethys is ther noon
This multeplyeng blent so many oon
That in good feith . I trowe that it be
The cause grettest of swiche scarcete
Philosophres speken so mystely
In this crafte that men can nat come ther by
For any witte / that men han now a daies
They mowēm wele chiteren / as that do Iaies
And in hire termes / sette hir luste and peyne
But to hire purpos / shull they neủer> atteyne
A man may lyghtly lerne / if he haue aght
To multiplie ⁊and brynge his good to naght
Lo swiche a lucre / is in this lusty game
A mannys myrthe / it wolle torne vnto grame
And empten also / grete ⁊and heuy porses
And maken folke . forto purchasen corses
Of hem that han hir good ther to y lente
O fy for shame / tho that han be brente
Allas kan they nat flee the fires hete
Ye that it vse I rede that ye \it/ lete
Leste ye lese alle / for bet than neủer is late
Neủere to thryue . were to longe a date
Thow ye prolle ay ye shulle it neủer fynde
Ye ben as bolde . as is bayard the blynde
That blondreth forth / ⁊and peril casteth noon
He is as bolde . to renne agayn a stoon
As forto goon bisides in the weye
So faren ye . that multeplye I seye
Yf that youre eyen kan nat sen a right
Loke that youre mynde lakke nat his sight
For thogh ye loken neủer so brood ⁊and stare
Ye shulle no thynge wynnyn on that chaffare
But wasten alle that ye may rape ⁊and renne
Withdrawe the fyre / leste it so faste brenne
Medlith namore / with that art I mene
For if ye doon . your threfte doon ful clene
And right as swithe I wole yow tellen here
What Philosophres seyn in this matere
¶ Lo thus seyth Arnalde of the newe toun
As his Rosarie maketh mencioun
He seith right thus / with outen any lye
Ther may no man Mercurie mortefye
But it be with his brother knowlechyng
How that he / whiche that first seyde this thyng
Of Philosophris Fader was hermes
He seith / how that the dragon douteles
Ne dieth nat / but that it be slayn
With his brother / ⁊and that is for to sayn
By the dragon . Mercurie. ⁊and non other
He vndirstood / ⁊and brymstoon by his brother
That oute of Sol ⁊and luna were y drawe
And therfore saide he . take heed to my sawe
Late no man besy hym / this arte for to seche
But that he / thentencoūn⁊and speche
Of Philosophres / vndirstonde kan
And if he doo ? he is a lewid man
For this science . ⁊and this konnynge qdquod he
Is of the secre / of the secretz parde
¶ Also ther was a disciple of Plato
That on a tyme / seide his maister to
As his book Semor / wole bere wittnesse
And this was his demaunde in sothfastnesse
Telle me the name . of the pryue stoon
And Plato answerde / vnto hym a noon
Take the stoon / that Tytanos men name
Whiche is that ꝙquod he / Magnasia is the same
Seyde plato . ye syre . ⁊and is it thus
This is Ignotum ꝑper ignocius
What is Magnasia good syre I yow preye
It is a water that is maad I seye
Of Elementz foure ꝙquod Plato
Telle me the rote / good sireꝙquod he tho
Of that watir . if that it be your wille
Nay nay ꝙquod Plato / certeyn that I nylle
The Philosophres sworn were euerichon
That they sholden discouere it vnto noon
Ne in no booke / it write in no manere
For vnto criste it is . so leef ⁊and dere
That he wole nat that it discouerid be
But where it lyketh / to his deite
Men for tenspire / and eke for to deffende
Whom that hym lyketh / lo this is the ende
Thanne conclude I thus / syn that god of heuene
Ne wol nat that the Philosophres neuene
How that a man shal come to this stoon
I rede as for the beste late it goon
And who so maketh god his adủersarie
As for to warkyn any thynge in contrarie
Of his wille / certes neủer shal he thryue
Though that he multiplie terme of lyue
And ther a poynt for ended is my tale
God sende eủery man bote of bale . Amen
Here is ended the tale of the Chanons yeman

l.hi: Here bygynneth the ꝓprophemie of the Parson

div.l: By that the yeman hadde this tale al ended
The sonne fro the South lyne was descended
So lowe that it nas nat to my sight
Degrees . 29 . as of hyght
Foure of the Clokke it was tho as I gesse
For xj . foot . and litel more or lesse
My shadewe was / at thilke tyme as there
Of swiche feet as my lengthe partid were
In . 6 . feet equal of ꝓproporcioun
Ther with the Mones exaltacioun
I mene libra alwey gan ascende
As we were entryng at a thropes ende
¶ For whiche oure hoost . as he was wont to gye
As in this caas / oure ioly companye
Seyde in thys wyse / lordynges euerichon
Now lakketh vs no tales moo than oon
Fulfylde is my sentence / ⁊and my decree
I trowe that we han herde of eche degree
Almoost fulfilde is al myn ordynaunce
I prey to god . so yeue hym right good chaunce
That telle vs shalle . a tale lustely
Sire preest ꝙquod he art thow a vicary
Oo erte a persoun . sey soth by thy fey
So what thow be . ne breke thow oure pley
For eủery man saue thow . hath toold his tale
Vnbokele / ⁊and shewe vs what is in thy male
For trewely me thynketh by thy chere
Thow sholdest knytte vp wele a grete matere
Telle vs a fable a noon for Cokkys bones
¶ This ꝑperson answerde at at ones
Thow geest fable noon y tolde for me
For Poule that writeth vnto Thymothe
Repreueth hem that weyuen sothfastnesse
And tellen fables . and siche wrecchidnesse
Why sholde I . sowen draffe out of my fest
Whan that I may sowen whete yf that me lest
For whiche I sey / that if yow lyste to here
Moralite ⁊ vertuous matere
And thanne that ye wole yeue me Audience
I wole fulfayn . at cristes reuꝰerence
Do yow plesaunce leueful as I kan
But trusteth wele . I am a sowthren man
I kan . nat geste rom / ram / ruf / by lettre
Ne god woot ryme holde I but litel bettre
And therfore yf yow lyste / I wole nat glose
I wole yow telle a mery tale in prose
To knytte vp al this feste . ⁊ make an ende
And IħuIhesu for his grace witte me sende
To shewe yow the wey in this viage
Of thilke ꝑperfit glorious pilgrymage
That hight Ierlm celestialle
And yf ye vouche saufe anoon I shalle
By gynne vpon my tale for . whiche I prey
Telle youre auys . I kan no better sey
But natheles / this meditacioun
I putte it ay vndir correctioun
Of Clerkys for I am nat textuel
I take but the sentence trusteth wel
Therfore I make ꝓprotestacioun
That I wole stonde to correccioun
¶ Vpon thys worde . we han assented sone
For as it semed it was for to done
To enden in som vertuous sentence
And for to yeue hym space ⁊ audience
And bede oure hooste he sholde to hym seye
That alle we / to telle his tale hym preye
¶ Oure hoost hadde the wordes . for vs alle
Sire preest qᵈuod he / now faire yow byfalle
Sey what yow lyste . and we wole gladly here
And with that worde . he seide in this manere
Telleth qᵈuod he youre meditacioun
But hasteth yow the sonne wole a doun
Beeth fructious and that in litel space
And to do wele . god send yow his grace
Explicit Ꝓprohemium

div.ab: Here bygynneth the Ꝑparsons tale

Ierꝰer .6o. State suꝑper vias / ⁊ videte ⁊ intꝰerrogate de semitis / antiquis /
que sit / via bona ⁊ ambulate in ea ⁊ inuenietis refrigeriūn aīnabz uris

Oure swete lorde / god of heuene that noman wole ꝑperisshe but
wole that we comen alle to the knoweliche of hym . ⁊ to the
blysfulle lyfe . þtat is ꝑperdurable /

a monesteth vs . by the ꝓprophete Iere
mye þtat seith in þsis wise . //

Stondeth vpon þee weyes and seith /
and axeth of olde pathes / that is to seyn . of olde sentences / whiche
is the good wey

⁊ walketh in that wey . ⁊ ye shal fynde refreisshyng
for youre soules

¶ Many ben the weyes espirituels . that leden folke
to oure lorde Ihu criste . ⁊ to the regne of glorie /

of whiche weyes . ther
is . a ful noble wey . and a fulle couenable . whiche may nat faille to
man ne to woman . that thurgh synne hath mysgoon . fro the righte
weye of Ierlm Celestial .

And this wey is cleped . Penitence . of whi
che man sholde gladly herknen ⁊ enqueren with al his herte

to wite
what is penitence And whennes it is cleped penitence . and in how
many maners ben the accions or werkynges of penitence /

⁊ howe
many spices ther ben of penitence / And whiche thynges aꝑpertenen
⁊ byhouen to penytence . And whiche thynges distorben penitence //

Seȳnt
Ambrose seith . that penitence is the pleynyng of a man for the gilt
that he hath doon // And nomore to doon any thynge . for whiche hym
oughte to pleyne //

And sōmme Doctour seith / Penitence is the waymen-
tynge . of man that sorweth for his synne ⁊ pyneth hym selfe for he
hath mysdoon //

Penitence with certeyn circumstaunces . is verrey repēn
taunce of a man . that halt hym selfe in sorwe ⁊ other peyne for his
giltes /

⁊ for he shalle be verrey penitent he shal first bewaillen
the synnes that he hath doon ⁊ stedefastly prraposen in his herte . to haue
shrifte of mouthe . and to doon satisfaccioıı̄un .

⁊ neuꝰer to doon thynge for
whiche hym oughte more bywaile or to compleyne . and to contynue
in good werkis . or ellis his repentaunce may nat auaille //

For as
seith seint Isydre / he is a iaper . ⁊ a gabbere . ⁊ no verray repentaraunt .
that efte sone doth thynge for whiche hym oughte repente

wepīng
⁊ nat stynte to do synne . may nat auaile //

But natheles men shal
hope . that at euꝰery tyme that men falleth be it neuꝰer so ofte that he may
aryse thorogh penitence . if he haue grace but certeynly / it is grete
doute .

For as seyth seint Gregorie . vnnethe ariseth he oute of his
synne . that is charged with the charge of yuel vsage /

And therfore
repentaraunt folke that stynte for to synne . and for to lete synne . er that
synne forlete hym . holy chirche halte hem siker of hire sauacioun

And
he that synneth . ⁊ verraily repenteth hym in his laste ende ; holy chirche
yet hopeth his sauacioun . by the grete mꝰercy of oure lorde iħuihesu criste / for
his repentaraunce . but take the syker wey //

And now sith that I haue decla-
red yow what thynge is penitence . now shulle ye vnderstonde . that
ther be .iii. accions of penitence /

The first . is that if a man be baptised / aftꝰer
that he hath synned /

Seynt Austyn seith . but he be penitente for hys
olde synfulle lyfe . he may nat begynne the newe clene lyfe /

For certes
if he be baptized with outen any penitence of his olde gilte ; he receyueth
the marke of baptyme . but nat the grace ne the remyssyoun of his syn-
nes til he haue repentaraunce verray //

A nother defaute is this that mēn
doon deedly synne . aftir that they han receyued bapteme //

The thrid
defaute is . that men fallen in venyal synnes . after here bapteme . fro
day to day .

Ther of seith seynt Austyn that penitence of good ⁊ hūmble
folke ; is the penitence of euꝰery day //

The species of penitence . ben
.iii. That oon of hem is solempne . Another is cōmmune / And the thridde
is piriue //

Thilke penaunce that is solempne ; is in two manꝰers / As to be
putte oute of holy chirche in lente / for slaughter of children . And
swiche manꝰer thynge //

A nother is ; whan a man hath synned openly
of whiche synne . the fame is openly spoken / in the cuntre / And than
holy chirche by Iugement destreyneth hym to doon open penaunce //

Comune penaunce . is . that preestes enyoynent men in certeyn caas /
as for to goon ꝑperauenture naked in pilgrymage . or bare foot //

Pryue
penauunce is thilke that men don alday for piriue synnes . of whiche we
shryue vs piriuely . and receyue piriue penaunce //

Now shalt thow vndir-
stonde what is byhouely and necessarie to verrey ꝑperfite penitence
And this stante in .iii. thynges /

Contricion of herte / Confessioun of
mouth . ⁊ satisfaccioun .

for whiche . seith seint Iohn Crisostom9 Peni-
tence distreyneth man to accepte benygnely euery peyne that hym
is enyoyned . with contricion of herte . ⁊ shrifte of mouthe . with
satisfaccioıı̄un / and in wirkynge of alle manere /

And this is fruitfulle
penitence a gayn .iii. thynges . in whiche we wrath oure lorde Ihu
Criste .
this is to seyn / by delyt in thynkyng by rechelesnesse in spekīng

And agayns these wikked giltes . is penitence that may be lyke-
ned vnto a tree /

The rote of this is contricion . that hideth hym
in the herte of hym . that is verray repentaraunt right as the rote of
a tree hideth hym in the erthe //

Of the rote of contricioun spryngeth
a stalke that bereth braunches . ⁊ leeues . of Confession and fruyt
of satisfaccion /

For whiche criste seith in his gospelle / doth digne
fruyt of penitence / for by this fruyt may men knowe this three . ⁊
nat by the rote that is hidde in the herte of man ne by the baraunches
ne the leeues of Confession /

And therfore oure lord iħuihesu crist seith
thus . By the fruyt of hem shulle ye knowen hem //

(base) Of this rote eke
sprengeth a seed / of grace . the whiche seed is moder of sikernesse / And
this seed is egre ⁊ hoot

The grace of this seed . spryngeth of god .
thurgh remembraunce of the day of dome ⁊ on the paynes of helle

Of this matere seith Salomon / that in the drede of god ; man forle-
teth his synne

The herte of this seed ; is the loue of god / ⁊ the
desiryng of the Ioye ꝑperdurable /

This hete draweth the herte of man
to god . ⁊ doth hym hate his synne /

For sothly ther is no thyng that
sauoureth so wele to a childe . as the melke of his norice ne noo
thynge is to hym more abhomynable than thilke melke . whan it is
medled thoowiththoowith other mete .

Right so the synfulle man that loueth
his synne . it semeth that it is to hym moste swete of any thyng .

but fro that tyme that he loueth sadly oure lorde / iħuihesu criste ⁊ desireth
the lyfe ꝑperdurable ; ther nys to hym nothynge . more abhomynable

For soothly the lawe of god ; is the loue of god fo whiche . Dauid
the ꝓprophete seith . I haue loued thy lawe ⁊ hated wikkednesse ⁊
hate /. he that loueth god. kepeth his lawe ⁊ his worde /

Thys
tree sawe the ꝓprophete Daniel in spirit vpon the auysion of Nabu-
godonosor / whan he counseilled hym to do penytence /

Penaunce is
the tree of lyfe to hem that it receyuen / ⁊ he that holdeth hym
in verrey penitence is blessed after the sentence of Salomon //

In
this penitence / or contricoıı̄un man shal vndirstonde .iiii. thynges þtat
that is to seyn what is contricoıı̄un / ⁊ whiche ben the causes that
moeuen a man to contricoıı̄un / and how he sholde be contrite ⁊ what
